HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
3M Earnings Off 12.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD, Minn., Jan. 22

 BODY:
The 3M Company said today that fourth-quarter earnings declined 12.2 percent, mainly because of the weak economy and the strong dollar, which reduced the value of foreign profits. The manufacturer reported fourth-quarter earnings of $259 million, or $1.18 a share, compared with $295 million, or $1.34 a share, in the comparable period of 1990. Sales totaled $3.224 billion, down 1.7 percent. For all of 1991, net income fell 11.7 percent, to $1.154 billion, or $5.26 a share, compared with $1.308 billion, or $5.91 a share, in 1990. Sales totaled $13.34 billion, up from $13.02 billion.

HEADLINE: Has Clinton Said Enough?;
A Yes or No Will Do

BYLINE: By Elaine K. Swift and Kenneth Finegold; Elaine K. Swift and Kenneth Finegold are assistant professors of political science at the University of North Carolina and Rutgers, respectively.

DATELINE: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

 BODY:
"Have you ever had an extramarital affair, Governor?" a New Hampshire television reporter asked Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic presidential nominee. As he has before, Mr. Clinton sidestepped the question. "Well," he said, "if I had, I wouldn't tell you."
We think Mr. Clinton should give New Hampshire Democrats -- and the American electorate -- a simple yes or no. The answer would reveal much about his character and electability. 
 For good reason, American voters look at character in making their choice for President. If Governor Clinton has not been able to keep his marital vows, voters might rightly wonder whether he could be trusted to keep campaign promises or uphold his oath of office.
More important, a male politician's record of philandering says far more about his basic attitudes toward women than any number of policy papers or speeches on women's issues. Can women trust him to see sexual harassment and discrimination as serious problems?
Questions about his character could undermine Mr. Clinton's chances. He portrays himself as the most viable Democrat. He argues he can help the party in the South, where it has done poorly recently. And he is less likely to be tarred as a liberal.
But Governor Clinton is not electable so long as questions remain about his personal past. Extramarital sex may not be an issue in Washington and for Hollywood activists, but it is for the rest of the country. A recent New York Times poll found 23 percent of the public would not vote for a Presidential candidate who had been unfaithful to his wife. In a Time magazine-CNN poll last month, 42 percent of those surveyed said they would be less likely to support a candidate who has had extramarital affairs. These attitudes are likely to be strongest in the the South and, of course, among women, who make up a majority of the electorate.
Asked in Sunday's debate whether the Republicans would be able to find a woman to substantiate charges of infidelity, Governor Clinton responded that it was "highly unlikely." But you can be sure that if he wins the nomination, the Republicans will do whatever they can to increase these odds. The G.O.P. would like nothing better than to shift attention from the economy to the personal life of the Democratic candidate.
Mr. Clinton's supporters may well point out that some revered Presidents were unfaithful to their wives. But that was when everyone abided by the "gentlemen's agreement" that personal matters would not be mentioned even in the heat of the campaign. Those days are over.
It's easy to see how Republicans might make adultery the central issue of a Clinton-Bush contest. After all, character attacks succeeded in 1988 when unfounded rumors that Michael Dukakis had sought psychiatric treatment caused the Massachusetts Governor to drop eight points in the polls that summer.
A Republican campaign based on "family values" would allow President Bush to emphasize his relationship with the First Lady, who is more popular than he is, and appeal to conservatives who have complained that he has not pursued their social agenda. In New Hampshire last week, the President showed every sign of following this strategy.
Hillary Clinton, the Governor's wife, has asked that her family "have some realm of protection from public life." Mr. Clinton and his family do have a right to privacy, but not at the expense of Americans' right to assess the fitness of candidates to the highest office. Mr. Clinton would do well to reflect on the words of Thomas Jefferson: "When a man assumes a public trust, he should consider himself as public property."

HEADLINE: EX-SOVIET LANDS TO GET SWIFT AID

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The 47-nation conference on aid to the former Soviet Union ended today with some general proposals on how to expand and accelerate humanitarian assistance but with lingering uncertainty over how to pay for the programs and carry them out.
In an effort to spur the aid process, the Bush Administration announced today that it would fly 54 shipments of emergency food and medical supplies to Russia and the other republics, beginning Feb. 10, to help the new Commonwealth of Independent States through the winter. On board the C-5 and C-141 aircraft will be some 16 million prepackaged meals left over from the Persian Gulf war. 
 In addition, at the end of the two-day meeting Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced new plans to send some 2,000 American farm volunteers over the next three years, for periods of up to 90 days, to work directly with private farmers in the commonwealth, and a new plan to establish a $25 million fund called the Eurasian Foundation for Democracy to help strengthen free market institutions in the former Communist nation.
Money for the American food and medical airlift, as well as the technical assistance programs like the Eurasian Foundation, will come primarily from funds urged on the Bush Administration by Congressional Democrats last year. While the Administration did not encourage Congress to appropriate the money at the time, it is now eagerly taking full advantage of it.
Following their talks, the 47 ministers present at the State Department announced a series of five sketchy "action plans" they would use in the coming months to improve and enlarge the transfer of medicine, food, shelter, energy and technical assistance to the commonwealth. The plans, each of which is being supervised by a working group headed by two countries that attended the conference, contain both new suggestions and proposals for insuring that aid already promised does not get duplicated or diverted to the black market.
Some of the plans, though, are so general and vague that it is still hard to see what they will involve. For instance, the food plan says the working group will try "encouraging competition and improving productivity throughout the food sector," and "establish contacts with the new states," and "build up links with the international institutions involved in assisting the new states."
If all of these plans are fleshed out, financed and carried out, the situation in the former Soviet Union will probably improve. But it is still unclear how many of these new initiatives will become reality.
 
Mood at Conference
 The mood at the close of the conference was best summarized by Portugal's Foreign Minister, Joao de Deus Pinheiro, spokesman for the European Community, who declared at the closing news conference:
"This is the first step of a process. Ahead lies the task of translating our commitments into effective and rapid results. We now need to insure that the people in the new state and their authorities at every level join us as partners in this task. Our aim is to contribute to their efforts and help them to reach the objectives they have chosen. If we succeed in this enterprise, as we must, we shall not only have helped to provide relief to millions of people. We shall need to build a strong momentum on the basis of our commitments at this Washington Conference."
The ministers agreed to reconvene again, at the beginning of May in Lisbon, to review progress. Each of the five working groups -- medical, food, energy, housing and technical assistance -- will have to report at that time on how well its plan has been carried out. American officials are counting on this pressure to help insure that the countries -- including the United States -- follow through on their promises.
 
Proposal by Baker
 When this aid conference was proposed by Secretary Baker in a Princeton speech last month, it was not greeted with much enthusiasm by either the White House or the Europeans. The Europeans in particular saw it as a gimmick, basically designed to allow the United States to take credit for leading the global aid effort for the commonwealth without having to spend any more of its own money.
Although Secretary Baker said this week's conference was intended not to secure more pledges of aid, but merely one to coordinate offers that had already been made, the European complaints embarrassed the Bush Administration into increasing its own contributions.
The President said yesterday he would ask Congress for $645 million more in humanitarian and technical aid during fiscal 1992 and 1993 -- which he apparently plans to take from the military budget -- and followed that up today with the announced airlift. Washington has now committed about $5 billion to the aid effort, but most of that is in farm credits for the Russians to buy grain from American farmers with loans that must be repaid.
Some other countries that were invited, though, also felt impelled to pledge real or token increases in their assistance, although many experts believe these still fall far short of what is needed if the commonwealth states are to avoid social unrest from shortages of food and shelter.
 
Dispute With Japan
 Japan, for instance, announced before coming to the conference that it would give $50 million more to the Red Cross for humanitarian aid to the commonwealth, but Tokyo made clear it would not make any larger contributions until Russia returns to Japan disputed islands the Soviet Union occupied at the end of World War II. The Japanese earlier had pledged $2.6 billion in aid, mostly in the form of credits.
Among the new pledges, Oman announced that it would commit $200 million to support energy exploration in the commonwealth. Thailand offered $450 million in loans for republics to buy rice and other commodities, while Korea offered $800 million for the same. Argentina proposed to absorb 100,000 Russian immigrants. Saudi Arabia and other gulf states agreed to unfreeze more than $1 billion in aid they had promised the former Soviet Union and frozen during the August coup. Finland offered to transport humanitarian aid to the commonwealth at a large discount.
"The conference created pressure on us and the people we invited to give more," said a senior Administration official. "In three months, people will have to say what they've done."
Mr. Baker said a delegation from this week's conference would sit down next week with leaders of the new Commonwealth of Independent States in Minsk to review the decisions and proposals put forward in Washington. He also announced the appointment of Richard L. Armitage, as the coordinator for American aid to the former Soviet Union, with responsibility for making sure that aid gets to its proper destination.
The Americans refused to allow discussion at the conference of a Russian request for a multibillion dollar currency stabilization fund, along the lines of that provided for Poland, to support any transition to free markets. Administration officials insist that such a program will have to be handled by the International Monetary Fund.

SKETCHY AID TO RUSSIANS
 A 47-nation conference in Washington on aid to the former Soviet Union ended with some sketchy proposals. The Bush Administration plans to use congressional financing for 54 shipments of food and medicine this winter, but some of the other plans are so vague that it is unclear who will carry them out. MOSCOW'S ALL-NIGHT SHOPS
 Pioneer shopkeepers in Moscow are opening all-night convenience stores that are threadbare by Western standards, but fantastically stocked by any local estimation. The view from some of the kiosks is definitely from the underbelly. A10
 
ESTONIA ADJUSTS ITS SIGHTS
 Estonia has fulfilled its dream of regaining the independence interrupted by the Soviets a half-century ago, but the costs have proved higher than expected. There is no fuel to fly its newly emblazoned planes or even to heat much of the capital. A10
 
BUSES ATTACKED IN INDIA
 Gunmen opened fire on a caravan of buses carrying political workers in Punjab state, killing 5 people and wounding 40, reports said. The caravan was being led by the head of India's far-right nationalist party to the strife-torn Vale of Kashmir. A3

THE U.N. AS PEACEMAKER

BEIJING'S SENSE OF MORTALITY
 The talk in Beijing these days is of cancer and illness and eventually funerals. Of the 8 or 10 leaders who still exercise ultimate control over China, only one -- President Yang Shangkun, who is 85 years old -- still regularly appears in public and seems vigorous and alert. A9

HEADLINE: Bush Weighs Health Benefits Tax And Cap on Medicaid Payments

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
As part of President Bush's effort to curb spending on health care, Administration officials want to limit how much Federal Medicaid payments can grow each year, and they want to impose a new tax on high-income people with health insurance purchased by employers.
Administration officials outlined their ideas at a meeting today with Republican senators and at a meeting on Tuesday with lobbyists for hospitals and health insurance companies. Both proposals are subject to approval by Congress. 
 Republican strategists have warned the Administration that the proposal to tax part of the health insurance benefits of affluent people is full of political peril for Mr. Bush and other Republican candidates in this Presidential election year. But the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, has brushed aside such doubts and defended the tax as sound health policy, Administration officials said.
Mr. Darman contends that the tax would discourage the purchase of excessive amounts of insurance and the resulting overuse of health care. And in speeches over the last 15 months, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, often said the existing tax subsidies for health insurance were costly and inequitable.
Under the Medicaid proposal, the Federal Government would pay states a flat amount, fixed in advance, for each person enrolled in Medicaid, the health-care program for the poor. The increase in payments for each person would be limited to about 6 percent in 1994 and 5 percent in 1995, the senators and lobbyists were told.
 
Jump in Federal Spending
 That represents a major change. Currently, only 2.6 million of the 29.8 million Medicaid recipients are covered by such prepaid health plans. For other recipients there is no limit on Medicaid payments; the Government pays more if they use more services.
Federal Medicaid spending shot up 28 percent last year, to $52.5 billion, partly because of surging enrollment as a result of the recession. The Congressional Budget Office predicts that under current law the Federal share of Medicaid will rise to $68 billion this year and $80 billion in 1993, almost twice the 1990 total. The average payment for a beneficiary has been increasing more than 15 percent a year.
Congress is unlikely to impose a rigid cap on Medicaid, but might well go along with a proposal, currently being discussed by Administration officials, to force large numbers of Medicaid recipients into health maintenance organizations and other "managed care" plans. More than 30 states are already experimenting with such plans. New York State aims to enroll half its Medicaid recipients in such plans within five years.
A Federal health official said the Medicaid proposals were part of "a massive cost-containment strategy." But the official did not disclose the amount of the expected savings.
Larry S. Gage, president of the National Association of Public Hospitals, who attended the White House meeting, said today, "Under the guise of national health-care reform, the Administration is trying to resurrect arbitrary caps on Federal Medicaid spending." Congress rejected such a ceiling when President Ronald Reagan proposed it in 1981 as a way to control costs.
States share the cost of Medicaid, and the program has become one of the fastest-growing items in state budgets. James L. Martin, director of state-Federal relations for the National Governors' Association, said, "Governors do not like Medicaid caps because if your Medicaid costs are going up more than the per capita increase in Federal payments, you would have to cut the program or find state revenues to pay for it." But he added, "Governors want more flexibility for statewide health-care reform, including greater use of managed care for Medicaid recipients."
At the White House meeting, Mr. Bush's proposals were outlined by Thomas A. Scully, associate director of the Office of Management and Budget; Dr. Sullivan, and Samuel K. Skinner, the President's chief of staff.
 
Tax on Benefits of Affluent
 Here, according to their description, is how the tax on health insurance benefits for affluent people would work: families with annual incomes of more than $125,000 would be subject to the tax if they received employer-paid health insurance worth more than $160 a month. Employer contributions exceeding that amount would be taxed as regular income for the employee. Under current law, such contributions are not counted as taxable income.
More than 138 million Americans get health insurance through their employers. The Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group, says the average monthly premium for a family was $318 in 1990. Insurers fear that once the principle of taxing health benefits is established, the income threshold would be lowered, so more people would have to pay the tax.
While Mr. Darman has defended the proposed tax as good health policy, William D. McInturff, a partner in Public Opinion Strategies, a Republican survey research firm, said the idea for a new tax on health insurance benefits was, "from a Republican perspective, the single worst idea" since President Reagan proposed cutting Social Security benefits in 1981.
Mr. McInturff said Democrats could easily run television commercials attacking the proposed health insurance tax, as Senator Harris Wofford did last year in Pennsylvania when his Republican opponent, Dick Thornburgh, expressed interest in such taxes.
The proposed limit on Medicaid spending would allow an increase in Federal payments if more people qualify for Medicaid as a result of unemployment or economic hardship. But it would curb the growth in costs resulting from greater use of costly medical services by Medicaid recipients.
The average Federal Medicaid payment varies with the type of beneficiary. In 1990, it was about $800 for a child and $1,400 for an adult with dependent children, according to preliminary data from the Department of Health and Human Services. The Administration's proposal focuses initially on services provided by doctors and hospitals, not nursing homes.
Several important questions about the Medicaid plan remain unanswered. For example, it is not clear how the Administration would adjust Federal Medicaid payments to reflect differences in medical costs among states. Nor is it clear whether states would be legally obliged to make up for all the money they lose as a result of the limits on Federal Medicaid payments.

HEADLINE: Japanese Bid for Seattle Team Gets Baseball's Cold Shoulder

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Reaching to Japan in an effort to keep the American national pastime alive in Seattle, this city's leaders announced today that a group led by Japanese investors had made an offer to buy the Seattle Mariners baseball team for $100 million.
The offer, by the family that founded Nintendo, the world's biggest video game company, is the first time that a potential buyer outside of North America has tried to buy a controlling interest in a major league baseball team. The offer was presented here as the best chance to keep Jeff Smulyan, the team's current owner, from moving the club out of town. As proposed, the Mariners would stay in Seattle and be under the control of a local board of directors; they could play some exhibition games in Japan, as well as develop a television following overseas. 
 But the package, which was unveiled here with a flourish of optimism and backed by the Northwest's most powerful political and business leaders, drew a terse and negative response from Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball. Mr. Vincent, as well as a majority of baseball's team owners, must approve the deal for it to go through.
In a statement issued late today, Mr. Vincent said: "Baseball has addressed the issue of ownership of its franchises and has developed a strong policy against approving investors from outside the United States and Canada. It is unlikely foreign investors would receive the requisite baseball approvals."
The issue of Japanese ownership of a United States baseball team comes at a tense time in trade and business relations between the two countries. On Wednesday, Los Angeles County officials canceled a contract with a Japanese company that had been selected to supply rail transit cars to the city, choosing an American company instead. Earlier this week, Yoshio Sakurauchi, the speaker of Japan's lower house of parliament, set off a furor when he said American workers were lazy.
In recent years, Japanese buyers have purchased everything from Hollywood film studios, to landmark buildings, to golf courses of national stature. The proposal to purchase the Mariners was made after an overture to the Japanese group by United States Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington. Seattle officials said the plan would keep jobs and a healthy segment of the local economy in the Pacific Northwest.
 
Political Clash Possible
 Mr. Vincent's seeming opposition sets the stage for a political clash in Congress, where this state's delegation, which includes House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, has raised the possibility of introducing a measure aimed at revoking Major League Baseball's exemption from antitrust laws if they were to allow the Mariners to pull out of Seattle.
Mr. Gorton, who initiated the deal when he approached the owners of Nintendo in December, said it was hypocritical for baseball to allow Canadian owners but not Japanese owners. The partnership would be made up of 60 percent Japanese money and 40 percent from Seattle. Minoru Arakawa, president of Nintendo's American subsidiary, which is based in the Seattle suburb of Redmond, act as chairman of the investor group.
Mr. Arakawa, the son-in-law of Nintendo's president, Hiroshi Yamauchi, has lived in Seattle for 15 years. The current owner of the team, Mr. Smulyan, lives in Indianapolis.
 
'Partnership Made in Heaven'
 The Nintendo group decided to get involved only after being approached by Senator Gorton, said Howard Lincoln, a spokesman for the new investor group, called the Baseball Club of Seattle. "Mr. Yamauchi and Mr. Arakawa decided to get involved, and their only motivation is to help this community," said Mr. Lincoln.
The team, which posted its first winning season last year and broke all their team attendance records, was put up for sale on Dec. 9. Mr. Smulyan had given the city until March 27 to come up with a local buyer.
Asked about the commissioner's concerns of foreign ownership, Senator Gorton said: "Major League Baseball crossed that bridge 20 years ago when it admitted two Canadian teams. The Pacific Northwest looks outward. This is partnership made in heaven for the Pacific Northwest."
Mr. Gorton said the Seattle deal was different from the recently canceled Los Angeles rail car contract because no local buyer had emerged here to compete with the Japanese offer.
 
Offer Surprises Owner
 The Pacific Northwest, unlike other parts of the country, has long had a trade surplus with Japan. Its economy is heavily dependent on Japanese trade, and it has strong cultural ties as well.
Mr. Smulyan, traveling from New York to Indianapolis, could not be reached for comment. The offer came as a surprise to him, said his spokesman, David Aust.
While Mr. Smulyan relied on two large bank loans to purchase the team for $76 million in 1989, the new ownership group proposes to pay cash from their own personal fortunes. The investor group that would co-own the team includes business leaders from this city's leading companies, such as Boeing, Microsoft, McCaw Cellular Communications and others.
In their 15-year history, the Mariners have never been run by a local owner. Two California businessmen owned the team, and then it was sold to Mr. Smulyan, who owns Emmis Broadcasting.
Last year, the city fell in love with the team, and stars like Ken Griffey Jr. and Randy Johnson became household names. The club drew more than two million fans, nearly as many as the pennant-winning Atlanta Braves, and posted its first winning season. But Mr. Smulyan, facing a February deadline to pay off or refinance a $39 million bank loan, said he needed more than fan support to keep the team afloat. He appealed to the business community for help.
In the last five months, business leaders raised more than $10 million a year in pledges to help the team. But in December, just as the business group was hitting stride, Mr. Smulyan put the Mariners up for sale. A group in Florida has been trying to get Mr. Smulyan to move the team to the Tampa-St. Petersburg area.
Before Mr. Vincent issued his statement today, Seattle civic leaders sounded as if they had solved their baseball problems.
"It's all good news," said John Ellis, one of the Seattle corporate leaders trying to keep baseball here. "This is new ownership for the Mariners that will finally bring financial solvency, permanency and local control of our team."
 
Playing Down Foreign Angle
 George Duff, the head of the Greater Seattle Chamber of Commerce, held aloft a baseball and said, "This deal will now permit us once and for all to take this little critter off the endangered species list."
In presenting the prospective buyers, Seattle leaders went out of their way to play down the nationality of the potential buyers. "In effect, all of the shareholders of the new company will be local Seattle area residents and all company decisions involving the club will be made in this area," said Mr. Lincoln. If the Japanese decided to sell any portion of the team, they would first have to offer it to a Seattle buyer, Mr. Lincoln said.
Nintendo has 1,400 employees in the Seattle area. The company has captured 80 percent of the American market for video games, and had sales of $3.5 billion last year.
Mr. Yamauchi's son-in-law, Mr. Arakawa, was introduced at the press conference today, but he declined to comment.

HEADLINE: Tisch Is Offering to Buy Macy's In Rescue From Huge Debt Load

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
In an apparent solution to R. H. Macy & Company's overwhelming financial troubles, Laurence A. Tisch, chairman and chief executive of Loews and CBS, has offered to buy the tottering retail company.
Already a major investor in Macy, Mr. Tisch would spend roughly $1 billion more to increase his stake substantially, people involved in talks to solve Macy's immense debt problems said last night. They added that negotiations were continuing and that details of the proposal could change. 
 Mr. Tisch is expected to wind up owning perhaps as much as 90 percent of the company's stock and to invest large sums to buy junk bonds and stock from creditors and investors at well below face value. It is not clear whether the management investors, including Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's chairman and chief executive, would lose their stake.
Macy's board is expected to approve the proposal in the next few days, people familiar with the talks said.
If that happens, Mr. Tisch's move would be expected to calm the maelstrom of speculation about the company's solvency that has engulfed Macy in recent years. Mr. Finkelstein and his top executives bought Macy from its shareholders for $3.7 billion in 1986.
By eliminating a substantial portion of Macy's debt, the 11th-hour rescue would relieve the worries of the company about its bills and interest payments and concentrate on operating its department stores. That firmer financial footing would also give Macy's normal sales operations more of a chance to carry the New York-based company through the recession that has claimed many of its once-formidable rivals.
 
Calls for Bankruptcy Filing
 Whether Mr. Finkelstein would remain in charge of the company that operates the Macy's, I. Magnin and Bullock's department store chains and several small specialty stores across the country is unclear. But Mr. Tisch and Mr. Finkelstein are close friends. It is also unclear whether Mr. Tisch, through his L.T. Holding Corporation, intends to try to sell any of Macy's assets, such as one of the department store chains.
A Macy spokesman declined to comment last night about the company's financial plans. Calls to Mr. Tisch's office and to other Macy board members were not returned.
The Tisch plan would call for the company to file for bankruptcy on its own terms and eliminate debt, rather than default on payments and be forced to seek protection from its creditors.
Holders of Macy junk bonds would be offered prices well below face value, but above the low market prices to which they have fallen as concern has grown about Macy's prospects.
Other Macy shareholders are expected to agree to sell their stock to Mr. Tisch for a fraction of what they paid, fearing that the only other alternative would be a bankruptcy filing that could result in even greater losses.
Those investors include the top echelon of Macy management, the GE Capital Corporation and A. Alfred Taubman, the real estate developer, through Ticsec Inc. Two other major investors are Winmex Investments, whose principal investor is Sir Run Run Shaw, a Hong Kong financier, and the Mutual Series Fund, an investment fund run by Michael F. Price.
In late 1990, when Macy had to scale another financial wall, Mr. Tisch and GE Capital were among a group of investors that chipped in $202 million to help the company over.
Macy's leveraged buyout at first seemed successful. But in 1988, the company bought the I. Magnin and Bullock's department store chains from Federated Department Stores Inc. for $1.1 billion, a price many analysts considered far too dear.
Shouldering the additional debt, Macy staggered into the recession about the same time its customers started curtailing their spending. Sales fell and losses soared. Although the company again began reporting sales increases last fall, the gains were not enough to cover the interest payments on its heavy debt.
 
Steps Already Taken
 Since adding I. Magnin and Bullock's, Macy has taken several steps to stave off insolvency, including renegotiating the terms of its bank debt 23 times, raising cash by selling assets and coaxing investors to increase their stakes.
But two weeks ago it became apparent the retailer was having a lot of trouble juggling its many payments, despite extracting much more lenient terms from its banks a month earlier. On Jan. 15, Macy told its suppliers it would delay their payments for two weeks to avoid defaulting on its newly renegotiated bank agreements. Those agreements were reached in early December, and the inability of Macy to meet a payment deadline so soon afterward was seen as evidence the Christmas season had been far worse than Macy had expected.
Even with a rescue seemingly near, it is not clear whether those payments will be sent out Saturday as promised. Mr. Tisch's plan reportedly includes paying off the suppliers -- but only after enough bondholders have approved his plan to make it virtually a done deal. Getting that approval might take several weeks, leading to another two- or three-week delay in payments, one person involved in the talks said. Such a delay could put Macy's stores behind in receiving spring merchandise, creating a competitive disadvantage.
Mr. Tisch apparently plans to carry out his plans with the help of a "prepackaged" bankruptcy, a tool that has gained favor in recent years as an expedient way to revive debt-laden companies.
 
Bankruptcy Is Different
 Such a bankruptcy differs from a normal Chapter 11 filing in that it is largely a formality. By the time a prepackaged bankruptcy is filed in court, a debtor and its creditors have already decided what each will settle for. But they still need to go through an expedited bankruptcy process to break the contract terms of their previous debt agreements.
This also allows the company to force recalcitrant bondholders to accept the terms of the deal, so long as most bondholders agree to take a little money and, in effect, go away.
A Jan. 10 report on the company by Jack Hersch, David Teolis and Raz Kafri of Lehman Brothers called a prepackaged bankruptcy the best option because it would allow the management, which is highly regarded in the retail industry, to maintain control of the changes.
If Mr. Tisch can gain the approval of his plan from bondholders representing two-thirds of the value of the bonds, Macy can file for Chapter 11 and present its plan for restructuring its finances as a fait accompli. That will avoid the drawn-out legal wrangling that so often accompanies a normal bankruptcy filing.
Federated Department Stores, which operates Bloomingdale's and other large department stores, recently emerged from such a bankruptcy after two years of intricate legal bargaining.
Mr. Tisch apparently is seeking approval to buy at a premium to the market price a significant portion of Macy's $1.3 billion worth of junk bonds, whose double-digit interest rates have crippled a company also reeling from the impact of the recession on consumer spending.
He is willing to pay bondholders more than the market price of their holdings to entice them to go along with his plan quickly. He would also buy the other investors' stock in the company for what one person involved in the talks described as just cents on the dollar.
And upon receiving the approval of the bondholders for his plan, he would pay suppliers, many of whom are currently holding shipments to Macy until its future is resolved.
Although Macy's more than 140 department stores represent significant real estate value, most of them are heavily mortgaged and thus are not likely to be one of Mr. Tisch's primary reasons for investing in the company.
Mr. Tisch over the years has gained a reputation as a shrewd investor willing to make big bets on companies and assets that others have given up on. Sometimes, as with the purchase of control of the CNA Financial Corporation in 1974, the gamble has paid off handsomely. Many eyes were raised in early 1990 when Mr. Tisch and his family went heavily into New England bank stocks, which were then suffering from a severe real estate recession. Some of those investments did not pay off, but on balance it seems to have been a profitable strategy.
Mr. Tisch, 69 years old, and his brother, Preston, built their fortune through hotels and then Loews Theaters, which they have since sold. The Loews Corporation, which they control, has a 23 percent stake in CBS Inc., but that is far from its only holding. Loews controls CNA and owns Lorillard, the tobacco company whose brands include Kent and Newport. It also operates hotels and owns Bulova, the watch company.
CBS has been a successful investment for Loews, which last year took $537 million out of the company through a stock repurchase plan. But Mr. Tisch's tenure has featured cuts in expenses that angered some employees, as similar cuts had at CNA.

HEADLINE: BUSH TO ASK MORE FOR BASE CLEANUPS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has sharply increased its estimate of the cost of cleaning up pollution on military bases, and plans to ask Congress for an immediate increase of $1 billion for this purpose beyond the $2.7 billion already included in this year's military budget.
The Administration's request for funds to clean up the environment at military bases in the fiscal year 1993, which begins Oct. 1, has also been raised about $1 billion, to $3.7 billion, according to budget documents made public today. 
 The spending plans were disclosed at a White House briefing where President Bush and his top environmental aides sought to highlight the growth in spending on the environment in this Administration. It is part of a strategy to squeeze maximum political benefit from the Administration's budget requests, which will be officially made public after the State of the Union Message next week. Just the other day, Mr. Bush announced in Baltimore a sharp increase in funds for Head Start preschool program for the poor.
 
A Way to Gain Attention
 The White House was apparently concerned that if the environmental program was not announced in advance, it would get scant attention amid other features of the President's program, like economic stimulation and Pentagon spending cuts.
"I think this preview of coming attractions in the budget will be good news for all of us who share our concern about America's environment," Mr. Bush said.
Whatever the motivation for the budget request, the plan was welcomed by private environmental groups and Congress members who had been seeking more money for cleaning up the bases, many of which are being closed and converted to civilian purposes.
"I think the Department of Defense supplemental budget request is very welcome and needed," said Ralph De Gennaro, a budget analyst at Friends of the Earth. "It is a second level peace dividend."
Representative Richard Ray, a Georgia Democrat who is a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said: "Each year you delay, the costs get greater. We had been discouraged, thinking that the Defense Department may be, in these tough budgetary times, backing away from an important responsibility."
 
Likely Military Cutbacks
 The rise in environmental costs facing the Pentagon comes at a time when its budgets for weapons, research and personnel are likely to be sharply cut because of the decline in the military threat posed by the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Ray said that estimates of what it would cost to clean up 1,800 known polluted sites on military bases easily exceeded $20 billion, and that the Pentagon budgets enacted last year by Congress fell at least $1 billion short of what was needed this fiscal year.
Along with a separate request to spend $5.5 billion next year cleaning up pollution from the Energy Department's nuclear weapon programs, the budget figures announced today show that cleaning up after the cold war is going to cost more than $9 billion in the fiscal year 1993. That is considerably more than the total spending of the Environmental Protection Agency, which is $7 billion under the budget request for 1993 that is to be sent to Congress next week.
William K. Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today at the White House briefing that since the start of the Bush Administration in January 1989, the agency's annual budget had risen 44 percent.
The budget documents did not disclose any drastic new programs, but they did include several large grants for specific regions, like the Great Lakes, the Gulf of Mexico, the Mexican-American border area, the Chesapeake Bay area and Boston Harbor.
The environmental agency's operating budget, considered by experts to be an important measure of its activities, would be $2.7 billion in 1993, an increase of $120 million above the current level, and up 54 percent since 1989, when the Administration took office.
But Mr. De Gennaro of the environmental group said that after accounting for inflation, the operating budget was up only 16 percent, while the agency's workload was increasing sharply because of several new environmental laws.
"Over all, there are some welcome incremental increases, and there are some cuts in the fine print that we will learn about next week," he said. "It does not add up to a big new domestic policy on the environment, if that was the goal."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House
Leader and Salesman;
Bush Turns to Power of Incumbency And Tries to Defuse Revolt in Party

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
After apologizing for the state of the economy and assuring Americans that he cares, President Bush this week has moved to a new phase of his re-election campaign in which he is trying to use the power of his incumbency to demonstrate that he is doing something about the nation's problems.
But underscoring the difficulties he faces in selling his policies to the entire country, the President is still struggling to gather members of his own party behind the economic growth package that he will present in the State of the Union Message next Tuesday. 
 Samuel K. Skinner, the White House chief of staff, met with about 50 House Republicans today in an effort to keep their disappointment with some proposals to be included in the package from turning into open rebellion.
Republican Congressional officials said many of the lawmakers, under pressure from constituents, had told Mr. Skinner that they wanted a deeper cut in the tax rate on capital gains than Mr. Bush is expected to urge. Administration officials have said Mr. Bush's proposal will mirror one he made last year: to cap the rate at about 20 percent, down from 28 percent.
 
'Some Level of Concern'
 "There was some level of concern and anxiety that the President would not make the kind of speech and growth package that some of the members feel is essential," one Republican Congressional official said today.
During the week, Mr. Bush has made a series of announcements on preschool education, the environment and other issues intended to show that he is coming to grips with domestic needs.
And while Mr. Skinner moves toward a reorganization of the White House staff intended to put it on a campaign footing, the re-election team has made final its plans to promote the goals of the State of the Union after the speech.
But the clear sense of urgency in the White House and the Bush campaign to regain ground in the Presidential race has been tempered by the underlying realities of this Presidency: The politics of 1992 demand action, but Mr. Bush and his economic advisers believe there are no quick solutions to the recession and are committed to observing the spending limits in the 1990 budget agreement with Congress.
 
Appealing to Common Sense
 This morning, Mr. Bush himself seemed to acknowledge the tensions between the needs of his campaign and the demands of the Presidency. "You're going to hear all kinds of proposals out there promoting a lot of gimmicks," he told the National Association of Wholesalers-Distributors. "Given the fact this country is hurting, people are hurting, you're going to see a lot of quick fixes that will supposedly turn the economy around. I don't believe we need them. I think we've got to set common-sense goals, stick with them."
Still, Mr. Bush's hectic schedule this week seemed to address his political problems as much as the imperatives of governing, and it was infused with the air of a President's rapidly turning into a full-time candidate.
Mr. Bush has clearly been using his Presidency as a campaign weapon, arguing that he is trying to govern while the Democrats are electioneering. He has said that his State of the Union Message and his budget proposal, both clearly political documents, are "Presidential" and "transcend politics," and that Congress should rise above partisanship to consider them.
These statements are part of a central strategy of the Bush campaign: If Mr. Bush's economic growth proposals do not pass in Congress, the Republicans want to be able to make the case that it is the fault of the Democrats, who control Capitol Hill.
 
A Strategy Emerges
 The Bush campaign's strategy for the early part of the race has emerged in recent weeks, now that the President has abandoned his attempts to assure the country that the recession is ending, and that the economy would soon right itself.
The White House conceded in December that the recession was continuing, and Mr. Bush began his campaign in New Hampshire last week by apologizing for the state of the economy and promising voters there that he is concerned about them. "Message: I care," Mr. Bush said.
But campaign strategists have said that it is not enough for Mr. Bush to say he cares, that he must now demonstrate that he is taking action to right the economy and to erase any impression that he is not spending enough time on domestic issues.
To that end, the White House announced plans today to increase spending on the environment, and Administration officials sought a compromise with lawmakers that would avert another fight over extending unemployment benefits.
Administration officials are also drafting plans for new arms reductions which they hope would demonstrate Mr. Bush's mastery of foreign policy and satisfy demands for further cuts in military spending. In another cost-cutting move, the Pentagon is planning to limit investments in new weapons systems to research and design. And on Tuesday, Mr. Bush proposed the biggest increase ever in spending for Head Start, the preschool program.
Some Administration officials and Republican strategists remain concerned that Mr. Bush is staking too much on his address to Congress next Tuesday. But they say that he has committed himself to a strategy of using the speech and his 1993 budget, due out the next day, as the launching pad for his campaign, and that all the short-term activities of the Administration and the campaign are now geared toward those events.
Mr. Bush and his top advisers held a series of meetings this week about the economy and the campaign, including a lunchtime session today attended by the President, his campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, and his campaign manager, Frederick Malek, officials said.
After the State of the Union, officials said, Mr. Bush will give two or three speeches, most likely including a trip to California and one to Cincinnati, to promote his economic proposals.
He is also expected to campaign in New Hampshire on the weekend before the Feb. 18 primary. His re-election team is to televise its first commercials in New Hampshire this weekend.
Campaign aides said they would underscore the theme that Mr. Bush is listening to the voters in that state. "The message is: 'I know what's going on here. I know there are problems. We will have a sensible, real plan, with real results," said Victoria Clarke, Mr. Bush's campaign press secretary.

HEADLINE: Sales of American Vehicles Dropped 1.9% in Mid-January

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America declined 1.9 percent in mid-January, auto makers reported today.
Industry analysts said the figures suggest that the market is neither improving nor worsening.
"It's a continuation of the malaise," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in Manhattan. "We're probably going to bump along the bottom of this trough another six to eight weeks."
 
Consumers 'Overly Cautious'
 
 Tom Webb, chief economist at the National Automobile Dealers Association, said that although some segments of the industry posted gains, "there is no denying that the retail customer remains overly cautious."
Auto makers with American plants sold 116,395 cars between Jan. 11 and Jan. 20, a decline of 7.1 percent from the corresponding 1991 period. Sales of American-made light trucks rose 7.9 percent, to 70,856, but those gains came over a particularly weak sales period in mid-January 1991, when consumers shunned less fuel-efficient vehicles at the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war.
Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.7 million, compared with 6.6 million in the period last year. There were eight selling days in the mid-January sales period both this year and last year.
Although the figures suggested strong consumer interest in Japanese-brand cars, several dealers said many foreign-car owners had expressed greater interest in American-brand vehicles since President Bush's recent trip to Japan, which underscored America's trade deficit with that country.
Edward Kalaydjian, who owns a Pontiac dealership in Mount Kisco, N.Y., said about a quarter of his customers were foreign-car owners who said they had decided to buy an American-brand car. One Midwest dealer with both domestic and foreign franchises said sales of his American-brand cars were up 20 percent over last January, while foreign-brand sales were flat. "It's not just one store; all three G.M. stores are ahead," said Ray Green, who owns five dealerships across central Illinois.
Martin Biener, owner of a Pontiac and Nissan dealership in Great Neck, L.I., said that Pontiac dealers in metropolitan New York would begin a television ad campaign this week designed to fan the "buy American" sentiment among consumers. The commercials will refer to the comments a leading Japanese politician made last weekend on the shortcomings of American workers.
Some dealers, however, said they had not seen renewed interest in American cars. At Bob Thomas Chevrolet-Cadillac-Honda in Bend, Ore., the sales ratio of foreign to domestic nameplates remained unchanged. Nick Taylor, sales manager, said sales of Hondas were flat in 1991 compared with 1990, while his Chevrolet franchise suffered a roughly 30 percent drop in sales.
In the mid-January period, the General Motors Corporation sold 53,959 American-made cars, a decline of 9.9 percent. G.M.'s light-truck sales fell 3.6 percent, to 26,211 units.
The Ford Motor Company's domestic car sales were off 8.8. percent, to 30,746 vehicles. The auto maker's light-truck sales were up 13.6 percent, to 25,283.
The sales results included an estimate for the Chrysler Corporation, which does not report 10-day sales. The estimates, provided by Ward's Automotive Reports, indicated Chrysler's sales of domestically produced cars fell 24.6 percent, to 11,800. Sales of Chrysler's mini-vans, Jeeps and pickup trucks rose 22.2 percent, to an estimated 15,800 vehicles in mid-January.
Both the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company reported sharp jumps in sales, partly because of leasing promotions.

HEADLINE: As Cabbies Protest, Taxi Panel Decides Against Fare Increase

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Unlike subway and bus passengers, cab users won't be paying more for their rides -- at least not right away.
The chairman of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission said yesterday that he would not propose a taxi fare increase. As he made the statement, more than 300 cabs drove through downtown and midtown Manhattan to protest even the possibility of an increase. 
 The chairman, Fidel F. Del Valle, said at a Commission meeting yesterday morning that he would not recommend a fare increase because it did not "make sense" now. Mr. Del Valle said an increase might be counterproductive to the taxi industry because it would drive away riders.
"It would certainly not be welcome by a public whose own incomes have suffered in the recession," he added.
Luckmann Lalanne, one of the drivers in the convoy, agreed. "We are here because we refuse the fare increase," he said. "The economy is bad and this will drive our business away. This will send our business to the gypsy cabs."
 
Convoy Effect Slight
 The convoy, off-duty lights on and horns blaring continuously, started in the morning and, at midday, wound its way through the heart of the city's major business and retail districts. But the impact on traffic appeared relatively light because the cabs were moving quickly and because the police split the convoy into smaller groups.
The Taxi and Limousine Commission had been reviewing the financial health of the taxi industry and the possibility of a fare increase since early last year, when the Persian Gulf war briefly caused gasoline prices to escalate. Under the City Charter, formal consideration of an increase does not begin until the chairman proposes one.
The current taxi rates are $1.50 at the start and 25 cents for each one-fifth of a mile. The charge for waiting time is 20 cents per minute, and there is a 50-cents-per trip surcharge in effect from 8 P.M. to 6 A.M.
Mr. Del Valle, in explaining why he did not recommend an increase, noted that at a public hearing last month, taxi industry leaders were divided about whether they wanted the fare to go up.
Some drivers and owners said that an increase would hurt their business, Mr. Del Valle said. Some taxi associations took no position on the fare and some industry representatives favored an increase, he said.
Mr. Del Valle said that proponents of an increase had not made a compelling case. As for those who were opposed, he said, "It would be almost perverse to propose a higher fare that lacks drivers' support."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A caravan of about 350 medallion cabs wound its way yesterday through New York City streets, including 42d Street, near Eighth Avenue, above, in a protest against a proposed 10-cent fare increase. Later, the Taxi and Limousine Commission announced that there would be no increase. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Mayors Appear Unmoved by the Major Candidates

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
After hearing pitches from the Democratic Presidential contenders on how they would revive America's cities, dozens of mayors meeting here today seemed to agree on one thing: the single candidate who truly understands urban needs is Larry Agran.
Given that Mr. Agran was once a mayor himself, of Irvine, Calif., it is not surprising that participants in a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors would rally behind behind his long-shot Presidential candidacy. 
 Though most of the mayors did not view Mr. Agran as a likely Democratic nominee, they did find his ideas appealing, which says less about Mr. Agran than about the unfamiliarity of the major Democratic candidates with the issues confronting urban America.
At a forum of the mayors here Wednesday night, the candidates offered their plans for helping cities after what they all said were years of neglect under Republican Administrations. But several mayors, from large cities and small towns, said in interviews today that while they were encouraged that the candidates were addressing the problems of cities, they were disappointed because many of the proposals were sketchy and sometimes naive.
Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, president of the Conference of Mayors, said he had hoped to rally the Democrats in the organization around one Presidential candidate for the first time. But he said today that this was not possible, at least for now, because none of the major contenders performed strongly enough to merit wide support.
"I want a little fire in the belly here for America's cities," Mr. Flynn said. "There's still this hesitancy among the candidates. We want people to be fiscally responsible. But we want somebody who's really going to have a feeling of commitment to problems like homelessness and AIDS."
Mr. Agran, who as a mayor ran a city with a population of 111,418 in the 1980's, is usually excluded from forums at which the major Democratic contenders appear. But he won approval from the mayors by proposing the most direct assistance to cities: $25 billion in "no-strings-attached" aid, with the money coming from a $150 billion cut in military spending.
"I thought the Mayor was the best candidate," said Mayor John Robinson of Wausau, Wis., echoing many of his colleagues. "He had a specific program and had given it some thought."
The other candidates sought to distinguish themselves at the forum but sometimes drew criticism. Several mayors said they objected to the suggestion by Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska that he would use the military to fight drugs in the cities.
Calling the drug problem a "national security issue," Mr. Kerrey said: "I would not hesitate to use our military forces, and to make them available in the cities to wage that war. I would not hesitate as well to use all available force to make certain that our children are protected from criminals and others who are preying on them in the streets."
Other mayors said they were disturbed that Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas said he was not ready to back a proposal by Senators Paul Sarbanes of Maryland and Jim Sasser of Tennessee, widely supported by mayors, that would pump $35 billion into the economy for public works projects, education and grants to state and local governments.
 
Clinton's Housing Plan
 "I just don't want to commit to the Sasser-Sarbanes proposal," Mr. Clinton said, "until I know that we have a way to pay for it and the money is going to be there."
J. Thomas Cochran, executive director of the Conference of Mayors, said that while Mr. Clinton was "really reaching out" among the mayors, his comments about the Sarbanes-Sasser plan "caused some concern."
Some mayors said they were encouraged by Mr. Clinton's proposal for a "genuine housing program" that provides housing for the homeless and and the "flat out poor who have fallen beneath the safety net."
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts assured the audience that "no matter which of us is elected President, you're going to be a lot better off than you are today." He want on to press for more private investment, saying, "The answer in the cities is the private sector providing private-sector jobs so that people have the dignity of that kind of work."
In offering their remedies for the cities, candidates often emphasized their basic speeches. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., of California, said the urban ills could be addressed by empowering the grass roots.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, citing a scheduling conflict, did not appear at the forum but addressed the mayors Wednesday. He vowed to meet with mayors in his first week as President.
Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore disputed some of the criticism of the candidates, saying, "They are concerned with the problems of the cities and they are not locking out the poor and minorities from their campaigns."

HEADLINE: Officials Defend Policies To Protect Bond Market

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Government officials who oversee the Treasury securities market asserted at a Senate committee hearing today that the changes they mandated on Wednesday would not disrupt trading and that they would move slowly before imposing the more contentious proposals.
A key goal of the regulators was to preserve the $2.2 trillion Treasury market as a place where speculators and investors can easily and quickly trade hundreds of millions of dollars of securities without causing a ripple effect on prices. 
 The intangible value of the Treasury market is great enough that David W. Mullins, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the committee that it was "a national resource." It is a market that has no trading floor but attracts tens of billions of dollars of speculators' money from around the world and in effect sets interest rates for other securities and home mortgages.
While the Securities and Exchange Commission favored broader changes than were supported by the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve, the three agencies, which issued an outline of their plan on Wednesday, agreed that the new practices should go a long way toward preventing rigged auctions of Treasury securities, and other abusive trading tactics like those that Salomon Brothers admitted using last year.
Salomon, whose heavy-handed trading was the catalyst for the broad study that led to this week's changes, remains the subject of an investigation by the S.E.C.
Richard C. Breeden, head of the S.E.C. said about 150 witnesses had been interviewed and more than 25,000 pages of testimony collected, with more interviews scheduled. The time needed to finish the investigation will depend on the cooperation of various witnesses, he said.
Mr. Breeden said the difficulty of piecing together exactly what happened at Salomon was one reason that he supports the proposal of giving regulators the authority to require Treasury securities firms to provide records of all their trades, as is now the case in the stock and options markets.
Securities dealers in New York gave the changes and proposed changes in regulation of securities dealers and Treasury auctions mixed reviews today.
"It was a pretty decent effort that balanced the need for some changes in the market, but still preserves its efficiency," said Jon S. Corzine, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of the largest dealers. Mr. Corzine and several other dealers said they doubted that one proposal to establish a new method of auctioning Treasury securities would reduce the interest rates the Government pays.
The Treasury, which is promising to automate its existing system of written bids, is also planning a new kind of auction in which the Treasury will poll dealers until it finds an interest rate at which all its securities could be sold at a single price, rather than various prices as is now the case. Dealers warned that prices and market conditions change minute by minute, and that the new system would be cumbersome because they fear it would take at least several minutes to complete. The auction is now conducted with a single deadline for all bids.
"It is an idea that needs a lot of study," said Stephen G. Thieke, president of J. P. Morgan Securities. "It may not cause any decline in participation at the auctions, but it may cost the Treasury some money."
Dealers dislike the proposal, favored by Mr. Breeden and the S.E.C. but not supported by the Fed or Treasury, to require large dealers to report their trades to regulators. "A lot of customers would find that intrusive," Mr. Thieke said. Other dealers said traders could shift their activity overseas or to other markets.
Another S.E.C. suggestion, that the amount and price of all trades be made public, was widely criticized by dealers who said the information would make them less willing to take the risk of trading large blocks of securities. Unlike the New York Stock Exchange, where trades are disclosed and securities dealers generally act as agent executing trades for customers at prices set by stock specialists on the floor of the exchange, Treasury dealers buy and sell mostly from their own inventory.
Dealers approved of the Treasury's plans to issue more securities in cases where traders might have cornered the market in a particular issue. "It is an excellent idea," said Rafe de la Gueronniere, chairman of the Discount Corporation, a government securities dealer.

HEADLINE: Congressional Democrats Mount Offensive on Unemployment Pay

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Democrats went on the offensive today over another extension of unemployment benefits and dared Republicans to delay the measure by objecting to its financing.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, appeared as a witness before a subcommittee of the panel and said that another 13 weeks of benefits for the long-term unemployed were essential now while the jobless waited for the economy to recover. 
 Lynn Martin, Secretary of Labor, declined to appear at today's hearing to discuss the Bush Administration's policy in advance of Tuesday's State of the Union Message. A White House aide said that extended benefits would be discussed in the message but that the President would not endorse paying for them by declaring an emergency and increasing the deficit.
 
Vote Planned Before Speech
 Democrats responded by scheduling a vote of the full committee for Tuesday, hours before the speech and in time to make evening television news programs. An extension of unemployment benefits would follow a 13-to-20 week program enacted in November.
The Senate Finance Committee plans to hold a hearing on a bill of its own on Wednesday, the day after the State of the Union Message. A House vote is likely the first week in February.
Mr. Rostenkowski said most of the $4.5 billion cost of an additional 13 weeks of benefits for people already out of work at least half a year could be financed out of savings by Congress as reflected in a recent report by the Administration's Office of Management and Budget.
The report said Congress had voted savings that would amount to $3.7 billion over the five years ending Sept. 30, 1996.
He said Mr. Bush should declare an emergency under the 1990 Budget Act to allow the $4.5 billion to be spent.
 
'Real Pain in My Neighborhood'
 Citing aid approved last year under similar provisions for Kurds, Turks, Egyptians and Bangladeshis, Mr. Rostenkowski said the November extension would begin running out in mid-February. He said rising unemployment had caused "real pain in my neighborhood, in my city, in my state and across America.
"If this is not an emergency, then tell me what is," he said.
If Mr. Rostenkowski's bill is enacted, either with a Presidential signature or over Mr. Bush's veto, it would automatically declare that emergency. It would help between 2 million and 2 1/2 million people.
Mr. Bush vetoed such a benefits bill last fall and was sustained by two votes in the Senate. But neither he nor Republicans in Congress relish the idea of taking that stand again, and White House aides indicated today that they were trying to devise a compromise in paying for benefits that would not require an emergency declaration.
 
Hope for 'Creative' Solution
 November's extension was deemed to be paid for under budget accounting rules that counted future tax extensions as current revenue. An O.M.B. spending estimate that made the program less costly than Congress thought it was also made it much easier to pay for.
The House minority leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, testified at the same hearing that while he liked Mr. Rostenkowski's idea of using the $3.7 billion in savings to help the unemployed, "I can't conceive of the President using the emergency option." He said he hoped a "creative" way of finding money could be developed.
Representative Marty Russo, a Democratic member of the Ways and Means Committee who faces a tough primary race in Illinois in March, challenged Mr. Michel, saying there already was money in the Federal unemployment trust fund to pay the cost of additional benefits. "We don't have to be creative," he said. "We already paid for it."

HEADLINE: Money Awaits at I.R.S., Working Poor Advised

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The nation's poorest working families can lose as much as $2,020 each by failing to file a Federal tax return this year, officials said today. About 2 million of these families failed to collect hundreds of dollars each by not filing tax returns last year.
The number of families eligible for this money -- called the earned-income credit -- is larger than ever because Congress raised the benefit and the recession reduced many workers' incomes, Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. of the Internal Revenue Service said at a news conference. 
 "This is a law that really does do good things for working families," Mr. Goldberg said. "The measure of our success is if every family entitled to this credit claims it and gets every dollar they are due."
Mr. Goldberg helped open a nationwide campaign to inform families with children and earnings under $21,250 a year that they are eligible for the credit. The campaign theme is "Two Simple Steps," reminding eligible workers that to claim the credit they must file a tax return and attach special schedule E.I.C., for earned income credit.
Wage earners whose incomes are so low that they have no income tax withheld can still receive money under the program. Government officials fear that many of these people are the ones who neglect to claim the benefit because they do not realize they are eligible.
More than 12 million families claimed the credit on tax returns filed last year and received a total of almost $7 billion. The I.R.S. estimated that 2 million eligible families failed to claim the credit and that 2 million more are eligible this year for the first time.
"This is the largest low-income and moderate-income program the Federal Government has," said Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a nonprofit organization that is heading the campaign.
Mr. Greenstein's group, along with the United Way of America, organized labor, the United States Conference of Mayors and other organizations are distributing information about the credit.
The credit was enacted to help offset part of the Social Security tax and to give lower-income workers an incentive to stay off the welfare rolls.
The maximum basic earned-income credit is $1,235. Two supplemental credits, made available last year for the first time, offer up to $357 more for a child born last year and an additional $428 to offset part of the cost of health insurance for a child.
Vincent R. Sombrotto, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers, speaking for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said that part-time workers and employees who were on strike during part of 1991 may qualify for all or part of the credit.

HEADLINE: Neediest Cases Surpasses '91 Total

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Setting records is nothing new for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Fifty of its 80 annual appeals have raised more money than any before them.
But this year's campaign, which surpassed last year's total of $4.44 million yesterday, is one of the few to set a record during an economic downturn. 
 Since it was founded in 1912, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has been a fairly reliable barometer of the nation's economy. During times of economic growth -- the 1920's, the 50's and the 80's -- the Neediest Cases has posted healthy gains in the amount of money raised. During bad times -- especially the 1930's and the early 70's -- it has suffered declines.
But with records set in the 1990, the 1991 and now the 1992 campaigns, the current recession is the first extended downturn that has not brought a decline in giving.
"Last fall, none of the seven charities participating in the Neediest drive believed that total contributions this year would even come close to the remarkable record set the year before," said Arthur Gelb, president of the New York Times Foundation, which administers the fund. "The fact that the Fund has now moved ahead of that record, with five weeks to go before the drive ends, is a triumphant achievement in these troubled times.
"On behalf of the seven charities, we thank the thousands of Times readers who have contributed -- and who are planning to do so -- for their outpouring of generosity."
 
Early String of Records
 From the first campaign, when $3,630.88 was raised, the fund seemed an irresistible force. In each of the 18 subsequent years, it raised more than the year before, reaching its peak in the 1929-30 drive, when $345,790.65 was recorded.
But the 1930-31 appeal met an immovable object, the Depression. Receipts plummeted 14 percent, to $298,002. The long Depression was almost immediately followed by World War II, and the Neediest Cases did not set another record until 1945, when $386,608.56 was raised.
During the postwar era, the fund reflected the intial period of dislocation, registering declines from 1947 to 1949. It also reflected the boom that followed, posting gains in 17 of the next 20 campaigns.
But beginning with the 1977-78 campaign, the fund entered its greatest period of growth. During the next 13 years its receipts quadrupled -- from the $1,103,189 raised that year to the $4,439,093.47 recorded in 1990-91. It set records in 11 of those 13 years, but declines were posted in two years of economic downturn, the 1979-80, and 1983-84 campaigns.
Although the campaign has grown during the last 80 years, little else has changed since it was founded by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The Times.
The newspaper covers all of the expenses so that every dollar is passed to charities that work directly with the city's poor, sick and disabled. The fund has never engaged solicitors or agents but, as an editorial from the first campaign stated, has always trusted Times readers to respond simply by being shown "a world of famine in the midst of plenty; of cruel heart and body hunger with bounty in sight but not in reach."

HEADLINE: Big Jump in Jobless Pay Claims

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Government said today that claims for jobless benefits surged in the second week of January by about 46,000 from the previous week.
The jump in claims for unemployment pay might pressure President Bush, who has adopted the electioneering slogan of "I care," to extend jobless benefits for the longterm unemployed for a second time. 
 After being adjusted for the season, the Labor Department reported that first-time claims for jobless benefits rose to 447,000 in the week that ended Jan. 11, up from 401,000 a week earlier. The rise probably reflects a surge in the number of people who delayed filing claims over the holidays, as well as an increase in layoffs at the end of the year, analysts said. "At almost 450,000, you are talking about rising joblessness," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University. "This is still at recessionary levels."
The number of people already receiving unemployment benefits also climbed, showing that the unemployed are facing a tough time getting another job. This number rose by 184,000 to 3.44 million in the week ended Jan. 4, the latest week for which the data is available, the department said.
That brings the number receiving unemployment pay close to the high of 3.49 million reached in mid-November, just before President Bush, under pressure from the Democrats in Congress, agreed to extend the six months of jobless benefits for another 13 to 20 weeks.
Those extended benefits expire in February, on the eve of the New Hampshire primary. The Washington Post reported on Thursday that Mr. Bush, abandoning his stance that economic recovery is just around the corner, is ready to extend benefits again. The unemployment rate stands at 7.1 percent.
One in three of the nation's 8.9 million unemployed in December had been jobless for at least 15 weeks, with many out of work for over half a year, the department said recently.
But in one encouraging sign, the four-week moving average for first-time jobless benefit claims dropped to 434,000 in the latest week, a decline of 5,000 from the previous period and its lowest since Nov. 2. Since weekly figures are highly volatile, the average rate is considered a more reliable indicator of trends.
