HEADLINE: An S.& L. Is Going Back to Basics

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The savings and loan industry may be putting its notorious past behind it, but the legacy of its headlong rush into deregulation a decade ago continues to haunt some of the nation's largest savings institutions as they scramble to adapt to new regulations and cope with a weak economy.
Nowhere is that scrambling more evident than at GlenFed Inc., the parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan. Considered by many analysts and industry executives to be among the biggest question marks hanging over regulators, GlenFed is virtually reinventing itself in an effort to assure its survival. 
 GlenFed is selling or winding down a host of businesses it entered in the 1980's, including title insurance, retail brokerage and real estate development. Under a plan developed by its vice chairman, Stephen J. Trafton, it has slashed costs more than a third by cutting employment and streamlining its operations, and it has bolstered its reserves for losses on loans.
Having been forced by Federal regulations to focus once again on the traditional savings and loan business of taking deposits and making residential mortgage loans, GlenFed has abandoned its dream of becoming a financial-services powerhouse. Mr. Trafton is instead trying to focus the company on community banking, which he defined as operating in towns and neighborhoods with branches that offer high levels of customer service. The authority to make loans, for example, has been pushed down to the level of the branches, eliminating bureaucratic delays as well as reducing costs.
GlenFed, parent of the Glendale Federal Bank, has 214 branches in California, Washington and Florida.
GlenFed's efforts come when most savings institutions, benefiting from declining interest rates and a renewed focus on their traditional deposit and mortgage businesses, are reporting improved profits. Two of the industry's strongest companies, the Golden West Financial Corporation of Oakland and the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, both in California, this week reported that 1991's earnings were records. H. F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles, the nation's largest savings company, which owns Home Savings, reported its second-best annual results.
Although rising default rates on home mortgages have led to increases in problem loans, the large losses on commercial real estate that battered results over the last two years have eased. And with almost all of the industry's most spectacular failures having been seized and sold off by the Government, the industry's overall results are showing marked improvement.
 
Fear Has Faded
 Through the first three quarters of last year, the most recent period for which figures are available, the industry's total loss narrowed to $2.6 billion from $9.7 billion in the similar period a year earlier, according to Sheshunoff Information Services Inc. of Austin, Tex., which tracks the industry. Three-quarters of the nation's 2,500 savings institutions were profitable and well capitalized in that period, and most of the losses were accounted for by fewer than 200 ailing companies.
"The amount of terror in the marketplace, the fear reflected in the valuations of the companies, has definitely faded," said Jonathan E. Gray, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York. "But while the hysteria is out of their values, I don't see any substantial strengthening on the part of many of these companies."
At GlenFed, there are signs that the overhaul is paying off. GlenFed posted earnings of $20.5 million, or 60 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $113.7 million in the corresponding 1990 period. The improvement came despite the deepening recession in California, which has caused more problems in mortgage loans and a decline in real estate values.
But to many analysts and industry executives, GlenFed's prospects remain unclear. GlenFed currently meets only two of the Government's three standards for financial strength. Although the company said it expected to bring itself back into compliance with the standard by the end of March, it acknowledged that it might fail to meet another new standard for capital strength that regulators are expected to impose soon.
Failure to meet the standards for capital, which is the financial cushion institutions keep to protect against losses, could lead to regulatory restrictions on GlenFed's growth or, in a worst case, seizure by the Government.
GlenFed would like to raise more capital by issuing stock or finding new outside investors. But Wall Street remains wary, especially because regulators have given no clear indication of how they plan to deal with the institution. GlenFed's stock price, which had been driven down to $3 last fall by investors who were worried about the company's ability to survive, has rebounded somewhat but remains far below the $25 level it was trading three years ago. The stock closed today at $6.375, up 50 cents on the Big Board.
"I think the effort that GlenFed has made to date puts them in the survivor camp," said E. Gareth Plank, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. "On the other hand, a $6 stock says my opinion is not shared by everyone."
 
Question of Size
 Even if GlenFed and other institutions facing similar situtations can overcome the problems posed by the weak economy and tightening regulation, they still face the question of whether there is a place for any but the largest and strongest savings and loans in an increasingly competitive financial services field.
Bert Ely, an industry consultant based in Alexandria, Va., said it was easy to argue that GlenFed and other institutions in similar positions, like GlenFed'a Los Angeles rivals CalFed Inc. and Coast Savings Financial Inc., were not going to survive. "That doesn't mean they are going to become insolvent, necessarily," he said. "But even if they are able to avoid being seized, I still don't see how they can survive for the long term because their market share is too small."
The view at GlenFed is far different. "There is absolutely a role for a family bank in a community setting," said Mr. Trafton, the GlenFed executive.
Mr. Trafton studied zoology in college but has spent the last 20 years working in the deepest jungles of the financial services industry, helping troubled banks and savings institutions work their way out of problems. When he joined GlenFed from Buffalo-based Goldome a year and a half ago, he was charged by its chairman, Norman M. Coulson, with examining the company from top to bottom and coming up with a vision of what kind of institution it should be and how it should get there.
"We needed to rework and re-engineer the company," Mr. Trafton said.
Mr. Trafton said he did not want to begin simply selling off GlenFed's most profitable loans, a step that other institutions have taken to raise capital, because such a strategy tended to backfire in the long run by leaving a company with a higher proportion of troubled loans.
But he did sell some assets, particularly those that were considered risky under the new regulatory rules. GlenFed also agreed recently to sell $500 million of its home equity loans for an undisclosed price. The company also used one-time gains on the sale of loans and securities to increase its loan-loss reserves.
To reduce costs, Mr. Trafton cut employment by 40 percent over the last 15 months, to 3,800 people. The resulting decline in operating costs -- to $72.7 million for the most recent quarter, 38 percent below the similar period a year earlier -- has helped increase profit margins.
Mr. Trafton said that he was optimistic about the company's future. But with the industry and investors still guessing about both the economy and the severity of future regulatory actions, he said the company still had difficulties to overcome.
"We need more capital, and we are working very hard on that," he said. "But potential investors simply don't know what new capital requirement might be imposed. It's difficult to go to an investor and ask for capital, and then two weeks later have new requirements imposed that put them at risk of having the capital seized."

HEADLINE: Centel Says It's Studying Possible Sale

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Centel Corporation, one of the country's largest non-Bell telephone companies and one of the few large cellular telephone properties not owned by a giant phone company, said yesterday that because of increasing industry consolidation, it might put itself on the auction block.
As recently as Wednesday, the stock market valued Centel at just over $3 billion. But yesterday, reacting to the news, the market bid up the company's share price by $9, to $46, raising Centel's value to nearly $4 billion. 
 Analysts said the company might be worth nearly $5 billion. They cited the potential value of the cellular telephone business, one of the fastest- growing sectors in a telecommunications industry slowed by recession.
Formally, Centel, which is based in Chicago, said simply that it was looking to "enhance shareholder value" and that it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company, which specialize in mergers and acquisitions, to advise management.
"All we're looking at is strategic alternatives," John P. Frazee Jr., chairman of Centel, said in an interview. "We think the consolidation of the telecommunications industry is inevitable, but we want to manage the process. A sale could be part of that, but I don't want to go into exact details of what we might do." He said there were "absolutely no bids on the table."
Centel's stock was the fourth most actively traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. With the $9 rise in price, Centel's 84.9 million shares are worth $3.9 billion. Marion M. Boucher, a telecommunications analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said Centel shares could be worth between $55 and $60 a share, or $4.67 billion to $5.1 billion, but that the maximum price seemed unlikely.
"The market is betting on the unrealized value of the cellular properties," Ms. Boucher said. "There really aren't any cellular properties left on the market, and all of a sudden this one is available."
Because Centel's biggest cellular telephone subscriber areas are in Nevada, Ms. Boucher said, Pacific Telesis, the regional Bell company in nearby San Francisco, is a logical buyer. But she said Bell South, Bell Atlantic and, to a lesser extent, the more cautious Ameritech, were also possible bidders.
And despite their recent large purchases of cellular properties, Ms. Boucher would not rule out GTE and McCaw Cellular, or an aggressive foreign company, like Britain's Cable and Wireless.
 
Steady Phone Earnings
 Centel is attractive because it is the 11th-largest local telephone company and the 10th-largest cellular-telephone company in the country. Local telephone carriers, despite heavy regulation, are attractive investments because of their steady earnings.
Centel has about 1.6 million telephone lines, about as many as Thailand, concentrated mainly in Nevada, Florida, North Carolina and Virginia. All of its 1990 profits of $47 million on revenue of $1.15 billion came from local phone service.
Centel lost $14.5 million on its cellular operations in 1990, but Mr. Frazee said it made a small profit last year. The cellular telephone industry, after heavy capital expenditures and substantial losses for start-up ventures, is just beginning to break even or earn small profits.
Of the top 10 cellular telephone companies, which cover two-thrids of the population, only Centel's business is not owned by McCaw, GTE or a Bell company. With 16.3 million potential subscribers, Centel dwarfs the rest of the independent cellular providers in the remainder of the top 25 companies.

HEADLINE: Donors in Need Aid Those Even Needier

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Instead of spending more on gifts this holiday season, thousands in the New York region gave more to charity instead, producing a surge of small donations that enabled many charities to reach goals that had seemed out of reach in November.
The deluge of checks for $100 and less defied widespread predictions that the deepening recession and a rising sense of indifference or anger toward the poor would lead to a drop in donations. 
 Instead, officials of some of New York's largest charities now say, the increasing visibility of suffering stirred compassion, often from families facing tighter budgets of their own. The charities see the increase as a tangible sign of an abiding sense of community at a time when some particularly ugly crimes of bias and against children have riveted New York City.
 
'Little Guy Came Through'
 Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York received 31 percent more donations under $75 between September and December 1991 than in the similar 1990 period.
"This was the year the little guy came through," said Msgr. Timothy McDonnell, the charity's chief financial officer. "It shows that when times are tough, New Yorkers are still there to help one another."
United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York raised 10 percent more last December than the year before because the number of small donations rose 20 percent. The Partnership for the Homeless received twice as many donations -- and three times as much money -- from this year's holiday mailing than the year before.
And The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which yesterday surpassed last year's record-setting total, is on a pace to raise 13 percent more money from 11 percent more contributors by the time the appeal ends on Feb. 29.
 
Offsetting Corporate Cutbacks
 Many charities in New York said the increase in individual contributions was especially timely because of declines in corporate and foundation grants. The Partnership for the Homeless reported a 37 percent decline in corporate gifts and an 18 percent decline in foundation grants. The Children's Aid Society received about $100,000 less in major grants this December, but individuals donated $135,000 more.
Telephone interviews with 21 large charities in seven cities suggest that the outpouring was a national trend. Most charities echoed reports from the Salvation Army in Chicago, the American Red Cross in Houston and the Glide-Memorial Methodist Church in San Francisco, all of which raised more money from more people.
The Neediest Cases and the independent campaigns run by the seven large charities it supports have so far raised $24.6 million from more than 34,000 donations. In addition, with a third of its campaign complete, the United Way of New York City is about 5 percent ahead of last year's pace, when $72 million was raised.
That more people are in need is clear, but donors said their decision to give was often the outcome of mixed impulses. Some described paring already tight family budgets to make sure there would be enough to give to charity; others talked of balancing anger at the problems that are so visible with the compassion that scenes of suffering produced.
On his way to work each morning, Larry Feldman, of Yonkers, N.Y., drives by dozens of tents set up by the homeless along the Bronx River Parkway. The tableaus of despair intensify as he gets closer to his engineering firm in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx: drug dealers sharing pay phones with addicts and prostitutes, crowds of homeless people huddled near trash bin fires, all oblivious to the cyclones of filthy debris that swirl around them on windy winter days.
At first, Mr. Feldman simply recoiled from these images. "Part of me says: I pay taxes; why do I have to put up with this," he said. "But another part of me says what a tragedy this is."
He finally decided to give $100 to the Neediest Cases Fund. "In the end the part of me that felt bad won out" Mr. Feldman said. "If people like me don't step forward and do something, then how will it ever change?"
 
No Restaurant Meals
 John Descovich, a 35-year-old mechanic for Con Edison, says things are tough for his family even though he has a job. His wife has begun clipping coupons religiously and working more hours at her part-time job. His two small children often wear hand-me-downs provided by his neighbors. He laughed derisively when asked how often he takes his wife out to dinner.
But when his company began its United Way charity drive he pledged money -- $1 a week -- as he has before, and served as an organizer for the first time. "How tough it's been for me made me realize how much worse it must be for a lot of other people," he said. "God knows, I could lose my job someday and be out there with nothing. I hope someone would help me."
 
Anxiety Proves Unfounded
 Many charity officials were anxious in late November -- at the opening of the holiday season that provides most of a year's donations -- when contributions were level or decreasing. Donations to The Children's Aid Society were down 7 percent from a year earlier, and unsolicited gifts to Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn were down 30 percent. As late as Dec. 21, the Neediest Cases was $115,000 behind the previous year's pace; yesterday, it was $546,000 ahead.
In response to early concerns, many groups deployed broader and more sophisticated direct mail efforts.
The Partnership for the Homeless hired an outside firm to prepare its two-page holiday appeal.
Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn -- which has received 67 percent more money from 32 percent more donors this year -- increased its Christmas mailing by 13 percent, sending out 186,000 letters. Patricia McElroy, who headed the campaign, said she also "toned down" the religious nature, replacing the picture of Bishop Thomas V. Daily on the cover with one of the Brooklyn Bridge.
But the focus is always personal.
Since she made her first contribution to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies in December, Allyson Gail King of Manhattan said she has been able to visit some of the programs her money supports.
"Since I got involved I feel my life is more well-rounded," she said. "I've always known that a lot of people have a hard time in the world, and by giving my time and my money I know I'm helping. It's a great feeling."

HEADLINE: The New Buy-American Auto Sweepstakes

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Maybe it was President Bush's mixed success in Japan, or the Japanese official who said that American auto workers were lazy and illiterate. Maybe it is the deep slump in Detroit. But all of a sudden, companies around the United States are saying it would be good for America to be good to G.M., and they are offering inducements to their employees to buy from General Motors, Chrysler or Ford.
Some, groping to define just what constitutes an American car, are authorizing employees to buy autos made at the Honda plant in Marysville, Ohio, or Nissan's factory in Smyrna, Tenn. But other companies have ruled out cars carrying American nameplates if they are manufactured in Canada or Japan. 
 The incentives to buy American come amid a continuing slump, with auto makers reporting yesterday that sales of cars and light trucks built in the United States fell 1.9 percent in mid-January. [Page D4.]
Yesterday the Monsanto Chemical Company offered its 12,000 employees $1,000 each to buy an American car. Earlier this week, the Tosco Corporation, an oil refining company based in Stamford, Conn., made the same offer, with half the money coming from an executive compensation fund.
Thomas D. O'Malley, the chairman of Tosco, who owns two Mercedes, said he came up with the idea after he told his children that he was thinking of buying a Ford Explorer. His 25-year-old son -- who drives a Mazda -- told his father to look at a Range Rover, an Isuzu and other imports.
"I got mad," Mr. O'Malley said. Young adults, he said, have "been in the syndrome that America makes junk." Besides, he said, if his program induces his employees to buy American, that will keep auto workers employed, and they can buy his gasoline. His program covers only those cars with 90 percent American content.
"I'm no believer in protectionism; I think it's absolute utter nonsense," Mr. O'Malley said. He added, however, that while his company sold gasoline in many other places in the Far East, it could not sell it to Japan.
Some of the buy-American programs are tinged with anti-Japanese sentiment. Even though other countries send cars to the United States, only Japan seems to be viewed as a threat.
Companies offering incentives are ambivalent about American branches of Japanese companies. James H. Gill, a Detroit-based spokesman for Nissan, pointed out that his company and Ford would soon start producing a compact family van from a factory near Cleveland. All the vans will come off the same assembly line and be produced by the same workers, he said, but some will be labeled Nissan Quests while others will receive the Ford Villager nameplate.
Under some of the new corporate incentive programs, the Villagers would qualify and the Quests would not, said Mr. Gill, who added that Nissan employed more than 60,000 Americans.
 
Storm? No. Prizm? Yes.
 At the company that says it started the subsidy movement, the Brown Paper Company of Greenwich, Conn., Douglas G. Brown, the owner, specified that the car must come from a plant that was at least half-owned by General Motors, Ford or Chrysler.
"One of the gals here was looking at a Geo Storm, and I told her N.G.," Mr. Brown said, because that car is imported from Japan even though it bears a General Motors emblem. But should she cast her eye on a Geo Prizm, he indicated, she'd be in the money: the car is made by Nummi Motors in California, a 50-50 venture of General Motors and Toyota.
Mr. Brown, who has been driving Audis for the last 10 years, is offering each of his 45 employees $1,000 to put themselves behind the wheel of a new American car. Shopping for a new model himself, he compared the Cadillac with a Lexus LS 400, an Acura Legend LS and an Audi V-6. He liked the American candidate.
 
'It's Not Japan Bashing'

 "Some cars out there are certainly worth a look," he said, "but the attitude of the average American is, 'I'm not going to look at an American car.' " Simply getting Americans into the showroom will be a good start, he said, adding that it is up to United States businesses to provide the nudge.
At St. Louis-based Monsanto Chemical, the president, Robert G. Potter, announced "Project Get Rolling," yesterday, saying: "We're a major supplier of plastics, rubber chemicals, resins, fibers and other performance products to the North American auto industry. So, it's in our interest that the auto industry be healthy." The Get Rolling incentive covers any vehicle built in North America.
Near the buckle of the Auto Belt, meanwhile, the Franklin Savings Bank of Southfield, Mich., is also offering its employees, and the employees of all the companies carrying commercial accounts with Franklin, checks for $100 if they get rolling in a new American model. Buying an import, said Rebecca J. Christian, senior vice president for communications and marketing at Franklin Savings, is "like buying Girl Scout cookies from the little girl next door and not from your own daughter."
"It's not Japan bashing," she said. "It's supporting your own economy."
The subsidies do not sit well with some industry officials, including Gregory Dana, a spokesman for the Association of International Auto Manufacturers, a Washington group that represents all the major importers except Mercedes. "The capitalist society we live in says to allow consumer choice, and we think that's the way it ought to work," he said. "It seems to me, if American cars aren't selling, there's a reason."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Omnicom Group to Acquire Goodby, Berlin

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
In an ambitious expansion effort, Omnicom Group Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy thestock that it did not already own in Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, a fast-growing advertising agency with a reputation for brash creativity .
Omnicom, the world's fourth-largest advertising group and owner of BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham Worldwide, intends to expand Goodby, Berlin, which is based in San Francisco, into a national operation that is expected to become its third agency network. 
 Omnicom's plans call for Goodby, Berlin, a midsized agency with about $250 million in billings, to open an office in New York sometime this year. Then, in all likelihood, it would expand overseas. If those plans pan out, Omnicom's three networks would match the number operated by two other global advertising giants, the Interpublic Group of Companies and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.
"The other two big networks we own are driven by advertising people who have creative backgrounds," said Bruce Crawford, chairman and chief executive of Omnicom in New York. "Goodby, Berlin just fits in very well with us."
Goodby, Berlin was named agency of the year for 1989 by Advertising Age, which praised its work for "unexpected freshness, typically accomplished with wit and warmth." The agency recently opened an office in Los Angeles to handle its largest and newest account, American Isuzu Motors.
Goodby, Berlin has rocketed to prominence since it was founded in 1983 by three men who had been co-workers at Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco. It has become known for audacious, attention-getting ads like its television commercials for The San Francisco Examiner, in which the newspaper's publisher, William Randolph Hearst 3d, stood up to the ghost of his legendary grandfather.
Omnicom "wants the same thing we want," Andy Berlin, a principal and co-founder of Goodby, Berlin, said in a telephone interview, "which is to make of Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, with their substantial resources, first a substantial national agency and then an international agency."
"I think you'll see in the course of the next year some bold and imaginative steps," added Mr. Berlin, who is likely to head the new New York office."
Such steps, comparable in their own way to the decision by General Motors to create the Saturn division to augment its five existing car lines, would be a challenge even during good times. But during an industrywide recession, it is nothing short of daunting.
"I'm an optimist, as opposed to some of the people who are whining a great deal," Mr. Crawford said, noting that the Goodby, Berlin purchase is the latest in a string for Omnicom that includes McKim Advertising, an advertising agency in Toronto, and the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership in London, an agency that had owned a 37.5 percent stake in Goodby, Berlin.
Mr. Berlin said he shared Mr. Crawford's perspective, adding, "At a time when clients are willing to move their accounts, the status quo might be as risky, if not more so, than change."
Agency companies like Omnicom, Interpublic and Saatchi have configured their agencies as independent, separate networks to attract, and retain, as many clients as possible, by allieviating potential client conflicts. Interpublic's three networks are Lintas Worldwide, the Lowe Group and McCann-Erickson; Saatchi's are Backer Spielvogel Bates, Campbell-Mithun-Esty and Saatchi & Saatchi.
The agency executives reassure clients that like parallel lines the networks never meet, so competitive strategies are safe from rival agencies. For instance, BBDO creates advertising for Chrysler's Dodge division, while DDB Needham handles Audi of America and Volkswagen of America.
"We've set it up so one has nothing to do with the other," Mr. Crawford said. Omnicom was formed in 1986 when three large agencies -- BBDO International, Doyle Dane Bernbach and Needham Harper Worldwide -- unexpectedly announced their amalgamation, under which BBDO remained separate, while Doyle Dane and Needham combined to form DDB Needham.
Already, Mr. Berlin said he was looking forward to battling BBDO and DDB Needham, anticipating that they will be "quite competitive" to Goodby, Berlin, particularly in New York. And, he added, the terms of the acquisition "give us all the independence and self-determination they have."
Mr. Crawford called it "premature to be talking about a third network." But, he said, "we're planning on expansion, no question about that."
While Goodby, Berlin's name might not now be a global advertising catch phrase, the agency has enjoyed a skein of American account victories that included The New Yorker, an image campaign for the National Basketball Association, the Carl's Jr. fast-food chain, various wine and liquor brands of Heublein Inc., and the Royal Viking Line.
That spate of billings gains was capped in August, when it was awarded the creative portion of American Isuzu's $90 million account in a fiercely competitive review.
Goodby, Berlin's first work for Isuzu, a television commercial to promote buyer incentives on the Rodeo sport-utility vehicle, began running earlier this week. The 30-second spot will also be seen during CBS's telecast of Super Bowl XXVI on Sunday. Typical Goodby, Berlin touches are evident in the spot, in which an unseen narrator, Mr. Berlin himself, discusses how the money to be saved by buying a Rodeo would enable consumers to afford other "stuff" like argyle socks and compact disks.
The transaction announced yesterday involves an agreement in principle by Omnicom to buy the remaining 62.5 percent of Goodby, Berlin's stock from the agency's four top executives, who will sign employment contracts. Three are the co-founders: Jeff Goodby, 40 years old; Mr. Berlin, 41, and Rich Silverstein, 42. The fourth is Colin Probert, 44, who became president in 1989.
In 1990, the last full year for which figures are available, Omnicom ranked fourth in both worldwide billings, at $9.7 billion, and worldwide gross income, at $1.34 billion.

HEADLINE: Ex-Officer Found Guilty of $17,000 Bank Fraud

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Jan. 23

 BODY:
After deliberating for less than an hour, a Federal jury today found Robert C. Fioretti, a former New York City police officer, guilty of stealing $17,000 from his first wife's savings account in 1986, two months after she vanished.
Mr. Fioretti, who is still the major suspect in the disappearance, sat motionless and stared blankly at the jury as the foreman read the guilty verdict. 
 The prosecutor, Assistant United States Attorney Charles Rose, immediately moved to have Mr. Fioretti remanded to Federal prison. He told Judge Leonard D. Wexler that a witness had come forward and told the Government that Mr. Fioretti had confessed to killing his first wife, Rita, and that he would flee at the first opportunity.
Mr. Rose said the witness, who he declined to name in open court, had shared a prison cell with Mr. Fioretti a year ago.
Judge Wexler remanded Mr. Fioretti to the Federal Correction Center in lower Manhattan pending the outcome of a further hearing on Mr. Rose's request on Monday.
 
'Cut and Dried'
 Mr. Fioretti's lawyer, Michael Soroka, argued that his client should remain free on bond and noted that he wore an electronic anklet, was limited to house arrest and had never missed a court appearance.
The jurors in the bank fraud trial said on leaving the courthouse this afternoon that they had carefully reviewed all of the evidence in the case against Mr. Fioretti and had reached a unanimous verdict on their first vote.
"It was cut and dried," said Laurie Schiavetta, 23 years old, of Selden, L.I. "After viewing the evidence, we had no doubts."
Another juror, Jennifer Corbett, 24, of Huntington, L.I., said the jurors "had a lunch, ripped little pieces of paper up for an informal ballot and found we all agreed, without a doubt, that he was guilty." The jurors deliberated for 45 minutes.
Mr. Fioretti was charged with forging his 33-year-old first wife's signature on two bank withdrawal slips and with illegally removing more than $17,000 from her savings account. He then deposited the money in another account he jointly shared with his second wife, Maureen Brooks, with whom he had lived and whom he married a few weeks after the disappearance of Rita Fioretti.
Mr. Fioretti was dismissed by the New York City Police Department in 1990 when he was charged with bank fraud. He has remained unemployed since then and has served nearly two years in prison awaiting trial. He now faces a 35-year prison term for his bank fraud conviction. No date has been set for sentencing.
He has never been charged in connection with the disappearance of his 33-year-old first wife. But he is to go on trial again in late February in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on charges of sexually assaulting his present wife's 12- and 13-year-old daughters and raping one of them in 1988 and 1989.
Both daughters and a third girl born to Ms. Brooks two months after she married Mr. Fioretti are now living with the father of the two older girls in upstate New York, law-enforcement officials said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Before Meeting; Gold Prices Fall Somewhat

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher against key currencies yesterday, strengthening largely on the uncertain outcome of a weekend meeting in New York by the finance ministers of the Group of Seven nations.
Gold prices weakened. At the Republic National Bank of New York, bullion fetched $354.60 an ounce as of 4 P.M., off $2.90 from Wednesday. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fetched $354.60 an ounce, off $3.30 from Wednesday. 
 Foreign exchange traders said the dollar's value rose out of concern that the financial emissaries from Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States, conferring on Saturday, would not directly address the question of what their currencies should be worth relative to each other.
Up until recently, many traders had expected the group would seek to promote world economic growth, particularly in the United States, by allowing the dollar to weaken versus the Japanese yen. They had sold the dollar partly on that expectation and hedged themselves yesterday by buying dollars.
John Lyman, a trader at the New York branch of the Bank of Tokyo, said the dollar also rose yesterday because of new weakness in the German mark, which stems from evidence that Germany's economy is deteriorating.
"There's a widely held feeling that the dollar's worth against the mark has bottomed, at least for the short term, so mark sales are occurring," Mr. Lyman said. "The market has got a whiff of recession in the air in Germany."
Curtis Perkins, a trader at Chemical Bank in New York, said the dollar also strengthened because of the timing of the Group of Seven meeting. The ministers are expected to release a communique late Saturday, when foreign exchange markets are closed. Many currency strategists protectively bought dollars, figuring that was less risky if there were any surprises in the communique.
"Everyone is very skittish," Mr. Perkins said. "You can't trade on the news" from the Group of Seven meeting.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 123.23 Japanese yen, from 123.34 yen on Wednesday. But later, in London, it rose to 123.85 yen. By the close of trading in New York, the dollar fetched 123.80 yen, up from 123.38 yen on Wednesday.
In London the British pound fell to $1.7960, from $1.8050 late on Wednesday. In New York the pound fetched $1.7850, cheaper than its $1.8055 value late on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York versus those of late Wednesday included: 1.6064 marks, up from 1.5905; 1.4260 Swiss francs, up from 1.4090; 1.1596 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1556; 5.4780 French francs, up from 5.4210, and 1,209.25 Italian lire, up from 1,195.50.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term U.S. Issues Off Steeply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell sharply and long-term interest rates rose further yesterday, as anxiety mounted among credit market participants about the coming battle in Washington over fiscal policy.
Traders and analysts said the sell off had nothing to do with underlying economic fundamentals, which remain positive for bonds. 
 In that vein, automobile manufacturers reported that annual sales of new cars rose slightly, to a still-anemic 5.7 million units, during the middle 10 days of January.
"Car sales are very soft, and the fundamentals still dictate lower interest rates," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "But right now the market is getting chopped to bits."
Prices of bonds and long-term notes took the brunt of the beating, but prices of shorter-term securities also moved lower, with most of the drop occurring after the Treasury announced the results of a five-year note sale.
 
Yields Up on 5-Year Notes
 At the auction, the $9.25 billion worth of securities were sold at an average yield of 6.28 percent, up from the 6.24 percent average yield at the last five-year note sale on Dec. 19.
The price of the issue eroded after the results were announced, and by late in the day the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.39 percent.
With the Federal Reserve Board seen as more likely to reduce short-term rates than to raise them in the foreseeable future, traders said the rise in short- to intermediate-term yields should generate some demand. But bonds are another matter, they added.
"I like the market, especially maturities of five years or less," one Government securities trader said. "But unless you can tell me what Bush is going to say next week, I won't go near bonds. And our clients won't touch them either."
Worries about whether Congress and the Bush Administration will concoct an overly stimulative package of tax cuts and other measures have been bubbling in the credit markets for months.
 
Waiting for the President
 Those concerns have mounted this week, since the President is expected to present his blueprint for recovery in his State of the Union address on Tuesday.
Given the market's uncertain, nervous state, a report from the Federal Reserve Board yesterday showing that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose by huge amounts in the week ended Jan. 13 compounded the pressure to sell securities.
The rise was bigger than most analysts had expected, especially a huge $37.3 billion increase in M-3, the broadest money measure.
But analysts said the big increases, coming on the heels of recent big declines, had more to do with year-end technical factors than anything else, and were not likely to have any policy significance for the Fed.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 103 1/4, down 1 1/8 points, to yield 7.71 percent, compared with 7.62 percent late Wednesday. Earlier this month, yields on long-term bonds were just under 7.40 percent.
 
Full-Point Declines
 Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year securities were offered at 101 7/8, down a full point, to yield 7.22 percent. And the new 4 7/8 percent two-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.12 percent, compared with 4.96 percent late Wednesday.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved higher.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.78 percent, up 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 7 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.88 percent.
The rise in interest rates slowed, at least temporarily, the number of new issues priced in the corporate debt market. Two large issues were priced, however.
 
New Corporate Issues
 The General Motors Assistance Corporation offered $1.8 billion worth of securities backed by auto loan receivables through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 5.05 percent securities, which have an average expected life of 1.17 years, carry a final maturity of Jan. 15, 1997. They were priced at $99.883 to yield 5.21 percent, 1.10 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the bond equivalent yield of one-year Treasury bills.
The securitites are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager for a $500 million offering of 10-year securities for Korea Development Bank.
The 7.90 percent notes were priced at $98.605 to yield 8.106 percent, 98 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent notes at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.
The big drop in Treasury prices contributed to a drop in prices of outstanding corporate and tax-exempt bonds. Corporate traders said prices of most issues had fallen by 1/4 point to 1/2 point.
And participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt securities said most widely quoted bonds dropped by around 3/8 point.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Conservative Plea To Aid Ex-Soviets

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AID to the former Soviet republics has become an ideological issue in this country, pitting those who say the United States and its partners should move rapidly and generously to provide assistance against those who would wait for them to collapse. Favoring large-scale aid, according to the oversimplified version, are liberals, pragmatists and internationalists, and on the side opposing aid, at least until authoritarian structures are destroyed, root and branch, are conservatives, supply-siders and America Firsters.
But Helmut Schlesinger, president of the German Bundesbank, celebrated as a conservative and anti-inflationist around the world, strongly supports Western aid for the Commonwealth of Independent States. Calling the Commonwealth a "fragile construction," Dr. Schlesinger said last week that "the Western part of the world must help to stabilize these young states economically, with the goal of stabilizing them politically as well." He said "huge transfers of capital and know-how" would be necessary. 
 In a speech to the American Council on Germany in New York, he said investment in the new countries "will probably yield a high social return and contribute to a new order of peace, from which "all our economies will benefit." He urged the Western countries to "face up to these challenges in our own interest." The 47 nations attending the Washington aid conference, assembled by the United States, fell well short of that objective.
Economic policy makers, Dr. Schlesinger said, would have to cope with "a huge problem for years to come -- namely a worldwide capital shortage." Demands for capital are rising in Eastern Europe, the former Soviet Union, the third world and the industrial countries as well, at a time when capital is being choked off by the decline in national savings, high budget deficits, and the weakneses of the world banking system. The sluggish growth of the world economy is both a consequence and a cause of the global capital shortage.
Germany itself is short of capital to help other countries. Dr. Schlesinger said public transfers from western to eastern Germany last year amounted to 140 billion marks ($87.5 billion at the current rate of exchange), or more than 5 percent of western German gross domestic product, and this year would exceed 170 billion marks.
By comparison, the aid proposed for the Commonwealth countries looks very small. Champions of Western aid are calling for total amounts ranging up to $30 billion a year. For the Commonwealth, with a population 15 times as large as eastern Germany's, that translates into less than $100 per capita, versus $5,000 in eastern Germany.
But capital transfers alone will not be enough to rescue the republics; they will also need technical help and organizational support from the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Dr. Schlesinger said. He singled out the I.M.F. for praise, saying it had been more "neutral" than national governments, "which always tend to couple their own assistance with internal economic problems."
At a time when growth is crucial to both East and West, as well as the third world, is not Germany doing just that -- focusing on its own problems to the neglect of those of its European partners, the United States and the world economy?
On Dec. 19, the Bundesbank raised its discount rate and Lombard rate one-half of 1 percent to curb inflation as the Federal Reserve was moving to cut its discount rate by a full 1 percent to spur economic growth.
Dr. Schlesinger said in an interview that he had not opposed the half-point rise in the discount rate but had favored only a quarter-point rise in the Lombard rate. This dissent, he said, was "not very important," and the money market had corroborated his judgment that a smaller increase in the Lombard rate would have been enough.
But he defended the overall policy as necessary to prevent "an acceleration of inflation, an acceleration of the money supply and an acceleration in the demand for credit."
Yet, his tone was conciliatory toward the Bundesbank's critics in Europe and America, concerned about recession. He said that "the German priority is always given to price stability" but that the Bundesbank believed in flexibility; as inflation came down, interest rates would come down. He added that he thought "the world economy can still grow in the coming year," and there was "no cause for a new round of inflation."
With his concerns about the need to overcome the world capital shortage to help Eastern Europe and the Commonwealth, as well as the third world, he said he was in complete agreement with the conclusion reached by the Group of Seven major industrial countries in Bangkok, Thailand, stressing the importance of "strengthening global savings, substantial reductions in high budget deficits, and the need to curb unproductive expenditures."
Does this hold for the United States now? "It is not my task to give advice to any other country," Dr. Schlesinger said.

HEADLINE: $187.6 Million Loss Posted By Delta Air

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines said today that losses for the last three months of 1991 were $187.6 million, an improvement over its results a year earlier, when airlines were hit by high fuel prices and sluggish demand. In the previous year's period, Delta lost $207.8 million.
The nation's third-largest airline said it lost $239.5 million for all of the calendar year 1991, when the carrier underwent a major expansion that included the purchase of primary Pan American World Airways assets. 
 Atlanta-based Delta said costs related to the Pan Am deal, a weak economy and the decline in passenger travel that followed the Persian Gulf war had all contributed to its recent losses.
The airline industry as a whole was pounded hard in 1991 and is expected to show a loss of some $2 billion for the year.
Revenues for the recent period, Delta's second fiscal quarter, were $2.62 billion, compared with $2.13 billion a year earlier.
For the first six months of its fiscal year, Delta lost $174.5 million, compared with a loss of $259.4 million, on revenues of $4.3 billion.
In New York Stock Exchange trading today, Delta shares were off $1.125 to close at $73.125.
Delta said it took a $50 million write-off in the October-December quarter for costs related to its participation in Pan Am's failed attempt to reorganize as a smaller carrier. Delta's withdrawal from that effort was blamed by some for Pan Am's demise, although Delta said it had determined that pumping more money into Pan Am would not be enough to save the troubled carrier.
Thomas J. Roeck Jr., Delta's chief financial officer, said he was encouraged by declining fuel prices and a "more rational" pricing structure recently in the industry. But his outlook for 1992 was pessimistic.
"Continued soft economic conditions, unacceptably high unit-cost growth plaguing the industry and the cost of initiating service on the newly acquired routes," he said, "are expected to have a negative effect on Delta's fiscal 1992 results."

HEADLINE: Clorox Profit Is Up by 24%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Clorox Company said today that profit for its second quarter ended Dec. 31 rose 24 percent despite continued weakness in the economy and a substantial increase in spending to introduce new products.
The consumer products company reported earnings of $25.3 million, or 47 cents a share, for the three months ended Dec. 31. Clorox earned $20.4 million, or 38 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
 Sales rose 5.3 percent, to $351.6 million from $333.9 million.
Clorox said profits were helped by elimination of losses from the detergent business, which the company left last year, higher shipments and a reduction in manufacturing costs.
In addition, costs associated with the 1990 acquisition of Pine-Sol cleaner and Combat insecticide lines had less effect on second-quarter earnings than in the corresponding quarter of the previous year.
Charles R. Weaver, chairman and chief executive, said Clorox was putting more emphasis on new products. The company plans to introduce a scoopable cat litter and a new Hidden Valley Ranch dressing in the next few months.
Clorox shares closed today at $43.75, up $1.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: A Large Loss For Tandem

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 23

 BODY:
Tandem Computers Inc. today announced a large first-quarter loss after taking a $98 million restructuring charge in an attempt to pare its operations and become more competitive.
The company, which makes "fault tolerant" computers with redundant parts to prevent crashes, reported a loss of $94.6 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31. That compares with net income of $7 million, or 7 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Revenues for the first quarter of the 1992 fiscal yearincreased slightly, however, rising 2 percent, to $454.5 million, from $443.8 million in the corresponding period a year earlier, the company said.
Tandem's president and chief executive, James Treybig, said the first-quarter revenues were below what the Cupertino-based company expected, even in light of the industry recession and typically slow year-end sales. But the news was not all bad, he said.
"Although revenues were disappointing, there were some positive notes to the quarter," Mr. Treybig said. "Year-over-year revenue growth in the United States improved for the second consecutive quarter. Worldwide, our business in the communications industry grew to approximately 25 percent of first-quarter revenues."
The company's stock closed today at $12.50, down 75 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Approval of Japanese Bid to Buy Mariners Unlikely

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Last year two of the Yankees' limited partners were looking to sell their shares of the club and were approached by some Japanese businessmen.
"They inquired with our office what our policy was on non-North American ownership," Steve Greenberg, baseball's deputy commissioner, said. "They were told what the policy was and that's the last I heard of it." 
 The Yankees' partners, Jack Satter and Harvey Leighton, did not sell their shares to the Japanese, or anyone else for that matter, and it's highly unlikely that the Seattle Mariners will be sold to a combined Japanese-American group that would put a major league team under control of a Japanese owner for the first time.
The Yamauchi family of Tokyo, proprietors of Nintendo of America, which is based in the Seattle area, announced a proposal yesterday to join some Seattle businessmen in buying the Mariners for $100 million. Minoru Arakawa, the son-in-law of the Nintendo founder, Hiroshi Yamauchi, is president of Nintendo of America and has lived in the Seattle area for 15 years. His family would own 60 percent of the Mariners.
 
Vincent Douses Some Cold Water
 The offer brought a quick splash of cold water from Commissioner Fay Vincent.
"Baseball," Vincent said in a statement, "has addressed the issue of ownership of its franchises and has developed a strong policy against approving investors from outside the United States and Canada. It is unlikely foreign investors would receive the requisite baseball approvals."
If nothing else, Vincent's position is similar to the stance adopted by Japanese baseball officials, who have told their American counterparts that they would not permit Americans to own Japanese teams.
Two minor league teams, Birmingham (Ala.) of the Southern League and Salinas of the California League, are owned by Japanese interests, but ownership of minor league teams is not subject to major league approval.
The commissioner, the eight-owner ownership committee and the owners of all 26 clubs, in separate league votes, would have to approve the sale of the Mariners. Fred Kuhlmann of the St. Louis Cardinals, the ownership committee chairman, said the committee planned to have a telephone conference call today to discuss the matter. He declined comment pending the discussion.
 
'It's Not Anything New'
 "We've discussed it before," he said by telephone from St. Louis. "It's not anything new to us or something we haven't given a lot of attention to."
The committee's view would presumably match the commissioner's, which means the Japanese group won't get very far. If such a stance would ever be unpopular with the American public generally or baseball fans specifically, this is the time.
On Wednesday, for example, the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission, by unanimous vote, canceled a $122 million rail car contract with a Japanese company that had won the contract over an Idaho company.
Yet the Japanese interest in the Mariners comes with a political involvement. Slade Gorton, one of the Washington State's two United States Senators, is eager to keep the Mariners in Seattle and has, in past discussions about the team's status, suggested an assault on baseball's antitrust exemption if baseball officials allowed the team to move elsewhere.
There could be times in the future when, under different circumstances, the commissioner and the club owners would be concerned about a threat to baseball's exemption. But they aren't very likely to take a threat seriously now, knowing the existing political and economic climate as it is.
Gorton also suggested yesterday that it would be hypocritical for major league baseball to refuse Japanese interests ownership when Canadians are permitted to own teams. The difference, of course, is that the Canadian owners own teams in their own cities. The residence of Arakawa notwithstanding, owners would still view the matter as Japanese interests owning a team in the United States.
 
Owners May Show Reluctance
 Owners would be reluctant to let Japanese businesses into their club for another reason. With those businesses having so much money available -- the Nintendo people said they had $25 million ready to use beyond the $100 million purchase price to shore up the franchise -- existing owners would fear that the Japanese owners would gobble up the most attractive free agents with lavish offers and would pay such high salaries that they would escalate the salary scale even significantly higher than it is now.
On the other hand, Japanese entry into American baseball could create a new market for the major leagues. An American team with Japanese ownership could create intense interest in Japan, which could translate into a lucrative new television and licensing market.
Seattle has not been a good market for a baseball team. The Pilots failed there in 1969, and the Mariners have struggled for 15 years. The Mariners finally broke the 2 million barrier in home attendance last season after having averaged barely over a million fans per season in their first 14 years.
Jeff Smulyan, the team's owner, would ideally like to move the team to Tampa-St. Petersburg area, whose vacant domed stadium eagerly awaits a major league team. Smulyan went so far as to meet secretly with St. Petersburg officials earlier this month and now faces disciplinary action by the commissioner for his nonapproved venture.
At the same time, the city of Seattle faces its second loss of a major league team if Smulyan cannot find an owner by March 27. Vincent is not eager to see a move by the Mariners, but he evidently is less eager to see an incursion of Japanese ownership.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Minoru Arakawa, left, president of Nintendo of America Inc., and Christopher Larson of Microsoft Inc., are two of three leaders of a group of investors that has offered to buy the Seattle Mariners. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Thanking Sakurauchi

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The Japanese -- some of them are beginning to get under our skin. I'm thinking now of that politician who said that American workers are lazy and a third of them couldn't read.
Lazy? American men and women line up to get work -- sometimes thousands waiting in the cold for too few jobs at too little money. American workers can still outproduce Japanese person for person. American industry, working people and servicemen did not seem all that lazy by the time World War II ended. 
 As for Japanese executives, when I was a reporter in Japan, they never seemed to work harder than American business people I knew at home.
Often Japanese executives outnumbered the desks. By 6 P.M. the executives were in their company cars heading home -- the long way home, via bars and restaurants where they boozed, ate and fondled on the company expense account. American auditors would have daily heart attacks in Tokyo.
So take that, Mr. Yoshio Sakurauchi, Speaker of the lower house of Parliament. I am hardly a Japan-basher, usually the contrary. But take your caricature of Americans, I thought, and pour it in your sake cup!
But just as I was working up a good head of indignation the thought struck me that the man was half right -- the literacy half -- and maybe we should thank him instead of wallowing in defensiveness.
About 5 percent of the young-adult population is totally illiterate, not a third. But that is not comforting once you take a look at Table 368 of the Department of Education's 1991 statistical digest. The literacy skills that prevent people from drowning economically in modern society are held by only a minority of Americans between 21 and 25.
Only 20 percent can use bus timetables, which means they could not follow work manuals. Only 22.5 percent can figure out the percentage of a restaurant tip, which I suppose means the others could not even earn it. Forty-four percent cannot locate information in an almanac or news story; would you hire one of them for a clerical job in any communications or financial company?
Diane Ravitch, an outstanding Assistant Secretary of Education, says achievement trends in academic progress have been "essentially flat for the past 20 years." In a world ever more demanding for workers, flat means down. Ms. Ravitch writes plainly enough for anybody to read: What was good enough 20 years ago isn't anymore.
Who is to blame? People who know the field say that Bush has been great in fighting for modern literacy -- Barbara Bush. If her husband has become the education President, I am indeed the King of Saudi Arabia. But what President in the past 20 years has done the education job right, which Congress or big city?
We can of course simply blame root causes for destroying the "learning environment" -- guns, poverty, race, drugs, drink, schoolyard crime, teen-age pregnancy, and forcing schools to substitute for jailers, parents, cops, preachers and epidemiologists, instead of teaching.
But without follow-up action, that would leave American work, literacy and education where it is now -- and Mr. Sakurauchi having a good chuckle with his parliamentary pals.
We will have to pay for action -- with more money if necessary, and lots no doubt will be needed. At a time when we need more school computers, some teachers are themselves paying for classroom pencils; a shame for us all. We need more therapeutic communities to handle drug-ridden children, and police to sweep human garbage from schoolyards.
Parents will have to pay with constant attention to their children's schools and their children's work.
Private citizens and business will have to pay for marketable literacy with volunteer time and devotion -- as in New York do Elizabeth Rohatyn, Parker Ladd, the publishing executive, the columnist Liz Smith, the business executive Saul Steinberg and Gayfryd Steinberg, the members of the New York Public Library board and people like them in cities everywhere -- but not enough people.
No one thing -- taxpayers, volunteers, teachers, parental attention, business, politicians -- will fix our school system. But put them together and you have the formula of Japanese educational success -- which the U.S. can achieve as well and maybe a bit better, Mr. Speaker.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: On Any Given Sunday, Try Reading a Book

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
I don't care what the President said, there are at least 10 good reasons for not banning football, all of them on display this weekend.
 1. CIVIC PRIDE: Buffalo, we are told, is gripped by a Bills Bedlam as invigorating as the Mets Mania of 1969, which convinced New Yorkers that their health, educational and safety services would improve as dramatically as did their team. If the Bills win, Buffalo will be saved, as was New York City. It's a lot of pressure, especially for two players: Scott Norwood, the kicker, who should take the blame for plunging Buffalo into economic recession last year by missing a Super Bowl field goal that would have beaten the Giants; and Bruce Smith, the defensive end, who might have incited riots this week by threatening to leave town because of racist mail from fans who accused him of malingering after a knee injury. 
2. MEDICAL RESEARCH: Pro football has done for bone stress what the space program did for metal fatigue. Shoulders, hips, knees, you wreck 'em and the team docs will solder 'em so you can get right back on the field, even if it means permanent damage. According to a Ball State University study, two-thirds of all N.F.L. players who played after 1970 had some sort of debilitating injury when they retired. Another study concluded that midcentury pro players died 12 years earlier than did their nonplaying cohorts.
 3. DRUG STORIES: By the late Sixties, Olympic athletes knew more about chemicals than most doctors, but it took those bighearted, book-writing football players to tell us how big and strong and sexy you can get on steroids, how good you can feel on cocaine and how booze enlivens an orgy. And then, just before publication, they all had the strength to Just Say No!
 4. NATIONAL SECURITY: No more cheap shots at Bill Parcells for lying on television about his Tampa Bay dealings. He proves that football is a mental game, too. Think of what would happen if there was no football, and a smart, tough guy like Bill had to go into government, start shuttling from the White House to a defense corporation to "Nightline" analysis, always looking out for the next job. Aren't you glad he's taking care of business in football?
 5. HISTORY LESSON: After Florida State and the Atlanta Braves and the Kansas City Chiefs got Tomahawk Chopped, only the Washington Redskins remained to remind us that Columbus discovered America, not Crazy Horse. I have gotten more hate mail than Bruce Smith this year from people who think Indians should "lighten up." Tell them yourself. Demonstrators from the American Indian Law Alliance, the American Indian Community House and the Solidarity Foundation will be outside the CBS Building on 52d Street today at 5 P.M. in support of groups demonstrating in Minneapolis.
 6. FRAT HOUSE PHILOSOPHY: Is football a preparation for war, a moral equivalent to war, a safety valve, bread and circuses, opiate for the masses? Do those snuff-cute cassettes from N.F.L. Films -- "Ten Best Non-Fatal Injuries of '91", "Green Bay Splatter and Spleen", "Knees: Snap, Crackle and Pop" -- make people passive, aggressive, thirsty? How would a Japanese quarterback affect our national self-esteem? These dissertation-level questions allow intellectuals to watch football without worrying that they should be reading instead.
 7. MEN ON MEN: Watch the game so you'll know when to switch to Fox for the halftime counterprogram from those "In Living Color" clowns. Maybe they'll be able to get beyond the Frat House Philosophy and talk about why domestic violence increases on Super Sunday. Based on anecdotal evidence, it's the busiest day for abuse hot lines and battered women's shelters. Dr. Lenore Walker of Denver says, "Fans see athletes get away with violent behavior." This seems to give losers permission to act out their alcohol-driven angst.
 8. STUFF: My official N.F.L. gift catalogue, a kind of Victor's Secret, has "skin thin" receiver gloves ($39.95), half-liter porcelain hofbrau steins ($49.95), red rubber workout jackets (47.95) and best of all, a "Tear-Apart N.F.L. Stress Doll" ($24.95), made in China and available in the uniform of your favorite team. The box says "calm down by ripping off his head." His arms and legs also rip off, too, thanks to Velcro. The doll is not anatomically complete.
 9. CHURN: Like lawyers and stockbrokers, sportswriters feed on the "churn," the unnecessary business that generates more business; lawyers sue to draw suits, brokers buy and sell to pile up commissions. For us, churning means reports that can then be refuted or explicated, sometimes both at the same time. Because we are the Lost Boys of literature, there is nothing like the Neverland of Super Bowl week to keep us crowing. If you're still reading this, you know exactly what I mean. Or ask Bill.
 Hey. That's only nine good reasons for not banning football. If I can't come up with one more, President Theodore Roosevelt may have his way after all.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
BUSH CAMP RENEWS STRATEGY DEBATE

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Bush campaign today made public a television commercial apologizing to New Hampshire voters for their economic pain, but at the White House a renewed debate broke out over the general tone of President Bush's re-election campaign.
The discussion of whether Mr. Bush should be conciliatory or combative in his State of the Union Message next Tuesday began Thursday night when his two top political aides, Samuel K. Skinner, the White House chief of staff, and Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman, summoned about 20 Republicans to a strategy session.
 
No Change in Program
 Bush aides have been saying all week that the address to Congress would kick off the election effort by offering Mr. Bush's plan to fix the economy. But Mr. Skinner and Mr. Teeter found themselves bombarded with demands that Mr. Bush also use his speech to declare war on the Democrats in Congress. 
 Today, White House officials said the program to be unveiled in the speech, including higher tax deductions for dependent children and a lower tax on profits from investments, would remain the same. But they were considering warnings from the Republicans that it was silly for the President to try to strike a statesmanlike attitude toward the opposition party in an election year.
The meeting and the release of the new commercial marked the latest White House effort to find powerful themes and a coherent approach for a sputtering campaign for which Mr. Bush has not yet officially announced his candidacy.
As part of that effort, Mr. Skinner has been reorganizing the White House staff, and officials said he told his aides tonight that he had chosen Henson Moore, a former Louisiana Congressman who is now the Deputy Energy Secretary, to be his deputy chief of staff. Mr. Moore will replace Andrew H. Card Jr., who was designated on Thursday to be the new Transportation Secretary.
 
Reviving Maladroit Trip
 The commercial uses videotape from a New Hampshire campaign trip last week that was regarded inside and outside the Bush camp as politically maladroit. Mr. Bush admitted that he had failed to realize the economy was in "freefall" and gave New Hampshire voters an assurance, "Message: I care."
Some Administration officials and Republican strategists said the White House still seemed to be struggling to dispel its aura of uncertainty and that the new commercial, entitled "Determination" by Mr. Bush's campaign advertising group, would do little to help because it revived the "I'm sorry" tone of the visit by Mr. Bush last week.
In the Administration, some officials continued to urge Mr. Bush to hold his fire with Congress and to take a conciliatory, bipartisan stand in the State of the Union Message in the hope of winning passage for his economic growth package.
But on Capitol Hill, where reports circulated that Mr. Bush would ask for passage of a tax cut within an extraordinarily short three weeks, Democrats were already preparing to take on Mr. Bush. And other Administration officials, and the strategists who met with Mr. Skinner and Mr. Teeter on Thursday night, said Mr. Bush had no hope of winning Democratic cooperation in an election year.
The strategists warned the two officials that Mr. Bush's approach was turning him into the status quo candidate and said he should, in the words of one strategist, "draw a line in the sand and take on Congress."
Mr. Bush's proposals are intended to help end the recession that has been hobbling the President's re-election campaign, even though Administration aides admit privately that the President believes there is little that can reasonably be done to that end. Mr. Bush has repeatedly said that after he speaks on Tuesday night, he will call on Congress to "put aside politics" and quickly consider his ideas before the campaign heats up.
"You can't put politics aside," said a Republican strategist. "It's a political year, and if the White House doesn't understand that, all they have to do is look at the pattern of votes that have come out of this Congress over the past 18 months. The Democrats have drawn the line and Bush should too."
The new commercial, which will be broadcast Saturday in New Hampshire, does not offer even a glimmer of Mr. Bush's plans for the economy. It is the first of at least two advertisements that Mr. Bush plans to run in New Hampshire before the Feb. 18 primary and is intended to prove that the President is not afraid to hear bad news and cares about people's problems.
But, with the exception of a brief opening from a woman who says, "I have never seen it so bad where people have to lose their homes," the words of those who deliver the bad news are muted. The voters mouth their words silently at the President while his voice is heard over their pictures.
But some Republican strategists said the Bush campaign was lingering too long on the phase of Mr. Bush's message in which he acknowledged the nation's economic problems and assured Americans that he cared, before moving on to say what the President was prepared to do about the economy.
"How can the President of the United States reconnect to someone who is crying about losing their house?" said one exasperated Republican with close ties to the White House.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In his first televised campaign commercials, President Bush is shown apologizing to New Hampshire voters for their economic pains. (The New York Times)(pg. 8)

BAKER SEEKS PROMISE FROM ISRAEL
Secretary of State Baker told Israel that to consider providing $10 billion in housing loan guarantees, Washington needed assurances that the money would not be spent to further the building of settlements, American officials said. 1
 
MOSQUE FINED ON NOISE COMPLAINT
The enduring conflict between Israelis and Palestinians has had many battlegrounds over the decades, and it shifted this week to still a new one: decibel levels. 5
 
JAPAN-U.S. COOPERATION PLEDGED
Shaken by scandals and new frictions with Washington, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan opened a Parliament session pledging to "make every effort to cooperate" with the United States. 2
 
CLOSING OUT EL SALVADOR'S WAR
El Salvador moved toward tying up the remnants of its 12-year civil war, with a judge sentencing two army officers for the killing of six Jesuit priests while guerrilla commanders made a surprise return before a formal cease-fire. 4
 
U.S. PLANS MILITARY AID TO PERU
After months of Congressionally imposed delays, the Bush Administration is preparing to release $10 million in military aid to Peru as the first stage of a new policy to help the Peruvian military fight drug traffickers and Maoist guerrillas. 4
 
WHITES HAVE VETO, DE KLERK SAYS
President de Klerk promised to include South Africa's disfranchised black majority in any referendum on political change but reiterated that the white minority would be able to veto the terms of transition to a nonracist constitution. 5
 
MORE PAINFUL REFORMS FOR RUSSIA
Under attack for letting prices soar, the Russian Government won reluctant approval for the next phase of its painful economic reforms: a budget that it says is virtually deficit-free but calls for deep spending cuts and higher taxes. 3
 
AID FOR ATOM SCIENTISTS WEIGHED
The Bush Administration is considering assistance to Russian nuclear scientists to keep them from accepting offers to work in developing nations trying to build weapons. 3
 
Serbs collected evidence of a mass killing by Croat extremists. 3

A proposal by Laurence A. Tisch to rescue Macy's fell through when a big creditor rejected the terms. The creditor is the Prudential Insurance Company of America, which balked at refinancing an $811 million mortgage on some 70 Macy stores. 1

A heated debate is under way among White House aides over what tone President Bush should adopt in his State of Union Message next week: conciliatory with Democrats in Congress in working to spur the economy, or combative in dealing with them. 1

THE CAPITAL HAS GONE GIDDY
In a city where winning is what matters most, the Washington Redskins have become a kind of civic religion, and the impending Super Bowl has made the population of the capital a little loony. 1
