HEADLINE: Tisch Proposal to Rescue Macy Falls Through as Creditor Balks

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Laurence A. Tisch's proposal to rescue R. H. Macy & Company from its crushing debt load at the expense of its creditors fell through late yesterday when a major creditor refused to agree to his terms.
In a statement issued last evening, the Loews Corporation, of which Mr. Tisch is chairman and chief executive, said it had ended its discussions to buy Macy. "The Loews proposal was conditioned upon the cooperation of various other parties," the statement said, "but was rejected by a major creditor of Macy's this afternoon." 
 Financial analysts and retailing experts say the Loews decision to withdraw its offer may have dashed Macy's last hope of avoiding bankruptcy and the stigma and operating restraints it carries. Of course, someone, including Mr. Tisch, could offer another plan.
Loews, which said it had been negotiating for several days, declined to elaborate. A Macy spokesman said the company would not comment on the discussions or the Loews statement.
 
$811 Million in Mortgages
 Discussions on the offer broke down when the Prudential Insurance Company of America balked at refinancing the $811 million mortgage it holds on some 70 Macy stores, about half the company's total. It is not known whether Macy's flagship store on 34th Street in Manhattan is one of those stores.
Frank McDougal, president of the Prudential Mortgage Capital Company, said in an interview yesterday that he was concerned about what might happen to Macy, but emphasized that his company's primary responsibility was to its policyholders.
"Everyone wants to avoid this company filing Chapter 11 if it is at all possible," Mr. McDougal said of Macy. "Our first and foremost job is to protect our policyholders."
As part of his offer to invest more than $1 billion to buy back a large part of Macy's junk bonds and get its financial structure into shape, Mr. Tisch asked Prudential to lower the interest rate on the mortgage it holds.
The Prudential mortgage has a base interest rate of 12 percent, although that could increase substantially depending on myriad complex formulas included in the mortgage agreement. Mr. Tisch asked the insurer to refinance the loan at a straight 9 percent rate. Prudential felt that such a substantial cut would hurt its own business.
 
Loans Were Renegotiated
 In late November and early December, Prudential and Macy renegotiated the loans to give Macy lower interest rates and Prudential extra interest if the company's sales exceeded certain targets.
Mr. Tisch now controls 17.7 percent of Macy's preferred stock through a Loews subsidiary, L.T. Holdings Inc., and he is on the Macy board.
When word of Mr. Tisch's plan got out on Thursday, analysts gave it strong chances of approval. Macy's overwhelming debt is propelling the retailer toward bankruptcy. Although investors were likely to lose much of their original stake in Macy under the Tisch plan, they would receive nothing if the company hobbled into bankruptcy.
But Prudential has more leverage than Macy's equity investors, banks and bondholders, and many analysts see the breakdown in talks as a standoff between powerful parties. Even if Macy is forced into bankruptcy, it would emerge operating virtually all of the stores it now operates.
"We feel we are adequately protected with our collateral, and we don't expect to lose any money on the principal," Mr. McDougal said.
Prudential may also be feeling pressure not to make concessions in its real estate portfolio. Yesterday, Moody's Investor Services cited Prudential's real estate problems as it reduced its triple-A rating of the insurer's financial strength.
Mr. Tisch's proposal was made at a critical time for the retail company, which operates the Macy's, I. Magnin and Bullock's department store chains and several small specialty store chains. Macy had subtly signaled that it was virtually insolvent when it told its 20,000 suppliers on Jan. 10 that in order to meet the requirements of its $587.7 million revolving credit line, it would have to postpone payments to them for two weeks.
It assured them at the time that it would send the checks today, but it has not asked its banks to draw on the account.
Macy has satisfied bank covenants requiring it not to borrow more than $150 million from the credit line during the last 30 days, freeing up the remainder of the account today.
But to siphon any additional money from the credit line, Macy must show the syndicate of 40 banks that control it that the company has cash flow of $185 million for December and January.
 
Difficulty Meeting Requirement
 Macy is apparently unable to meet that requirement and thus cannot draw on the line to pay its suppliers.
The Loews statement yesterday said that in addition to a substantial equity infusion of cash by Loews, the discussions had contemplated "the payment in full of all Macy's trade creditors upon consummation of the transaction."
The banks had indicated that they would consider waiving some terms of the agreement while the Tisch plan was under negotiation. Now that Loews has withdrawn its offer, however, many analysts feel the banks may be unwilling to do anything that might result in even greater losses to them if Macy goes into bankruptcy.
Several apparel manufacturers said yesterday that they did not expect Macy to send out their checks today. All the major factors who finance shipments to Macy have told their clients they will not guarantee payments on goods sold to the company's stores until some suppliers start receiving checks.
Smaller manufacturers are not likely to ship any more merchandise to Macy without that protection. That could leave Macy's stores short of the new spring merchandise they need to keep shoppers from going to the competition.
"Every day they delay in resolving their financial problems, it jeopardizes their franchise, particularly on the West Coast," said Alan G. Millstein, publisher of the Fashion Network Report, a newsletter focusing on the apparel industry. "In San Francisco, La Jolla and Los Angeles, if a woman walks into an I. Magnin or Bullock's store and can't find spring dresses, she'll go right across the street to Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus."
 
Some Still Shipping
 Some suppliers are still shipping merchandise to the company, but most of them are only sending parts of orders. Liz Claiborne Inc., one of the largest apparel manufacturers in the country, declined to comment about Mr. Tisch's proposal or Macy's, falling silent after saying publicly for several weeks that it was shipping orders to the retailer.
The price of Macy's junk bonds escalated sharply yesterday on news of the Tisch proposal. Lehman Brothers high-yield bond desk said Macy's 14.5 percent bonds due 1998 were quoted at 70 cents on the dollar, up from 58 cents at the start of the day. The Loews announcement that its plan had fallen through came after trading closed yesterday.

HEADLINE: From Russia with Hope: In America to Stay - A special report;
Seeking Shelter in U.S. After the Soviet Storm

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

 BODY:
The scene is familiar. Immigrants are crowded onto cots in the back rooms of a church in Los Angeles. But these are not Latin Americans escaping poverty and civil war. They are penniless Russians, members of a new wave of underground immigrants to the United States.
Sheltered under the gold domes of the Protection of the Holy Virgin, a Russian Orthodox church in Hollywood, are what might pass for a cross section of Russian society: a jeweler, an actress, a merchant seaman, a would-be fashion model, a Soviet Army deserter and a mother who fled with her three children from an outbreak of ethnic violence. 
 Just two or three years ago, only a carefully regulated flow of mostly Jewish emigrants were allowed to move to the United States from the Soviet Union. Visits were limited to a trickle of academic and cultural exchanges. But the end of the cold war and the disintegration of the Soviet Union have brought tens of thousands of tourists, businessmen, students, writers, athletes and government representatives from the former Soviet lands.
 
'Much Richer Cross Section'
 Most visitors from the former Soviet Union come to the United States legally, but a growing number of them, like the people who have taken shelter in the Los Angeles church, are going underground when their visas expire. One estimate puts their number at 30,000. But whether they are here legally or not, the immigrants' interaction with American society has helped to change long-held cold war suspicions and prejudices.
"It's quite a shocking difference in the types of people who are coming, just a much richer cross section," said Gregory Guroff, a Soviet expert at the United States Information Agency. "And I think there is a personal reaction: here you have people coming from what has been the enemy and the other superpower, and these people are coming here penniless."
Irina Paliashvili, a lawyer from Ukraine who has recently completed an exchange program with a law firm in Chicago, looked at herself through American eyes and said: "We used to be so uniform. Meeting one Soviet was like meeting another. Now each person has his own views and his own agenda."
One bureaucratic detail seems to symbolize the topsy-turvy nature of the changed Soviet-American relationship. In the past, when a Soviet citizen wished to travel abroad, his Government forced him to leave behind a close family member to help insure his return. Now it is American consular officials in Moscow who often require that a family member be left behind as proof that a tourist does not intend to overstay his visa.
The Soviet Embassy once tried to keep a careful eye on every one of its citizens in America. Now it has has all but given up.
"It is hard to keep track of all these people because there are just so many of them," said Andrei Rogov, an attache at the consulate in San Francisco.
 
Fleeing Home
Flood Unleashed By the Kremlin
 Since late 1988, when the Kremlin began to relax emigration restrictions, hundreds of thousands of people have flooded into Europe and the United States from the territory of the former Soviet Union.
The number of non-immigrant visas to this country for most types of temporary visits climbed to more than 100,000 in each of the last two years. In October, 11,732 Soviet citizens received non-immigrant visas, almost as many as the 12,028 who received them for all of 1987.
Among these visitors are students, researchers and other academics who come here on exchanges. There were only 60 of these in the 1986-87 academic year. The 1990-91 figure was 2,811.
Immigrant visas, primarily for family reunification, nearly doubled to 1,374 in 1990 from 782 in 1987.
In addition, the United States continues to offer refugee status to members of certain groups judged to be oppressed. Under this longstanding program, 61,000 people were offered entry in 1991. Most of these are Soviet Jews. The waiting list for these visas has grown to about 500,000.
 
The First Three Waves
 The Jews have long been considered the third wave of Soviet emigrants; the first wave came after the Russian Revolution in 1917 and the second after World War II. The new exodus is beginning to be called the fourth wave.
A striking set of figures characterizing this wave is the one showing how many arrive legally, mostly as tourists, then overstay their visas and apply for political asylum. The Immigration and Naturalization Service says that only 90 people applied for tourist visas in 1988, but the number jumped to 1,043 in 1990. And in just the first half of 1991, that number nearly doubled, to 1,891.
Mark Popovsky, a journalist with the Russian-language newspaper Novoye Russkoye Slovo in New York, who has written extensively about the phenomenon, estimates that there may be 30,000 illegal immigrants from the former Soviet Union who had not applied for asylum.
That figure seems certain to grow because the number of people leaving the former Soviet republics, already at an all-time high, will increase in the coming years even if conditions in that region improve, according to a recent study by the Rand Corporation, a research center in Santa Monica, Calif.
 
Settling In
Taking Advantage Of Old Contacts
 Sergei N. Khrushchev, the 56-year-old son of the former Soviet leader, seemed almost surprised when asked why he chose to do historical research at Brown University rather than at home in Moscow.
"If one has a choice between working in the best circumstances or the worst circumstances, one will of course choose the best circumstances," he said.
He said that as soon as he was permitted to, in 1989, he traveled to the United States for the first time since he visited with his father when he was Prime Minister in 1959. Now he is comfortably settled here on a one-year fellowship and says he is not certain when he will return home.
Mr. Khrushchev is one of many prominent figures who have traded on their contacts with American officials to find niches at universities and research centers in the United States.
 
The Politically Unemployed
 Among them are Genrikh Trofimenko, a former analyst at the Institute of the United States and Canada; Fyodor A. Burlatsky, former editor of Literaturnaya Gazeta, an influential Moscow weekly; Roald Sagdeyev, former head of the Space Research Institute in Moscow, and Sergo Mikoyan, former editor of the journal Latin America whose father, Anastas I. Mikoyan, was a Soviet head of state.
These are the people Anthony Richter, executive director of the Soros Foundation-Soviet Union, calls the politically unemployed: prominent figures who have been left behind by the fast-changing politics of their land.
"Essentially, you have a giant corporation, which is the Soviet Government, which is in Chapter 11," Mr. Richter said. "All the top executives are either on the market for a Russian Republic position, or being picked up as consultants by Western businesses and think tanks."
One such man is Vitaly Korotich, former editor of the magazine Ogonyok, who is now a visiting professor of journalism at Boston University. "I think my generation, the men of the 1960's, including Gorbachev and Yeltsin and others, has fulfilled its historical task," he said in explaining his move to America. "Now it is time for us to free the way for the next generation."
 
Trading Places
Chances to Study American Ways
 A rapid expansion of exchange programs is bringing to America everyone from rock musicians catching up on West Coast trends to environmentalists attending workshops in Pennsylvania to microbiologists working on a joint project at Columbia University to an Estonian photographer studying at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan.
One illustration of the hunger for American expertise and perspective is a program that offers internships to young lawyers intent on creating legal systems for the Commonwealth of Independent States, successor of the Soviet Union.
Miss Paliashvili, the lawyer who worked in Chicago, said that in view of "all these national fights and all these tragic events" back at home, "it's very hard to cool down our emotions and take a reasonable and practical pragmatic approach."
"That's why we need your help in America," said Miss Paliashvili, an ethnic Georgian. "We need somebody who can give a kind of look from the side and see things from a long-term perspective."
Another law intern is Yelena Barikhnovskaya, 37, who recently completed a six-month stint with the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights in New York and now plans to found a similar organization in her home city, St. Petersburg.
 
'What Kind of Changes?'
 "Our legal system does not work, and it should have changes," she said. "But what kind of changes? About this, I am even less clear than I was before, because I understand that American standards cannot be simply blindly transferred there."
For example, she said, Russian courts are preparing to introduce an Anglo-American style jury system in a nation whose people have learned the hard way not to assert their individual opinions.
"I would not like to be a defendant tried by a jury of Soviet citizens," Miss Barikhnovskaya said. "They have been brought up in a Communist system. They were brought up on lies and hypocrisy. They need to be a little bit enlightened first before they can be responsible for human life."
The number of people making private visits to the United States has also soared in the last two years. Among them are a small but growing number of Russians and others who are arriving on business visas. Some have come to learn from large American companies, while a few others are trying their hand at American-style entrepreneurship. In addition, people from the former Soviet Union can now apply directly for admission to American colleges.
The new freedom of travel has produced an increasing number of ordinary human contacts for people like Olga Kamp, who was visiting on a tourist visa two years ago, fell in love, married and settled down in Spokane, Wash. Her brother joined her and is now selling cars in Seattle, and her mother, Nina Bergoltsev, recently visited from Moscow for Christmas.
Circuses, dance troupes and hockey and basketball stars are also seeking a share of the American entertainment dollar, joined by former political figures who are coming not for arms negotiations but for book tours.
Yelena S., who is 28 years old, was a civil judge in Moscow when she came to New York on a tourist visa last year and decided to stay. Bridling at the bureaucratic pressures and corruption at home, she was taken with what seemed to be the broad horizons of life in America.
Now she is working as a housekeeper in Manhattan. "It's really difficult," she said, speaking on the condition that she not be identified by her last name. "I try to live. I try."
 
Getting Help
How Newcomers Are Welcomed
 All around her in New York and elsewhere, other members of this fourth wave of immigration are struggling to live alongside other illegal immigrants from around the world. Many work as laborers or housemaids and live crowded together in what amounts to a Russian import: communal apartments.
Among them is the three-member Limpopo band that arrived a year ago with balalaika, guitar, trombone and tourist visas. And as they play on street corners, they seem so happy to be here that passers-by sometimes begin to dance along with them.
For the most part, these new immigrants have not yet had time to put down roots and achieve the economic success of members of the third wave.
But despite their privations, the clamor to come to America is so great that a cottage industry has been formed to serve these illegal immigrants just as it has for other illegal-immigrant groups.
 
Many Choose Anonymity
 Gregory Maizus, an aide to New York State Senator Donald M. Halperin, said entrepreneurs were selling the personal invitations that are required for exit permits. Other organizations charge fees for advice on how to apply for political asylum.
But thousands prefer illegal anonymity, perhaps recognizing that they would fail the test of "a well-founded fear of persecution." Larissa L., who spends her days at the church in Los Angeles, said that when she was interviewed by the immigration service she was asked, "What are you running from?" The interviewer went on: "You don't have Communism. You don't have the K.G.B. any more." She also agreed to be interviewed only on condition that her last name not be used.
Zoya Arzamastseva fled with her children and her mother after her husband was killed in anti-Russian riots in Moldova and now spends most of her days and nights at the church, uncertain about what she will do next.
Given the fast pace of changes in the former Soviet Union, officials say they have not yet had to face the question of whether to send people like these back home. At least one applicant in New York has already received a preliminary "notice of intent to deny" from the Immigration and Naturalization Service based on what the letter called "political change in the Soviet Union."
"It's going to be hard to make a case of discrimination against you by officialdom," said Jack F. Matlock Jr., a former United States Ambassador to Moscow. "Everybody is having a pretty rough time."
Tsilya Kacheva, a recent immigrant who lives in Philadelphia, is the widow of an army colonel and, at the age of 74, is as old as the former Soviet Union. She believed and hoped and suffered through all the hard years of Kremlin rule.
"We didn't understand how badly we lived," she said. "We thought it was the only way to live." But at last, she said, she gave up.
"We lived through a lot during the war: famine and hardship. But we lived on hope for a better life. Now we know there is no better life. We have lost our belief. There is nothing more to believe in."
 
Hopes Rekindled
 America, on the other hand, seems to offer the sense of hope that has been lost in the collapse of the Soviet empire.
"I would like to stay here two or three years and then try something new -- Africa, China," said Igor Yuzov, the 28-year-old guitarist for Limpopo band, as he gloried in his new horizons, no longer limited by international boundaries.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Assist Peru's Army in Fighting Cocaine and Rebels

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
After months of Congressionally imposed delays, the Bush Administration is preparing to release $10 million in military aid to Peru as the first stage of a new policy to help the Peruvian military fight drug traffickers and Maoist guerrillas involved in the cocaine trade.
The program marks a change after more than two decades of limited relations between Washington and the Peruvian military, which had long retained close ties to the Soviet Union and which had recently been criticized by Administration officials for its dismal record on human rights. 
 Moreover, as recently as two months ago American officials accused elements of the army of taking payoffs from drug traffickers and of blocking Peruvian police efforts to interrupt the cocaine trade.
 
U.S. Aid Up in Last 5 Years
 United States involvement in Peru has slowly increased in the last five years. The Drug Enforcement Administration and antidrug officers under State Department contract have worked at the Santa Lucia police base in the Upper Huallaga Valley advising the police on eradicating drugs and maintaining helicopters. In the last two years, members of the United States Army Special Forces have trained Peruvian police units but up until now have not trained military units.
State Department officials now say the Peruvian military is being reformed, can be vital in the war against drugs and will only improve with increased American tutelage.
"The Peruvian Army is making rather impressive gains to the degree they have opened themselves up to the judicial authorities," said a senior State Department official, who added that the aid would begin to flow in the next few weeks. "Together we have the beginnings of a serious counternarcotics program. They need our help."
The initial aid package will include sending about 15 military trainers to instruct a Peruvian marine company and police antinarcotics units, spare parts for helicopters and jet aircraft, and road-building equipment for army civic action. The package is far smaller than the original $34 million program the Administration proposed to Congress last year, which included sending dozens of military advisers to train three special army battalions.
 
Fear of Bigger Role
 Still, Congressional critics and human rights groups warn that the program could open the door for a growing American role in Latin America's most vicious guerrilla war. Such fears were reinforced this month when three Americans under contract with the State Department to help maintain Peruvian police equipment were killed in a helicopter apparently downed by Shining Path rebels high in Andes.
With the close of the cold war and the shrinking military budgets, the war on drugs is one of the few growth areas the Pentagon has left. Its antinarcotics spending has increased to a projected $1.2 billion this year, from $440 million in 1989. For years the American military expressed reluctance about engaging in operations that they considered police work, but today the United States Southern Command in Panama fields about 500 soldiers working on intelligence and antinarcotics training programs in Latin America.
Administration officials say their strategy in Peru is to improve the coordination of the Peruvian Army and police, so that law-enforcement units can safely operate in the Upper Huallaga Valley where the Shining Path guerrillas operate. Along with the military aid program, the Administration is sending $60 million in economic assistance to help peasants switch from coca cultivation to other crops.
More than half of the cocaine consumed in the United States originates from coca plants cultivated in Peru, making anticocaine efforts there crucial to the Administration's declared war on drugs.
American officials insist they have no interest in deploying ground troops in Peru to fight the guerrillas, who have been accused of not only serving as middlemen between peasant coca growers and the traffickers but also of trafficking to finance their operations. Nonetheless, in a Jan. 17 letter to four senior members of Congress, Janet G. Mullins, Assistant Secretary of State for Legislative Affairs, said the Administration intended to send nearly $25 million more in military aid once Lima demonstrated better antidrug and human rights efforts.
 
Congress Sets Conditions
 Congressional leaders are meeting to decide how to respond to the Administration's intentions. Although lawmakers released their hold on aid late last year when the State Department agreed to release the funds only after Lima fulfilled a number of Congressionally set targets on human rights, they could block future aid proposals from the Administration.
Those targets included a commitment from Lima that all military aid would be channeled through President Alberto K. Fujimori to reinforce civilian rule, that military prisons be open to international inspection and local civilian prosecutors, that military prisoners be listed on a national registry, and that a number of politically charged human rights cases involving military officers be prosecuted.
In her letter to Congress, Ms. Mullins said the aid would be released because Congressional conditions "have been fulfilled." She noted that the International Red Cross had been allowed to tour military and police prisons unhindered on a regular basis since late September and that Lima had developed a registry of detainees.
But international human rights monitors are expressing doubts.
"It is clear that while limited progress has been made in complying with certain conditions, the overal human rights situation has not improved and may in fact be getting worse," said Coletta Youngers, senior associate at the Washington Office on Latin America, a human rights group. Ms. Youngers said Peruvian human rights monitors were reviewing and trying to verify 70 reported cases of disappearances linked to the security forces in the last few months.
In a trip to Peru this month, Ms. Youngers said she had found that Red Cross visits to military installations were prearranged and therefore unspontaneous and that Peruvian human rights workers said the registry of prisoners was incomplete.

HEADLINE: Japan Premier, Under Pressure, Opens Parliament

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Shaken by scandals and new frictions with Washington, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa opened a new session of Parliament today pledging to "make every effort to cooperate" with the United States to solve its economic problems.
He also offered "profound apologies" for the fact that one of his closest aides had been arrested on a "most regrettable" bribery charge and said he would push for political reforms "so politics does not languish because of such incidents." 
 Mr. Miyazawa's comments were a clear attempt to overcome not only the scandals but also a sagging economy, opposition to several of his legislative measures and, most of all, an image of disarray that threatens to bring his time in office to an early end. After real estate and stock market prices dropped sharply last year, projections for economic growth for the fiscal year that ends in March flattened to about 3 percent.
But analysts predicted that the Prime Minister, after only three months in office, would have enormous difficulty enacting more than a minimum legislative program in the new parliamentary session, which is to last five months.
 
Bill on Joining U.N. Forces
 Among the key measures backed by Mr. Miyazawa, but considered unlikely to pass soon, are a bill to send Japanese troops abroad to take part in United Nations peacekeeping forces and another set of bills to curb the flow of private money into politics.
Mr. Miyazawa's approval ratings in the polls are in the range of 40 to 50 percent, a respectable level, helped in the view of politicians by the way he comforted President and Mrs. Bush this month when Mr. Bush collapsed with the flu during a dinner in Tokyo.
But some Japanese fear that if he handles his political problems badly and fails to accomplish much of his legislative program, his popularity could plummet to 20 percent or so. If that happens, some feel he could be ousted and replaced before the next national elections this summer.
"He has yet to make a clear-cut start," a senior party leader said this week. "It is still not too late, but he should clearly set out a program indicating what he will be doing."
The governing Liberal Democratic Party is concerned about elections in the upper house of Parliament in May or June. If the party loses many seats, Mr. Miyazawa could be forced out.
 
Problem of U.S. Anger
 Another wild card is the new burst of anti-Japanese feeling in the United States, caused in part by a senior ally of Mr. Miyazawa's belittling American workers as lazy and illiterate. The Prime Minister could suffer if he is seen as failing to respond to American anger on this subject.
Mr. Miyazawa did not specify what he would do to ease American anger, but he alluded to agreements reached with Mr. Bush to step up Japanese purchases of American automobile parts and other products, again saying Japan should take such steps out of compassion for the United States.
"Japan-U.S. relations are the cornerstone of Japanese foreign policy," Mr. Miyazawa said. "It would be no exaggeration to say Japan could not have achieved its postwar prosperity had it not been for the good-hearted support of the United States." He added:
"Today the United States has some problems of its own, and it behooves Japan to make every effort to cooperate with the United States as it works to overcome these problems."
In international trade, Mr. Miyazawa is widely reported to have decided in principle to ease Japan's ban on imported rice, possibly by instituting tariffs, but no such system has been announced.
 
Apologies for Arrest
 Mr. Miyazawa sought to put a raging scandal behind him by apologizing for the arrest of Fumio Abe, a former top aide of his, on bribery charges. "I would like to offer my profound apologies to the people that such an incident has ever taken place," he said.
Mr. Abe was arrested on Jan. 13 for allegedly taking $650,000 in bribes from the Kyowa Corporation, a bankrupt steel-frame maker, while he served as a state minister in charge of development in Hokkaido, the northernmost island of the Japanese archipelago. He has denied the charges of bribery.
Although it is common for senior politicians to receive gifts from corporations it is illegal to do a specific favor in return. Mr. Abe is charged with helping the company in resort development in Hokkaido.
Opposition parties are demanding a thorough investigation, charging that some of the money may have directly benefited Mr. Miyazawa's political organization, which Mr. Abe served as secretary until recently.
 
Long-Promised Law Unlikely
 But politicians say that despite the furor over the scandal, it is unlikely that any of the long-promised legislation to curb the flow of money into the political system will be enacted soon.
Mr. Miyazawa's predecessor as Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, had made it a priority to enact new ceilings on corporate contributions, along with new government subsidies for elections. But these bills have foundered because they have been tied to a legislative redistricting program that has drawn widespread opposition.
Mr. Miyazawa has offered to separate the political reform measures from the redistricting but this ploy will probably not revive the chances of the package, according to politicians.
And few expect the bill regarding peacekeeping forces to be brought to the floor in the new session. The public has deeply mixed about the possible rearming of Japan, and the sending of Japanese troops into harm's way.
 
Hopes for New Budget
 Legislative aides to Mr. Miyazawa say his main hope for success lies in approval of a budget this year that would fulfill his pledge to revive the economy and make it serve as a "locomotive" to pull the United States and other countries out of a slump.
But the budget plans are drawing fire, especially from Socialists and other opposition parties that want military spending trimmed fast.
Mr. Miyazawa told reporters this month that they should have patience with him. Leading Japan, he said, "is not like riding a white horse and telling the people to follow me."
"In a large country like Japan," he added, "it's more like being a captain of a huge tanker. Sometimes the captain is not seen very often. But the captain is here doing his job."

HEADLINE: White Collars and Mortarboards Are No Shield in This Recession

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
The recession loitering in the region for three years now has been paying surprise visits to the homes of many people who had always thought that blue-chip educations and white-collar jobs made them immune to cutbacks and unemployment.
For these people, the economics of the slump have brought home a hard truth: recessions that used to spell trouble mostly for factory workers are now also disrupting the lives of the educated and the professional elite. 
 Their problems are still small, compared with the devastation succeeding slowdowns have caused blue-collar manufacturing employees in the region. But visits with some of the people affected show that the fact that jobs paying $50,000 and more can be scaled back or lost has come as a shock to many.
"I think we really got spoiled," said Georgianne Phipps of New Canaan, Conn., whose son, Bill, is unemployed. Mrs. Phipps, who heads the development office at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, reports a sense of fear across her community, one of the country's wealthiest.
"We were lulled into this complacency that was not founded on anything," she said. "We thought the economy would continue to grow and our wages would continue to grow year after year. Now economic reality has set in, and the bills have come due."
Mrs. Phipps is not alone in her concerns. Although the recession has stung college-educated and professional workers in many areas of the country, the New York City region has been particularly hard hit, both because the recession started here before it did in the rest of the country and because several industries that are concentrated in the New York region, notably advertising and financial services, have suffered disproportionate employment losses.
Mrs. Phipps was one of 1,726 adults interviewed in a recent New York Times poll of residents in the region immediately surrounding the city. The poll showed, among other things, that even among college-educated respondents with family incomes of $50,000 a year or more, many are coping with worsening family financial situations and unemployment.
When asked if their family financial situations had gotten better, worse or stayed the same in the last year, 22 percent of people in that well-off group said their situation had gotten worse.
Nineteen percent said it was the same as it was a year ago, but still something with which they were dissatisfied. Twenty-nine percent said their family's finances had gotten better, and another 29 percent said their finances had stayed the same and were satisfactory.
The telephone poll was conducted Nov. 2-12 with adult residents of 14 counties immediately surrounding the city in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut. The poll included 463 adults who said they had a college education and a family income of $50,000 or more in 1990. The margin of sampling error for this group is plus or minus 5 percentage points.
 
'I See Real Despair'
 "Out here in suburbia, in an affluent community, I see real despair," said Ms. Phipps, one of several poll respondents who agreed to be re-interviewed after the poll. "I see families living in million-dollar homes declaring bankruptcy, fathers who have lost their jobs and who can't find a new position. People just can't understand it."
Even among the well educated and highly paid, more than one in five said that at some point in the last year at least one adult in their household had been out of work and actively looking for a job.
Twenty-eight percent of all residents in the 14-county region surrounding the city said an adult in their households had been out of work and looking for a job.
"This is a different kind of recession because it has hit many of these white-collar people for the first time," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. "These are people who thought, 'Unemployment never happens to me.' Who ever heard of I.B.M. laying off workers? Who ever thought that young lawyers, full of vim and vigor, would be out on the streets looking for a job? But the white-collar job just ain't what it used to be."
In fact, blue-collar workers have been hit far harder in this recession, which the B.L.S. dates from the end of January 1989, than professional and office employees, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. In the region, white-collar unemployment has inched up, from 2.3 percent in 1988 to 2.9 percent last year, while blue-collar joblessness has climbed to 15 percent, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
But for people who have never experienced anything but the upward arc of prosperity, the white-collar recession has been unsettling. The exasperation at having even a big salary trimmed, of being cut back on work hours, of having a newly graduated son or daughter at home, jobless, or of losing one's position outright and finding the job market radically changed -- these are the elements adding economic insecurity to the comforts and privileges of middle-class suburban living.
"I asked myself, 'I made all this money, how can we have all this debt?' " said Cynthia Cobb of Stamford. "And I realized that we spent all the cash and used up all the credit. That may be the great summary of the life in the 80's -- we spent the cash and used up the credit, and now the reckoning comes."
This is not from someone who suddenly finds herself on the street. Mrs. Cobb, 37 years old, made about $100,000 in 1991. The problem is that during the last decade she was making $170,000 a year creating and selling newspaper advertising inserts, the glossy fliers that come in the Sunday paper.
During that time, she and her husband, a musician recently retrained as a computer consultant, accumulated the trappings to go with those numbers: a Jaguar, furs, a condo in Vermont, private school for their young daughter.
Now the advertising business, one that is as synonymous with New York City as Wall Street and the Yankees, is in a slump. The Cobbs's condo is for sale, and the Jaguar would be, too, if Mrs. Cobb could get out of the lease. "I'm stuck with this," she said. "Nobody else wants it, either."
Like others who were interviewed after the poll, Mrs. Cobb said the workplace itself has changed with the recession. Her company, hurt by the slump, was bought by another, and that put her in competition with the new owners' sales people and forced her into a less profitable side of the business. Even that arrangement may end, with worse to come, she said.
Bryan Lovelace, who handles props for filming TV commercials, has seen his income drop from $80,000 in the mid-1980s to about $40,000 in 1991, and blames not only cutbacks in advertising spending, but also cost-cutting in the way films are made.
"They don't want to put as many people on, and they don't want to work as long," he said. "For a car commercial, we would get a couple of days prep, a couple days shooting, and end up with a week's work. Now they want to do it all in two days."
 
Living Like College Students
 Mr. Lovelace, who is 37 years old and single, left Manhattan for an apartment in Nyack, N.Y., to save money. He knows that he is hardly alone in making these adjustments.
"We have seen a whole generation of advertising people just absolutely canned," he said. "The guys 40 and over, who have been in business for 20 or 25 years, if they didn't own a piece of the agency, they were just ditched, because they had their seniority and would want more money. People my age are living like college students, they're stuffed in $1,200-a-month studio apartments, living with roommates. It boggles the mind."
He lives with a sense of stalled progress. "I thought, at this point in my life, that I would own several pieces of property," he said. "I don't own anything."
Of course, money worries are relative, and the problems that college-educated, middle-class suburbanites face in the trough of the business cycle are easier to bear because of the options they have.
"One of the things my husband and I did was to say, 'Hey, we're red-blooded Americans. We are going to take this situation in our own hands make this work,' " Mrs. Cobb said.
So, despite her $2,000-a-week income, she took a second job at Macy's over the holidays, selling jewelry for $7.50 an hour plus 1 and a half percent commission. Her husband did carpentry and freelanced as a computer installer. They had an all-cash Christmas.
"The first time ever," she said. "No Mastercard, no Visa, no Lord & Taylor bills hanging over my head."
Mr. Lovelace, meanwhile, works part-time in a recording studio to stretch his income. And Victoria Faggiano, 40 years old, a former municipal bond saleswoman on Wall Street who lives in New Brunswick, N.J., took a three-month secretarial job to stretch her unemployment compensation until things get better.
She was earning more than $80,000 a year on Wall Street before losing her job, but a rent-controlled apartment and a frugal lifestyle let her get by on her $140 a week in unemployment insurance.
"Things are really dead out there," she said. "I've put out some resumes and gone for some interviews, and I've heard nothing since Thanksgiving."
Ms. Faggiano says she is sure that, with her bachelor's and master's degrees, she will eventually find a job. But echoing Mr. Lovelace's warning that employers have changed the way they do business, she said that unemployed professionals like her will find the office a different place.
"The firms may start to hire, but they have a tremendous number of experienced people to choose from," she said. "When I started in Wall Street in the early 80's, there were the grunts like me and the front men who went out and kissed the babies and had four-martini lunches and made the deals. Now they're looking for the rocket-scientist guys who can do computer trading, technical analysis of the stock market and that sort of thing."
Ms. Phipps, of New Canaan, spoke of the frustrations of the coming generation of professionals who graduated from college with high hopes, only to confront the teeth of the recession. Her son, Bill, earned a degree in government from St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y., 18 months ago, she said, and has not been able to start on a career path since then.
An unemployed college graduate affects the lives of parents, too, said Ms. Phipps. "The kids who are finding work are starting out at $15,000 a year, and they're living at home -- aren't we lucky?" she said with an affectionate laugh.
"I was always envious," she said. "I have always worked for nonprofits, and I used to think if I worked in a corporation I would have a corporate salary and the expense account and take those big trips. But now I think I am better off than that. At least nobody's taking my Mercedes away, because I never had one."

HEADLINE: 6th Quarterly Loss in Row for Texas Instruments

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Texas Instruments Inc. today reported its sixth consecutive quarterly loss, but analysts said cost-cutting moves taken last year by the giant chip maker appeared to be working.
The company trimmed 6,000 jobs through voluntary retirement, layoffs, attrition and assets sales during 1991 for a one-time charge of $240 million, leading to a loss of $85 million. But the $220 million in yearly savings projected today by Jerry R. Junkins, chairman and chief executive, contributed to a small operating profit of $12 million in the fourth quarter. 
 "The actions to reduce fixed costs, overhead and operating costs have begun to have some impact," said Thomas A. Thornhill, semiconductor analyst and principal at Montgomery Securities, in San Francisco. "The operating profit was above expectations."
The fourth-quarter loss compared with a loss of $56 million in the period in 1990. Revenues fell slightly, to $1.75 billion from $1.76 billion.
The company's biggest struggle now is improving lagging production of dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's, capable of storing four million characters of information, or four megabits. Global demand for these higher-capacity memory chips took hold in 1991, but Texas Instruments was left in the dust by big Japanese suppliers, led by Hitachi, Toshiba and NEC.
According to Dataquest, a research firm in San Jose, Calif., those three companies combined sold 86 million four-megabit memory chips, compared with 3.5 million by Texas Instruments. The total market was 140 million units.
Falling prices also squeezed profit margins. The current price for the four-million-character D-RAM is about $13, down from nearly $20 a year ago. "Because T.I. got in late, they have to be more aggressive in pricing to win business from companies who are more established," said Lane Mason, a Dataquest analyst.
Worldwide sales for the chips will amount to $20 billion through 1994, he said. William P. Weber, president of the semiconductor group at Texas Instruments, said the company would increase market share of four-megabit chips in 1992, with three plants -- in Italy, Japan and Taiwan -- now in various stages of production. Within two years, he added, the company would increase its chip output capacity to eight times last year's level.
 
Share Price Dips
 In a statement, Mr. Junkins said the company was "planning to return to profitability in 1992" but he did not say in which quarter. The company's share price fell by 75 cents, to $35, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"If we get a decent economy, as the stock market is anticipating, they clearly will make money," said Richard L. Whittington, an independent analyst in New York. "If they get those D-RAM plants cracking, they could take a lot of market share in '92 because of cutbacks the Japanese have made in their own D-RAM capacity."
The recent quarter included a $55 million charge related to cutting 1,000 additional jobs beginning today, mainly in computer chip and information technology business segments, and phasing out older chip production equipment. The total charge of $80 million was reduced by a $25 million gain posted from a pension plan involved in the voluntary retirement program.
Royalty income from chip-licensing agreements was $57 million in the quarter, compared with $53 million in the quarter a year ago.
For the year, Texas Instruments posted the steepest loss in its history. The company lost $409 million, compared with a loss of $39 million in 1990. Revenues rose by 3.2 percent, to $6.78 billion from $6.57 billion.
Semiconductor sales rose to $3.4 billion, from $3.1 billion in 1990, with the loss rising to $188 million, from $76 million. Operating profit in the military-supply unit fell to $111 million, from $170 million. The unit's revenue fell to $1.95 billion, from $2.12 billion a year ago, but orders surged by 84 percent as the Pentagon moved to bolster supplies of missiles and other equipment made by Texas Instruments that were used in the Persian Gulf war.

HEADLINE: Bush to Seek More Money for Major Space Missions

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Telling an enthusiastic group of young people that even in hard times the public must invest in the future, President Bush said today that he would seek additional money for the space station, robot missions to the moon and other aerospace projects.
Mr. Bush, surrounded by 23 space shuttle astronauts who were visiting Washington, told more than 100 cheering school children and their advisers, "America's destiny must include manned exploration" of space. 
 Noting that he has committed the country to returning people to the moon and reaching further into space, the President said his 1993 budget proposal to be made public next week would include $2.25 billion for Space Station Freedom, an 11 percent increase over the current amount.
 
'We've Challenged America'
 In addition, he said, the Administration will seek $250 million to triple spending on a new series of unmanned space rockets, request more money for a hypersonic plane that could fly from an airport runway directly into low orbit and ask for money to start a program to send two robot craft into lunar orbit to complete the mapping of the moon.
"I set a goal for young Americans like you to travel to Mars," Mr. Bush said to the Young Astronauts' Council, a national group of grammar school children interested in space exploration. "We've challenged America to go back to the moon to stay and then on to Mars."
Mr. Bush stressed the economic value of investing in space to create jobs and economic opportunity for the country. The United States exports more than $1 billion a year in space goods and services, an effort that is worth 20,000 jobs, he said.
"I'm asking Americans to make a far-sighted commitment, one that looks dozens of years and millions of miles beyond the recession and the other things that preoccupy us today," Mr. Bush said.
Administration officials familiar with the space program said the President's 1993 budget request for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration would not match the increases sought in previous years, but would exceed the current 3 percent rate of inflation. NASA's $14.3 billion budget will go up modestly under the proposal, a concession to the recession, the officials said.
The proposal also shows continued support for projects that did not do well in the Congressional budget process last year, said a White House official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Mr. Bush said he would ask for $80 million for NASA's share of the hypersonic plane, which is to be built in a cooperative program with the military. Last year Congress cut the Administration's $72 million request on behalf of NASA for the plane to $5 million, and reduced the Defense Department's share from a requested $232 million to $200 million.
Dr. John Logsdon, director of George Washington University's Space Policy Institute, said Mr. Bush appeared to be putting forth a budget that emphasized newer technology rather than upgrading old capability, like building new expendable rockets instead of recycling old military models. "This is the kind of budget that should be put forward if the country expects to move ahead in space in the future," he said.
Representative George E. Brown Jr., the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, said he was pleased the President's proposal appeared to maintain a balance between space exploration and science. But he said finding money for an expanded space program in the current economic climate "will be challenging."
Mr. Bush met with the children and the crews of four of NASA's most recent space shuttle missions as part of a program to kick off International Space Year, a yearlong worldwide celebration of space cooperation that involves 29 national space agencies, 10 international groups and the United Nations.
 
Talked to Crew in Space
 Mr. Bush and some of the children talked with the crew of the space shuttle Discovery, which went into orbit on Wednesday carrying astronauts from three countries and an international microgravity laboratory.
The astronauts, whose picture from inside the laboratory was projected on a large screen to the surprise of the children meeting Mr. Bush at the White House, said most of their experiments were going well and encouraged the children to study science and mathematics if they wanted careers in space. During the television hookup, the astronauts juggled a 120-pound camera on their fingertips to show how light things are in space and performed some acrobatics.
NASA said the planned weeklong mission was going well, despite problems with a balky toilet and unexpected difficulty growing a rare kind of crystal. Members of the seven-member crew were trying to fix a loose handle on the shuttle's toilet that prevented it from flushing. If a solution cannot be found, the six men and one woman aboard will have to use plastic bags carried aboard for such emergencies, an agency spokesman said.
The astronauts were able to grow an unusually pure mercury oxide crystal in the absence of gravity, said Keith Robinson, a spokesman at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala. Mercury oxide crystals are used to detect X-rays and gamma radiation, and are difficult to grow in the ideal shape and size on Earth because of the influence of gravity.
Early today when astronauts looked at the seed crystal used as the core of the one to be grown, they found numerous small, imperfect crystals growing at its base that threatened to ruin the experiment. But Ulf Merbold, a German physicist and crystal expert, was able to manipulate the temperature in the growing chamber to dissolve the small crystals and later reported that a smooth, perfect main crystal was beginning to form, Mr. Robinson said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush leading a discussion with the astronauts on board the shuttle Discovery, on monitor, and members of the Young Astronauts' Council, a group of grammar school children interested in space exploration. From left in foreground, were, Russell Frisby, Conner Sabatino, Rachel Heckman; back row, Vice President Dan Quayle, Mr. Bush and Richard Truly, NASA Administrator. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Boston Journal;
When Gilding the Roof Can Tarnish One's Image

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Oliver Wendell Holmes called the State House that sits proudly atop Beacon Hill here "the hub of the solar system."
Even allowing for hyperbole, in Massachusetts, at least, the State House's golden dome has traditionally served as the measuring rod by which distances to Boston are calculated. The building was designed in 1795 by Charles Bullfinch, the noted architect whose elegant creations transformed Boston. 
 So when word recently spread that the gold foil that covers the dome is flaking off in spots, revealing an unsightly black undercoat, it might have been expected that Gov. William F. Weld, one of whose ancestors helped found Harvard College in 1636, would have acted expeditiously to restore the famous dome.
But no. Instead, Governor Weld last week ordered his Department of Capital Planning and Operations to stop its plans to re-gild the 9,073-square-foot dome, at a projected cost of about $250,000. "The Governor ordered a halt to any gilding pending a structural evaluation of the dome to see if there is any public safety reason for doing it," said his spokesman, Ray Howell.
Re-gilding the dome, with the necessary 13 pounds of gold foil, threatened to become an unhappy symbol for Mr. Weld, a Republican and avowed libertarian who, as part of a major effort to reduce the size of state government, has sharply cut state spending for education, welfare and other human services. How would it look if he spent a quarter of a million dollars on gold for a dome?
Moreover, Massachusetts is in its worst economic slump since the Depression, having lost more than 11 percent of its jobs in three years. Demonstrators troop through the State House almost daily, protesting cuts in spending for welfare, teachers, police officers or firefighters.
Perhaps seeking to minimize any political fallout, Russ Aims, an official of the state's capital planning agency, said the only reason talk of re-gilding the dome had come up at all was that the department was preparing to replace the State House roof. The roof has been leaking for years, he said, with rain and snow seeping into the building's walls and ceilings, causing stains and other damage. Replacement of the roof, exclusive of re-gilding, is expected to cost $2 million, Mr. Aims said.
The interior of the State House is now being repainted by about 20 inmates from Massachusetts. This is part of a program begun by Governor Weld to get tougher on crime and make inmates work.
When the State House was originally completed in 1798, on the site of a cow pasture that had belonged to John Hancock, the dome was shingled and painted. But it leaked then, too, so Paul Revere, naturally, came to the rescue, putting his metal-working skills to work and sheathing the dome in copper in 1802.
The dome was not decked out in its full finery until 1872, when it was covered with 23-karat gold leaf, in the period of American history known as the Gilded Age. The cost was $2,862.50.
In the late 19th century and early 20th century the dome was re-gilded every five or 10 years. In World War II it was painted gray to shield Boston from the eyes of German U-boats.
Mary Ellen Shattuck, a member of the Doric Dames, a group of volunteers who give tours of the State House, can recall those days, but said the darkly painted dome did not concern her then. In her blunt Yankee fashion, she curtly said, "I was working at Harvard," as if that ought to explain everything.
Mrs. Shattuck, whose husband's family came to Massachusetts in 1630, takes enormous pride in the State House, but she said she understands Governor Weld's decision to hold off on the re-gilding, which was last done in 1969. "It's just not a top priority now, with the way our economy is," she said.
What she would really appreciate, she said, would be fewer demonstrators disrupting the decorum of the State House. "It's such a lovely building," she said, "and they make such a fuss."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Clintons to Rebut Rumors on "60 Minutes"

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and his wife, Hillary, have agreed to appear together on the CBS News program "60 Minutes" on Sunday night after the Super Bowl to respond to accusations that he has had extramarital affairs.
Campaign aides spent the day sifting through invitations to appear on news programs over the weekend before deciding on "60 Minutes," a Clinton campaign spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said. CBS said the program would start about 10 P.M. 
 The Democratic Presidential candidate, who spent yesterday in Little Rock, and his wife, who campaigned in Georgia, will record the segment in Boston on Sunday, Ms. Myers said.
Mr. Clinton stayed with his announced schedule today, meeting in Little Rock with his cabinet and staying in the state for the execution of a convicted killer. He is scheduled to appear Saturday at a Rainbow Coalition forum here and deliver a speech in Boston before traveling to New Hampshire for a rally.
Campaign officials said the joint appearance reflected an intention to engage the candidate's wife in the effort to combat allegations that he had a 12-year extramarital affair with Gennifer Flowers, who now works for the state.
The accusations have been published in Star, a tabloid that says it paid Ms. Flowers for her account but declined to say how much.
Mr. Clinton has acknowledged knowing Ms. Flowers. She started working for the state last June as an administrative assistant at the Arkansas Board of Review, which hears appeals involving unemployment compensation. William D. Gaddy, director of the state's Employment Security Division, which provides administrative suport for the board, said an aide in Governor Clinton's office referred her to the board as part of a routine process.
Her supervisor, Randall Wright, said she was hired from a merit list because she was the best qualified. He said no one from the Governor's office contacted him about hiring her.
At a news conference in Savannah today, Mrs. Clinton said: "As with most married couples, we've had our good times and our bad times. We are more committed, more stable and more in love now because when the tough times came we didn't cut out. When people get to know us and talk to our friends in Arkansas, they won't give that story the time of day."

HEADLINE: U.S. Weighing Aid for Russian Nuclear Scientists

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is considering several plans to provide assistance to Russian nuclear scientists to keep them from accepting offers to work in developing nations trying to build weapons, the State Department said today.
Congressional leaders and private organizations concerned about the spread of nuclear weapons are pressing the Bush Administration to act quickly to provide assistance not only to prevent a brain drain but also to speed up the process of dismantling weapons in the former Soviet Union, a process that the scientists could assist. 
 "There is a lot of serious thinking going on on this subject," the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said today. "But that there is an interagency single proposal or one that has been forwarded to the White House for approval -- we're not at that point yet."
 
Fellowships and Employment
 The proposals, reported today by The Los Angeles Times, include providing fellowships to scientists and employing them in the dismantling of Soviet weapons, members of Congress and nongovernmental nuclear experts say.
Some officials expect that President Bush will announce an American initiative in his State of the Union speech next week. Reginald Bartholomew, Under Secretary of State for International Security Affairs, returned Thursday from a trip to Russia, where all issues about the disarming of Soviet weapons were discussed, the State Department said.
A team of American nuclear specialists remained in Moscow for in-depth studies, Miss Tutwiler said, adding that the specialists are expected to return to Washington in time to brief Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d before he leaves for Russia on Sunday. Mr. Baker, who will meet the Russian Defense Minister and attend an international conference on the Middle East, was briefed by Mr. Bartholomew today, Miss Tutwiler said.
 
Backing for European Idea
 On Wednesday, Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, asked in a Senate speech that the Administration support "enthusiastically" a European proposal for a fellowship program that would pay to keep Russian scientists in the Commonwealth of Independent States.
Mr. Pell recently returned from a trip to Russia and Ukraine, where he said he found many people eager to see nuclear weapons moved or dismantled.
On the same day, Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, proposed an international agency to find employment for the scientists. His proposal has won wide backing in Europe.
 
Salary Plan for 2,000 Experts
 Senator John W. Warner, a Virgina Republican and member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, confirmed in an interview today that the Administration was seriously considering, among other proposals, a plan to provide money to pay 2,000 experts in the former Soviet Union to oversee the destruction of weapons.
"The cost effectiveness of this is astonishing," the Senator said. "For a small amount of money, you can give them the opportunity to work with the U.S. private sector in demilitarizing and also cleaning up the nuclear sites."
Congress has authorized $400 million to assist in the dismantling of weapons in the former Soviet Union. Miss Tutwiler said today that she could not say how that money would be spent until proposals had been formalized and sent to the President.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Campaign's New Prop: A Prescription in Print

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 24

 BODY:
Last Sunday, when the Democratic candidates met for a televised debate, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas brought a prop: a copy of his 86-page prescription for solving the country's problems.
"This is not rhetoric," he said at one point, waving the gray booklet in front of the camera. "This is a real economic plan." 
 What the gesture lacked in genuine drama it made up with its sober show of specificity. After getting a bad reputation during the last few campaigns, details -- or at least the idea of them -- are making a comeback in the 1992 Presidential election.
Indeed, so high a premium is being put on specifics that one of the hot new issues of the primary campaign is which candidates have published bound volumes of their plans, and which have not.
 
A Three-Volume Set
 So far, three of the five major Democratic candidates -- Mr. Tsongas of Massachusetts, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa -- have published novella-length booklets. Mr. Tsongas's plan, "A Call to Economic Arms," was the first in the series and remains the lengthiest. Mr. Harkin's plan, "A Blueprint to Build a New America," which weighs in at a more modest 35 pages, was released just this week and appears in large part to be an effort to keep up with the competition.
The biggest build-up belongs to Mr. Clinton's booklet: "A Plan for America's Future." In a television commercial that is being broadcast in New Hampshire, Governor Clinton sits in front of an American flag and assures voters that they "deserve more than 30-second ads or vague promises." Then he urges them to visit their libraries to review his plan, or to call his office and receive a free copy.
"Campaigns have always had position papers," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic consultant. "But I don't think they've ever been marketed in quite the same way."
At least for the time being, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska has declined to publish a special booklet. This decision is one that he seems increasingly compelled to justify.
"I don't believe this election is going to be won by presenting a flurry of position papers," he said in Sunday's debate.
Despite Senator Kerrey's efforts, however, the "plan gap" has become a point of contention between him and Governor Clinton.
"Our opponents are complaining that we shouldn't be measured by position papers," said Frank Greer, Mr. Clinton's media adviser. "Well, they may not think so, but the voters think so."
The Kerrey campaign, meanwhile, portrays the whole battle of the booklets as vaguely ridiculous. It has tried to recast the issue as one of comprehensive plans versus clear priorities.
"The Clinton people keep repeating like a new mantra that specificity is the new character issue," said Michael McCurry, an adviser to Senator Kerrey. "People do want specifics. But it's not quantity that counts, it's priorities."
Mr. Kerrey has made health care his first priority, and has introduced in the Senate a detailed bill to provide national health insurance. The campaign has no plans to publish a plan, Mr. McCurry said. But if it did, he said, "I guess we should come in higher than Harkin and lower than Tsongas; if we clocked in at 40 to 45 pages, that should be about right."
Political analysts attribute this year's proliferation of plans to the recession, and to the disillusionment it has produced with the glib nostrums of the last few elections.
 
Studiously Vague
 But even though the candidates advertise their plans as carefully detailed solutions to the country's ills, truly cynical voters may still find grounds for skepticism. While they are chock-full of statistics, when it comes to paying for their proposals, the plans are studiously vague.
Mr. Clinton, for example, advocates an increased tax exemption for families with children; he says the increase could be paid for by cutting the Federal bureaucracy but never mentions how much the plan will cost, or where he intends to cut. Similarly, Mr. Harkin asserts in his plan that he will provide health care to all Americans. But he never puts a price tag on the plan, and the only savings he mentions, cutting "bureaucratic waste, red tape and padded prices," are not quantified.
In the end, though, what seems to be more important than what is proposed in the plan is the idea that the plan exists. While all of the campaigns report that demand for their plans is brisk, it is unclear whether voters are actually reading the plans, or just collecting them, the way one might collect clippings on important but dull topics, to be perused at some unspecified time in the future.
For example, the reference librarian at the Bedford Public Library, Susan Rotch, had a copy of Governor Clinton's plan on her desk. She said she thought the plan was a "very good idea." But when asked whether she herself had read it, she shook her head regretfully.
"I know I should have," she said.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Mail-Order Rule Likely to Change

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If the Justices' questioning during oral arguments is any guide to their ultimate decision, the Supreme Court seems likely to overturn a landmark 1967 ruling and decide this spring that a state may levy sales taxes on mail-order merchandise from outside its borders.
The Court seemed quite unsympathetic on Wednesday to the position of the Quill Corporation, an Illinois-based marketer of office supplies. Its sales in North Dakota have produced a high-stakes challenge to the principle that states could not make tax collectors of companies with no physical presence within their borders. 
 North Dakota asserts that this gives mail-order houses a significant advantage over local merchants and that modern technology has made the physical-presence requirement obsolete.
One Justice whose comments pointed to overturning the 25-year-old precedent, which involved National Bellas Hess Inc., was Antonin Scalia, who demanded of Quill's lawyer: "I want you to tell me why collecting the tax is worse if you use the phone to sell than if you use salesmen." He added, according to an account by Tax Analysts' Daily Tax Highlights and Documents: "You're elevating the method of selling to a point of principle."
The tide seemed so strong, in fact, that some Justices wondered aloud about how, assuming they overturned National Bellas Hess, the Court or Congress might deal with a potential consequence: North Dakota and other states seeking to collect the tax retroactively.
Economists have debated for years whether individual retirement accounts prompt people to raise their savings or merely confer tax benefits on those who shuffle around money they would have saved anyway. In the latest analysis, Jonathan Skinner of the University of Virginia concludes that I.R.A.'s do indeed raise savings, though he acknowledges a continued lack of hard evidence. Professor Skinner cites psychological factors, like advertising, peer pressure and, most importantly, the "lockup" effect, under which available money is put out of reach, subject to a stiff penalty for early removal. "I call this soft evidence, but to me it's fairly compelling," he said. His results come as Congress is about to consider amendments the I.R.A. rules, including one for penalty-free withdrawals by people buying their first homes.
Even if an investment in an I.R.A. is initially shifted from, say, a money market fund, Professor Skinner contends, the lockup effect tends to increase this person's savings since he or she will, put back part of the money market account.
"I view people as thinking about their financial planning through this hazy fog," he said, denigrating the assumptions of orthodox economic models that have studied behavior during and since the heyday of I.R.A. deductibility between 1982 and 1986. One of the most effective tools for promoting new savings, he says, would be for the Government to send each taxpayer an annual notice stating the amount currently eligible for contribution.
 
Footnotes
 * Paul Craig Roberts, a Treasury official in the Reagan Administration, said this week that President Bush could cut the capital gains tax unilaterally by changing the definition of cost to include inflation. He contended that the cost basis of an asset, the starting point for calculating gain, was defined by regulation rather than statute.
* The House Ways and Means Committee has rescheduled its Long Island field hearing for Feb. 10 at the Nassau County police headquarters auditorium in Mineola. Representatives Raymond J. McGrath and Thomas J. Downey will preside over the session on the local economy and various issues that are scheduled to come before the tax-writing committee.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
American Brands Profit Sets Record

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 24

 BODY:
American Brands Inc., the maker of Lucky Strike cigarettes and Jim Beam bourbon, today reported record profits of $216.6 million in the fourth quarter.
For the year, the company's profits rose by nearly 37 percent. 
 Despite the recession and new taxes overseas, American Brands had strong increases in tobacco and liquor sales, William J. Alley, the chairman and chief executive, said.
"Over all, our operations are generally performing very well in their markets," he added. "We remain optimistic about the future and, despite continued weak economic conditions, we expect another record year in 1992."
 
$1.04 a Share
 The fourth-quarter earnings of $216.6 million, which amounted to $1.04 a share, were up from $7.1 million, or 2 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter. In the 1990 period, the company had recorded a $214.6 million write-down of the preferred stock it held in the McGregor Acquisition Corporation.
American Brands' revenues edged up slightly in the quarter, to $3.79 billion from $3.75 billion.
For all of 1991, American Brands' earnings totaled $806.1 million, or $3.91 a share, compared with $588.6 million, or $2.95 a share. Its revenues last year were up by 2 percent, to $14.06 billion, from $13.78 billion in 1990.
The results helped American Brands' stock advance 87.5 cents today on the New York Stock Exchange, where it closed at $45.875.
 
Solid Tobacco Sales
 Besides its tobacco and liquor businesses, American Brands, based in Old Greenwich, has operations in hardware, office products and life insurance.
Tobacco sales, through its American Tobacco Company and British-based Gallaher Tobacco units, posted strong quarterly results, the company said. Its total tobacco revenues during the year rose 1 percent, to $8.2 billion. American Tobacco's brands also include Carlton and Pall Mall.
American Brands' distilled spirits operations reported 12 percent higher earnings in 1991 than in 1990. Besides Jim Beam bourbon, the company's other brands include Lord Calvert Canadian whisky and Gilbey's gin. British sales were offset by a 12 percent rise in taxes.
 
Record for Hardware Unit
 Despite the worst year for housing starts since World War II, the company's Masterbrand hardware and home-improvement group had a record year. The division's income totaled $141.5 million.
Income during the year dropped by 57 percent, to $37.7 million, at American Brands' ACCO World office products unit. The division blamed the recession and fewer white-collar jobs. ACCO cut 10 percent of its workers last year.
At the Franklin Life Insurance Company unit, meanwhile, its revenues totaled $870 million in 1991, up by 8 percent from a year earlier. The operation's revenues rose 12 percent in the fourth quarter.
