HEADLINE: Legislators Try to Save Seawolf Program

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
With Connecticut's vital defense industries already hard hit by layoffs and preparing for more, the state's Congressional delegation is desperately trying to save the Seawolf nuclear submarine and the thousands of jobs it provides.
"It's like standing in the face of a blizzard and a hurricane simultaneously," said Christopher J. Dodd, the state's senior Democratic Senator. "It's a real maelstrom. And obviously we're bracing for more tough news." 
 Just days ago, the state's largest private employer, United Technologies, announced that it would be cutting 6,400 jobs in Connecticut. And worse news could come as soon as Tuesday, when President Bush is to outline his budget priorities in his State of the Union Address. There have been reports that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney may choose to slash the attack-submarine program, sending tremors through the state and its Congressional delegation.
 
Legislators Mount Campaign
 And so, in what could be a major political test for some members of the state's delegation, the legislators have banded together in an impassioned press to save the submarine, which is built in Groton by Electric Boat, a division of the General Dynamics Corporation. Electric Boat is the second largest private employer in Connecticut and a major employer in neighboring Rhode Island.
"It's very important," said Representative Rosa L. DeLauro, the New Haven Democrat. "The issue is larger than a single program or company. It's the entire defense industry in Connecticut."
The campaign on behalf of the submarine, which costs about $2 billion a copy, is a microcosm of the skirmishes breaking out across Capitol Hill as legislators battle to save home-state weapons systems and bases threatened by cuts in the defense budget in the wake of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the cold war.
The entire Connecticut and Rhode Island Congressional delegations met this week to present the case for the Seawolf to Mr. Cheney. The legislators said the Defense Secretary listened politely to their argument that the submarine's cancellation would lead to the loss of pivotal manufacturing skills but gave them little reason for optimism.
The legislators also have sought to build a Congressional coalition behind the submarine by calling in political chits from colleagues, while Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has pleaded the attack submarine's case in an open letter to the Bush Administration.
Connecticut is in particularly dire straits. Its economy has been dependent on defense industries since the time of the quintessential Connecticut Yankee, Eli Whitney, whose inventions included a rifle with interchangeable parts.
At no time was the relationship between Connecticut and the military closer than in the 1980's. Although represented in Congress largely by doves, the state grabbed a substantial share of the Reagan Administration's defense buildup. While it had only 1.3 percent of the country's population, Connecticut in 1988 received 2.61 percent of defense spending. At its peak in the late 1980's, defense spending in the state totaled almost $3,000 per resident. That was the engine for an economic boom that pushed Connecticut's per capita income to the highest in the nation.
But now the boom has turned to bust, and the state's big defense contractors have announced layoffs. Connecticut's unemployment rate in November jumped to 6.9 percent from 5.3 percent a year ago.
"We're a victim of our own success," said Senator Dodd.
The United Technologies announcement is the latest such decision to stagger the recession-racked New York metropolitan region, which has long relied heavily on the defense industry. On Long Island, the Grumman Corporation and myriad other smaller military suppliers have lost an estimated 20,000 jobs since the procurement boom of the mid-1980's. And Electric Boat said some months ago that it would eliminate 10,000 jobs, many of them in a previous scaling back of the Seawolf program.
Even tougher times may lie ahead. A cancellation of the Seawolf program, Electric Boat officials have indicated, could lead to the shutting down of the company, which employs 22,000 people in Connecticut and Rhode Island. Even a sharp cutback in the current procurement program would lead to the termination of many of those employees, company officials said, and would bring about layoffs at thousands of subcontractors throughout the region.
 
The Importance of Seawolf
 Unless the Federal cutbacks are balanced by an influx of money for new domestic programs, the impact is likely to be especially painful for the region, which gets less Federal money per capita than almost any other region in the country. Connecticut, for instance, which sends Washington 2.1 percent of the taxes it collects, receives only 1.27 percent of Federal expenditures for programs other than defense.
"That's why the defense cuts hit us with a double blow," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Connecticut's junior Democrat. "It will have a disproportionate effect because we've been very able, very fortunate when it comes to defense spending. But when it comes to social programs, Connecticut doesn't get its fair share."

HEADLINE: Crossland Is Seized By the U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The slumping New York real estate market claimed another victim yesterday afternoon when Federal banking regulators closed Crossland Savings, the city's largest savings bank. One hour and $1.2 billion later, they opened the new Crossland Federal Savings Bank, with new management and Federal ownership.
The seizure has no immediate effect on the bank's 400,000 customers. Depositors at Crossland, which is based in Brooklyn and has 44 branches in the New York area, continue to be insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for up to $100,000 an account. Interest rates on certificates of deposit will not be changed until the deposits mature.
 
Notes Taped to the Doors
 Notices taped to the doors of all Crossland branches at 3 P.M. told customers of the change, and said branches that normally stayed open late on Fridays would reopen at 4 P.M. About a dozen branches in Nassau County that are open on Saturdays will also be open today for business as usual. 
 To put the new Crossland on a strong financial footing after heavy losses on bad loans for construction of commercial buildings in the city, the F.D.I.C. invested $1.2 billion in the company. About $800 million of that was immediately absorbed by losses on bad loans, and $400 million is the bank's capital now. F.D.I.C. officials said they planned to try to sell the new Crossland within a year or two, and they estimated that after the sale, the Government's loss would be $500 million to $1 billion. It will be one of the F.D.I.C.'s 10 most costly bank failures.
 
No Buyers for Bad Loans
 William Taylor, chairman of the F.D.I.C., said the cost of the Government's investment in Crossland would be less than the cost of selling the old Crossland. Although the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Republic New York Corporation had bid for Crossland, they were not willing to accept most of Crossland's loans, which would have been left with the F.D.I.C.
"It is more cost effective for us to spend on repairs for Crossland than to rip out its wiring and sell its parts," Mr. Taylor said at a news conference in New York.
The decision to strengthen Crossland rather than sell it may be good news for some Crossland borrowers strained by the local economy. Mr. Taylor said that if the bank had been sold, there were about $2.5 billion of loans that are not delinquent but that the buyer would not have accepted, and would have been transferred to the F.D.I.C.
The transfer of those loans would hurt borrowers and the Government, Mr. Taylor said, because the F.D.I.C. has a low tolerance for any delinquencies and is prone to foreclose quickly. Quick foreclosures mean losses for the Government that are generally higher than would be suffered by a private owner, who is more likely to work out new loan agreements to keep borrowers afloat until the economy improves.
To manage the new Crossland, the F.D.I.C. hired Richard A. Kraemer, a banker who spent his entire career at New York savings banks, starting with Dime Savings in 1962. Known for his experience in handling the kinds of commercial real estate loans that got Crossland into trouble, Mr. Kraemer has been chairman of the Bowery Savings Bank and Home Savings Bank, and a top official at H. F. Ahmanson & Company, the California company that owns both New York savings banks.
 
Shift in Concentration
 Mr. Kraemer said Crossland would concentrate on issuing new-home mortgages, and steer clear of the commercial real estate business -- "where we have more than enough loans to work out before we even think of doing more."
Maurice L. Reissman, Crossland's chairman, who started his career as a branch teller, left the bank yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Taylor stopped short of saying that the F.D.I.C.'s $1.2 billion investment indicates a change in its policy for weak and failing banks. The agency has previously made similar investments, like that in Chicago's old Continental Illinois Bank in the mid-1980's, but for the most part has preferred to sell or close failed banks.
"In cases where we can find good management, and where the bank is viable with a strong business," Mr. Taylor said, the F.D.I.C. is more willing to consider investing in a bank to keep it alive. Mr. Taylor, whose office is in Washington, visited some Crossland offices in Brooklyn a month ago and saw firsthand the bank's loyal following at neighborhood branches.
Because Crossland's branches average more than $100 million of deposits, with some exceeding $300 million, the bank's branch system would be an attractive source of low-cost deposits for other banks. But Crossland's inability to invest those deposits in good-quality loans has been a long-standing problem.
Beginning in the mid-1980's, the bank began to make a splash in the New York real estate market by financing new apartment buildings, office towers and stores. Today, it has about $2 billion in loans that are not expected to be repaid in full or have already been foreclosed, and another $2.5 billion of loans that are not yet badly delinquent but are for such risky real estate projects that losses are possible.
 
Earlier Deal Fell Through
 In 1989, Crossland talked with the Pritzker family of Chicago about making a large investment in the bank. Those talks ended in early 1990, and by the summer of 1991 regulators said Crossland was insolvent but would remain in business until it could be sold. In the 21 months ended Sept. 30, Crossland lost $739 million, as prices of New York real estate fell and regulators forced the company to recognize its losses.
Shareholders in Crossland were wiped out last year after regulators said the bank was insolvent.
The grandiose expansion plans of the company, encouraged by its expansive real estate lending and typified by its change of name in 1985 to Crossland from Metropolitan Savings, led Representative Charles Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, in an interview yesterday, to call it "a case study of what is wrong with our banking system, with institutions soaking up insured deposits and using them to fund high-risk, speculative loans."
Peter Treadway, an analyst of savings institutions at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said Mr. Kraemer, Crossland's new chairman, has "a very good reputation, but he faces a tremendous challenge in finding profitable assets" where the deposits may be invested.

HEADLINE: Profits Drop for Exxon, Mobil and Chevron

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Three of the nation's biggest oil companies reported lower earnings today for the fourth quarter, as world crude prices slumped and the recession slowed sales of gasoline and other refined products.
Exxon said net income fell 28.2 percent. Mobil reported an earnings decline of 38.5 percent. And Chevron, which took a one-time charge against earnings of $244 million, said net income plunged 93.8 percent. 
 The reports followed the trend of sharply lower earnings for the oil industry in the quarter, which partly reflected the unusually high profits most oil companies posted in the last quarter of 1990.
Profits in exploration and production units soared then amid worries of war and destruction in the Persian Gulf oilfields that pushed crude prices to an average of nearly $30 a barrel.
Over all, Exxon, Mobil and Chevron each reported better results overseas than in the United States during the recent quarter, in both exploration and refining operations.
"U.S. refining and marketing operations were particularly disappointing, but that's starting to turn around," said Bryan Jacoboski, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. "December was the first month with evidence of improvement, and profit margins have improved the first two weeks in January for most companies."
Allen E. Murray, the Mobil Corporation's chairman and chief executive, said business conditions were not improving. Prices were weak for crude oil worldwide and for natural gas in the United States; refinery profit margins were "very weak" in the United States, he added.
Following are details from each of the three companies' earnings reports:
 
Exxon
 Net income at the Exxon Corporation, the world's biggest oil company, was $1.12 billion, or 89 cents a share, compared with $1.56 billion, or $1.23 a share, in the period a year ago. Revenues fell 12.1 percent, to $30.87 billion from $35.12 billion.
The company, based in Irving, Tex., said the price for its crude sold in the fourth quarter fell by an average of $10.50 a barrel from the comparable quarter in 1990. For that reason, earnings from worldwide exploration and production also fell, to $616 million from $862 million.
Worldwide refining profits declined, to $261 million from $304 million. The company posted an $84 million charge in the fourth quarter for projects to improve environmental standards at its refineries, compared with a charge of $108 million a year ago.
Chemical earnings fell, to $96 million from $102 million, as global demand weakened, but Exxon's chemical unit in the United States doubled its profits in the period, to $73 million from $37 million.
For the year, the most profitable in Exxon's history, earnings rose 11.8 percent, to $5.60 billion, or $4.45 a share, from $5.01 billion, or $3.96 a share, in 1990. Revenue was nearly flat, at $116.34 billion, compared with $116.94 billion.
Lawrence G. Rawl, chairman and chief executive, said virtually all of the higher profit came in the first quarter, when big refining profits in Europe and the Middle East enabled Exxon to earn $2.2 billion, or double the level of the following three quarters. He said that three-fourths of Exxon's profits and all of the profit growth came from outside the United States.
Exxon's share price rose $1.25 today, to $60.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Mobil
 Net income for the nation's second-largest oil company fell to $401 million in the quarter, or 97 cents a share, from $652 million, or $1.58 a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues declined 14.2 percent, to $16.63 billion from $19.38 billion.
Mobil's operations for the quarter posted a deeper decline of 51.2 percent, after removing the effects of special charges in both quarters. The company added $12 million to operating earnings because of one-time charges in the most recent quarter. In the quarter a year ago, special charges pared earnings by $145 million.
Profits in worldwide exploration and production fell to $419 million, from $573 million, as prices for both crude oil and natural gas plummeted. Mobil's crude prices in the United States fell by an average of $10.64 a barrel, to $16.29, and in international operations by an average of $11.65 a barrel, to $20.60.
Refining earnings plunged to $37 million, from $258 million in the corresponding period a year ago. Excluding special items, earnings from operations were not as depressed, falling to $113 million from $224 million. The unit recorded a one-time gain of $74 million from asset sales in the 1990 quarter.
For the year, Mobil earned $1.92 billion, or $4.65 a share, compared with $1.93 billion, or $4.60 a share, in 1990. Revenues fell by 2.8 percent, to $62.68 billion from $64.47 billion.
Mr. Murray said Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., increased its reserves during 1991, adding more oil than it produced. Production rose to record levels in Indonesia, the Beryl field of the North Sea and Nigeria.
Mobil's share price rose by 37.5 cents today, to $67.125, in trading on the Big Board.
 
Chevron
 The Chevron Corporation's net income was $39 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with $633 million, or $1.80 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1990. Revenues fell 24.6 percent, to $10.40 billion from $13.80 billion.
The nation's fourth-largest oil company, Chevron reported last week that it would take a $244 million charge in the quarter, with $185 million allocated to layoffs and operating cutbacks at its refinery in Port Arthur, Tex.
In the United States, earnings from exploration and production fell, to $28 million from $325 million. The figure for the recent quarter was calculated following a charge of $84 million accumulated from losses on asset sales, reserves for environmental costs and unfavorable tax rulings. Profits for international exploration operations fell, to $157 million from $356 million.
The domestic refining unit lost $226 million, including the special charge of $244 million, while the international refining operation earned $150 million, down slightly from $160 million.
For the year, net income for the San Francisco-based company fell 40.3 percent, to $1.29 billion, or $3.69 a share, from $2.16 billion, or $6.10 a share, in 1990. Total revenues declined 4.0 percent, to $40.90 billion from $42.60 billion.
Chevron's share price fell 50 cents today, to $66.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: U.S. Expected to Push Germany to Cut Rates

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
When the Group of Seven finance ministers meet Saturday on Long Island, the United States will continue its campaign to put pressure on Germany to lower interest rates as a way to promote economic growth around the world, American officials say.
With the American economy continuing to languish, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is expected to enlist France and some other industrial countries to call on Germany's central bank to reduce its interest rates. 
 But how successful he will be is unclear. When Germany raised its rates last month, its European allies complained to no avail.
The one-day meeting, which brings together the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada, has been called to discuss the world's economic situation and to confer on economic policies. The meeting is being held at the Garden City Hotel on Long Island because of its convenience to Kennedy Airport, where most of the Group of Seven officials will be arriving, Administration officials said.
 
Germany's Preoccupation
 Britain, France and Italy, which are all suffering from economic weakness, share Washington's concern that Germany's preoccupation with holding down inflation through high rates is braking their hopes for economic recovery.
"The Europeans are very concerned about the German policy mix," a senior Treasury official said.
But German officials said in interviews this week that they would continue with their tough anti-inflation policies, which aim in part to resist the double-digit wage demands of several large German unions. These officials say they hope the Bundesbank may be able to begin lowering the rates before long.
"Some countries will say we don't like the interest rate policy of the Bundesbank," said one official in Germany's Finance Ministry. "But we think it's better to have an economically stable Germany. If we adopt an easier monetary policy, it won't have much short-term effect in other countries and it could produce unfortunate developments for inflation in the longer term."
 
Aid for Ex-Soviet Nations
 The finance ministers are also expected to discuss the economic situation in the former Soviet Union. Following up on the 47-nation meeting in Washington this week on aiding Russia and the other republics, the seven finance ministers are expected to focus on the state of reforms and the details of allowing the republics to become members of the International Monetary Fund.
American officials say they hope that Russia and some of the other republics will be officially invited to join the I.M.F. this spring.
The officials are also expected to discuss exchange rate parities. Several European officials say they see no reason to change the dollar's parity with European currencies. However, as last week's intervention by the Federal Reserve to buy Japanese yen showed, at least some countries thought the yen was too weak against the dollar, especially with Japan's trade surplus with the United States growing.
In addition, the French Finance Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, has called for allowing the yen to float upward against European currencies to help reduce Japan's trade surplus with the European Community.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower Amid Jitters on Conference

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against major foreign currencies in volatile, rumor-driven trading yesterday, with currency dealers jittery about the meeting of the finance ministers of the leading industrial democracies this weekend.
Gold prices fell. At the Republic National Bank of New York, bullion was quoted at $354.50 an ounce as of 4 P.M., off 10 cents from Thursday. At the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fetched $354.40, down 20 cents from Thursday. 
 Hubert Pedroli, manager of corporate foreign exchange at Credit Suisse, said there was no rhyme or reason for the volatile trading during the session.
The dollar fell after a rumor circulated that the Federal Reserve was buying dollars. But traders said they saw no evidence of any central bank intervention.
Mr. Pedroli said intervention was unlikely ahead of the meeting of the Group of Seven nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- in Garden City, L.I.
A large portion of the trading was based on technical factors, with traders taking profits from Thursday's rally and staking out positions in advance of the Group of Seven meeting, Mr. Pedroli said.
Jeff Mondschein, foreign exchange manager for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in Chicago, said traders exhibited anxious anticipation ahead of the Group of Seven meeting.
At such meetings, the finance ministers can strike agreements on valuing their currencies for global economic growth. Such agreements would have a significant impact on the foreign exchange markets.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8070, from $1.7960 late Thursday. In New York, the pound was worth $1.7955, more expensive than Thursday's $1.7850.
The dollar fell to 1.5865 German marks in London, down from 1.5950. In New York, the dollar closed at 1.5950 marks, down from 1.6064 late Thursday.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.34 yen, to a closing 124.57 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 123.45 yen. And in New York, the dollar fetched 123.53 yen, down from 123.80 yen late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, were: 1.4165 Swiss francs, down from 1.4260; 1.16965 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15955; 5.4375 French francs, down from 5.4780, and 1,200.50 Italian lire, down from 1,209.25.

HEADLINE: Where Recession Is an Ocean Away

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Less than four hours at sea, Stephen and Marion Bartlett of Mount Bethel, Pa., were at their usual table in the Queen's Grill on the Queen Elizabeth 2. "I don't care where the ship's going," Mrs. Bartlett said with a laugh, "just as long as it takes me with it."
As it so happens, the QE2 is taking the Bartletts around the world. They and about 250 other people who paid as much as $126,900 (double occupancy) are on board for a 100-day voyage to Honolulu, Bali, Hong Kong and 28 other warm-weather ports. By the time the ship returns to New York on April 14, winter and opening day of the 1992 baseball season will be only memories. 
 At a time when most of the travel industry still feels battered by the recession and fallout from the gulf war last year, the cruise business is one of the few bright spots. Spurred by heavy discounts and heavier advertising, cruise ships had an occupancy rate last year of about 90 percent for their 90,000 berths. Most of those bookings were for cruises of a week or less.
But no discounts are needed to attract world cruise passengers, at least not repeat passengers who have the time, money and inclination. Cunard, the QE2's owner, depends more on word-of-mouth publicity than on marketing.
Company officials estimate that only 20,000 such people in the world are circle-the-globe potential, and 9,000 of them belong to Cunard's World Club, which bestows an array of privileges on frequent travelers.
"Assuming they have the funds," said John Maxtone-Graham, a sea-travel historian, "world cruise passengers need make no other decision than to buy a ticket. Theirs is a moving resort that brings them to every corner of the globe. They enjoy impeccable service and unlimited servants, so nothing is required save their presence."
Of the thousands of cruises that will be offered this year, only five go around the world. It is easy to see why: World cruises tie up a ship for more than 25 percent of the year, making them a huge risk and a tremendous expense for a company. The 67,000-ton QE2, launched in 1967, carries a crew of more than 1,000 and burns 18 tons of fuel an hour, at an average cost of $75 a ton. Panama Canal tolls are $110,000 to $160,000, depending on the number of passengers.
The Sagafjord, a smaller vessel in Cunard's seven-ship fleet, left Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Jan. 6 for a 107-day world cruise. Aboard are 418 passengers who paid $30,340 to $74,490. The other world cruises, all currently under way, are the Canberra (90 days) and the Sea Princess (92 days), both of which belong to P & O Cruises. The other is Costa Cruise Lines' Danae, which left Genoa, Italy, last month on a 101-day cruise.
These days, such long cruises are economically possible only because they are segmented to fill the other berths with passengers who want to sail just 11 days or 2 weeks. That is what the other 3,750 QE2 passengers are doing.
"In the old days passengers could not sail on segments," Mr. Maxtone-Graham said. "They had to take the whole cruise or nothing."
 
Many Repeat the Trip
 But there certainly are people who want the whole cruise. The Bartletts, who have also made more than 30 trans-Atlantic crossings, are on their eighth world cruise aboard the QE2. That is far from a record. Kay Trafford, a soft-spoken widow from Norfolk, England, is on her 17th time around. Several other passengers have circled the globe on the QE2 at least 10 times since 1975. That is when Cunard reinstituted the world cruise, which it originated in 1922.
"But the record for world cruises probably belongs to a widow from Houston who died about a year ago," said Priscilla Hoye, a Cunard vice president. "She had taken 39 world cruises, the last 15 on the QE2."
Like Floyd Ingram, a well-weathered 84-year-old widower from Ogden, Utah, most of the world cruisers are Americans and average over 70 years old. Less than a day into his 15th world cruise, Mr. Ingram said, "I'm already planning to sign up for next year." On this year's cruise, he is looking forward to the ship's first calls at Monte Carlo, Monaco, and Rhodes, Greece.
Those "ancient mariners," as some crew members affectionately refer to the world travelers, are hardly symptomatic of the estimated four million passengers who took $5 billion in cruises last year, according to the Cruise Lines International Association. One-half of all passengers are under 45, the association said, one-half earn no more than $35,000 a year, and the average fare is $185 to $240 a day, double occupancy, including air fare.
 
From $25,935
 The cost per person to go around the world on the QE2 is $25,935 for the lowest of the ship's 22 price categories, to $126,900 for the highest of four luxury categories. Almost 70 passengers are paying 15 percent more to room alone. In addition, two $453,170 apartments and two $407,800 apartments are booked for the entire trip. World-cruise passage includes first-class air fare.
"The economy clearly had an impact this year, because bookings are off about 20 percent," said Ronald A. Santangelo, Cunard's senior vice president of worldwide marketing and sales. "But the top 250 beds are filled, 80 percent of them for the full journey, and the next category is also close to being fully booked."
Founded in England by Samuel Cunard in 1840, the line was acquired in 1968 by Trafalgar House, P.L.C., a multinational conglomerate with headquarters in London. Its properties include seven hotels and resorts, including the Ritz in London and the Hotel Atop the Bellevue in Philadelphia.
For the first time in his 20-year experience, Mr. Santangelo said, the cruise booked "from the top down" -- that is, from the highest-priced berths to the lowest.
One possible explanation, Mr. Santangelo said, is that the low interest rates on savings have taken a toll even on people who normally could have afforded the lower-priced berths.
"There's a financial crisis, no doubt about it," said Nicolas Meliniotis, a chain-smoking resident of Nice, France. An inveterate traveler since his retirement in 1965 as a textile salesman, the spry Mr. Meliniotis, 82, considered staying home this year. But only briefly, because he stayed away last year out of worry about the impending Persian Gulf crisis. There were no QE2 world cruises in 1989 or 1990, because the ship was chartered by the Japanese ports of Yokohama and Osaka.
The QE2, longer than three football fields, also boasts a casino as well as more than a dozen designer boutiques featuring such names as Gucci, Louis Vuitton, Harrods and Dunhill. It has a florist and, for the eight formal balls, a tuxedo rental shop.
 
'A Testament to Survival'
 For repeat passengers "the cruise is less an excursion than a testament to survival," Mr. Maxtone-Graham said. He lectured aboard the QE2 before debarking at St. Thomas, in the Virgin Islands.
Not all world cruise passengers are elderly. Joseph and Eileen Miele of Mendham, N.J., who are on their first world cruise, are 51 and 41, respectively. But the youngest of their three children is 21, and Mr. Miele is confident that his 20 companies (including a law office and real estate development) are in good hands. "We want to see the world while we can still walk," he said.
For the elderly, however, the world cruise offers passengers a chance to spend a lot of time with peers.
For Mrs. Trafford a world cruise is like a family reunion. "I have so many friends here, and I get such a welcome from the crew," she said. "I call them my QE2 family. We write letters and cards at Christmas. And it's much better than staying home in an empty house."
Mrs. Trafford's daughter, Susan Pollok, sailed with her from New York to Los Angeles, and her son and daughter-in-law will board in Singapore and sail to Athens.
 
Favorite Cruise Stories
 Many world cruisers know the crew and the officers. "A lot of them ask about our wives and families," said Colum Sanders, a butler on one of the ship's 13 decks. The convivial Mr. Sanders, a 42-year employee of Cunard, lives in Dublin the three months each year he is not at sea.
Regular passengers also delight in regaling newcomers with stories of life aboard a floating resort hotel.
Some love to tell about the passengers who spend their $100,000 for the cruise and then take every meal in their cabins, never emerging the entire trip.
Other favorites are about marriages that dissolved during world cruises. It seems that even wealthy couples married for years found out they could not bear being confined with each other for 100 days.

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
University Tightens Its Belt, Loses a Head Football Coach

 BODY:
JIM REID, a longtime football coach at the University of Massachusetts, resigned yesterday after being told that budget cuts would curtail athletic scholarships.
"All I am is just one more victim of what has been a disastrous economy statewide and nationally," said the 41-year-old Reid, who had been a coach at the school in Amherst, Mass., for 18 years, the last six as a head coach. 
 RICHARD O'BRIEN, chancellor of the state university with an enrollment of 17,400 students, said that three years of reduced state funding, shrinking revenues from student fees and higher operating costs meant less money for the football program.
Reid said he was told on Thursday by the UMass athletic director, FRANK McINERNEY, that all $80,000 allotted for football scholarships in 1993 would be withheld.
"When you go into people's homes and make promises, they listen to you, they believe you," Reid said. "When you have to come back and take away those promises, there's no alternative. You have to resign."
Reid's teams had an overall record of 37-28-2 and won three Yankee Conference championships, the last in 1990. UMass had a record of 4-7 last season.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Uproar Over Mariners Creates Bad Feeling in Japan

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Government officials and businessmen in Japan reacted with indignation and puzzlement today over reports that American baseball officials were opposed to the offer by a Japanese company to help buy the Seattle Mariners.
Hiroshi Yamauchi, president of the Nintendo Company, which has teamed up with a group of businessmen in Washington State to bid for the Mariners, held a news conference today to explain the offer. He said he might be forced to withdraw the bid if the public reaction was negative. Although the reception in Seattle was favorable, the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, said it was unlikely the bid would be approved. 
 Yamauchi said the company should not be criticized for making a takeover attempt because it was first approached by political leaders in the United States.
"This is entirely different from an acquisition of an American corporation by a Japanese corporation," said Yamauchi.
 
'Simply a Response'
 "It is simply a response to the urgings of the Senator and Governor of Washington," Yamauchi said at a news conference in Kyoto, where his company has its headquarters. "A foundation was established, and upon request, I invested in that foundation."
If accepted and approved by baseball officials, the offer by the family that founded Nintendo would represent the first time that a potential investor outside North America had bought a controlling interest in an American club.
The controversy over the bid for the Mariners was one of a string of episodes in the last week that have emphasized what some say is growing American resentment of Japanese economic strength.
News reports have focused all week on American anger over a comment by a leader of the Japanese parliament that American workers are lazy and illiterate. There has also been considerable publicity over the rejection by Los Angeles of a previously awarded bid by subsidiary of the Sumitomo Corporation for construction of railway cars.
Japanese officials have been careful not to denounce the County of Los Angeles by name, but some warn that the cancellation of the Los Angeles contract could have damaging repercussions for the American drive to get construction contracts in Japan.
"This new Japan bashing is very unfortunate," said a senior economic policymaker, asking not to be identified. "Any backlash in Japan will make it more difficult to make progress in our own government procurement procedures."
He was referring to Japan-United States pacts in recent years permitting American construction companies to bid on dozens of projects, many of them airports and other projects put up by local authorities.
A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, Masamichi Hanabusa, said that the latest efforts to block Japanese activity may be part of a wave of criticism or Japan bashing, but that this was a temporary phenomenon caused in part by the recession.
In defending the Nintendo baseball proposal, Yamauchi said the bid was in keeping with the community-minded spirit of the American subsidiary of the company, which has made considerable money in America.
"This is a kind of social service, not a business activity intended to make a profit," Yamauchi told The Yomiuri newspaper today. He said it was not his intention to change the name of the Mariners or to utilize the Mariners' name in the Nintendo business.
Echoing this view, Hanabusa of the Foreign Ministry said he could not understand why there would be a negative reaction to a possible Nintendo purchase, because it should be seen as part of Japanese efforts to support community activities.

HEADLINE: Just Who Can Raise the Shades and Peek Into Private Matters?

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Louis Brandeis once said that "privacy is the most comprehensive of all rights."
Now the issue of privacy is inspiring new and heated debate. On the one hand, credit bureaus and others who gather personal data about consumers say that they must have it to provide lenders and employers with information they need to do business. On the other are those who say that too much private information about the way people live, spend and save is becoming available to industry and government without the knowledge of the individuals involved. This, they say, infringes people's rights. 
 A group has now been formed to strengthen the right of privacy and develop new ways to do so. The coalition, established in June, is the United States Privacy Council, and its leaders are some of the foremost proponents of privacy in the United States.
Evan Hendricks, publisher of the Privacy Times newsletter, is chairman. The 10-member board also includes Mary Gardner Jones, a former member of the Federal Trade Commission; Eli Noam, a former member of the New York State Public Service Commission, and John Barker, a senior program associate of the National Consumers League.
 
What the Computer Reveals
 "Privacy has exploded into a major consumer issue of the 90's, because how one fares as a consumer increasingly depends on how one looks in the computer," Mr. Hendricks said. "A lot of times people lack the legal ability to control their personal information."
Who has the information? Not only are Federal, state and local governments repositories of an array of facts and figures, but credit bureaus, direct marketing companies, credit card issuers, insurers and other private concerns are big collectors of personal data. And the way this private information is sometimes used for commercial purposes is a continuing concern for privacy experts.
The Privacy Council, which has an office in Washington, has developed broad objectives, many of which would require Federal legislation. Here are some of them:
*Requiring companies to get the individual's consent before transferring personal information electronically.
*Encouraging the development of new technology to protect privacy.
*Analyzing how government record-keeping systems affect privacy.
*Opposing the idea, popular among some law-enforcement agencies, of a national identification card.
On March 17, the group will hold its first seminar in Washington on specific privacy problems and possible solutions. The seminar will precede a three-day conference on broader issues involving computers and privacy, sponsored by organizations that include the Privacy Council.
The Federal Office of Consumer Affairs, a White House agency, has supported a variety of ways to tighten the protection of privacy. They include letting consumers decide whether they want their names and information about them to be given to direct marketing programs, and telling people when and why certain personal information is collected.
Last month, Congress passed the Telephone Consumer Protection Act, which seeks to reduce unwanted telephone and facsimile solicitations. The measure, which has been signed by President Bush, requires the Federal Communications Commission to establish a system for listing people who do not want unsolicited sales calls, especially from dialing machines that play recorded messages.
"We're trying to balance what the business community's interests are with consumer concerns," said Ann Windham Wallace, director of the Consumer Affairs Office. "We feel that we are making progress."
But privacy advocates maintain that there is much more to be done.
"The Government traditionally thinks it has the right to collect arbitrary information about people and make it available to anyone," said John Gilmore, a council board member. "I think privacy is fundamental to having a tolerant society, and tolerance is a way to avoid friction and violence." Mr. Gilmore is also a director of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, which focuses on the interaction of computers and society.
One issue for council members is that private companies often have unrestricted use of information that individuals originally provided voluntarily for a specific purpose. Many consumer advocates say that such use violates an understanding established between two parties when the information was first provided.
"Consumers don't realize that when they sign warranty cards they can give others a detailed profile of themselves," said Ms. Jones, the former trade commission member. "They give people who want to abuse it potentially damaging information." Ms. Jones is now president of the Consumer Interest Research Institute, an organization that specializes in privacy and telecommunications.
Another issue is the growth of technology that makes it easier to collect personal information. For instance, some companies are already issuing "smart cards" that look and act like credit cards and contain a great deal of data about individuals on a tiny memory chip. One example is a plastic medical history card issued by health insurance companies to policyholders, who are required to use it when having prescriptions filled.
"We're particularly worried where a person has a smart card, but doesn't know what information is on the card," said Mr. Barker of the National Consumers League. "It might save you a lot of time and trouble to carry one small plastic card listing your blood type and medications. But you may also be carrying around a lot of derogatory information about yourself on that card that somebody else can read."
 
Privacy Commission Sought
 The council is also trying to foster the establishment of a Government data protection board or privacy commission, similar to those in Great Britain, France and Germany. And the European Community is proposing to standardize privacy laws and to guarantee individual privacy in its member countries, particularly for data on race, religion and health.
"There are problems in maintaining an international free flow of information," said Mr. Noam, who is now a professor of finance and economics at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. "Some countries are extremely protective of data, while others are less so."
The sparkplug of the Privacy Council is Mr. Hendricks, who founded Privacy Times in 1981 and has been trying ever since to raise public interest and awareness on the subject. Consumers, he said, should "demand the right to know what information is being kept on them, the right to correct it when it is wrong and the right to stop it from going to people who have no business seeing it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Weighing perils to privacy, from left: Marc Rotenberg, Evan Hendricks, John Barker and David Banisar of the United States Privacy Council, with Simon Davies, director of Privacy International in Sydney, Australia. (George Tames for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
A New View of History

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
There is a one-liner I first heard in the 9th or 10th grade that has become a metaphor for the reality of loss, gain and fairness in America.
It came after someone had left a seat at the movie, only to return moments later to find that seat had been taken. 
 "This is my seat," he said. "I was here first."
The person sitting down looked up and grunted: "So were the Indians."
For me, that line and this Super Bowl are trenchant reminders of loose ends and business that must be respectfully addressed and finished.
The residue of this nation's unresolved history continues to filter through the vents and ducts of our society, despite feverish efforts to seal them up. Beginning last summer with the Major League Baseball playoffs, and continuing here at Super Bowl XXVI, American Indians have demonstrated against the use of their religious and spiritual symbols as mascots for teams.
There is perhaps no better place than Minneapolis, no better institution than the National Football League, no more fitting event than the Super Bowl to play out the issues of race and territory that are tied up in the protest.
Minneapolis has the United States' eighth largest urban population of American Indians. The N.F.L. has a persistent racial problem that is more spiritual than numeric. The Super Bowl is a grand mirage of excess amid a recession.
Super Bowl week began on Tuesday when Deacon Jones, a Hall of Fame defensive end, fired a shot at the N.F.L. from Calgary, where he said that racism in the N.F.L. forced him to take a job in marketing with the Calgary Stampeders of the Canadian Football League.
Later that day, Bruce Smith of the Buffalo Bills told of hate mail he had received in Buffalo.
On Saturday, members of the American Indian Movement will be at the University of Minnesota to protest the University of Illinois' use of an Indian mascot. On Sunday, A.I.M. and other groups will demonstrate at the Metrodome.
Growing numbers of people wish it would all just go away. Unfortunately, the nation's complex and bitter racial history never percolates far from the surface, and it's virtually impossible to escape. No matter how much the history is revised, expunged, misrepresented or ignored, the truth never entirely disappears. It always seems to be there, waiting to be discovered -- be it at the World Series, the Olympics or here at frosty Super Bowl XXVI.
Obviously, Washington has been a primary target of criticism. Most Indians feel that the organization's nickname is a vulgar, commercial denigration of a proud heritage.
The irony of the Indians' protest is that "Redskins" is the offensive term, but the man after whom the Bills were named played a major role in facilitating the Indians' current predicament.
Bill Cody may have been a great person in the context of American folklore, but in relationship to American Indians, Cody -- like Christopher Columbus -- was no hero.
Buffalo Bill helped find and kill Indians -- along with the buffaloes on which they depended for food, shelter and clothing. He participated in several major campaigns against the Indians, and as a scout for the United States Cavalry, Cody was part of the early "urban removal project" in which land was cleared -- of Indians -- to make room for settlers. While descendants of Africans worked the plantations, Indians were gradually forced onto reservations.
Decades later, the plantation and the reservation motifs represent profound truths about the United States that, it would seem, must be reconciled before we truly become united.
And there's a lot of reconciling to be done.
During a symposium on racism in sports and the news media here this week, Matthew Little, president of the Minneapolis National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called on all professional athletes, especially black ones, to protest the use of emblems and nicknames offensive to American Indians.
That will be a hard sell.
Black athletes in particular sometimes fail to hear the echoes. They fail to see the connection between the way they are viewed by management, the manner in which management trivializes something like the Indian issue, and the failure of even great black athletes to be reabsorbed by the system in significant numbers.
So they retire after how many ever Pro Bowl years of toeing the line, then rush back to the table only to discover that their seats have been taken.
Then they say: "But I was here first."
So were the Indians.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXVI NOTEBOOK;
Gambling Hot Line Awaits Flood of Calls

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Super Bowl XXVI is the jewel in the crown of the National Football League season, but the frenzied interest in the game also produces the single biggest day of betting fever for the nation's compulsive gamblers.
As legal sports books in Nevada prepare to handle at least $45 million to $50 million in Super Bowl wagers, the Compulsive Gamblers Hotline (1-800-332-0402) is planning for the usual onslaught of crisis calls during and after the game. 
 "Last year we had 400 calls in two days, compared with 300 calls in a month," said Dr. Valerie Lorenz, executive director of the National Center for Pathological Gambling in Baltimore, which operates the hot line. Calls usually start coming in during the game, she said, and continue for a few days afterward.
"For a compulsive gambler," she said, "the anxiety level during the game is most stressful to their bodies. They are so stressed out that they have heart palpitations, migraines and skin rashes. When they lose a lot of money, the bookies and guilt come after them."
Lorenz said the Super Bowl comes at a particularly bad time for compulsive gamblers, a month after Christmas, compounding feelings of guilt for losing money and the shame of continuing to hide the gambling addiction from friends and families. The Super Bowl is likely the culmination of a season's worth of losing money, exacerbating the compulsive gambler's illness.
"We expect to get a lot of suicide calls," Lorenz said. "We've gotten people who say they're going to rob a bank to pay their bookies."
Callers are told of options for help. "We let them know we understand their illness," said Lorenz, "and it helps that people like Art Schlichter and Pete Rose had gambling problems."
Meanwhile, in Las Vegas, Nev., the sports books are preparing for the anticipated onslaught of last-minute weekend betting. "People don't get going until Sunday, really," said John Harper of Las Vegas Sports Consultants, an oddsmaker and consultant to 40 sports books in Nevada.
"People make it a holiday to come in over the weekend and make a bet on Sunday," he said Friday. "Seventy-five percent of the action is yet to come."
Until the bets are in, however, Harper said it's too soon to tell whether the country's recession, which has started to affect the Las Vegas resort business, will impact betting, legal and illegal.
Estimates of illegal gambling in all its permutations on the Super Bowl range as high as $3 billion. But Eugene Christiansen, whose consulting firm, Christiansen-Cummings Associates, has studied gambling extensively, says virtually any estimate is dubious.
"We estimated all forms of illegal gambling at $26 billion in 1989," he said, "but we found that the statistical basis, by the National Gambling Commission, had no meaning."
 
Not Counting Chickens . . .
 Coach Marv Levy of the Bills refused to have his picture taken with the Super Bowl trophy today, saying it would be presumptuous to do so.
"Fellows, I'd prefer not to pose with the trophy," Levy said when photographers made their way to the stage after his news conference here today. "I'll be glad to pose with it on Monday if we win. I posed with it last year and they told me that the pictures wouldn't be used if we didn't win, and they were used."
Coach Joe Gibbs of the Redskins had no problem posing with the trophy today.
 
Madden on Instant Replay
 "What do you hear about instant replay?" asks CBS's John Madden. "I hear they may not keep it."
Indeed, National Football League owners may vote out the oft-criticized system for reviewing officials' calls via instant replay. But Madden insists they should improve the system, not junk it.
"They can improve it," he said. "First, make the screens larger. Second, give them clickers to watch the tape, the way coaches look at tape, rather than going back and forth the way they do. Third, get younger guys in there to run it. Old guys aren't used to VCRs. The older you are, the more likely you are to have the '12:00' blinking on your VCR. Young guys are better at things like this. I can't even win the video game I created. My kids beat me and younger kids can beat them."
 
Just Another Assignment
 CBS's Lesley Visser, who has been following the Washington Redskins, will preside over the presentation of the Vince Lombardi Trophy to the winner of Super Bowl XXVI.
Visser's presence in such a role Sunday is believed to be a first for a woman, but she is approaching it as just another assignment. "I'll know what questions to ask," she said, "and I hope it will be entertaining and smooth."
 
'Road to the Super Bowl'
 Call it SabolVision: For 24 hours a day, televisions at major hotels in Minneapolis are playing the grandiose, filmed epics made by NFL Films, of which Steve Sabol is president, producer and chief mythologizer.
"Steve, you're my night light," a friend told him the other day, referring to the round-the-clock onslaught of Sabol's works.
Sabol's films are the type that the peerless Russian director, Sergei Eisenstein, might have made if he had graduated from the battleship Potemkin to the battleground of men and pigskins.
Thunderous music, dramatic camerawork and terse, muscular narration make Sabol's films into stories of courageous men who clash like titans from the University of Mount Olympus each Sunday on fields as contested as St. Lo.
The apex of Sabol's season is his annual "Road to the Super Bowl," which recaps the themes and major stories of the season and how the Buffalo Bills and Washington Redskins made it to Minneapolis. The hourlong film appears at 3 P.M. today on WNBC (Channel 4), and if there's a star of the program, it is the dancing, rapping Atlanta Falcons and their head coach, Jerry Glanville.
Sabol films are easy to spot, with their strong storylines, heavy use of slow-motion, generous helpings of comments from players and coaches wearing microphones, and never, ever, any videotape.
Sabol, who is 49 years old, said, "We deliver the metaphor for the joy of competition, no matter how cynical you are."
Perhaps the most dramatic moment of "Road to the Super Bowl" does not take place on the field, but on the sideline, when Kansas City Chiefs Coach Marty Schottenheimer talked to an upset linebacker, Derrick Thomas, like an exasperated parent to a recalcitrant child. "Look at me, son!" he implored. "Listen to me!"
Said Sabol: "We work six months a year to get coaches to be miked. We have no privileged access. It's a sales job."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Redskins' Coach Joe Gibbs, left, holding the Super Bowl trophy, while Bills' Coach Marv Levy refused to hold it until he wins it. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: P.O.W.'s Questioned by K.G.B. in Vietnam

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was bewildered on reading your Jan. 13 editorial on the continuing question of U.S. servicemen missing in action in Vietnam. At no time in the United States or anywhere else did I say, as you assert, that American prisoners of war were interrogated by K.G.B. agents inside the Soviet Union years after the war was over. The public record shows that all my statements on the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue related to a handful of American servicemen who were interviewed by Soviet intelligence officers in Vietnam, not in the Soviet Union. 
 I first broached this subject many months ago, and cited it simply as a K.G.B. field operation, just another episode in the cold war. All my later statements are based not so much on my own recollections as on conversations with my former subordinate, Col. Oleg Nechiporenko, who elaborated on the circumstances of his two visits to Vietnam.
These conversations took place from September to December 1991 after several journalists and at least two United States officials asked me to clarify certain points.
I must admit I was shocked and chagrined by Colonel Nechiporenko's retraction of his own words, a cowardly act prompted and probably dictated by his former superiors in the intelligence service. But this is yet another story that merits separate consideration.
I fully comprehend the emotional side of the P.O.W. story and sympathize with American families as well as with untold numbers of Vietnamese whose kin fell victim to the war.
For this reason, I suggest we look beyond the inaccuracies and discrepancies, however nagging they may be, and concentrate on the principal issue: Are there United States P.O.W.'s still in Vietnam? Are they kept against their will in concentration camps or solitary confinement?
One may call my statement risky, but I do state unequivocally that I see no reason -- political, military, economic or practical -- why the Vietnamese should keep any United States servicemen in detention. Vietnam is far more interested in normalizing its relations with the United States than in creating additional obstacles to progress in this area.
I do not exclude a possibility that a few former U.S. servicemen, for personal or other reasons, got stuck in Vietnam or neighboring countries, but I'm sure that was their choice rather than due to pressure from local authorities or deliberate policies of the Vietnamese Government.
I hope the joint U.S.-Vietnamese commission now set up to look into the matter and possibly a similar U.S.-Russian commission will produce sufficient evidence to eliminate suspicions and unwarranted accusations from whatever source.
 
OLEG KALUGIN
Washington, Jan. 21, 1992
 
The writer is a former K.G.B. official.
