HEADLINE: Syria's Game

BYLINE: By Judith Miller; Judith Miller is a staff writer for this magazine.

 BODY:
At a school in Damascus on a rainy day in early December, a well-dressed young woman stepped up to the ballot box to vote on whether Hafez al-Assad, Syria's sole ruler for 21 years, should be given an unprecedented fourth seven-year term as President. Smiling broadly, she withdrew a safety pin from her purse, pricked the index finger of her right hand and marked the green circle labeled "Yes" on the ballot in her own blood.
Not all Syrians were as enthusiastic. At the school that day, two hapless voters filled in the black "No" circle instead of the green, the color of Islam. But members of the President's ruling Baath Party overseeing the balloting quickly detected the mistakes. Surely, the officials asked the befuddled pair, they had intended to vote for the President? Yes, indeed, each rapidly agreed. The ballots were promptly discarded and replaced by Syria's version of politically correct votes. 
 To no one's suprise, the Syrian people voted overwhelmingly -- by 99.9 percent, according to Government statistics -- to extend President Assad's rule, with only about 50,000 of the 6.5 million electorate failing to vote, an extraordinarily high turnout.
"Even if Allah had run, he wouldn't have done as well," a Syrian writer said.
Inexplicably, some 360 people were reported to have voted no. According to a diplomat who discussed the results with the Minister of Interior, 334 of them were Syrians living overseas who had voted at their local embassies. And the others? "We're looking for them," the local joke goes.
But to many Syrians, the "bayaa," as the election was called -- an Arabic term referring to the pledge of loyalty Islam's elders gave their prophet Mohammed's successor -- was no joke. Rather, it was bizarre, disturbing and deeply embarrassing.
"Even Romania knew it had to have an alternative candidate on the ballot," sputtered a long-serving Western diplomat who professes to admire the country.
Syrians agree the event was, as the state-controlled press called it, "unprecedented." There were days of rallies and endless tributes to "our father," "our saviour," "our beloved," the "darling of the people;" displays of sword-twirling and folk dancing at night; banners professing unswerving devotion to Assad from all of Syria's unions and professional and trade associations -- "Syria's pharmacists salute the nation's No. 1 pharmacist" proclaimed one -- and hundreds of thousands of posters and photos of Assad in more than a hundred different guises that plastered windows of buses, cars and almost every urban inch of the country.
For days, Syrians speculated: Why had Assad, a man noted for his political cunning, sanctioned such an obvious sham? Why had the man who had destroyed any semblance of unmonitored political opposition and who enjoyed a genuine, if narrow, base of support, felt the need to stage an $80 million show of devotion? Why had he resorted to the discredited tactics of the defunct Kremlin to justify his legitimacy at the same time that he was repositioning his traditionally pro-Soviet state in America's orbit? Why had he authorized an election that borrowed as much from the Marx Brothers as from George Orwell?
Some dismiss the display as standard dictatorial behavior. "You can't judge this in Western terms," a Jordanian analyst says. "It's the only thing leaders like Assad know how to do or risk doing."
But others see it as a message from Assad to the United States, whose influence in the region after the collapse of the Soviet Union and the crushing defeat of Iraq, is paramount: Don't impose your values and institutions on us. Syrians support me because I represent stability and security.
"The election was an insult to us and to you," says Jamal Atassi, a former Cabinet minister and one of the few opposition politicians permitted to criticize the Government openly because of his participation in Assad's takeover in 1970. "It is a way of saying: 'You want democracy? Here it is.' It is a way of portraying Syrians as backward, as a rabble who should appropriately be ruled by a strongman."
If nothing else, the absurd spectacle demonstrated the regime's total control over its citizens' public behavior. "Ten years ago, when the Moslem Brothers were assassinating officials and blowing up buildings, we couldn't have risked turning a million people loose in the streets," one Syrian official observes, referring to the efforts in the early 1980's by Islamic fanatics to topple the Assad regime. In 1982, Assad responded by ordering the massacre of the activists, along with some 10,000 Sunni Moslem civilians, in the city of Hama. Protests have since ceased. "For the referendum, you had a million people in the street and not a stone was thrown," the official says.
But above all, this complex signal to the outside world and to the "masses," as Syrian political rhetoric continues to label its citizens, reflects Assad's determination to adjust his country's policies without fundamentally changing the country itself, to adapt to an American-dictated new world order without relinquishing political control and to hold firm in playing what he believes is Syria's natural role as a power broker in the region.
In a world of crumbling dictatorships and decentralized communications, of faxes and mobile phones that intelligence services find frustrating to monitor, Syria's centralized, autocratic and repressive regime is an anachronism, as antique as its staged election rallies, its frayed telephone lines and the 1950's-vintage DeSotos, Packards and Studebakers that hurtle through the ancient streets and broad modern boulevards of Damascus.
The Soviet Union, its key patron and weapons supplier, is gone. America and its concerns must be placated. As a result, there are fewer arrests or reports of torture. Syrians feel freer to voice their civic anger publicly, so long as they stop short of criticizing Assad directly.
The regime faces another source of pressure: the decrepit economy. Assad has embarked on a program of economic liberalization and privatization to redress the heavy-handed statist policies that crippled his country's Soviet-bloc counterparts. But the economy, a mix of textiles, agriculture and, lately, oil, is still a mess. It depends heavily on smuggling and drug revenue for hard currency and has yet to win the confidence of wealthy investors at home and abroad. Most ominously, its middle class, once the largest and most entrenched in the Arab world, is being pauperized.
These pressures -- from within and without -- have produced what Patrick Seale, a British journalist who has long followed Syria, calls "a quiet revolution" that reflects Assad's mastery of his political environment.
Assad knows that Syria must continue opening up economically, or risk disappearing. Yet, if the change is too fast, too poorly managed or too profound, his regime will also be jeopardized, as the fate of the Eastern European regimes demonstrates. Can Syria open up economically, without opening up politically?
A familiar predicament of aging dictatorships, it is one that Assad has never before had to confront.
NOTHING SEEMS TO infuriate Assad as much as comparisons with Saddam Hussein. Syria and Iraq are ruled ostensibly by rival factions of the Baath Socialist Party, but in reality, by stubborn, often ruthless men who operate, more or less, alone. Both men come from minorities and depend heavily on family and clan ties to survive: Saddam is a Sunni Moslem in a majority Shiite country; Assad is an Alawite, a secretive offshoot of Shiite Islam, which constitutes only 12 percent of Syria's population. Both regimes are secular, vehemently anti-Israeli and outwardly proponents of socialism; both are notorious violators of human rights and anti-terrorism conventions.
Yet at closer glance, the differences are more striking than the similarities.
"Syrians are Levantines, people of the Mediterranean, natural traders by virtue of history and geography," says Mohammed Salman, Syria's Minister of Information. Iraqis, by contrast, are "tough central Asians."
Sadallah Wannus, one of Syria's finest playwrights and critics, agrees. "Saddam Hussein is very stupid," he says. "Hafez Assad's Government is much smarter."
And unlike Iraq, Syria is no longer ruled primarily through acts of terror, but rather by the mere threat of it. After the Hama massacre, the arrests of thousands of prisoners for political dissent and what Middle East Watch, the private, New York-based human rights group, estimates is the killing of at least 10,000 Syrians in the past decade, Syria has largely been subdued. Most troublemakers are in jail or in exile, so the Government no longer needs to be brutal to make its point. "The most deadening censorship is now self-censorship," says Mamduh Udwan, a witty and popular Alawite playwright.
The regime functions thanks to what one Syrian political scientist calls a "merchant-military complex." The Alawite ruling clique, which controls the military and Syria's 15 different intelligence and paramilitary services, needs the country's merchants to survive, this observer explains. "The merchants have risen largely at the expense of the country's traditional elite, the Sunni landowning aristocracy. As long as they avoid politics, the merchants are given considerable latitude."
Whereas Iraqi businessmen before the Persian Gulf crisis were terrified by contact with foreign journalists, most Syrian businessmen are open and hospitable, eager to entertain foreigners in their apartments with lavish buffets of endless trays of excellent food and wine, to talk frankly about their country, even to complain about its economic management, or mismanagement. And unlike the sinister disco culture and artificial night life of Baghdad, Damascus is a genuinely lively capital by Arab standards, with some experimental theater, an occasional film festival, poetry readings, concerts, a celebrated souk (or bazaar) that stays open late and restaurants serving Arabic and Western cuisine that are crowded night and day.
SOMETHING OF AN intellectual life has survived in Syria. Although many of the country's best writers, artists and intellectuals have been driven into exile, some have refused to budge, risking harassment or worse but providing Syrian culture with refreshing pockets of vitality.
Wannus, the playwright, says the Government needs intellectuals like him to demonstrate to Western journalists that there is freedom of expression and democracy in modern Syria. His last play, "The Rape," which contains a sympathetic and hopeful dialogue between the author and an anti-Zionist Israeli psychiatrist, was performed in Cairo and Amman, but not in Damascus. "Do you know that Al Thawra and al-Baath newspapers are barred from even publishing my name?" he says. "Like Israel, I have become an abstraction."
Protest poetry, in particular, retains its traditional popularity here in what the state-controlled press, ever faithful to the empty slogans of Arab unity, calls "the beating heart of Arab nationalism." University students in Aleppo recently packed a hall to hear the poet Ali Kanaan recite "Shards," which appears to attack Assad: "The King is made of glass. His castles are of clay. But back in the henhouse, rights are luxuries. So beware of fleeing the coop, and don't bother spending too much on fodder."
Duraid Lahham, a slapstick comedian and film director who often presents savagely satirical portraits of Arab life and politics, says he avoids censorship by never mentioning venue. "All of my signs, streets and names are fictitious," Lahham says. "You can never tell what country you're in. But invariably, audiences in each Arab country believe my film is about their country."
Lahham has been permitted to work, thanks in large part to the influence of a powerful fan -- President Assad. But even some of Lahham's recent work has not been shown in Syria. In "Cheers for the Nation," the hero, played by Lahham, is interrogated by the security forces for protesting his daughter's death in a letter to Amnesty International. "Why are you laughing and not screaming?" the security agent shouts as he sends an electric shock into the hapless Lahham, who is tied to a crudely wired chair. "Because the electricity has reached my tail before it has come to my village," he replies.
Lahham blames Syria's "demigod bureaucrats" who "outdo each other in poetic obsequiousness" to the leader.
The election is a case in point. Shortly before the voting, Assad appeared on the balcony of his modest villa -- he has never moved into the new lavish, Saudi-financed Presidential Palace atop the sand-colored mountain that dominates Damascus -- to greet his fans and thank them for their support. That night, 23 minutes of Syria's 30-minute evening news program was devoted to the balcony scene, in which Assad uttered not a single word.
Rivaling such looniness were two Government-organized "spontaneous" outpourings of affection and support for the chief staged by Syria's now-tiny Jewish community of 3,800, whose numbers stood at 50,000 in 1900 before mass emigration began. The first was an evening auto rally, which the Syria Times, the only English-language newspaper, described as an occasion for Syria's Jews to drive their "fancy cars" through the streets of Damascus, a not-so-subtle reference to the widely held Syrian belief that the country's Jews are the richest minority.
But the rally was not covered in the Western media, as the Ministry of Information had hoped. When news groups complained that a procession of cars -- at night, in the pouring rain -- was hardly compelling television, a second spontaneous demonstration for Assad was organized -- this time a march -- on foot, in broad daylight -- through the Jewish quarter of the Old City.
Since there were too few Jews for a proper march, other Syrians were added to the procession. For the first time ever, Syrian television broadcast the Jews of Damascus parading through the streets under a banner in Hebrew letters. But when a Jewish merchant whom the Government had ordered to attend the rally was asked what the banner said, he answered that he could not read it: "Most of us speak only Arabic and English."
The banner was eventually translated by one of the many young men there dressed in black leather jackets and white bobby socks, standard attire of the Mukhabarat, one of the main intelligence agencies. It read: "Yes to Assad, Man of Peace."
Jews, even more than other Syrians, are closely monitored. And though they are free to practice their religion, many would emigrate if they could. "I think about three-quarters of the community would leave," a young Jew says. "But I admire Assad; I support him. If it weren't for him, the Moslem Brothers and the Sunni majority would slit our throats."
Almost every human rights report asserts that Jews are unable to travel outside the country as a family, but Syrian officials deny that they are virtual hostages.
"They are citizens like everyone else," Farouk al- Sharaa, Syria's Foreign Minister asserts in an interview. "In fact, they're better off than other Syrians. They don't serve in the military. That is a privilege."
HARAA HAS become a kind of folk hero since he attacked Prime Minister Yitzak Shamir of Israel at the Mideast peace talks last October in Madrid. It was Sharaa who cast aside his prepared text and waved around a photo of a much younger Shamir, whom he called a terrorist on the run from the British mandate government. The display, which befuddled or enraged Westerners, won praise among Arab audiences. The Syrian Foreign Minister articulated a widespread rage about what many Arabs see as an unending stream of American-sanctioned concessions to Israel in the peace process and a reflection of a perceived American double standard in its views of terrorism.
"Syrians desperately want peace," one Western diplomat says. "But intellectuals and businessmen alike don't want to 'surrender' or 'capitulate' to the Israelis. Many see this peace process as fatally skewed in Israel's favor. They don't believe that Israel is willing to trade occupied territory for peace, and they don't believe the United States is going to force it to do so."
In fact, one of the most striking aspects of political rhetoric in Syria is the extensive and growing skeptisism about Assad's participation in the peace talks, as well as lingering disgust with Syria's support for what is called America's "massacre" of the Iraqi people in the Gulf war.
In a new book on Syria, two Middle East scholars, Alasdair Drysdale and Raymond A. Hinnebusch, argue that Assad has long believed that an accord with Israel -- one restoring Syrian sovereignty to the Golan Heights and granting Palestinians some political rights -- would enhance his standing within Syria and the Arab world. But Syria's intellectuals are still steeped in the rejectionist Arab nationalism that their leader had preached until the Gulf war. Their hard-line rhetoric also reflects their country's isolation under the Assad regime.
Indeed, many of the most ardent champions of liberalization and democratization within Syria are also the harshest critics of Syria's participation in the Gulf war and the American-sponsored peace talks. Udwan, the playwright, for instance, was among 60 writers and intellectuals who signed a petition protesting the American bombing of Baghdad. While several signatories were questioned by police for having signed the petition and three freelance writers for Syrian radio were barred from entering the broadcast center, no one was arrested or tortured. "This is a sure sign that things are loosening up," Udwan suggests.
But it may also indicate that Assad, too, is a cliche Arab who shares his people's visceral disdain for contacts with the neighbor and enemy whom 40 years of Syrian propaganda has branded the Zionist entity. Assad may talk of his sincere desire for peace to visiting dignitaries, but the message at home is different. During the Madrid peace conference, for example, Syrian television never showed a single picture of an Israeli delegate. And the Government has continued to jam Jordanian television, only two hours away from the Syrian capital, which provides detailed coverage of Israel and the peace process.
"Syria, a country of wonders!" Wannus says with a sigh. "Three years ago, they arrested people for not being anti-American. Today, they threaten to arrest you for being anti-American."
PARTICIPATION IN THE peace process is just one of many concessions President Assad has made to win Washington's favor. His adroit political maneuvering and dazzling shifts in foreign policy -- among them, his literal and figurative embrace of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, whom he had ostracized for eight years -- reflect a dexterity that Arab and Western diplomats alike have long begrudgingly admired.
"Assad is going to the talks because he has no choice," a friend and admirer says. "But he also thinks that it's safe for him to do so. At best, he stands an outside chance of getting all his territory back and securing political rights for the Palestinians. While he fears that America may try to pressure him into making unacceptable concessions, he has become convinced that Israel will not yield land for peace, and therefore, that there is little danger of an accord."
In the meantime, the friend argues, Assad loses nothing -- indeed, gains a great deal -- by talking to Israel: trade with the West, Arab cash and recognition of his indispensable role in restoring stability in Lebanon and, not incidentally, securing the influence there that he has sought for 16 years. Assad, true to his nationalism, has always considered Lebanon part of "Greater Syria," as indeed it was until the French and British carved up the realm, which also included Jordan and what is today Israel.
He is careful to remain on close terms with revolutionary Iran, which much to the horror of fellow Arabs, he supported throughout the Iran-Iraq war.
And while he waits and plays the American game, new options may appear. If and when Saddam Hussein is overthrown, Syria could well resume contacts with Iraq, a senior Syrian official suggests. In fact, another high-placed Arab official reports, Iraqi and Syrian oil officials have already discussed a possible reopening of the pipeline between them that was closed during the Gulf crisis. Moreover, Assad, in his last meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, threatened to make the exclusion of Iraq from the Middle East peace talks an issue if he felt ill-served by the Americans, Syrian sources say.
According to Mustafa Tlas, Syria's Deputy Prime Minister and long-serving Defense Minister, Assad began repositioning his country long before Moscow informed him in 1989 that it would not -- indeed, could no longer afford to -- provide Syria with weapons that would supposedly guarantee it "strategic parity" with Israel.
The 1980's were tough years for Assad. The Gulf Arabs cut off aid because of his support of Teheran. In 1986, Britain severed ties and trade with Damascus after Syria was implicated in the botched attempt to blow up an Israeli airliner at Heathrow Airport.
Then came a godsend -- the Gulf crisis. Once again, Assad ignored the sympathy so many Syrians harbored for Iraq and sent 20,000 soldiers to Saudi Arabia.
According to Saudi and Syrian accounts, Assad's critical decision to join the American-led coalition was made in less than five minutes. Soon after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Saudi King Fahd sent Prince Bandar bin Sultan to seek Assad's help. "Assad asked only three questions," an Arab official recounts. "Are the Americans serious about stopping the Iraqis? Will they finish the job by going all the way? And do you trust them?"
Syria was richly rewarded for its charter membership in the coalition and for subsequently providing Washington with critical information about planned terrorist attacks on Western targets. Though reports of Gulf Arab gratitude have been exaggerated, Arab officials say that Saudi Arabia alone provided an initial check of $500 million in 1990, most of which was used to buy Scud-C missiles from North Korea and 100 T-72 tanks from Czechoslovakia, and pledged some $500 million in project aid in subsequent years. An additional $2 billion a year in aid was promised as a result of Syria's willingness to participate in an Egyptian-Syrian defense force in the Gulf -- the so-called Damascus accords of March 1991. Though neither the force nor the funds has materialized, other funds might. Damascus has become the foreign nexus of the emerging dissident movement within Iraq, which is bound to be supported by former coalition members.
The growing coziness with Washington has prompted Assad to make other changes to improve Syria's image. For example, he has evicted some of the most infamous terrorists and international pariahs who have long called Damascus home. Chief among them are the terrorist Carlos, who is said to have sought refuge in Baghdad or Sanaa, and the Damascus-based representative of the Japanese Red Army Faction.
But Assad has refused to expel Ahmed Jabril, head of a radical Palestinian group known as the P.F.L.P.-G.C., which the President insists is a resistance group fighting Israel for the liberation of Palestine. In effect, Assad argues that terrorism against Israel and Israeli citizens is legitimate. He has also refused to use his 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon to disarm Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed militants who kidnapped and held most of the American hostages until Syria and, more critically, Iran found it in their interests to have them released. "When Israel withdraws its forces, we'll disarm Hezbollah," Defense Minister Tlas says, "and that's a promise."
Until recently, the United States and Britain suspected the P.F.L.P.-G.C. of playing a leading role in the downing of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. But now spokesmen for both countries have blamed Libya for the disaster. However, L. Paul Bremer 3d, a former ambassador at large for counterterrorism in the Reagan Administration, maintains that the Bush Administration has "clear information" that Iran contracted with the P.F.L.P.-G.C. to blow up United States airlines. Only after its operation was uncovered in Germany did it hand over the Lockerbie mission to the Libyans.
Syria is furious that Washington has not yet removed it from its terrorist list after the exoneration in the Lockerbie affair. "The list prevents us from becoming a major trading center again," says Mohammed Imady, the Minister of Economy, an avid proponent of economic liberalization. But United States officials say that Syria is not likely to be removed from the list anytime soon.
"Where Syria shows willingness to change its behavior, to act in ways consistent with our interests, it's crazy not to encourage it," says a senior Administration official, echoing impulses disquietingly similar to those that molded American policy toward pre-Gulf-crisis Iraq. "Syria is a fact of life in the Mideast. We have to deal with them, but we have no illusions about the Syrians. We're not about to make them B'nai B'rith men of the year."
SYRIA WAS ONCE, and could be again, a very rich country, with an estimated 1.7 billion barrels of oil reserves and, thanks to help from Western oil companies, recent oil exports of almost 300,000 barrels a day. More importantly, Syria has a wealth of human talent, including a million university graduates, with one of the highest proportions in the Mideast.
But it is precisely these people whose sense of enterprise has been smothered by the Government's heavy-handedness, its clumsy "socialism" and what one businessman calls the "mediocre tyranny of bureaucrats." The Government, which between the military and civil service employs about 40 percent of the work force, pays a civil servant an average of less than $75 a month. Second jobs are a necessity.
Since 60 percent of Syria's budget goes to the military, the Government cannot afford to raise wages. So people who once considered themselves bourgeois have become poor because of steady inflation. "Economically, Syria desperately needs peace," one Syrian businessman says. "Everyday life is now so difficult that the average Syrian is preoccupied with survival. Assad no longer needs prisons."
To make ends meet, smuggling and corruption have become widespread, and essential. The prime beneficiaries are Alawites, senior Baath Party officials and generals and their children, the "sons of the revolution" as they are sarcastically known, or the "Abu and sons club," abu meaning father of.
Assad's brother, Jamil, and Jamil's sons are said to be major smugglers in Latakia, an Alawite stronghold in northwest Syria. And Assad's son Basil, head of the presidential guard, also has business interests. In Damascus, the villas of senior military men are readily identifiable by the brand new Mercedes parked in front of them. "I think there are more Mercedes here than in Germany," says one disgruntled Syrian, noting that the Government alone authorizes car imports and that even a 30-year-old car can cost about $25,000, when one can be found.
Resentment of payoffs to military officers is also building. In Madaya, for example, a picture-postcard mountain town near the Lebanese border, shops are full of smuggled goods from Lebanon. But in early September, a local wood smuggler and his brother refused to make their routine payoff of 25,000 Syrian pounds a week, about $600, touching off a shootout in which several Syrian officials were killed. The Syrian military cordoned off the town and went on a rampage through its shops and houses.
Minister Imady says Syria must reform its economy if smuggling is to be eliminated. The Government, which granted 300 private import licenses in 1985, gave out 5,000 last year, mostly for raw materials and manufactured parts, the latter a boon to Western Europe. And private sector exports, chiefly marble, textiles and fruits and vegetables, which account for almost 60 percent of all export revenue, rose from 3.5 billion Syrian pounds in 1987 to 23 billion Syrian pounds in 1990. A key element of the privatization process is the creation of joint-venture companies between the public and the private sectors. So far, 140 have been formed, initially in tourism and more recently in industry and agriculture.
But the Government still monopolizes banking and insurance. While Kuwaiti money is financing the installation of 600,000 new German-made telephone lines, Syrians without political connections wait an average of 14 years and pay about $2,500 for a telephone. Syria's Prime Minister is said to approve the allocation of each and every line.
Some 500,000 Syrians work overseas, and recently thousands more have left for lucrative jobs in the Gulf, where they are replacing Palestinians, considered politically unreliable in the aftermath of the war. The brain drain of Syria's most capable youth is among the country's most daunting problems.
Syrians also complain that the new economic opening has largely been limited to entrenched businessmen, the ruling elite and their sons and daughters. "Assad knows that economic power is political power," one diplomat says. "And he is loath to share it."
Those who hoped that economic liberalization would lead to political relaxation have so far been even more disappointed. In the spring of 1990, some opposition politicians were invited to return and two minor new parties were allowed to operate. The Government also increased independent seats in Parliament, a powerless forum. But most of the political changes have been, as Drysdale and Hinnebusch concluded, "meager and mostly cosmetic."
THE ISSUE OF succession is much on the minds of Syrians. A history of heart trouble has made Assad's health a subject of intense speculation. Many analysts fear that his sudden death any time soon would plunge Syria into a fierce, bloody power struggle among its many ethnic and religious groups.
From the time of independence from France in 1946 until Assad came to power in 1970, Syria experienced more than 15 military coups, or attempted coups. Assad's essential strength, and the core of his support stems from the stability he has provided for so long. Syrians under 20, who make up 60 percent of the country's 12.5 million people, have never known any other ruler. Even Assad's harshest critics fear a resurgence of chaos if he dies soon.
Those who hope for a democratic Syria after Assad often cite Spain's Franco as a model. They hope that their strongman, too, will lay the groundwork for a pluralistic society.
But Assad seems to envision a different future, the clue to which was apparent during the election. For the first time, election banners and the media referred to Assad as "Abu Basil," or father of Basil, his 30-year-old son.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 6; Column 4; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 204 words

HEADLINE: POWER STRUGGLE

 BODY:
Verhovek's fine article on the Quebec power problem doesn't fully portray the New York Power Authority's aggressive efforts to insure a thorough environmental review of the proposed Great Whale project and to reopen our Hydro-Quebec contract to reflect current economic realities.
Largely at my urging, Hydro-Quebec agreed not to begin construction of roads and other ancillary features until the entire project has undergone review -- a major victory for those who feared that such work would make the project itself inevitable. I have personally advised Hydro-Quebec that we will not buy a single kilowatt of its power unless environmental and native peoples' concerns receive full scrutiny under Canadian procedures. To facilitate this process, I negotiated an 11-month extension, through next Nov. 30, in the deadline for a decision on the contract. 
 The extension also will permit review of the contract's economic benefits in light of changes in New York's energy needs, due largely to successful conservation programs by the Power Authority and investor-owned utilities.
 
RICHARD M. FLYNN
Chairman, New York Power Authority
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Down on the Farm;
Million-Dollar Mansions Near Princeton

 BODY:
As Kevin Dey watched the region's economy unravel in the late 1980's he wondered about the timing of his family's decision to turn Dey Farm, its 78-acre homestead near Princeton, N.J., into a new community of mansions on large lots.
But since then five residences have been built at a cost of about $1 million each at Dey Farms Estates, where lot sizes average six acres, and construction is to start in March on a sixth.. All but five of the development parcels there have been sold. 
 "Princeton is a fairly wealthy area," said Mr. Dey, whose family owned the farm for more than 100 years. "But I am surprised that all of the buyers so far are from this general vicinity."
Dey Farm Estates is in West Windsor Township just north of the intersection of Route 571 West and Rabbit Hill Road.
The property was an active potato and grain farm until 1985. Mr. Dey said that local zoning rules would have allowed up to 72 residences, but he decided to limit the number of homes to 13 to maintain the farm's rural quality. Mr. Dey also decided that the minimum size of each home built should be 4,000 square feet.
Michael Macaluso, the architect who has designed the sixth of the new residences, said the plans call for it to have 18,000 square feet of space; 13,000 square feet on the main level and 5,000 square feet below grade. Among the amenities planned are an indoor swimming pool with a retractable skylight, a gymnasium, tennis courts, a workshop and a 3,000-square-foot master bedroom suite.
The asking prices of the five unsold parcels start at about $300,000.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: New York City Growth Symposium;
Planning the Use of Land

 BODY:
You won't be able to attend -- it's already playing to a sellout crowd. But it's worth noting, in part because the issue is so important, and in part because you can catch it on television some weeks hence.
On Thursday, from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., 16 lawyers, city planners, architects and academics, among them such notables as Peter Salins, an urban affairs professor; Michael Kwartler, an architect, and R. Susan Motley, a former City Planning Commission member, will gather at the New York University School of Law to present -- and debate -- papers about land-use plans and rules for New York City. 
 The session is part of a year-long effort by the City Planning Commission that will culminate in December in a comprehensive new zoning and land-use plan.
The symposium will discuss both the history of planning in the city and alternate scenarios. The morning symposium will run through the permutations of New York's zoning law since its passage in 1916. In the afternoon, planners, consultants and academics will offer up ideas on whether to maintain the status quo in zoning rules, or to change them to yield a more efficient city, a more esthetic city or a more equitable city.
Whether those are mutually exclusive goals is likely to make for heated debate.
A tape of the proceedings will be aired on cable television in a few weeks. (Call 720-3277 for details). Also, the Center for Urban Policy Research Press at Rutgers University will offer copies of the papers in a few weeks. (For timing and fees call 908 932-3101).

HEADLINE: Perspectives: The Owners' Outlook;
Sounding the Alarm on Mortgage Loans

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE normally ebullient Bernard H. Mendik seems an unlikely messenger for unpleasant news. "I try to be upbeat," he says. He usually is.
But as the new chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York, Mr. Mendik deems it a duty to deliver woeful news to Washington. This is that owners of investment property are being driven into a corner by the unrealistically harsh standards of banks on mortgage refinancing. He wants a relaxation of rules that he says are obliging banks to judge value on the basis of current rents only, rather than projected rents after building improvements or market gains. 
 The banks' tighter lending policies have led to lower loan-to-value ratios on mortgages, which is particularly tough in a slow market when properties must compete for tenants with costly space improvements. Even well-leased properties may have trouble meeting the new terms of mortgage refinancing. In part the new practices reflect lenders' own decision to lighten their real-estate portfolios.
"That's the difference between today and 1974 and '75," Mr. Mendik said. The market recession was more severe then, but banks were helpful. "We could borrow money, and the banks preserved equity," he said. "We never lost buildings." In the end, the market rose.
In fact, it surged. That brought a new assessment system, designed to let New York City benefit sooner from the gain. In the current downturn, valuations have receded more slowly, and current tax bills reflect the prices of four and five years ago. That adds to the problems. Average property taxes on midtown office buildings are the highest in the country at $10 a square foot, according to a survey by Julien J. Studley, the brokerage firm.
There are problems on the development side too, Mr. Mendik said. Over time, he said, the city will lose major tenants if it cannot accommodate them at competitive rents in new buildings. He believes that means continuing the short-term tax incentives that help make this possible. But the city appears prepared to discontinue them in key Manhattan locations. "I think it's very shortsighted," Mr. Mendik said.
SO with all this, how does he stay upbeat? It may come from living through cycles past. It may also come from the recollection of successes past. There have been disappointments, too -- a $10 million out-of-pocket loss by himself and close associates on the MacArthur Foundation properties, the 6,250 Manhattan apartments, including Lincoln Towers, that he bought with Equitable Life and Martin J. Raynes for $500 million in 1985. The combination of tax law changes and market collapse was fatal.
Mr. Mendik is the 63-year-old chairman of the Mendik Company, the owner of 12.1 million square feet of investment real estate, most of it in Manhattan office buildings and some in Connecticut, Westchester and Long Island. He was born in Scotland. His parents emigrated to the southeast Bronx in 1930. His father was a handyman in Manhattan apartment houses. The son found his way to Bronx High School of Science, City College, and, at night, to New York Law School. Three years ago he became chairman of the law school's board of directors.
At law school he met and eventually married Annette Silverstein, who died in 1981. Her father, Harry G. Silverstein, was a real estate broker who later established a syndication firm, Harry G. Silverstein & Sons. The sons were Larry A. Silverstein and Mr. Mendik. They purchased mainly Manhattan loft buildings, acting as general partners in private syndications with anywhere from 25 to 60 investors. Harry Silverstein died in 1966.
As partners Larry Silverstein and Mr. Mendik continued to acquire properties until recession reined them in in 1972. Five years later the partnership broke up. One reason was that Mr. Silverstein was interested in development, Mr. Mendik said. He himself had no patience for it. "It's a long tedious process and it's at least three to five years before you see any fruits of the tremendous risks," he said.
The two men established separate partnerships for the syndicated properties, each one operating about half as managing partner and maintaining investment interests in each other's buildings. Each separately continued to buy properties.
The 12.1 million square feet acquired by Mr. Mendik include 2 Penn Plaza, a 1.7-million-square-foot office building purchased from Gulf & Western; 330 Madison Avenue, an 800,000-square-foot building between 42d and 43d Streets; 909 Third Avenue, the 1.2-million-square-foot building at 54th Street, and eventually the MacArthur properties. Sometimes wealthy partners have participated, but at other times, as in the MacArthur purchase, all the equity came from Mr. Mendik with close associates within the company.
In all the time since 1957, Mr. Mendik says, he has experienced only one great upcycle in commercial real estate in New York City. It lasted three years -- from 1979 through 1981. "It was extraordinary," he said.
At 330 Madison Avenue, where he now has his office, rents went from $13.50 a square foot to $35 a square foot in that period. Mr. Mendik had bought it for $35 million in cash -- or $45 a square foot -- in July 1979. There had been so little new construction in the 70's that even the national recession that began after 1981 barely had an impact on New York City real estate. The higher rents held firm.
The formula worked again at 11 Penn Plaza, the former Equitable Life headquarters at Seventh Avenue and 32d Street. It was purchased for $40 million in cash when rents were averaging $7.50 a square foot. The building was improved, new space was leased out at $25 a square foot and three years later a $60 million mortgage was placed on the property. The partners got their cash back, and a continuing income.
NOT so on the MacArthur properties. Mr. Mendik and his close associates had a 25 percent equity position in the purchase of the 6,250 apartments, 3,850 of them at Lincoln Towers. The majority partner, Equitable Life, with a 50 percent interest, also was responsible for guaranteeing 90 percent of the financing from a consortium of banks.
"We were buying apartments with a 1 to 2 percent yield for co-opping," Mr. Mendik said. The partnership had paid $80 a square foot for the real estate, and sold 55 percent of the apartments to insiders on the first round, averting costly litigation with tenants.
The objective was to sell the unsold renter-occupied apartments to investors. But the tax law change made syndications of renter-occupied apartments impossible. And in 1989 many people turned against co-op buying in mixed-occupancy buildings, making vacancy sales difficult.
When Equitable decided to pay up its own $40 million guarantee to reduce the bank indebtedness, Mr. Mendik followed suit. Later Martin J. Raynes' interest was converted to that of a limited partner.
"I still think it was the best deal I ever made," Mr. Mendik says.
Now he is back to buying for all cash. He did it last year, paying $108 million for the Mutual Life Insurance of New York building at 1740 Broadway, at 56th Street. Ninety percent of the cash came from an individual overseas investment client of the United Bank of Switzerland and the rest from the Mendik Company.
"The building has good leases running for 7 to 12 years at modest rents. We'll ride out the recession and get the upside. If I'm wrong, at least there's no mortgage. It's hard to get hurt."
But in the credit crunch, it is easy to get hurt. Tight credit leads to foreclosures or workouts, a weakening ability to compete for tenants, and ultimately a weakening of the tax base.
UNDER current rules, Mr. Mendik says, "banks are being forced to write down real estate to liquidation values." Even with changes on that front, he says, owners will have to look to new sources of capital. Pension funds are considered a possibility.
Beyond all this, the Real Estate Board under Mr. Mendik hopes to work harder at rallying community organizations to a concerted effort in behalf of a "safe, clean and functioning" central business district.
Among other things this means a stronger effort to reduce sidewalk peddling, he said. And the pathways between the airports and central Manhattan should be made more attractive, he said, so that tourists get a good impression of the city on first arrival.
"Atlanta did it, and Chicago is trying," he said. "So why not New York?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bernard H. Mendik, new chairman of Real Estate Board of New York, in lobby of 1740 Broadway, which he purchased last year. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

HUNGARIAN ENSEMBLE
 The Philharmonia Hungarica conducted by Sir Yehudi Menuhin will make a swing through the state this week, performing in New Haven, New London and Storrs. 
 The first appearance will be on Tuesday in Woolsey Hall on the Yale campus in New Haven. Haydn's Symphony No. 8, the Mozart Concerto in E Flat for Two Pianos, and Dvorak's Symphony No. 8 are on the program, with Ralph Markham and Kenneth Broadway at the keyboards in the Mozart work. The concert begins at 8 P.M. and tickets, priced from $17 to $37, may be reserved by calling 776-1444. Student rush tickets will be on sale at the box office for $7, one half-hour before curtain time.
The program will be presented for a second time Friday at 8 P.M. in Palmer Auditorium at Connecticut College, New London. Tickets are $13 to $23, student prices are $7 to $18. The box office number is 447-7610.
Jorgensen Auditorium at UConn in Storrs is the third venue. Tickets cost $4 to $20 and the curtain goes up at 8 P.M. Call 486-4226 for reservations.
 
JOYCEAN PARTY
 For 10 years Paperback Alley, a bookstore in South Windsor, has unfailing celebrated the birthday of James Joyce. This year's do will take place Saturday and next Sunday in the bookshop at 984 Sullivan Avenue (Route 194).
At 11 A.M. on both days the film "Ulysses" will be shown, followed at 1:15 P.M. by "A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man," and a screening of "Joyce's Women" at 3 P.M.
Dr. Richard Bonaccorso, a specialist in modern Irish literature at Central Connecticut State College, will deliver a lecture about the two central characters of "Ulysses," "Dedalus and Bloom: Getting to Know Them," at 7:30 P.M. on Saturday.
At 6:30 P.M. on Sunday Milton Moore will discuss "Saturn's Choice," an astrological study of Joyce, attempting to explain his life in zodiacal terms. Copies of the horoscope will be distributed to the audience.
Throughout next Sunday, which is Joyce's birth date, recordings of the writer singing and reading from his works will be played, and soda bread and Irish tea will be served. After each evening program a cake on which the first page of "Ulysses" is reproduced in icing will be shared by the audience.
Lila and Marshall Cohen, proprietors of the bookstore, will be on hand all weekend to welcome visitors and talk about their muse. Everything is free, but reservations for the evening lectures are advisable. Call 644-9979.
 
WILD BIRDING SPOTS
 A preview of a nature film featuring Roger Tory Peterson may be seen Tuesday at 7:30 at the Connecticut Light and Power Building on New Road in Madison. The film, made by Michael Male and Judy Fieth, will be shown on the PBS "Nature" series on Feb. 16.
In "A Celebration of Birds" the 83-year-old naturalist travels from one end of the Eastern seaboard to the other, visiting his favorite wild birding spots. Mangrove swamps and heron rookeries in Florida, shorebirds on Delaware Bay, ospreys, least terns and piping plover near Mr. Peterson's Connecticut home, and puffins on a remote Maine island are among the areas he explores for the camera.
His "Field Guide to the Birds," first published in 1934, has played a substantial part in awakening Americans to the endangerment of its birds and other wildlife. The film includes segments about people who have been inspired by his message, including a group out birdwatching in the wee hours in Central Park.
Admission is free. For more information call 245-9056.
 
BATTLE OF WILLS
 "Crazy Horse and Three Stars" by David Wiltse, the new workshop production at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, describes a battle of wills between Crazy Horse, leader of the Lakota nation, and three-star Gen. George Crook during the Indian wars of the 19th century. On a collision course, the two leaders were driven by the needs of their people -- to maintain freedom and dignity for American Indians on one hand, and to acquire land and economic opportunies for a growing nation of immigrants on the other.
Mr. Wiltse is no stranger to Long Wharf. His plays "Grand Romance," "A Dance Lesson" and "Temporary Help" were presented there from 1985 through 1990. In New York he received the Drama Desk award for "Suggs," and "Doubles" ran on Broadway for eight months.
The workshop series is a laboratory for developing new works by established playwrights and by newcomers to the field. Presented with a minimum of sets, costumes and lighting, the series focuses on the plays themselves, soliciting written comments from the audience after each performance.
Curtain times are 8:15 Tuesday through Saturday, Sunday at 2:15 and 7:15, and Saturday matinees at 4:15. The play will run through March 3. For tickets, priced at $27 and $32 call 787-4282.
 
ANTIQUE MIRRORS
 Antique framed mirrors go on display at the Yale Art Gallery in New Haven Saturday through March 22. Many examples, from 1775 through 1850, in an exhibition titled "Looking Glasses in America," will be out of storage and on view for the first time. The majority were imported from Europe and England.
Prized for their elegance and fragility, they were stylish and highly ornamented status symbols. The more elaborate they were, the more they attested to the wealth of the owner.
Some 50 pieces are in the exhibition, displayed in period settings among antique prints and furniture. Two sections show how the looking glasses were carved and gilded, and how genuine antique mirrors may be distinguished from reproductions and fakes.
A symposium on vintage American mirrors will be held on Feb. 29 from 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. in the art gallery lecture hall. Speakers will include Geoffrey Beard, chairman of the Furniture History Society in England; Elisabeth Donaghy Garrett, director of Sotheby's educational studies in New York, and Brian B. Considine, conservator of decorative arts for the J. Paul Getty Museum in California.
Admission will be $25, or $15 for students. For reservations or more information call 432-0615.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Eligibility for Housing
 
Question: My sister and I have applied for an apartment in the Penn South co-op in Manhattan. Our first choice was for a two-bedroom apartment. But we were told that we would have a better chance if we accepted a one-bedroom apartment and switched to a two-bedroom apartment once we had moved in. 
 When I inquired last about the availability of apartments I was told that we would not qualify for a two- bedroom apartment because of city housing rules. Can this be true? . . . Catherine Gordon, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. A spokesman for the management office said that some policies have changed because of the demand for apartments in the complex. Now two-bedroom apartments, for which there is a 12- to 14-year wait, are reserved for families of three or more.
According to Roz Post, a spokesman for the Department of Housing, Preservation and Development, when Penn South, which is a limited equity co-op, decided not to become private a few years ago, the corporation accepted more stringent rules imposed by the city in exchange for continued tax benefits.
You and your sister are still eligible for a one-bedroom apartment in the complex.
 
Harassed Tenant
 
Question: I am unemployed and two months behind in my rent. Understandably, my landlady is concerned about my ability to pay. But recently she has begun to bother me by coming into my apartment without my permission. She uses her own keys and has even used a hammer to disengage the chain. Once when the check I wrote for the rent was returned, she had her son unlock my door.
I understand that she is within her rights to file for an eviction, but in the meantime do I have to endure her tactics to try to scare me out of the apartment? . . . Cindy Wardell, Manhattan.
 
Answer: No. Tenants do not loose their statutory right to privacy when they fall behind in rent.
"The only legal reason," said Bruce D. Friedberg, a Manhattan real estate attorney, "for a landlord to enter a tenant's apartment without permission would be to address an emergency. The bullying tactics are against the law."
Mr. Friedberg said that Section 235 of the New York State Real Property Law prohibits the use of violence, the threat of violence or tactics like removing a tenant's belongings or lockouts, as a means of eviction. An eviction must be through a Housing Court order.
State law also says that landlords who use illegal methods to force tenants to move can be open to criminal and civil charges. Mr. Friedberg said that you might have grounds for a trespassing or harassment claim against your landlord. Tenants forced from their apartments unlawfully may collect treble damages.
If your landlord comes into your apartment again or unlocks the door, you should call the police.
 
A Leak in the Ceiling
 
Question: I live in a co-op and for several months an interior leak has caused stains and bubbles in the paint on the ceiling and walls of the entry. I have been in touch with the management agent and board since last May but there has been no response to the complaint. Should I withhold maintenance and place it in an escrow account until the problem it is corrected? . . . Scott Rubin, Manhattan
 
Answer: Probably not. Withholding maintenance is risky in all but the most serious circumstances. In all probability, it is a violation of your co-op's proprietary lease and could result in eviction from your apartment.
David L. Smith, a Manhattan attorney specializing in real estate, said that if you do establish the maintenance escrow fund you should leave it with your attorney after giving written notice -- through certified or registered mail -- to the co-op's board.
As an alternative, he suggested an action in Small Claims Court."The cost would be low," said Mr. Smith, "It would get the board's attention because it would be forced to hire an attorney. And there would be no risk of default on the lease."

LENGTH: 2016 words

HEADLINE: Vision of Rail and Office Complex Moves Nearer to Reality

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
STANDING at the window of his fifth-floor office in Rutherford, William E. McCann looks out over an expanse of rooftops and meadow grass to a spot nearly four miles away in Secaucus. There, amid a jumble of railroad tracks and swaying cattails, he imagines a gleaming oasis of glass and steel rising above the marshlands.
In his mind's eye, Mr. McCann sees five office towers set atop a sprawling train station that would serve nearly 70,000 commuters a day and create thousands of new jobs for New Jersey residents. 
 For the last six years Mr. McCann has watched his dream take shape -- not in the Meadowlands in Secaucus but in the plans, charts and architectural renderings that line his office walls. Last month that dream came one step closer to reality with the passage of a Federal appropriations act that provides billions of dollars of transportation aid for New Jersey.
"This gives us the opportunity to take New Jersey out of the shadows of New York and create our own skyline," said Mr. McCann, who is president of the Rutherford-based Allied Junction Corporation. The company is the developer of the proposed train station and office complex, called Allied Junction.
Despite the good financial news, Allied Junction officials must still obtain a construction permit from the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission -- a permit that may be contingent upon the construction of a new turnpike interchange that turnpike officials say is unlikely to occur in the near future.
The Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, which was led through Congress by Representative Robert A. Roe, Democrat of Wayne, will provide New Jersey with as much as $5.6 billion in Federal highway and mass transit funds over the next six years.
Among the many projects that will benefit from the infusion of Federal dollars, officials say, are a light rail line along the riverfront in Hudson County and two railroad track modifications -- one in Secaucus and the other in Kearny -- that are the linchpins of the Allied Junction project.
The waterfront plan and Allied Junction are two of the last remaining elements of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean's much-publicized "circle of mobility." The circle of mobility, a public-private venture that was proposed by Mr. Kean in 1989, was intended to improve mass transit within the Meadowlands and waterfront areas, while increasing the efficiency of commuter traffic to New York.
The concept included plans for a monorail that would connect the Meadowlands with the waterfront and the rehabilitation of some long-abandoned railroad rights of way as an east-west commuter highway.
"The circle of mobility contained several extraordinary transportation benefits," said the Hudson County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski. "Its goal was to provide a mass transit alternative that would separate New York City-bound traffic from waterfront-bound traffic."
Though many of the original elements of the circle of mobility are no longer under consideration, Mr. Janiszewski said, the waterfront transportation plan and the Allied Junction project, which are both being actively developed, could accomplish much of what the original plan intended.
The waterfront transportation plan, he said, would provide public transportation for residents and visitors who wanted to commute to the waterfront itself rather than New York, while the Allied Junction and Kearny rail connections would make it possible for New York City-bound commuters to travel directly into Manhattan without having to switch at Hoboken.
Mr. Janiszewski said that though the waterfront plan and the rail connection plans were being actively pursued, no one was sure where the money would come from when the plans were finalized. Passage of the transportation act, which provides the state with billions of dollars in mass transit aid, however, removed much of that doubt.
"All the elements are now coming into place," Mr. Janiszewski said.
Martin E. Robins, the director of waterfront transportation for N.J. Transit, said the plan that officials would present to the public was a blend of eight alternatives that had been studied over the years. "We expect to be in public hearings by June," he said.
Mr. Robins said the current waterfront transportation plan consisted of a light rail line that would go from Route 440 in Jersey City east toward the waterfront. From there it would travel up the waterfront to Weehawken and then west, through an existing tunnel in the Palisades. The rail line would then go north to the New Jersey Turnpike's Vince Lombardi Service Area park-and-ride lot in Ridgefield, where Manhattan-bound commuters can make connections to public transportation.
The plan also calls for a bus route that would go through the Weehawken tunnel through the Palisades.
"It's about a 15-mile system," Mr. Robins said, adding that the total project would cost about $550 million. "We think our project is looking more and more positive all the time. We are heartened by the fact that New Jersey is expected to receive $6 billion, and we are going to be competing for some of that money."
For Mr. McCann at Allied Junction, the transportation act has also made it possible for him to move ahead with plans to build an office complex, hotel and train station, totaling 4.7 million square feet, on property it owns in the Meadowlands.
The Allied Junction Corporation, a company formed by Allied Outdoor Advertising Inc. in South Hackensack, owns a 28-acre parcel of land in Secaucus through which nearly every major passenger rail line in New Jersey passes. Converging on Allied's property are all the N.J. Transit northern New Jersey commuter lines that eventually terminate at the Hoboken train station or Pennsylvania Station in New York.
Also passing through the property is Amtrak's Washington-to-Boston "northeast corridor," one of the busiest rail lines in the country.
For years officials have been contemplating a more complete connection between the N.J. Transit system and the Amtrak northeast corridor line. Such a connection would make it possible for commuters to change trains there and head directly into Penn Station in New York rather than have to take PATH trains into Manhattan from Hoboken.
 
Cost of Nearly $1 Billion
 Seeking to take advantage of what they regarded as an ideal location in the Allied Junction site, company officials drew up an elaborate development plan for the site, including a 200,000-square-foot train station, a 600-room hotel and conference center, 100,000 square feet of retail space and about 3 million square feet of office space. There would be a 40-story central office tower, Mr. McCann said, and the project would cost the company nearly $1 billion.
The company could not proceed with the development, however, until the Amtrak northeast corridor was increased to four tracks. "You can't stop a train on the northeast corridor today because it's only two tracks," Mr. McCann said.
The transportation act, however, has designated about $400 million for the installation of two additional tracks on the northeast corridor where it passes the Allied Junction site. "We'll be able to take trains off the northeast corridor, bring them into Allied Junction and then put them back onto the track," Mr. McCann said.
As a result, he said, passengers could switch from any N.J. Transit train to any other N.J. Transit train, including those running into New York's Penn Station.
 
4-Lane Road Extension
 In addition, he said, Allied has agreed to build a connection between N.J. Transit's Bergen County/Pascack Valley Lines and the Main Line, which would then continue into Allied Junction, and use the resulting abandoned rail bed to create a four-lane extension of a local roadway.
"We're putting in in excess of $100 million," Mr. McCann said, referring to money that the company has agreed to spend on infrastructure improvements and construction of the train station.
When the connection between the northeast corridor and the N.J. Transit system becomes operational, Mr. McCann said, "it will be a six-minute train ride to Manhattan." He added, "It's going to remove over 10,000 automobiles and 500 buses from the tunnels."
Amtrak officials say they have been working with Allied Junction in developing plans for train movement in the proposed station. "We have made it clear from the beginning that we have no opposition to the project as long as it in no way impedes intercity train traffic on the northeast corridor," said Clifford Black, Amtrak's director of public affairs.
Mr. Black said that though Amtrak currently had no plans to stop its trains at Allied Junction, "it's not out of the realm of possibility."
In a recent interview, Mr. Roe, who is chairman of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, called the Allied Junction project "extraordinarily important not only for New Jersey, but for the entire East Coast."
Mr. McCann said that when the planned development was complete, it would serve 70,000 commuters each day and create as many as 15,000 new jobs. He said that the project could be completed within five years and that he was already negotiating with prospective tenants.
"I look at this project, and unless I have rose-colored glasses on, I think it's the greatest thing that could happen to this state," he said.
 
Facing a Major Hurdle
 There is, however, one major hurdle that Allied Junction must overcome before it can start construction. Though the company has already obtained nearly all the approvals it needs for the project, it has not yet received final approval from the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission.
Bob Grant, a spokesman for the commission, said such approval would most likely be contingent upon the New Jersey Turnpike Authority's agreeing to build a new interchange adjacent to Allied Junction.
"The staff is very strongly predisposed to having the turnpike interchange in place; otherwise the local traffic problem will be difficult," Mr. Grant said. "The commission anticipates that there will be a requirement to have a letter of agreement from the Turnpike Authority for an interchange."
The Turnpike Authority, however, has no immediate plans to build such an interchange. Gordon Hector, a spokesman for the authority, said that while an interchange proposal was in the turnpike's capital budget for the 1990's, the money that has been allocated was only to study the proposal.
"No construction funds have been made available as yet," Mr. Hector said. "And there wouldn't be any construction on such a project until at least after 1995."
 
More Accommodation Urged
 Some supporters of the Allied Junction project say the Turnpike Authority should be more accommodating to the developer. "This is as bold a risk as a developer can take," said Richard Fritzky, president of the Meadowlands Regional Chamber of Commerce, alluding to Allied's willingness to start construction on a major development in the midst of a recession. "The bottom line is that you have a private developer working to make something happen that is in the public interest of the state of New Jersey."
"We need that transfer station, but the transfer station won't work unless there's development on top of it," he said. "Allied Junction needs the government to cooperate with them big time on this."
Richard T. Roberts, chief of transportation policy and planning for the interstate transportation department of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, agreed that work on the rail component of the Secaucus transfer should be accompanied by development at the site.
"It makes every bit of sense when you have a major transit hub like this to put economic development around it," Mr. Roberts said. "People will take transit to places where transit is."
"It's always been my belief that to build a transfer station out there without putting in other development is not a wise move because you'd end up with a station out in the middle of no man's land," he said. "And that is no man's land."

HEADLINE: Labor Raises Its Voice On L.I. Sound

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE environmentalists inside the Stouffer Westchester Hotel last weekend called their gathering a citizens summit to clean up Long Island Sound. The construction workers marching outside called it a conference to ban all building projects along the Sound.
Carrying signs like "Labor Votes. Crabs Don't," about 1,500 steamfitters, carpenters, plumbers and electricians demonstrated for two hours in cold winds. A balloon floating 40 feet overhead capsulized their message: "A Sound Economy Needs Jobs, Not Sewer Bans." 
 The building industry in Westchester, where the unemployment rate is estimated to be as high as 50 percent, is fearful that efforts being considered for protecting the Sound's water quality will destroy what little opportunity still exists for construction work in the shore communities. But there are also suggestions that the need to build new and upgraded sewage plants could form the basis of an alliance between labor and environmentalists.
Earlier this month the State Department of Environmental Conservation banned expansion of the four sewer districts in Westchester that empty into the Sound and also stopped plans by the county to expand a sewer district in North Castle. But that moratorium halting new development was lifted on Jan. 17 when county officials submitted an alternative plan to limit pollution in the Sound. The county's plan will limit fertilizers used on golf courses, construct new wetlands and curtail boat discharges. It comes in response to a call by Federal and state agencies sponsoring the Long Island Sound Study, a six-year partnership of Federal, state and local agencies to identify the most pressing environmental threats to the Sound and to produce a Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan to guide solutions.
Excess amounts of nitrogen, one of the elements released in the treatment of human waste, in agricultural and lawn-fertilizer runoff and by natural causes, including plant decay and acid rain, is believed to be responsible for reduced oxygen levels in the Sound. That, in turn, has caused large numbers of fish and shellfish to suffocate.
 
Back to 1990 Levels
 Last fall, sponsors of the Long Island Sound Study, whose final report is to be released this November, became so concerned about pollution that they ordered a no-net nitrogen-increase as an interim solution. Officials in Connecticut and New York are developing legal mechanisms to enforce that order to limit the flow to 1990 levels.
"No one wants a building moratorium, including us," said Cesare J. Manfredi, the water-pollution control engineer for the state's Department of Environmental Conservation and the official who had imposed the temporary ban. "We do want to insure there is no net increase in nitrogen flow."
To accomplish this goal, tradeoffs are necessary, he said.
"It's fine to allow new construction, which will increase sewage," he said, "but you have to decide where the reductions will come from."
Although in December Westchester County had authorized the expansion of the Blind Brook Sewer District to North Castle, Mr. Manfredi said, "You can't just build a new district or expand old ones without a plan to reduce nitrogen flows elsewhere."
It was because of pressure from his department, he said, that the county's interim plan was quickly put into place. A committee of municipal officials has been looking into ideas for controlling pollution in the Sound.
 
A Meeting This Week
 On Wednesday, Mr. Manfredi said, his agency will meet with representatives of the county's Department of Environmental Facilities to discuss an impending $150,000 to $250,000 Federal grant that will enable the monitoring of major tributaries that feed into Long Island Sound from the county. Data from this survey will help the state agency conduct periodic followup surveys of nitrogen levels.
Although restricting nitrogen flows to the Sound through tradeoffs could allow development to continue, the relationships are complex. At least one county sewer district, the one centered in Blind Brook, is seeking Federal aid to help it modernize and reduce the amount of nitrogen the plant releases into the Sound. Reduced volumes from this plant could provide a "bank" of permitted nitrogen flow and allow new construction in areas served by plants discharging into the Sound from Mamaroneck, New Rochelle and Port Chester.
Rye city officials who supervise the use of the Blind Brook plant are reluctant to discuss sharing the benefits of reduced nitrogen flow with their neighbors until the financial implications are cleared up. "We have no assurances that we will get Federal money to upgrade the plant," said Warren R. Ross, the Mayor of Rye. "Without that money, our sewer district taxpayers must pay the cost, and if so, they should be the ones to benefit."
There are critics who charge that the environmentalists' support of nitrogen restrictions is a smokescreen to prevent development on lands bordering the waterway.
 
'There's a Conflict Here'
 "There's a conflict here," said Gerald Lloyd, one of a handful of construction-industry supporters who attended the Jan. 18 environmental conference here, which was sponsored by the Long Island Sound Watershed Alliance, a 150-member coalition of environmental and civic groups.
"That's why those guys are out there," Mr. Lloyd, who represented the Westchester Chamber of Commerce, told the 150 conference participants. "They don't trust you any more."
Calling the Sound "an economic as well as an environmental resource," Robert Bendick, deputy commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation and a conference speaker, defended his department's limit on nitrogen increases "as a way to get everybody to the table."
Resolving the issue, he said, will require a partnership with the Federal Government. Helping sewage-treatment plants upgrade their operations and reduce nitrogen flow into the Sound will require as much as $6 billion for the region, including Long Island and Connecticut, Commissioner Bendick said.
"That's lots of money and lots of construction work," he said, explaining why he believes "a very strong coalition between environmentalists and industry can be developed here."
David J. Miller, chairman of the Watershed Alliance, agreed. "Labor and environmentalists are not on opposite sides of the spectrum of Long Island Sound issues," he said, adding that the workers' demonstration provided "a great window of opportunity" for the two groups to begin working together.
 
A Link to Labor Perceived
 The alliance was formed a year ago after the National Audubon Society's Listen to the Sound Citizens Hearings Campaign, a series of 15 public forums that offered people living in the Sound area an opportunity to discuss their concerns and make recommendations for the future of the Sound.
Pointing to "the link between labor's call for jobs and development and our call for sewage-treatment plant upgrading and growth management," Mr. Miller, who is also regional vice president of the National Audubon Society, said both groups support Federal financing to upgrade sewage-treatment plants.
Without Federal aid "both jobs and the Sound will be losers," Mr. Miller said.
He will meet with construction industry leaders for the first time on Wednesday to discuss mutual goals. "There has been a barrier of communication that has to be crossed," Mr. Miller said. "Now, if we both go to Washington seeking Federal money to upgrade sewage-treatment plants, we'd both be winners. This is the beginning of a marriage of ideas."
While the leaders of both groups planned discussions, those talks appeared to be a long way from the men on the line last weekend.
 
Running a Gantlet
 Nick Colombo, agent for Local 38 of the Sheet Metal Workers union, was among those making up the thick gantlet of workers on West Red Oak Lane, through which Harrison police officers guided cars carrying conference guests up to the hotel. Mr. Colombo said he had had no trouble getting many of his 480 members to attend the rally.
"Half of them are out of work, many so long they have run out of unemployment," he said. "We have a food bank and a work-sharing program to help these guys, but it's not enough." Union members, he said, are being evicted from their apartments in increasing numbers, losing their homes and finding that they can no longer meet their car payments.
Another knot of men representing Carpenters' Local 149 stood nearby. Several identified themselves as "the lucky ones," the ones still working. Almost half the members in their 450-member local do not have jobs.
Steve Sullivan, for example, was recently notified by the Department of Labor that his unemployment benefits had expired.
"So many in the media view us as a bunch of labor goons," said Mr. Sullivan, who has four children. "What you see here is a group of fathers, Scout leaders and Little League coaches. We care about the environment. The only difference is that when we run out of work, we panic."
