LENGTH: 1529 words

HEADLINE: As Zaleski Settles In, the Mayoral Profile Changes in Yonkers

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
TERENCE M. ZALESKI stood in the original mayor's office in City Hall, his words echoing off the unadorned walls of the empty room. "This was where the Mayor sat decades ago," he said. "We're restoring it, hopefully permanently."
Mr. Zaleski, who became the first executive mayor of Yonkers in 50 years by winning a closely contested three-way race last November, pointed out the architectural details of the room and the magnificent view it afforded. Then he strode briskly into a cluttered adjacent room, where the work of his first month in office was piled high on chairs, desks and even the floor. 
 The 39-year-old former State Assemblyman, a Democrat, has moved quickly to establish an administrative staff, mostly former aides who served in his election campaign, his Albany office or in the two constituent offices he operated in Yonkers. A few positions remain unfilled.
Mr. Zaleski, deliberate and methodical by nature, has provided a dramatic contrast to the more flamboyant makeup of his predecessor, Henry J. Spallone, who came to be recognized chiefly for his role as the voice of opposition to a court-mandated housing desegregation plan for Yonkers.
Under Mr. Zaleski, the city's official opposition to the plan appears to have evaporated. It represents not only his own policy but apparently also that of the City Council, where a Republican, John D. Spencer, has "bolted," as Mr. Zaleski put it, to join three Democrats for a working majority.
In his first few weeks, Mayor Zaleski has helped to negotiate new bus routes to serve the 148 new low-income housing units on five sites -- eventually there will be 200 units on seven sites under the court order -- by persuading Westchester transportation officials to include the miniroutes in the county system, thus saving money at two levels.
"I knew from working in Albany," said Mayor Zaleski, who for six years was a member of the Yonkers delegation, "that to be eligible for operating subsidies it is necessary to be part of the county bus system. The city could have provided the service, but there would have been no reimbursement."
He is working with parties to the desegregation lawsuit on the so-called long-term housing plan, which the Federal Court has said should provide an additional 800 units of affordable housing to help remedy the racial discrimination it found that Yonkers had caused in the city's housing and schools for four decades.
 
Making Use of Existing Housing
 Mayor Zaleski said he planned to form a leadership council, "a sort of board of directors of prominent individuals and experts, who can help us develop and market a plan that will take advantage of existing housing as much as possible."
He referred to a detailed study of the subject drawn up in mid-December by Oscar Newman, the housing expert who serves as an adviser to Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan, who has handled the desegregation case since it was initiated by the Justice Department in 1980.
Mr. Newman, in his seven-page memorandum, began with the observation that "with the conclusion of one administration and the beginning of another of a decidedly different structure, I thought it might be helpful to explore the use of existing apartment stock in Yonkers" rather than limit the possibilities to the construction of new units.
Mr. Newman said last week that Mr. Zaleski's administration represents "a whole new ball game." Calling the new Mayor "intelligent, cooperative, rational, even daring," Mr. Newman added: "He knows the issues, and he knows the risks to the city and to himself. But he's aboveboard, genuinely refreshing and comes up with creative ideas."
If the mayor's new tenure has enabled him to reverse the city's approach to the divisive subsidized housing, it has also provided the opportunity for him to identify with a three-year effort to revive a private condominium venture, Pierpointe-on-the-Hudson, which had been a victim of the city's dispute with the court.
The developers of Pierpointe, a project of 1,850 condominium units planned along the Hudson River in southwest Yonkers, completed the first building, Scrimshaw House, a few years ago but sold only 25 of its 138 units. Problems included an increasingly soft real estate market and an order by Judge Sand halting all construction in Yonkers while the city refused to build the subsidized housing.
A week and a half ago, the developers, Yonkers Waterfront Associates, and officials of the American Savings Bank, announced an agreement they said would lead to the completion of sales in Scrimshaw House and the start of construction on a second phase, 115 condominium units over a 525-car garage.
 
Lottery Planned Next Month
 The revitalization hinges on a lottery next month in which 52 Scrimshaw apartments will be sold at prices ranging from $62,000 to $100,000, and city workers earning $30,000 to $50,000 will get first priority. The remaining apartments will be sold at market levels, from $90,000 to $150,000.
Mayor Zaleski said that the negotiations, which included the participation of city officials, had been under way for two years, long before he took office. He was on hand for the announcement, nevertheless, to stand behind the city's contribution of $1.6 million to help reduce sales prices and enable the lottery to proceed. The city expects to recover the $1.6 million eventually, beginning with a rebate from the developers of $1,000 for each apartment.
Mr. Zaleski said he hoped the lottery would "jump start the rejuvenation and move it into the next stages," which could include four more residential towers, a 200-slip marina, a renovated pier and a movie theater, a restaurant and a health club.
But housing has not taken up all of the new mayor's time. In a lengthy interview about his first month in office, he said he had also been seeking to retain the city's bond rating after the state's was downgraded by rating agencies earlier this month. "School districts are especially vulnerable," he said, adding that their bond ratings are tied to the state's.
 
Two New Deputy Mayors
 The mayor's new team includes two new deputy mayors, one for finance and economic development and the other for operations. Selected for the financial post was Andrew Maniglia, 34, "who worked for Marine Midland Bank as their regulatory officer in New York City," Mr. Zaleski said. "I knew him through his coming to Albany to talk about regulatory changes." Mr. Maniglia has been a Yonkers resident since 1984 and was finance chairman of the Zaleski mayoral campaign.
The operations post has not been filled yet. "It will deal with day-to-day operations of the different departments and agencies, the daily operational flow," Mr. Zaleski said. "It will make sure the different pieces of government machinery are operating efficiently, allowing me to devote my attention to the prime policy issues.
"We've been talking to candidates who are very cognizant of the need to provide a high level of services while cutting back on personnel," Mr. Zaleski added. "We're going to rearrange departments to provide services with a reduced work force. We're looking at layers of middle management that have been added on by past administrations, with an eye to seeing if some folks in higher levels might pick up more responsibility for what the line people are doing."
James Surdoval, 35, is the mayor's chief of staff. He served in that role for former Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko, a Democrat who lost to Mr. Spallone in 1990 and who is now a member of the City Council. Mr. Surdoval and the deputy mayors earn $90,946 a year.
 
The Rest of the New Team
 Other members of the Zaleski team earn from $35,000 to $55,456. They include:
*Nicholas Biondi, 25, a former Zaleski campaign aide responsible for fund raising, who is serving as executive assistant to the mayor. In this post he is the Mayor's link to boards, commissions and other government agencies, including the City Council.
*Andrea Stewart Cousins, 41, the mayor's liaison to community and civic groups. She is a member of the Black Women's Political Caucus.
*Barbara Flatley, 41, Mr. Zaleski's administrative assistant during his three terms in the Assembly, who is handling constituent matters.
*Betty Pettiford, 55, a former administrative aide to the Assemblyman, who is supervising the Action Center, which deals with constituent problems.
*Richard Slingerland, 25, a legislative assistant to the mayor, who serves as his link with the City Council.
Mr. Zaleski has hired Lucille LaBarbara, his former administrative assistant, to be his "liaison to the whole state government network," as Mr. Surdoval put it. Critics have called her a high-priced lobbyist, citing her salary of $41,699.
"Lobbyists have up to two dozen clients," the Mayor responded. "She will work fulltime for us. She will give us a leg up on other municipalities, reaching out not only to the Legislature but interacting with state agencies, talking with them on a daily basis on issues related to Yonkers. All we need to justify her involvement is one opportunity that would have been missed."

LENGTH: 190 words

HEADLINE: TICKET PRICES;
Inflation Is One Thing . . .

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Accompanying Frank Rich's article "Previews, That Broadway Malady" [Dec. 22] there was a photograph of an ad for "Cabaret" in 1966. Nearly buried in the small type at the bottom of that ad was one major reason for the collapse of Broadway: ticket prices. 
 The ad announced that regular ticket prices for that show, Monday through Saturday evening, would range from a top of $12 in the orchestra to $2 at the back of the balcony. That $12 compares to the $60 collected for top tickets to the recent "Nick and Nora."
Simply on the basis of inflation, the $60 top tickets for "Nick and Nora" was very much out of line. In the 25 years between 1966 and 1991, the average cost of commodities in the United States rose 246 percent. So, on an inflationary basis, a $12 top ticket in 1966 should have grown to a $41.50 top ticket in 1991. Charging $60, "Nick and Nora" was raising prices 400 percent over 1966: overcharging by $18.50, or 45 percent.
People are simply not going to go to the Broadway theater if its prices continue to be so out of line. Something must change.
 
JOSEPH WESLEY ZEIGLER
Montclair, N. J.

HEADLINE: Planes and Trains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the president of the Air Transport Association, I would like to respond to your review of "Supertrains: Solutions to America's Transportation Gridlock." It failed to mention that the author, Joseph Vranich, is a consultant to the High Speed Rail Association. That's an important omission, because the review strongly implies that Mr. Vranich is on to an exciting new idea. What he's on to is something he has a vested interest in seeing succeed, and which most people believe will succeed only with government subsidy. That's what bothers the airlines about this growing bandwagon touting high-speed rail. Its advocates want the use of public money to build these expensive new systems -- so they can compete with unsubsidized airlines. High-speed rail, while potentially attractive, should pay its own way. It should rise on its own merits. If the concept makes sense economically, the private sector will build it.
 
ROBERT J. AARONSON
Washington

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Hot Times for a Hybrid

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Convertible subordinated debentures. No other phrase seems to capture quite so perfectly the essence of Wall Street jargon. Indeed, comedians poking fun at the financial world have long known that they could simply pronounce that term, in slowly rounded tones, and rest their case.
Well, it looks as if Wall Street will get the last laugh. With yields at rock-bottom levels and with stocks soaring into regions that only an astronaut could love, some savvy investors are taking a fresh look at these obscure securities. The reason lies in the neat parlor trick they perform: in a soaring stock market, they act like a stock, but when stocks slump, they act like a bond. 
 "Institutional interest is definitely increasing," said John P. Calamos, president of Calamos Asset Management in Oak Brook, Ill., which specializes in convertible securities. "We're seeing a lot more activity."
Prices of these hybrid investments have increased, too, outpacing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index last year. But while stock market prices are making cautious equity investors nervous, Mr. Calamos said, most convertibles are still bargains. Moreover, convertibles tend to be issued by small and mid-sized companies, the darlings of the 1991 market, and thus they offer latecomers a safer and more affordable way to participate in that booming sector.
"We're still fully invested," Mr. Calamos said in an interview last week. "Looking at the risk-reward balance in convertibles, we still think it looks very good."
A convertible bond, like any other bond, pays a stated rate of interest -- nearly 8 percent, on average, as of last week -- for a fixed period of time. But unlike a classic bond, a convertible can be redeemed at any time at the investor's option for a fixed number of shares of the issuing company's common stock. In the creditor pecking order, the owners of convertible bonds typically stand behind the holders of non-convertible bonds -- hence, the "subordinated" modifier.
A close relative is the convertible preferred stock, which can also be converted into common stock. Preferreds pay a stated dividend but have no fixed maturity date.
Convertible securities are not new to Wall Street. They have been around since the late 19th century, when they were a favorite financing method for the nation's burgeoning railroads. With a record boom in new issues last year, there are roughly $250 billion worth of convertibles outstanding. But despite their long history and the size of the market, convertibles still tend to be viewed by many investors as an annoyingly complicated instrument -- difficult to price, difficult to understand and difficult to trade.
Much of the market's distaste stems from the 1987 crash, said Mr. Calamos. With the crash, investors who had been willing to give up a bit of yield in exchange for the right to convert their bonds into stock suddenly lost all interest in the so-called "equity kicker.' As a result, convertible issues began to trade as if they were merely bonds. "That has been the story for years," Mr. Calamos said.
In fact, there were periods in 1990 when convertible yields almost exactly matched straight bond rates -- when, in effect, a convertible bondholder was getting the equity kicker for free.
Last year, that started to change, as investors began to show a slightly greater appetite for the equity aspects of convertibles. But Mr. Calamos said that the spread between convertible bond yields and the yield on straight debt securities remains very narrow. As a result, investors are still giving up very little yield on their bonds for the right to convert them into stock.
There have been structural changes in the market, as well. Several large Wall Street firms have set up separate trading desks to make markets in convertible issues, analysts are devoting more attention to them, and several leading firms -- Merrill Lynch; Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, and First Boston -- have created indices to track convertible performance.
The nature of the investors is changing too. According to the Investment Company Institute, more than two dozen mutual funds have been set up in the past few years to invest exclusively in convertible securities. And, more recently, insurance companies are beginning to add convertibles to their portfolios.
The entry of insurance investors is especially important, in the view of Mr. Calamos, because "they tend to buy and hold." He added, "So that will soak up some supply and improving pricing."
Another change has been the wider acceptance of stock options pricing theory -- once considered highly arcane -- as a sensible way to price convertible securities. Mr. Calamos pioneered the application of options theory to convertibles, but now, he said, "Almost everybody uses some version of it. That has helped keep the issuers honest."
The market is not yet ideal, however. Credit quality, while stronger than in 1990, is still a risk. The trading in lower-grade "junk convertibles" is still thin and is dominated by professional bankruptcy investors who are trying to take a controlling stake in a beleaguered company. As a result, spreads between the bid price and the asking price tend to be so wide that even experienced traders steer clear. In addition, Mr. Calamos said he is beginning to see "less capital committed to making markets," a development that is affecting liquidity.
For these reasons, most of the new interest in the convertible market is still "on the institutional side," he said. And that is just as it should be, he added.
"You can't just buy new issues -- letting the investment bankers be your portfolio manager is not smart -- but buying seasoned issues required very good research," he said. "So even large institutions typically allocate their funds to professional managers."
In these convertibles, he added, "It's best not to drive yourself."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1740 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 19-24

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Prudential Puts a Stop to Laurence Tisch's Miracle on 34th Street 

Earlier this month, R. H. Macy & Company sent a shudder through Seventh Avenue when it announced it would be late paying its suppliers. The big cash-strapped retailer, with sales hurt by the recession and a dismal Christmas, was struggling with debts from a $3.7 billion leveraged buyout in 1986 and its $1.1 billion acquisition of the I. Magnin and Bullocks department store chains in 1988. Macy's seemed near the brink. Then last week -- briefly -- the Avenue sighed with relief. Lawrence A. Tisch, chairman of the Loews Corporation and CBS, was close to putting together a $1 billion deal to buy Macy's outstanding junk-bond debt and take over its stock. But the deal fell through when one of Macy's creditors, Prudential Insurance Company, just said no. The Pru, which holds more than $800 million of Macy's mortgages, did not want to drop its interest rates, as Mr. Tisch demanded. So far there are no plans to resume the talks.
 
Happy as No. 2?
 
Robert C. Wright, president of NBC, told a group of investors last week he did not really mind NBC's losing out to CBS as the nation's top-rated network. NBC dominated the ratings for six years, but this season CBS elbowed its way past NBC by spending big to acquire the rights to air major league baseball, the Super Bowl and the winter Olympics. Though the strategy is working, it has been costly. CBS may lose $400 million for 1991, analysts said, though it expects to make money from its new viewers when the economy recovers. Mr. Wright told investors he'd rather make money than be No. 1. That may sound good, but, in fact, NBC will lose $50 million to $60 million for the year, analysts said.

Exporting TV to Russia
 
The descendants of Lenin's "New Soviet Man" will soon get to savor the life of the American couch potato. For a week, they will be able to veg out on American prime-time TV. Michael Jay Solomon, president of Warner Brothers International Television Distribution, put together a deal that includes "Murphy Brown," "Perfect Strangers," TV movies and Bugs Bunny cartoons. But Russians will only get half a look at the decadence to which they aspire; they won't see commercials. Sponsors backed down because they felt "it would create a bad impression to advertise now with the lack of money there and the suffering," Mr. Solomon said.

Japan Eyes the American League
 
The timing could not have been worse. Days after Yoshio Sakurauchi, speaker of Japan's lower house of Parliament, called Americans lazy, an investor group headed by Japan's Nintendo -- the world's largest electronic game manufacturer -- made a bid to buy the Seattle Mariners baseball team. The group, which includes some Seattle businesses, said it would pay $100 million in cash. The Japanese may have scooped up some of America's most important cultural icons -- two Hollywood studios, for example -- but a baseball team? In this xenophobic climate? Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent has given the deal the brush-off. It won't get "the requisite baseball approvals," he said in a statement.

Discounts, and Hold the Decor
 
At 47th Street Photo Inc., deep discounts on consumer electronics, cameras and assorted gizmos made up for its lack of decor. "It looked like a hole in the wall, but it did incredible volume," said Martin Brochstein, senior editor of Television Digest. But last year sales of $225 million -- a drop of 21 percent from 1990 -- were not incredible enough for the store to stay current on the $57 million it owes. Last week, after defaulting on a $500,000 payment to the Transamerica Corporation, 47th Street Photo filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11. It will reorganize but leave its decor unchanged.

A G.M. Unit That Performs
 
At least one General Motors unit is doing well. Last week Electronic Data Systems said it will provide computer services to Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts in a 10-year contract valued at $800 million. Its biggest customer is G.M., which pays it $3 billion a year to crunch its numbers.
 
Cray Gives Up Its Independence
 
Nothing is more important to the nation's computer makers than choosing the right chip. Microprocessors, more than anything else, determine which machines can work together. So when Cray Research Inc., the supercomputer maker, said last week it would develop a line of $1 million-to-$3 million machines based on the Spark chip made by Sun Microsystems Inc., it conveyed a lot about its strategy for the future. Cray was saying it believes in network computing, rather than in going it alone. It was also saying it wants to link its machines to the thousands of Sun workstations already in place.
 
Drug Makers Work on Image
 
Now that their backs are against the wall -- pushed there by irate consumer groups and an angry Congress -- some of the nation's largest drug companies are reconsidering their pricing policies. Last week, following an earlier announcement, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said it would give 17 heart, blood-pressure and cholesterol-lowering drugs to patients whose doctors certify they are unable to pay. The Syntex Corporation said last week it would give 12.5 percent rebates to Federal programs for the poor. "The companies are being politically astute," said Ronald Nordmann, an analyst with Paine Webber Securities.
 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
Waiting for Recovery
 
Last week, Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told Congress not to do anything about the recession. The reason is the deficit: Mr. Reischauer projects a record this year of $352 billion.

Connecticut's Unlucky Streak
 
Connecticut's economy is more dependent on military contracts than any others state's. That point was made particularly clear last week when the United Technologies Corporation said it would would eliminate 13,900 jobs. Half are in Connecticut. This comes just after the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation said it would cut 10,000 jobs in Groton, Conn.

An American Car by Definition
 
President Bush did not bring back much from Japan that will help Detroit. So a number of American companies are taking out their wallets. The Monsanto Chemical Company and the Tosco Corporation are offering employees $1,000 if they buy American. But what's an American car? Hondas, Toyotas and Nissans are assembled here. At Tosco, American cars are those with 90 percent American content. The problem is that leaves out dozens of models the Big Three sell.

More Time to Spend
 
When Albert V. Casey, chief executive of the Resolution Trust Corporation, went to Congress last week, he asked for more money (a cool $55 billion) and more time to spend what the agency already has. The R.T.C. has until April to spend or forfeit the $25 billion Congress gave it last fall. That sum is in addition to $77.7 billion it received previously. Mr. Casey wants until October to spend the money. The extension is needed, he said, because with the sluggish real estate market, it is taking longer to sell the R.T.C.'s real estate portfolio, which is worth about $136.9 billion.
 
Follow the Housing Starts
 
Housing starts are the economy's bird dog. They lead the country into and out of recession. So it was good news last week when the Commerce Department said that housing starts in December were at their highest level in more than a year. Housing starts ran at an annual rate of 1,103,00 last month, 2.6 percent above the November rate. Building permits were up even more -- 5.8 percent, to 1,051,000. "Last month's rise in housing starts shows that low interest rates clearly are stimulating demand," said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist at the National Association of Realtors.
So how long until the economy follows?

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Aid, in Many Guises
 
Last week delegates from 47 nations gathered in Washington to discuss ways to aid the former Soviet Union. At the meeting, the Bush Administration came up with some novel, if somewhat inexpensive, proposals. Beginning Feb. 10, America will send the new Commonwealth of Independent States the 16 million prepackaged meals left from the Persian Gulf war. In addition, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said 2,000 American farm volunteers would be sent to work with farmers in the commonwealth for periods of up to 90 days over the next three years. (Since there are more than a million farms, those volunteers will be busy.) But an even more novel approach came from bankrupt Argentina. It will not give money, its delegates said, but will accept 100,000 Russian immigrants. Presumably, they will have to pay their own way.

To lure investors, the former Soviet Government and a private investor group published "Business in the USSR," a slick English-language magazine printed 11 times a year in France. Last week, when the latest issue appeared, it had a new name: "Business in the Ex USSR."

A Pledge -- Make That Target
 
When President Bush and the heads of America's Big Three auto companies visited Tokyo earlier in the month, they though they had a deal -- although not a very good one. Japan, they thought, had made a pledge to buy an additional 20,000 American cars, a number Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said was far too few. But last week Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa explained that 20,000 was really a "target," not a promise. So how many cars will Japan buy? Well, last week Japan's Parliament placed an order for two Buick Park Avenues, made by the General Motors Corporation. Detroit hopes there will be more.

Los Angeles County canceled a $122 million contract with the Sumitomo Corporation of America to build 41 automated rail cars last week. The contract will go to Morrison-Knudsen of Boise, Idaho, which put in a lower bid but has less experience. The cars are part of a $150 billion, 30-year plan to remake the city's transportation system.

An Economy-Model Porsche
 
Porsche AG, the German sports car manufacturer, startled its classy clientele last week with two announcements. The company said it would put 4,000 of its workers on part-time schedules due to slim order books. It also said it would shelve plans for developing a pricey four-seater in favor of bringing out an inexpensive new sports car.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Minneapolis Looks for a Super Payoff

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
The winners of the 1992 Super Bowl are: Minneapolis and Minnesota -- hosts to the game. The Washington Redskins and the Buffalo Bills must still settle the small matter of football supremacy. But the event should generate about $120 million worth of fresh economic activity and $7 million in new state and local taxes, according to a University of Minnesota study.
Most of the new revenues will go to the state, courtesy of its 6.5 percent sales tax. Moreover, the city must bear the cost of policing and cleaning up after the event. But Michael Forrester and Robert Durante, municipal bond analysts at Standard & Poor's, note that many Super Bowl fans are also executives who can steer new convention business to a host city. Tampa saw such a gain after hosting the 1991 classic, they said. 
 And unlike a home-team sports championship -- the baseball World Series, for example -- the Super Bowl attracts fresh money to the region. Minneapolis has a Triple-A rating from S.& P.; the state's rating is one notch lower.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Echo of Gould: The Treasury Intervenes

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The politicians are again trying to fix the nation's economic problems. And Wall Street is a bit nervous about the prospect.
Last week share prices gyrated and bond prices fell as investor attention began to focus on just what President Bush will propose Tuesday night in his annual State of the Union Address. 
 The last time Washington did something about the economy was in the fall of 1990, when Congress and Mr. Bush agreed to raise taxes. In retrospect, that seems dumb from almost any perspective. The budget deficit did not decline -- unemployed workers and bankrupt companies tend to pay less in taxes no matter what the rate -- but the economy did go into what Mr. Bush now describes, in surprising overstatement, as a "free fall."
Now it seems possible that Mr. Bush will reverse course and call for tax cuts. Or maybe he won't. Mr. Bush has never been known as a model of ideological consistency, and now he risks being portrayed by opponents as a President whose only principle is winning elections. With his aides split, the result may be a compromise proposal that will be dead as soon as it is made.
That might be viewed as good news on Wall Street, where fear runs high that the Government will only make things worse. The consensus view, widely but not deeply held, is that the economy is finally starting to recover anyway, as shown by rising housing starts.
The economy is not the only thing that Mr. Bush is supposed to fix. The rising cost of health care, which has acted as a tax on the economy and may help to explain the economic malaise, is the other. Unfortunately, Washington seems unclear regarding which of two problems it is supposed to correct: the fact that many people can't afford health care or the fact that health care siphons off an ever-rising share of national income. Most solutions to fix one would hurt the other.
What may emerge from the debate is a new effort to control medical costs with price controls on suppliers, a proposal that might put a halt to the bull market in health stocks.
That kind of proposal could do better now because the climate seems more open to some kinds of government intervention in the economy, as was shown by the general approval given to the Government's proposal to intervene to prevent squeezes in the Treasury bond market. If prices are too high for a particular bond, the Treasury will just print a few more bonds. Richard Sylla, an economic historian, compares the idea to Ulysses Grant's decision, after much hesitation, to sell Treasury gold in 1869, breaking Jay Gould's attempt to corner that market.
Bond market intervention may work, but it could also create problems. Valuable information on Government plans could leak, enriching some traders. To this day, no one knows how Gould learned of Grant's plan to sell gold, but he evidently did. Just before the market crashed, Gould sold most of his gold at high prices.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
100 Cents on the Dollar

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
Last spring, upon learning that he would be in charge of rehabilitating the troubled Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, Kevin E. Foley was immediately apprehensive. For one thing, the office Mr. Foley runs, the New York State Insurance Department's Liquidation Bureau, had never attempted to rehabilitate a life company, only property-and-casualty insurers. Moreover, when compared with other insurers that had failed, Executive Life was huge; its 118,000 customers reside in 23 states.
"We all felt a tremendous sense of responsibility," Mr. Foley said in a telephone interview.
Last week, however, the 41-year-old Mr. Foley announced the details of a plan that should pay every one of Executive Life's customers 100 cents on the dollar. Holders of deferred annuities and life insurance would turn in their policies in exchange for new policies from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. 
 For Mr. Foley, who became head of the Liquidation Bureau in 1987 after working in the insurance department's public affairs office, the challenge now is to defend the exchange offer from critics who will attempt to persuade a New York State judge to reject it. Some policyholders, for example, will argue that the plan is unfair because Met Life will be paying a somewhat lower interest rate on some account balances than did Executive Life. And Executive Life's numerous agents, who as creditors of the company stand virtually last in line, are fuming.
"We are still servicing our clients' accounts; we should be paid," said Gerald Lind, a big Executive Life agent in New York.
Mr. Foley is taking it in stride. Despite having received numerous calls from concerned -- in some cases, irate -- Executive Life customers, he is convinced that most of them will support the plan, largely because it should keep them all whole.
"What people have to appreciate is that their company got into trouble," said Mr. Foley. "There is no getting around that."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Plenty of Pain for the Gain

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Robert F. Daniell tried to put an upbeat spin on the announcement last week. The United Technologies Corporation, he said, was embarking on nothing less than a "sea change" that would produce a "leaner, tougher-minded company" capable of enduring the current recession and seizing opportunities as they arise in the future.
Then came the bad news. United Technologies plans to eliminate almost 14,000 jobs over the next few years, with the heaviest cuts falling on its Pratt & Whitney jet engine subsidiary -- and its home state of Connecticut. To pay for the cutbacks and for environmental problems, the Hartford-based company took special charges of $1.53 billion, producing a loss of $1.22 billion in the fourth quarter and $1.02 billion for the year. 
 Mr. Daniell, who has been chief executive of United Technologies since 1986, insisted that the job cuts were necessary, although he conceded they will do nothing to improve consumer confidence and end the recession. "We recognize that we are contributing to the overall problem," said Mr. Daniell (pronounced as if it had just one "l").
But the harsh reality, he said, is that a shrinking military budget means fewer orders for the company's military jet engines and sophisticated electronics; the slump in construction means less business for its Otis elevators and Carrier air-conditioners; and the steep decline in domestic car sales means less business for its auto parts business.
"I'm very comfortable with this action, because if we did not do it at this time we would end up in a situation where we would have to take even more devastating action," he said.
If there was a bright spot in the otherwise gloomy picture, it was the company's Sikorsky helicopter subsidiary, where sales are expected to hold steady over the next few years.
Mr. Daniell, who is 58 years old, knows a lot about the helicopter business. He started as a design engineer at Sikorsky in 1956 after graduating from Boston University's College of Industrial Technology. He rose to project engineer and then shifted into marketing, becoming vice president for commercial marketing in 1974. By 1980 he was chief executive of Sikorsky, a post he held until being named a corporate senior vice president for defense systems in 1983.
Looking ahead, Mr. Daniell said he hopes to forge more international alliances, like the one established between Pratt & Whitney and the jet engine subsidiary of Daimler-Benz.
"We have to recognize that there has been a leveling of technology in the developed world," he said. "So we have to ask if we can afford the duplication of effort in the design and manufacture of new products."

HEADLINE: In Options Trading, Volatility Is a Virtue

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Richard Witten, who is in charge of foreign exchange sales at Goldman Sachs, is sitting at the computer terminal in his office. He taps some keys and the screen blossoms with a colored display that reveals the details of a "plain vanilla" option -- in this instance an option to buy American dollars with Canadian dollars next June.
Because Mr. Witten, or a customer, needs to know more, the computer displays the welter of currency options arcania: the strike price, the premium, the delta and the volatility. 
 Is a plain vanilla option too tame?
Mr. Witten changes his program, clicks the the computer mouse and new products appear, a bevy of exotic Canadian-American dollars options that are even more complicated than the original and best purchased only by the very knowledgable. There are "lookbacks" and "knockouts" and "range forwards."
"Our business has increased to the point that if you do ten transactions, at least three are options and maybe as many as five," Mr. Witten said.
In other words, the options business is good, very good.
And business is booming, too, at the other leaders in the business: Citibank, Banker's Trust, First Chicago, J. P. Morgan, Merrill Lynch, Societe Generale and Swiss Bank.
Options, of course, are nothing new to Wall Street. But their use has grown rapidly in recent years and now, with the sharp run-up in the stock market and the dollar's recent volatility, they are enjoying an upsurge.
The darlings of the moment are stock options and currency options, and investors have been placing big new bets.
Some investors think the current bull market will continue, and they are buying stock options that in a few weeks or months will allow purchase of shares at a set price, known as the strike price.
The hope is that the market will have risen enough by then that the price for the shares will be higher than the price that must be paid through the option, resulting in a handsome profit, either by selling the stock or just selling the option.
Wide swings in prices makes such bonanza winnings possible. Thus, aggressive traders welcome volatility, or what they call implied volatility, the expectation that sudden price changes are likely in the near future.
"Volatility is out of sight," said David Puth, a managing director of the foreign exchange group at Chemical Bank in New York. "We have been seeing levels for current volatility we have not seen for a long time."
Other investors are betting on a fall in the stock market and they are using options to protect themselves against it. This use of options as a hedge, or insurance, against movement in financial markets can become artful in the hands of the experts.
The availability of ever more exotic (read "complicated" and "potentially costly") species of options is growing rapidly as investors seek new ways to hedge risk, enhance investments or just speculate. Mr. Witten's specialty is currencies, but with a few taps at the keyboard or clicks of the mouse other Goldman specialists can bring to their screens options available on everything from stock indexes to crude oil.
And because options generate fees for the institutions that market them, armies of salespeople are pushing the new products, particularly to corporate customers.
"Where you have a product that is customized and complex and difficult for the buyer to figure out what it is worth, you have an enormous opportunity for profit," said John Finnerty, a professor of finance at Fordham University in New York.
There is no better example of the potential profits in options for the securities industry than at Banker's Trust. Revenues from options and other derivative products averaged $50 million a year at Banker's from 1981 to 1985. But by 1989 they had jumped to $313 million, rose to $601 million in 1990 and hit $800 million in the first three quarters of last year, suggesting the possibility they might top $1 billion when the final tally for the year is in.
"Our growth in revenue and profits is driven by having a critical mass of clients, highly advanced technology, continuous innovation and a preference for acting ourselves as counter parties -- using our own capital -- so that a transaction can be completed and then hedged," said Brian Walsh, who runs the bank's worldwide business in options and other "derivative" investment products from London.
He expects the market to continue to grow. "The potential for derivatives to manage risk is just beginning to be understood in the markets."
Indeed, it is in this idea of controlling the risk of other investments by purchasing options that banks and brokerages are pushing the hardest. Firms are developing glittering new options packages, hiring consultants to educate corporate executives about the benefits of options as a hedge and arming sales staff with computerized systems like the one Mr. Witten at Goldman Sachs uses.
Investment industry analysts think this line of business offers a great potential for growth -- and profits -- for the banking, investment banking and securities industry, both in serving customers and in trading for a firm's own account.
But options can carry enormous risk -- particularly for firms selling them, if they get caught short by sudden market moves.
"Options are a wonderful way to get free money if things do not go against you," said Philip M. Johnson, chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission during the Reagan Administration. "If you are the writer of options, you collect fees. And if the market behaves, it's fine. But if the market goes south in a big way, you can get killed."
One of the most famous examples of this in recent years occurred at First Boston. Though the firm never publicly disclosed the details, people familiar with its trading of options on Treasury securities said the firm lost $100 million in April 1987, which contributed to a second-quarter loss that year of $13.2 million. There have been other options disasters at Wall Street firms, though few of such magnitude.
The rapid growth in the variety of complex options also is highlighting the jumbled Federal regulatory bureaucracy that oversees options, which will be the subject of debate in Washington again this year. The Securities and Exchange Commission has some jurisdiction, but so does the C.F.T.C. And a large part of the business, over-the-counter options, is subject to far less regulation than the options traded on exchanges.
"I don't think it is the lack of regulation that is the issue," said Thomsas A. Russo, a partner at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, a New York law firm, and a C.F.T.C. official during the Reagan Administration. "It is the confused state of the regulation that is the issue. Economically many of the products are similar, but they have different regulatory people to look over them."
In its basic form, an option allows a company to protect some of its revenue. For example, an American company selling auto parts in France might sign a long-term contract with a customer and want to protect it's revenue, which would be in francs, against fluctuations in the value of the franc that could cut into profits when it came time to convert francs to dollars. Purchasing an option to buy francs at a set price in the future protects the company from a fall in the franc and still allows it to profit from a rally.
The new products go well beyond something as basic as this. Creative Wall Street firms are designing products that provide tailor-made hedges against specific market risks. They are lowering the costs of some options, which can be quite high, by getting the customer either to take on more risk or limit their gain in return for lower fees.
And firms are focusing increasing attention on convincing companies that hedging risk with options should be a regular part of corporate strategy.
Charles Smithson, a managing director at Chase Manhattan Bank in Princeton, N.J., devotes all his time to educating businesses on the concept of buying options to offset risk. "I spend most of my time talking at conferences," he said. "I ask what kind of problem you have and say what are the range of solutions out there for you."
Options experts credit two men, Fisher Black and Myron Scholes, for opening the door to a booming options industry. As university professors in 1973, the two pioneered the methodology that allowed computers to figure out how to create and price options profitably. Mr. Black is now at Goldman Sachs and Mr. Scholes is at Salomon Brothers.
The key was designing a computer model that could manage the complex risk a firm takes on when it sells an option, since a turn in the market that makes an investor rich must come at the expense of the firm that sold the option. Many firms have spent heavily on powerful computer systems that can weigh all the variables and tell the firm how to manage its own portfolio of investments so it will not lose vast sums when options are exercised.
But the increasing expertise with which Wall Street firms are concocting ever newer and more complex options packages and pricing them so the firm can make a profit has begun to raise some questions about whether so many financial products are really needed -- and whether they are priced fairly.
"I have seen people who have overpaid," said Mr. Finnerty. "You have to be very careful. You have to call around and be sure you're paying a fair price. You can jazz a product up so it looks more sophisticated than it is. What happens is that companies get enamored with a particular product and the acronym that a bank uses to identify it."
Mr. Johnson said he thinks that too many users of complex options products do not really know what they are buying. "They do not understand the risk of the deal they are getting into or they think they have found the magic potion that will allow them to do what they want for less cost," he said. "In most of the situations that I have heard about, it is almost invariably true that they're trying to get something cheaper than it really costs."
Merton H. Miller, an economist at the University of Chicago who won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1990, contends that the options and related products are very useful. But he has a caveat about the options sales process.
"They are like salesmen in any other business," he said. "They sell the sizzle as well as the steak, and there is a certain amount of sizzle in this."

HEADLINE: At Work;
As Seen From a Wheelchair

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Like a lot of people, George Biechler takes his physical confidence pretty much for granted. So when the vice president of the Meridien Bank sat down in a wheelchair recently to get a sense of how it would feel to maneuver through the world from a sitting position, he looked a little tight around the mouth. Mr. Biechler pushed clumsily through a swinging door and made it past one orange traffic cone before banking off a wall and onto the rim of a second cone. Freeing himself, he wheeled with furious inefficiency for the swinging door.
"I haven't felt that uncomfortable since I got my learner's permit when I was 16," he said later, watching another Meridien employee carom between wall and traffic cone. 
 Like hundreds of other commercial enterprises across the country, Meridien, the Reading, Pa.-based unit of the Meridien Bancorp, is preparing for the Americans With Disabilities Act, legislation passed by Congress in July 1990 that guarantees accessibility and employment rights to the 43 million Americans with physical and mental impairments. The first phase, requiring businesses to provide services and access to people with disabilities goes into effect today. Starting in July, the employment and workplace rights sections of the law will be phased in. Depending on who is speaking, A.D.A. has either plopped the unfair burden of retrofitting American society on the back of business or started a revolution in consciousness.
"We have been terribly concerned from the day we saw this bill," said Wendy Lechner, manager for research and policy development at the National Federation of Independent Business, a trade group in Washington that represents half a million small businesses. "A lot of legislation is carrot and stick. This is all stick. Everything in the bill means trouble for business owners." She added: "I'm getting a lot of panic-stricken calls asking, 'What do I do?' "
Ms. Lechner said small businesses do not object to the law's admirable goals but to the potential cost and vagueness of its guidelines.
"People all over the country have some high expectations that they now have a right to be full consumers and participants," said Elaine Ostroff, a co-founder of the National Center for Access Unlimited, a disability issues consulting group with offices in Chicago, Boston and Washington. "The big change is attitudinal. It means people have to pay attention and look at issues." A.D.A. will be enforced by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Justice Department and by private lawsuit.
For many larger businesses, the legislative and regulatory controversies are moot. When the enthusiasm in Washington for the measure became apparent two years ago -- "It was politically unpopular to oppose this bill," Ms. Lechner said wryly -- many companies bit the bullet. A report by Blank, Rome, Comiskey & McCauley, a labor and employment law firm in Philadelphia, said 75 percent of the businesses surveyed have taken some action to comply with A.D.A. Many followed a popular managerial approach and formed A.D.A. task forces.
Which is why one morning last week, the normal sedate decor of Meridien's Independence Mall branch in Philadelphia, just down the block from Independence Hall, yielded to the artifacts of sensitivity. At the first of a series of workshops for 2,200 employees in Meridien's 215 branches, trainers took employees through exercises intended to build an empathic bridge between people with and people without -- "temporarily without" as disability activists like to say -- disabilities.
"This focuses on things that are less obvious than wheelchairs," said Linda Sopko, a Meridien trainer, as she handed two earplugs to Gary Reinert, a banker who was about to experience briefly the aggravation of being hearing-impaired. Ms. Sopko looked down and, while shuffling some deposit slips, asked him to write the date. He leaned forward, tilted his head and looked alarmed. She asked again, looking at him this time, and he complied. He had, he said, read her lips.
Ms. Sopko advises tellers to look for cues in body language, then to project their voices and look busy until the transaction is over, so the customer does not feel rushed.
As Meridien's Mr. Biechler surveyed the sensitivity free-for-all before him, he dispelled the notion that his bank, or any business, regards its efforts merely as a chance to flaunt its altruism: "Forty-three million people is a major market segment."
 
 
SOLVING PROBLEMS OUT OF COURT

 Rarely has writing on a wall been clearer than in the months before July 1990, when Congress passed the Americans With Disabilities Act. Despite lobbying that made the wars of Gog and Magog look like a fortnight of cricket, support from a Bush Administration making good on campaign promises and a network of determined activists made A.D.A. all but inevitable.
The month the law was passed, Safeway Inc., the supermarket chain, formed a task force. "We had meeting after meeting," said Brian Dowling, a company spokesman. Store managers were asked to assess their stores and to help remove barriers. New stores are being built to A.D.A. specifications.
The Norwest Bank Corporation in Minneapolis has assigned a person in each region to coordinate compliance. James A. Gossen, a bank vice president, said Norwest is retrofitting ATM's that are not accessible now and looking into machines that will incorporate Braille and voice synthesizers.
Rights advocates say the fear of litigation among some small-business owners isn't irrational but has been overplayed. "You need a problem-solving attitude," said Elaine Ostroff, of the National Center for Access Unlimited. "No one wants to be the bad guy in this economy. Good faith goes a long way."

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Those Giving the Word Also Suffer in Layoffs

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
Don't call them executioners. They feel bad enough already.
Nothing, of course, can match the shock of losing one's job. The body blow to self-esteem, as well as financial well-being, that comes with being laid off is nearly always traumatic. But handing out the pink slips can take a toll, too. 
 Just ask three executives involved in the process at Nynex, the telephone company in White Plains, N.Y., that is in the throes of layoffs that will affect nearly 3,400 people over the next two years. Donald J. Sacco, the executive whose name goes out on every Nynex layoff notice, felt a stabbing pain when he saw friends' names on the "at risk" list. Daniel C. Petri, who has had to personally deliver bad news to his staff, can't help recalling the outrage he felt when he was almost laid off at another company years ago. And Christine A. Killorin, whose husband was recently laid off, has spent sleepless nights worrying about having to inform some of her staffers that they must go.
Winnie Downes, an executive vice president at Lee Hecht Harrison, the New York consultants advising Nynex on the layoff process, warned the company's executives that they would feel this way. Despite elaborate business plans and personnel evaluations that take place before an execution, executives still feel wrenching pain, said Ms. Downes. "We told them, 'Don't bottle up your emotions,' " she said. "This is going to be tough for you, too."
People being told they are losing their jobs are likely to be angry or numb and may even try to bargain with their boss or appeal to a more senior supervisor. To ease the tension for both managers and employees, Ms. Downes told executives, it is important not to be drawn into such behavior.
Don't say, "I know how you feel," because you really don't and the remark could sound patronizing, according to Ms. Downes. Don't say, "They're making me do it;" that's shirking responsibility. Above all, she advises, don't say, "It's a blessing in disguise," because it is belittling.
What to do? Empathize, but underscore that the layoff is an irreversible fact of life that would be best dealt with by planning or getting some career counseling.
That this is untraveled territory for the phone company only makes matters worse. Unlike General Motors and other companies accustomed to huge cyclical hirings and firings, a job at the telephone company was supposed to be good for life.
All that changed, of course, with the 1984 breakup of the Bell system. Nynex, the parent of New York Telephone and New England Telephone, had special problems. In the early 1970's, it hired a bumper crop of young employees to cope with economic expansion in New York State and, particularly, the explosion in demand for telephones by Wall Street and the booming banking business.
Twenty years later, Nynex finds itself with thousands of employees in their mid-40's -- too young to retire but too expensive to keep. In recent years, Nynex has asked four times for volunteers to retire early and four times not enough people did so. "We looked at the numbers and asked ourselves was there any other way of doing it, and there just wasn't," said Mr. Sacco, Nynex's vice president for human resources.
In November, Nynex took a $550 million charge against earnings, 70 percent of it for work force reduction costs like severance packages. It was by far the largest such charge for the Baby Bells.
The month before, Nynex executives had worked out a "position analysis," laying out how much work needed to be done and, later, a "people analysis," laying out who was qualified to do it. The employees most at risk for layoff were told on Jan. 7, the first such date in a vast shrinkage that is likely to last into the mid-1990's, analysts say.
"You wind up seeing the names of your friends as the ones going to leave the business," said Mr. Sacco, whose 350-member staff was reduced by more than 100 positions. "It's anguishing for the people let go and for the people who let them go, no matter where you are in the organization chart." As one of the most senior Nynex officers, the 50-year-old Mr. Sacco did not have to inform anyone personally.
By contrast, Mr. Petri, New York Telephone's general manager for Midtown Manhattan, had to tell his people personally, a dozen so far in his 220-member staff. "I never had to lay off anybody," said Mr. Petri, who is 43.
When he was a young aerospace engineer on Long Island, he was threatened with layoff. "I remember that surge of energy, that feeling you want to fight the system," said Mr. Petri. "If I tell you that you are at risk of losing your job, you don't sit there and doze off. I remember that and I feel that." After his near-brush with job loss, Mr. Petri left for New York Telephone -- attracted by its job security.
Reflecting on his recent interviews with employees likely to be laid off, Mr. Petri said, "I don't have nightmares or bad dreams, but I do take that stuff home with me."
Ms. Killorin, New York Telephone's general manager for operator services, has had restless nights. She had to reduce her staff of 330 managers by 17 positions. Her husband, who was laid off last summer, tried to convince her that layoffs were the price paid for a free-market economy.
Still, she could not sleep. "That's kind of my way of dealing with problems," said Ms. Killorin, who is 40.
"I've fired people before for cause," such as incompetence, she said. "That wasn't hard because you at least had the conviction that somebody didn't belong in that job. But these were all good people and it was tough dealing with how hard it was."

HEADLINE: FOOD;
If You Need a Reason, Now's the Time for Meatloaf

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
RECESSION, nostalgia and winter invariably add up to meatloaf on the menu. The traditional meatloaf is made with ground beef or a combination of beef, veal and pork. But today, it might even mean turkey loaf or chicken loaf as the anti-cholesterol squad keeps careful watch over the diet.
Regardless of the basic material, meatloaves are appealing because they are easy to prepare and to eat. They can be made in advance and reheated or sliced and used in sandwiches. What is pate but a sophisticated meatloaf? Like pates, meatloaf mixtures can be wrapped in pastry or used to stuff vegetables. Meatloaf mixtures can even be formed into small, individual portions. 
 When making meatloaf, it is important to season the mixture well. Spices, fresh and dried herbs plus ample onion and garlic give meatloaves character. The texture should also not be too dense, lightened by the addition of bread or bread crumbs or some other grain. Rice, oatmeal, bulgur and bran are some possibilities.
The texture of a good pate is achieved by blending in fat, which is why these savory loaves are enjoyed in small slices as a first course, not as a main dish.
In the past the vegetables for a meatloaf might have been sauteed in butter or bacon fat and the loaf itself baked with slices of bacon draped over it. Eggs are typically used as a binder and hard-cooked eggs might even have been tucked into the center of the loaf to create attractive slices.
Today these high-cholesterol embellishments can be reduced or eliminated. The onions and garlic are sauteed in olive oil and the extra fat is avoided. Instead of using whole eggs to bind the mixture, egg whites can be substituted.
With meatloaf, of course, mashed potatoes must be served. But even these can be made with the amount of butter reduced or with olive oil instead of butter.
 
Crusty Meatloaf
 
Total time: 2 1/2 hours
 
3 pounds lean ground beef
 3 egg whites, well beaten
 1 cup rolled oats (not instant)
 1/4 cup dry white wine
 3 cloves garlic, minced
 1 medium onion, grated
 1/2 cup milk
 2 tablespoons tomato paste
 2 tablespoons minced parsley
 1 teaspoon dried thyme
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper
 2 tablespoons dry bread crumbs.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
2. Mix the beef with half of the egg whites. Soften the oats in the wine and add them to the meat along with the garlic, onion, milk, tomato paste, parsley and thyme. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
3. Shape the mixture into two loaves. Place them on a rack in a shallow baking pan that will hold them without crowding.
4. Mix the bread crumbs with the remaining egg whites and frost the loaves all over with this mixture. Bake about 1 1/2 hours, until the loaves are crusty and brown. Serve at once or allow to cool, then refrigerate. The loaves can be reheated -- whole or sliced -- in a conventional oven or a microwave oven or sliced and used for sandwiches.
Yield: 10 to 12 servings.
 
Turkey Patties With Mustard Sauce
 
Total time: 35 minutes
 
2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
 1/4 cup finely minced shallots
 1 1/2 pounds ground turkey
 2 tablespoons finely chopped parsley
 2 tablespoons Dijon mustard
 1/4 cup dry bread crumbs
 1 tablespoon brandy
 1/4 cup chicken stock
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper.
1. Heat one tablespoon of the oil in a heavy skillet. Saute the shallots over medium heat until they begin to turn golden. Remove the pan from the heat, scrape half the shallots into a mixing bowl and reserve the rest in a small dish.
2. Add the turkey, one tablespoon parsley, one tablespoon mustard and the bread crumbs to the bowl. Mix until the ingredients are well blended. Shape the mixture into eight patties of equal size, each about three-fourths of an inch thick.
3. Heat the remaining oil in the skillet. Add the patties and saute over medium heat about 10 minutes, turning them once, until they are cooked through. Remove the patties to a warm platter and cover with foil.
4. Return the reserved shallots to the pan and stir in the remaining mustard along with the brandy and stock. Cook, stirring, a minute or two until the sauce thickens slightly. Season to taste with salt and pepper and stir in the remaining parsley.
5. Pour the mixture over the patties and serve.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
Garlicky Mashed Potatoes
 
Total time: 40 minutes
 
3 pounds Idaho potatoes, peeled
 6 cloves garlic, peeled
 3/4 cup hot milk
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper
 6 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened, or 2 tablespoons olive oil.
1. Cut the potatoes into uniform two-inch chunks and place in a heavy saucepan along with the garlic. Cover with water, bring to a boil, lower heat to medium and cook until the potatoes are tender, about 20 minutes.
2. Drain the potatoes and garlic and mash the potatoes and garlic together. Stir in the hot milk, season to taste with salt and pepper and add the butter -- less if desired -- or oil. Serve at once.
Yield: 6 servings.

HEADLINE: Mount Vernon Law Should Be Changed

 BODY:
As a tax-paying homeowner in the city of Mount Vernon, I go along with the city officials quoted in your article of Jan. 5, "Mount Vernon Challenges Definition of a Family," when they express their eagerness to protect their cities against increased density and other housing evils.
However, as a member of the board of directors of Genesis Housing Corporation, the not-for-profit organization that was denied a building permit for a two-family shared-dwelling unit for seniors, I disagree strongly with their method of attaining their stated goals. A little history is in order. 
 About three years ago, Genesis attained title to a piece of land on Union Avenue, a low-income area in Mount Vernon. The debris-strewn lot was located between a two-family house and a vacant six-story apartment house. After discussions with City Hall, Genesis decided to build a facility for senior citizens. Further discussion with social service agencies led to a decision to make the building into a shared (or congregate) housing facility similar to the ones in operation in Mount Kisco and Bedford for physically able low-income seniors.
Architectural plans were drawn up and successful application was made to the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. With funds from that and other sources secure, Genesis applied to the Mount Vernon Building Department for a building permit and to the Mount Vernon Zoning Board of Appeals for some necessary minor variances. Both applications were turned down, essentially on the ground that the proposed occupants did not constitute a family and that the facility would amount to no more than a boarding house. (Boarding houses are illegal in Mount Vernon.)
Genesis went to court. The court decided that Mount Vernon's definition of what constituted a family was faulty; that the proposed house as outlined could fit into legally accepted definitions of family and that Genesis should be allowed to proceed with its project. The City of Mount Vernon has appealed the decision and, according to the article, is being supported by counsel from White Plains, New Rochelle and Peekskill.
I am no lawyer and am not capable of making a plea to a court of law, but I can and do make this plea to the court of public opinion and to the legal lights in the various city offices. What Genesis is saying is the following: If the Mount Vernon law on family is so constituted that it can't tell the difference between a commercially run boarding house and a home that is affordable to people who need and want it, a home run by a not-for-profit group, then something is wrong with the Mount Vernon law and it needs changing.
No one is asking the City of Mount Vernon or the other cities to give up their right to make appropriate zoning regulations. No one is asking it or the other cities to give up their right to protect the density and livability of their cities. What we want is for these officials to stop being petty, to stop seeing grave constitutional issues in any innovative plan that helps to meet a present, pressing need.
 
ROBERT M. PHILLIPS
Mount Vernon
 
On Jan. 13, the Appellate Court in Brooklyn upheld the State Supreme Court decision that allowed Genesis to proceed. Mount Vernon has not announced whether it plans to appeal the latest ruling.

HEADLINE: FIGHTING WORDS;
As Ugly Feelings Grow, It's Hard To Separate Fact and Friction

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan

 BODY:
IN asserting last weekend that America can't compete because its workers are "lazy" and a third of them "cannot even read," a Japanese legislative leader violated Japan's first rule of engagement with the United States: Never criticize America in any harsher terms than America criticizes itself.
In normal times, such indiscretions by Yoshio Sakurauchi, even with their edge of racial superiority, probably would have been written off as the ramblings of an aging and largely powerless legislator. But given the level of American anger now directed at Japan, these times are hardly ordinary. Last week a legion of spin-controllers led by Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe raced to assure the American public that the comments by Mr. Sakurauchi, the speaker of Japan's lower house of Parliament, do not "reflect the way of thinking of the Japanese people in general." 
 The problem is, they do. In December, a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted with the Tokyo Broadcasting System asked, "If you had to describe most Americans, would you say they were hard-working or lazy?" Only 13 percent of the Japanese chose the first option; 66 percent agreed with Mr. Sakurauchi. Not long ago, when a college lecturer asked her freshmen to come up with adjectives describing America's national character, lazy was the overwhelming first choice -- although their descriptions were tinged with envy over relaxed American lifestyles.
If Mr. Sakurauchi's comments, which he said later he "regretted," seemed a veiled version of Nikita Khrushchev's "we will bury you" speech, it was only the latest measure of the rising emotions in the Japanese-American dialogue since President Bush's disastrous trade mission pulled out of town. The Japanese, with some justification, feel that they are being made the scapegoat for decades of American inattention to domestic problems, all of which, in their view, flow together on General Motors' beleaguered factory floors. That is the message underlying Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's recent spate of condescending-sounding speeches saying Japan must now show "compassion" for a "great country" struggling to solve AIDS, street crime, homelessness and a moribund education system. Mr. Sakurauchi simply took the next leap, effectively declaring that the Japanese culture of discipline, education and productivity is already emerging as the real winner of the post-cold war era.
As Mr. Sakurauchi's comments and the sharp American reaction resounded across the Pacific, protectionists in Congress introduced a bill to restrict the sale of Japanese autos, even those made in American "transplants," if the trade deficit is not reduced 20 percent a year -- as if the responsibility for closing the trade gap is only Japan's problem, not America's. And Los Angeles canceled a $122 million contract with Sumitomo Corporation to build a commuter rail line.
Mr. Sakarauchi's exquisitely bad timing was matched only by that of the Nintendo Corporation, whose owners should know better than to drive their spaceship into a galaxy of angry aliens. At the request of Seattle's government leaders, the Yamauchi family of Kyoto, which controls the game-maker, offered to buy the Mariners and keep the team under local management, rather than let the current owner move it to Florida. But the prospect of a piece of the ultimate in Americana going the way of Rockefeller Center and Hollywood studios seems bound to incense Congress. In the end, it probably won't happen: Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, quickly said the major leagues were not ready to sell their level playing fields to overseas owners.
Amid the epithets and the deals, governments on both sides turned to their cure-all: symbolism. President Bush, desperately trying to show that he returned from Tokyo with something more than the flu, held an unusual White House signing for an otherwise run-of-the-mill trade agreement on computers. Here in Japan the parliament ordered two Buick Park Avenues.
The problem is that few Japanese could be persuaded to do the same. Japanese will buy anything that sniffs of American culture: blue jeans, movies, California cuisine. But they also receive a barrage of little daily signals that when it comes to industrial goods -- especially cars and electronics -- Japan's success hinges on a culture whose innate discipline and uniformity encourage attention to detail and quality. Nothing attracts headlines here like the failure of an American component or a bug in American software; seven years after the crash of a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet, Boeing is still fighting off Japanese accusations that a shoddy repair triggered the accident.
But it is easy to lose track of the main point that Mr. Sakurauchi crudely touched upon: Are the Japanese more productive, and what does that mean for American competitiveness? Like most economic issues involving Japan, the answer depends on where you look.
 
The Productivity Phantom
 By the extremely imprecise measure of productivity -- gross domestic product produced per person -- America remains significantly more productive than Japan. So does Britain, a country whose competitive prowess rarely makes grown industrialists quake. But productivity is a deceptive thing -- countries that pump and refine a lot of oil have artificially high productivity rates that mean virtually nothing. In the area Mr. Sakarauchi was referring to, automobile factories, every study suggests that the worst Japanese plant is as good as the best American one.
Far more important, America's productivity lead is narrowing, and may be gone by 1995. Though Japan's economy is only two-thirds the size of America's, it spends more on new plants and equipment every year, automating new factories and replacing old ones. The results are startling: Since 1975, Japanese productivity in manufacturing has roughly doubled, while American productivity has increased a little more than 50 percent. Over the same period, Japan's working hours have decreased by about three hours a week, while America's have held steady. More important, the differences between Japanese and American work places still exist, and Japanese wonder what further economic humbling America will have to suffer before it gets the message.
Motoo Suzuki, the director of passenger car development and engineering at Mitsubishi Motors, notes that his 3,000 engineers "produce three times as many new car designs" as their 8,000 counterparts at Chrysler. "There is no secret to it," he says. "We bring in our suppliers and marketing people from the start, and do it together. They bring in the budget-cutters."
Such cultural explanations of Japanese efficiency, however, fall apart whenever you leave the easily measured world of the factory. Anyone who has spent time waiting in a jammed, paper-laden Japanese office is overwhelmed by the inefficiency: huge amounts of paper to be shuffled and stamped at each level of bureaucracy, endless meetings to reach the ever-elusive "consensus," long nights at the bar to build relationships -- at considerable cost to productivity the next morning.
The service sector is padded with unnecessary employees: scores of perfectly dressed young women greeting shoppers at department stores, train stations full of ticket-takers and ticket-checkers performing monotonous jobs that could easily be done by machine. It is marvelous for consumers, as long as you are willing to pay the very high price. The distribution system to get goods to hundreds of thousands of small shops is not only unnecessarily complex, but frightfully expensive and a major obstacle to newcomers who are not already part of the system -- a major complaint of American retailers. Rice farms are notoriously small and inefficient. But most of these are recognized inefficiencies, part of a seemingly deliberate full-employment plan that ensures that virtually everyone in Japan, down to grandmothers who make a few yen as weekend rice-farmers, gets a well-protected slice of the action. Older Japanese complain that the system is breaking down, partly because of a crushing labor shortage, partly because a younger generation of workers will not tolerate so much scut work. If this country ever really got efficient -- for example, making full use of a formidably talented work force of women -- America might really be in trouble.
Instead, America has been demanding at trade talks that Japan undercut its own efficiency, giving workers more leisure time, encouraging them to spend more and save less. Many here think that is a ridiculous invitation to plunge the Japanese economy into the kind of troubles that they think are crippling America. But a few prominent Japanese are beginning to argue that there is more to life than competitiveness. Japan "is in desperate need of a new philosophy of management, a new paradigm for competitiveness; a new sense of self," Akio Morita, the peripatetic chairman of Sony Corporation, who often seems to have more clout in America than in his own country, wrote recently. Japanese companies, he said, sounding a lot like Carla Hills, have a "preoccupation with market share" that leads them to accept razor-thin profit margins and offer paltry dividends to shareholders that no Western company would tolerate. "It is precisely this philosophy of competitiveness which also leads to multilateral trade friction," he said.
It sounds nice, but asking Japan Inc. to stop playing to win is like asking Ty Cobb, the baseball great of early this century, to stop sliding into home with his spikes high. Not very likely, no matter who owns the Mariners.
