HEADLINE: The Nation;
Where 'Buy American' Is More Than a Slogan

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
MOTOWN'S emotions have been rubbed raw by disparagements of American cars and the workers who build them.
But the latest crack by a Japanese politician may have pushed Detroit to a new level of irritation. A Chevrolet dealer invited shoppers to pound a Japanese-made truck with sledgehammers. Flag-waving members of the United Automobile Workers picketed Toyota dealerships. The exhortation to "buy American," increasingly chorused around the nation in recent weeks, has always been part of Detroit's credo and is being sounded here more insistently than ever. 
For Detroiters, the American car has always been a symbol of pride, the embodiment of their accomplishments. As the Big Three auto makers struggle to pull out of their tailspin people here are worried that their schools, churches, unions, clubs -- their whole way of life -- may vanish. Last week, the industry reported that mid-January sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell 1.9 percent this year from last year's levels.
Increasingly, that worry is expressed as anger. Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, delivered a bellicose broadside before the Detroit Economic Club on Jan. 10, calling for America to confront Japan: "I for one am fed up hearing from the Japanese, and I might say from some Americans, too, that all our problems are our own damn fault."
 
Protecting the Big Three
 Mr. Iacocca's words were dismissed by many outside the Rust Belt as parochial and myopic. A poll last week by The Detroit Free Press showed that 67 percent of car owners think Japan gets too much blame for American problems. The Michigan Congressional delegation has sponsored legislation that would protect the Big Three from imports, though it is questionable how popular the proposal will be outside the Middle West.
In auto country, the Iacocca speech and proposals in Washington were heard as a call to action. Read Patton, president of the Franklin Bank in Southfield, Mich., was so inspired that his bank is offering $100 to employees of commercial customers who buy a car made by General Motors, Ford or Chrysler. Mr. Patton concedes that his promotion is meant to drum up business for his bank, as well as the Big Three. "The fate of southeast Michigan is tied to the auto industry," he said.
The Monsanto Company of St. Louis, which has a subsidiary supplying the auto industry based in Auburn Hills, Mich., promised $1,000 to any of its 12,000 workers who buys a car assembled in North America before July 31. (Monsanto's offer also applies to Japanese models built on United States soil. Franklin, on the other hand, excludes all Japanese-brand cars from its offer.)
It is the consensus that Detroit's products have improved vastly in recent years, but the Japanese cars have also improved so much that gaps remain. Big Three auto executives go one step further, insisting that their products are now comparable to Japan's. But American auto makers also claimed parity in the 1980's when, as Mr. Iacocca now admits, domestic vehicles were demonstrably inferior. The resulting gap in Detroit's credibility has left some buyers of Japanese cars wondering what reason there is to switch back, except perhaps for one: the nation's economic vitality may depend on the Big Three.
Most economists say it is debatable whether "buying American" is a strategy tha ultimately can fortify the economy, which is better driven by competition than by sentiment.
However, if the Big Three can convince shoppers that buying a Taurus instead of a Toyota carries some cachet, then buying an American brand may represent added value in the same way that buyers pay extra for the prestige of owning a Cadillac or Mercedes, said Clifford Winston, a senior research associate for the Brookings Institution.
It can also make sense for a buyer to support the local economy. "If these consumers are at the same time workers in the auto industry, then they're certainly helping themselves by buying American," said Edward Gramlich, who teaches economics at the University of Michigan.
 
What Foreign Car?
 Many doctors, lawyers and merchants living in or near auto-manufacturing centers wouldn't dream of owning a foreign car, for fear of displeasing clients who work for the auto makers. More and more, they see buying American as good for their own business. And such feelings can transcend the issue of quality.
"My personal opinion is that we should stick with the Americans, whether they are bad cars or good cars," said Michael J. Chetcuti, manager of Quality Metalcraft in the Detroit suburb of Livonia. "It's our economic survival. I wouldn't care if the cars have cement tires on them."
Longer term, nationalistic enthusiasm for American vehicles won't help Detroit nearly as much as would matching Japanese competition. When Japanese politicians offered only grudging support for the Persian Gulf war, some surveys suggested that Americans, in a burst of patriotism, would be turning to Chevys and Fords. Yet during 1991 the Big Three lost market share and the Japanese gained.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 4; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: Bush Digs In;
Abortion Case Adds an Edge To the Election

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
POLITICIANS are instinctively drawn to compromise, which helps explain their discomfort with the issue of abortion.
Even a master strategist like the late Lee Atwater had a hard time managing the abortion issue, when he tried to recast the Republican Party for the 1990 elections as a "big tent" where both sides could feel at home. Last week, the Supreme Court might have guaranteed that the issue will be even hotter in 1992. The court set the stage for an election-year ruling that could further weaken or even overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 case recognizing a constitutional right to abortion. 
 While protesters clashed in the streets of Washington, underscoring the passions roused by the issue, the Supreme Court agreed to decide the constitutionality of a Pennsylvania law that restricts access to abortion through a variety of regulations. The Supreme Court's action means that a decision is highly likely before the November election -- probably by late June or early July.
President Bush, a staunch opponent of legalized abortion, was already in a political vise on the issue, and the court's action tightened it. He is clearly unwilling to further antagonize his right, particularly when Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, is pressing a troublesome challenge in New Hampshire. Phyllis Schlafly, who is heading a drive to preserve the Republican Party's anti-abortion platform, said coolly: "I think people generally understand what happened when the President reneged on his no new taxes pledge. They can't afford another one."
At the same time, Mr. Bush is under mounting pressure from supporters of legalized abortion, who have been galvanized particularly by the 1989 case, Webster v. Reproductive Health Services. The National Abortion Rights Action League has begun airing ads in New Hampshire declaring, "The Bush Supreme Court is getting ready to make abortion illegal again." Kate Michelman, the head of the league, said, "It will be more important in this Presidential year than it has ever been in any Presidential election."
 
A Clear Partisan Line
 "Will it be enough to defeat George Bush?" she asked. "I don't know in and of itself if it will be enough, but it could certainly provide the margin of victory in states where it's close." There will be a clear partisan line on the issue: the five Democratic Presidential contenders all support abortion rights.
Republican backers of abortion rights are increasingly vocal, warning that the party platform is out of step with the American public. A fight over the platform, which now calls for a "human life amendment" overturning Roe and the appointment of judges who "respect the sanctity of innocent human life," is widely expected when Republicans gather in Houston this summer.
In the midst of all this, Mr. Bush seems to be digging in. On the anniversary of Roe, when anti-abortion forces traditionally rally in Washington, Mr. Bush delivered a statement of support for their "righteous cause." The same day, Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, an adamant opponent of abortion, was named to head the committee to draft the platform.
In an interview, Mr. Nickles sought to play down the prospects of a divisive fight on the issue. "The Republican platform four years ago had 104 pages and abortion dealt with maybe half a page," he said. "I'm sure abortion will come up, but it's not going to be the sole source of discussion." Without being specific, he said he expected the platform language on the issue to remain "pro-life." Mrs. Schlafly said she had "every sense that the President is going to hold absolutely firm."
The electoral consequences of that are a subject of considerable debate. Many analysts say that the Republican Party's anti-abortion stance can hurt among moderate suburban voters. Mervin Field, a veteran polltaker in California, said the abortion rights position has a sizeable majority in that critical Presidential state.
But organizers for abortion rights acknowledge that it is often difficult to get their supporters to become single-issue voters. In contrast, the anti-abortion forces say they can consistently turn out their voters.
Moreover, one strategist close to the Bush campaign argued on Friday that voters dislike overt politicking on the issue, perhaps especially in a Presidential election. "We've never seen this issue injected in a Presidential campaign in a high voltage way," the strategist said.
The 1990 elections showed how the issues of war and the economy can overwhelm almost anything. Eddie Mahe, a veteran Republican consultant, asserts that even if Roe were overturned before the election, Mr. Bush would survive. "Will it make the campaign noisier? Yes," he said. Will it cause George Bush to lose if he might have otherwise won? No."
Moreover, even if Mr. Bush wanted to shift his position, it could be politically dangerous. He changed once before, during the Reagan era, abandoning a flexible stance for a harder anti-abortion line. Changing again could turn into a "character" issue, many Republicans say; Democrats like former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts already use his previous shift to attack Mr. Bush as a man "without a core."
At the end of the week, the Bush forces seemed far more preoccupied with Tuesday night's State of the Union Message, and how its economic recovery program will be received. On abortion, Mr. Bush remained unmoving, perhaps recognizing that no compromise could satisfy either camp.

HEADLINE: Helping Hand, Heavy Foot: Both Are the Real China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
THERE is a country in East Asia that imprisons and tortures dissidents, that sells missiles and nuclear technology to unstable third-world regimes, that exports prison-made products, that fires on Buddhist monks who demonstrate to demand freedom for Tibet.
There is also a country in East Asia that has revolutionized its economy along market lines, that provides free prenatal checkups for expectant mothers, that is rapidly extending the web of roads and electricity lines to remote villages, that provides wheelchairs and other help to the disabled, that offers Tibetans and other ethnic minorities preferential university admission -- that, in short, is raising standards of living of most inhabitants about as fast as any society in the world. 
 The gulf between these two faces of China is vast, and the question seems to be: Which is the real China?
The problem, though, is that both descriptions capture part of the Chinese reality in the 1990's. Some academics and business executives warn that the West risks misleading itself by focusing on the negative side today -- just as the West misled itself by focusing on the successes of economic and political liberalization before the crackdown two years ago in Tiananmen Square.
Ma Musha, a 37-year-old Muslim farmer in Qinghai Province, is enthusiastic about the Government policies. "Everybody," he told a visitor, "is getting much wealthier, and building better houses." Mr. Ma was giving a tour of the new house he is building, the third brick home in a village where most of the 20 houses are made of mud. Beaming, he pointed out the tile floor, electric radiator and elegant woodwork on the door. He shrugged without interest when asked about politics, but volunteered that the Communist Party was doing a good job in allowing people to get rich and build nice houses.
Then he spotted a couple of plainclothes policemen -- acquaintances of his, as is everyone in the area -- skulking outside. He excitedly called them over to meet a genuine American journalist who had hiked alone across the fields to talk to various villagers. Embarrassed, the policemen dawdled over, but they acknowledged that introductions were unnecessary. They had tailed the journalist to monitor whom he talked to and to punish anyone who spoke critically of the Government.
So which counts more? The Government policies that enabled Mr. Ma to get rich? Or those that authorized imprisoning him if he criticized the leadership?
China challenges foreign critics because it does not easily fit into a mold. In recent decades, the other Communist countries simultaneously repressed and impoverished their citizens. But China is presiding over rapidly rising living standards for the society as a whole, even as it suppresses the minority of intellectuals and workers who take a stand for democracy.
Of course, China is not unique in this respect; the Soviet Union under Stalin and Iraq under Saddam Hussein both saw economic progress under political repression. But in the 1990's, perhaps no country more than China combines such staggering economic growth with such ruthless repression.
Like Mr. Ma, most Chinese workers and peasants seem to care far more about personal prosperity than about issues like human rights or torture of political prisoners. Rather, the most common criticisms that ordinary Chinese seem to have involve such issues as corruption and extravagance among officials.
 
What's the Major Trend?
 "At least in southern China, I don't think the issues on local people's minds have anything to do with the issues the U.S. is bringing up," said Roderick W. Macneil, an American who runs a Hong Kong consulting firm that is active in southern China. "The people are simply worrying mostly just about how to get ahead in life." He argues that the preeminent historical trend in southern China is not repression but the emergence of an enormous export-oriented economy linked to Hong Kong's.
In response, many Chinese intellectuals argue that the regime ultimately will crumble because it brutalizes demonstrators and refuses to listen to criticism, and in this sense human rights issues are central. It is high time, they say, that the West gave the same support for freedom in China that was long standard in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Comparisons between China and India illuminate the ways in which the regime here resists easy stereotyping. For four decades, much of the world has been studying the performance of India's democracy and China's totalitarian system as competing models of how to seek modernization. And while India's voters have never chosen to place themselves under the kind of controls that prevail in China, it is also difficult to find Chinese who would trade places with Indians of equivalent social standing.
After all, China enjoyed an economic growth rate over the last decade that was 83 percent higher than India's, China's life expectancy of 70 years of age is 11 years longer than India's, and illiteracy rates are only about half as high in China as in India. For an infant born in China today, the chance of dying in its first year of life is only one-third as high as it would be in India -- and that may mean more to the parents than issues of voting or freedom of speech.
A young university graduate expressed the ambivalence that many Chinese intellectuals feel when they are asked about India. She said China has done much better economically but gave credit to the Chinese people, not the Government. And she added that India may have better long-term prospects, because a democracy perhaps is more able to chart a stable course toward prosperity. "India is far freer than China," she said as she tried to sum up her mixed feelings. "We admire India a lot. But I don't know anybody who wants to live there."

HEADLINE: The Region;
Plenty of Gas Arrives, But at Shortage Prices

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

DATELINE: SOUTH COMMACK, N.Y.

 BODY:
ON Tuesday, a new natural gas pipeline from Canada will come to life as an economic anomaly, a megaproject that was planned when energy shortages were still a fresh memory but completed in an era of energy surplus, declining prices and recession.
The pipeline, the Iroquois Gas Transmission System, is by far the largest single new source of energy for the New York region since the 1950's. It is capable of pumping enough gas yearly to replace 30 million barrels of oil, and nearly double that amount if additional pumping stations are added in upstate New York. 
 Over the next decade, government and utility industry officials say, the Iroquois system will redress an imbalance that has hobbled New York, New Jersey and Connecticut since before World War II. Few other states are as dependent on Middle East oil to heat their homes and fire their power plants.
"Energy shortages are not a hot topic these days, but one gunshot in the Middle East or a sudden cold snap would put them back on the agenda," said Richard M. Kessel, director of New York state's Consumer Protection Board.
Experts say that in addition to reducing the region's dependence on oil, abundant new supplies of natural gas will provide a cleaner and more environmentally acceptable fuel for manufacturers, power plants and homes.
Still, financial analysts say the project may be a drag on the New York regional economy instead of a boon as it struggles through the most protracted recession in decades.
The cost of the Canadian gas to be pumped through the Iroquois system is expensive compared with domestic supplies that are already available, according to analysts for Merrill Lynch & Company.
 
Cries of Outrage
 "We can already hear the cry of outraged commissions when they see soon-to-be filed purchase gas adjustments that contain Iroquois gas purchases," said Donald DuFresne, an energy analyst for Merrill Lynch, referring to possible fluctuations in the price consumers pay for the gas.
The criticism is the latest in the rancorous history of the Iroquois pipeline, which runs through shallow trenches for 370 miles from Iroquois, Ontario, southward through Upstate New York, where it connects with existing pipelines already carrying gas to Massachusetts, Rhode Island and New Hampshire. Continuing southward, it crosses southwestern Connecticut and the Long Island Sound, ending in a muddy construction site here at South Commack. Other already established pipelines intersecting the system will carry its gas to Long Island, New York City and Central New Jersey.
A consortium of Northeastern utilities and gas distribution companies -- including the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, the Connecticut Natural Gas Corporation and the Long Island Lighting Company -- built the pipeline for $655 million. It was fiercely opposed by oil industry executives, who argued that increased imports from Canada would undermine United States exploration for gas, and by landowners along its route.
Just over half the pipeline's gas will be purchased by distributors in New England; the rest will be pumped into smaller, existing pipeline systems that thread their way across Long Island, New York City, central New Jersey and upstate New York.
Although construction has taken only 11 months, it came after years of surveying, land acquisition and regulatory approvals. Even before all the project's construction bills and legal fees have been paid, the consortium said last week the pipeline has exceeded its original budget by $70 million.
Yet as a business venture, the pipeline is almost assured of success. The utility group will operate its pipeline much the same way that United Parcel Service handles packages: it will collect a fee for each cubic foot it delivers. The pipeline's customers include more than 20 utilities in the New York region and the Northeast that signed contracts in 1987 to buy its gas for 15 years. After pumping pressure is phased in, Iroquois officials expect to collect $100 million in annual sales this year and $130 million in 1993.
The utilities say most of the natural gas, at least for now, will be sold to homeowners and landlords for residential heating. But other uses seem certain to include large-scale electrical power generation. On Long Island alone, the Long Island Lighting Company has already begun converting part of its Northport plant, the nation's largest electrical power plant fueled by oil, to natural gas. And this month New York state, which last year assumed control of the failed Shoreham nuclear power station, asked for bids by major engineering companies that might convert it to a gas plant.
Quietly, at the very time the project has moved from contentious public hearings to completion, the supply of natural gas from United States oil fields has risen, and its price declined. The major pipelines in the Northeast since the 1950's have embarked on expansion programs that, in addition to the Iroquois line, will greatly increase the capacity to provide gas to the region.
 
Expensive at First
 Energy experts say the result will stimulate competition, insulate the Northeast against shortages and stabilize or reduce oil prices. But because the price of gas delivered under the 15-year contracts signed by Iroquois customers is linked to a "market basket" of energy costs -- including prices of domestic gas and oil -- it will start at a higher level than gas sold elsewhere, and any reduction will be gradual at best.
"Gas from the Iroquois will be more expensive than the existing supply, but that is a short-term issue," said Anthony F. Earley Jr., the president of the Long Island Lighting Company, which helped build the pipeline and is one of its biggest customers.
Like other utility executives, Mr. Early said the costs and benefits of the Iroquois project can only be considered with a view to the future, when the added gas supplies will enable them to convert oil-fired power plants to gas and build much larger markets among residential customers.
While utility officials plan a future with greater supplies and wide selections of fuel sources, others say the main benefit may ultimately be the one foremost in the minds of the pipeline planners in the early 1980's.
"History provides ample reminders that you cannot count out the threat of oil shortages," said Robert Stobaugh, a professor of business and energy expert at the Harvard Business School. "Particularly in a region that is so reliant on oil, this project has to be regarded as a good thing."

HEADLINE: The Cold War of Cuba and the Miami Exiles Heats Up

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
THE cold war may be over in Washington and Moscow, but it rages on in Florida and Cuba. The execution in Havana by firing squad last week of a Miami man recently captured with two other exiles after landing on the Cuban coast in a dinghy quickly produced angry demonstrations in front of the Bay of Pigs Monument here and defiant rhetoric from Fidel Castro and his increasingly beleaguered Communist regime. On both sides of the Florida Straits, any relaxation of tensions now seems more remote than ever.
In the past, Mr. Castro might have dealt less harshly with an infiltration episode. But with the Soviet Union gone, and billions of dollars in subsidies vanishing with it, the Cuban leader is looking unusually vulnerable. So Eduardo Diaz Betancourt, a 38-year-old mechanic who confessed to joining a shadowy Miami paramilitary group called Commandos L after fleeing Cuba on a boat last April, was deemed to have betrayed "the fruits of the revolution." He was made an example and executed. 
 Cuban-Americans, a million of whom live in South Florida, sense fear and desperation in Mr. Castro. Events like the daring and spectacular helicopter escape of 34 Cubans earlier this month convinced them that his end is approaching. But the veterans of the Bay of Pigs and the firebrands who belong to Alpha 66 and other paramilitary groups are not content to watch the Castro regime stagger under the weight of its own repression, inefficiency and corruption; they want to be able to claim they brought the whole structure tumbling down.
Passions have been especially inflamed by the recent conference on the 1962 Cuban missile crisis held in Havana. For years, Cuban exiles here have chafed at what they assumed was an American pledge, made by John F. Kennedy to Nikita Khrushchev in settling the crisis, not to invade Cuba. But correspondence between the two leaders, made public on the eve of the conference, revealed that despite verbal assurances, Mr. Kennedy refused to agree to any formal pact that would prohibit the United States from attacking Cuba.
As a result, leaders of the Cuban community here, whose votes and campaign contributions are essential to President Bush's hopes of winning Florida in this year's election, have now thrown their energies into a petition drive urging Mr. Bush to grant exile groups here the right to use force to overthrow Mr. Castro. The State Department on Friday strongly rejected that notion: a spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, warned that "any efforts to use the territory of the United States to prepare or promote violence in Cuba" are violations of the Neutrality Act that "will be vigorously pursued and duly prosecuted." Nevertheless, thousands of exiles have already signed the document, and Havana has expressed its alarm at the idea that American policy might change. "We think that, yes, it should remain valid forever," Jorge Risquet, a member of the Central Committee of the Cuban Communist Party, said of Mr. Kennedy's 30-year-old guarantee. "A committment is a committment."
 
The Divided Opposition
 At the same time, however, disagreements over how to hasten Mr. Castro's fall have opened divisions among his opponents here. On Wednesday, Mayor Xavier Suarez of Miami joined Jorge Mas Canosa, chairman of the Cuban American National Foundation, the most powerful of the exile lobby groups here, and other prominent Cuban-American business and civic leaders in founding the Cuban Anti-Defamation League. They said the new group would "defend the good name and influence of the community against those who would distort and defame" leaders of the drive to oust Mr. Castro. But other prominent Cuban Americans have criticized the infiltration episode, some even suggesting it was so inept that Mr. Diaz Betancourt must have been a double agent.
With the Cuban economy in a virtual state of collapse, Mr. Castro has indeed been quick to exploit the raid for maximum propaganda value. The trial of Mr. Diaz Betancourt and his compatriots, which was televised, featured frenzied accusations of their supposed links to the C.I.A. and to Cuba's own small but persistent human rights movement. Mr. Castro's brother Raul, who is Defense Minister, warned all exiles "seeking signatures asking George Bush for permission to wage war" that "those who live by the sword die by the sword."
Fidel Castro, however, does not appear to believe what his own Government is saying about an American threat. "I don't think the United States is contemplating an invasion," he said at the conference, according to several participants. He was also reported to have pledged that Cuba would "live by accepted norms of international behavior" from now on and end its adventurism abroad. "Times have changed," he was quoted as saying. "We have changed." Those remarks, all made behind closed doors, were enough to convince some Americans who attended the conference that it is time for some sort of rapprochement.
For militant Cuban exiles here, detente in any form would be the worst possible outcome. But neither do they like having the F.B.I. looking into their activities as violations of the Neutrality Act, which is one of the few concrete results of the failed raid. At the moment, it is both easier and safer for Cuban Americans to make their influence felt in Washington than in Havana. But for some, the temptation to continue "tweaking the beard of the tyrant," in the words of one radio commentator here, may also be too hard to resist.

HEADLINE: Corruption and Waste Clog Aid Pipeline to Russia

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 25

 BODY:
As the United States and other Western nations get ready to send large amounts of aid to the former Soviet Union, people here are struggling to overcome inexperience and disorganization at both ends of the pipeline, as well as a strong temptation to divert scarce food, clothing and medicine to a hungry black market.
Rushing to stitch together some kind of safety net for the needy and to keep up with the foreign response to their country's growing emergency, Russian Government officials have created a Ministry for Social Protection. 
 Together with a Commission for Humanitarian Aid, the new ministry has identified 31 regions and 65 million pensioners, single parents, Chernobyl victims and domestic refugees as the most deserving of foreign aid and other forms of government assistance.
 
Private Groups Spring Up
 Private organizations are also springing up faster than anyone can count. A conference for social service groups organized recently in St. Petersburg by the Russian Salvation Army drew representatives from 114 groups instead of an expected 21.
In Russia, which is the largest of the former Soviet republics and has received by far the biggest share of the 352,000 tons of foreign aid delivered since December 1990, officials in and out of government acknowledge their handicaps.
 
Wishing Donors Would Listen
 But as 47 nations met this week in Washington to outline their latest charity drive -- including a $450 million loan to buy Korean rice, a donation of 16 million prepackaged meals left over from the United States war effort in the Persian Gulf, and a pledge from Argentina to take 100,000 immigrants -- some Russians were quietly saying they wished that someone would ask them about their needs.
"Look, the West is afraid of a social explosion in Russia, and they say, 'We will tell you where it is likely to be,' " said Gennadi A. Zhukov, deputy chief of the working group of the Russian Commision for Humanitarian Aid.
"The European Community decided it is going to be in Moscow and St. Petersburg, so that is where they send 200 million ECU's of humanitarian aid," he said. "Of course, that way it is more convenient for them, and easier to show on television."
There have been other more bitter disappointments. Workers at a soup kitchen in Moscow run by a Western charity were recently dismayed to open a truckload of United States Government aid and find that half of it consisted of paper plates and cups, preserved bread, hashed brown potatoes, boxes of instant grits with an 1984 expiration date and fruit juices that had gone sour.
In a country lacking in almost everything except potatoes, bread and kasha, the Russian word for grits or porridge, the shipment was virtually useless, said one charity official who asked not to be identified. "You opened a box and anything could be in it," she said. "And the worst part is that we will have to throw most of it out."
Russian officials share Western nervousness about insuring that aid shipments reach their destinations. "Most of all, what worries us is that the help gets to those people who need it, " said Yevgeny P. Ivanov, head of the agency for international humanitarian aid in the Ministry of Social Protection. "When you have such huge amounts, not everything can be ideal, but we do what we can."
Since the aid began in earnest last winter, the press has carried occasional reports that food, clothing or medicines were disappearing onto the black market or into the kitchens of the old Communist Party nomenklatura.
 
Containers Sit in Train Yard
 But some of the misrouting of aid has as much to do with donors' eagerness to rush to Russia's assistance as with Russian inefficiency. For instance, a shipment of 28 containers of aid from Germany has been sitting in a Moscow train yard since Dec. 25 without any address label, the newspaper Izvestia reported today.
Last week the Salvation Army received, without any advance warning, 140 cartons of clothing and food from Nashua, N.H..
Russian officials are also concerned that Western donors are putting too many restrictions on the aid. The rules seem to be creating more difficulties for local governments, which are desperately trying to help the aged, the poor and big families, whose tight budgets have been strained or destroyed by the leap in consumer prices since cost controls were eased on Jan. 2.
With much of the aid marked for orphanages, homes for the aged and hospitals, the public often does not see the promised goods. Suspicions have arisen that it has all been whisked off by the ever-present "mafias," both criminal and bureaucratic.
 
Exaggerated Expectations
 Mr. Zhukov said that such suspicions were fueled, both here and in the West, by exaggerated notions of how much aid has been distributed. "Just last night, I heard the television anchorman talk about millions of tons of aid," he said. "It is not millions of tons, it is thousands."
Most disappointing, he said, has been the delay of the long-promised $165 million in food aid from the United States. It has yet to materialize.
Of the 1,144 aid flights that have arrived in the last 13 months in the Svoiet Union, he said, only 103 were from the United States, while 604 were from Germany.
"Although there are a lot of these announcements, it is just propaganda," Mr. Zhukov said. "As far as reports of active American involvement, at this point, we are not seeing it."
The question of foreign aid is double-edged here, particularly for an older generation that finds the idea of being dependent on food parcels from Germany particularly humiliating.
"I am a man who has not lost his worker's conscience and honor," said Ivan Shakhtyor-Semyonov, of the city of Cheboksary in the Urals, in a letter to Sovetskaya Rossiya.
"If some donors bring these gifts, I will throw them into the street, stomp on them with my feet," he wrote. "We are people. We are not donkeys, sheep, cattle to be calmed down and consoled by food. We have our own dignity."
 
Tracking Down Deliveries
 Most Western programs now insist on tracking deliveries of goods to the door of the hospital or orphanage, a practice that Russian officials for the most part encourage. "It is a constant battle," said Elizabeth Gardner of Project Hope, which has delivered four planeloads of medicine and medical equipment to Russia in the last two months. "Drugs are a valuable commodity here, and so there is a constant temptation for diversion."
Some shipments -- of chocolate, for instance, or dried army rations -- have deliberately been sold commercially for high prices, with the proceeds funneled back into aid projects. Russian aid officials saddled with the cost of redirecting some of the money to distant cities say they need it to cover transportation and other organizational costs.
Most of the aid to Russia remains in Moscow, a city of nine million where, foreigners and Russians agree, the food crisis is worse than anywhere else. Of the 350,000 tons of aid delivered to the old Soviet Union since December 1990, 162,000 tons went to Moscow, 83,000 went to St. Petersburg, 41,000 to other cities in Russia and 16,000 to Ukraine, according to Mr. Zhukov.
But even those figures -- which may not reflect aid shipments of which the Russian authorities are unaware -- are small compared with needs.
Sven-Erik Ljungholm, captain of the Russian Salvation Army, said that aid officials in St. Petersburg were reporting that despite a desperate solicitation effort by Mayor Anatoly A. Sobchak, the city had received only 18 percent of the aid it had calculated it needed to get through the winter.
 
From Denial to Desperation
 Until last year, the old Soviet Government would barely admit to having social problems like hunger or homelessness, let alone organize any effort to alleviate them. Since then, the Soviet Union has collapsed, along with most of its institutions. Now, with their economies in a nosedive, Russia and other republics are trying to create something resembling a welfare system.
Those working with the new Russian bureaucracies are more encouraged by the efforts than they are discouraged by the confusion and frustration that typically accompany any endeavor here. "There is a system, even if it means standing in line, or waiting for a phone that doesn't work," said Mr. Ljungholm. "It may be chaotic, but it is a system."
Typically, any complaints about the way Western aid is distributed are coupled with expressions of gratitude that more prosperous nations are coming to the rescue.
But as they become more experienced at the business of being a charity case, Russians are beginning to realize that the most reliable aid may have to come from themselves.
"The hopes that 'foreigners will help us' pull ourselves out of our hole is naive to say the least," the newspaper Pravda said today in a commentary on the aid conference in Washington. "They have their own troubles. And they will help us only to the extent that it helps their own interests, not ours."

HEADLINE: 7 Nations Say Drag on Growth Is Dissipating

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 25

 BODY:
Seeking to raise consumer and business confidence, the finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations said today that the conditions slowing worldwide economic growth were dissipating and that the seven nations would step up their cooperation to stimulate expansion.
After a seven-hour meeting here, the ministers issued a statement saying that economic output should soon increase because inflationary pressures have eased and long-term interest rates have begun to fall. In an apparent response to American pressure to put more emphasis on growth, the ministers said they were convinced "that the forces that have been inhibiting economic activity in many countries are dissipating and that the conditions for improved global growth exist." 
 Eager to revive the United States economy before November elections, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady boasted that Washington had succeeded in getting all seven countries to make an "unequivocal commitment" to focusing more on increasing output.
But Mr. Brady's campaign to get Germany to cut its interest rates to spur investment and growth apparently bore less fruit. The communique cautiously suggested that Germany's current policies "could create room for lower interest rates."
German officials struggled today to ward off pressure from Washington, arguing that their country needed high interest rates to protect the mark and to subdue inflationary pressures.
"The stability of the German mark is important not just for Germany, but also for our partners," Helmut Schlesinger, president of Germany's central bank, said at a news briefing.
The finance ministers and central bankers from the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan reiterated their goal of achieving "sustainable growth with price stability."
Reviewing the economic situation in each of the seven nations, the communique said that President Bush would announce measures in his State of the Union address on Tuesday to strengthen growth, including incentives for investment.
As for Germany, the ministers said that an easing in German wage pressures, the country's efforts to reduce its budget deficit and the slowdown in growth of the money supply could create room for lower interest rates. The Germans pledged today to discontinue a 7.5 percent income tax surcharge in mid-1992 and to introduce incentives to spur housing construction.
One senior Treasury official praised the move, saying it would stimulate German growth as well as the country's appetite for exports. The official said the decision would benefit American exports, which have been crucial to preventing the United States from falling deeper into recession.
Treasury officials said that pushing harder for growth in the industrialized world would make it easier for the nations of Eastern Europe, the former Soviet Union and the developing world to cope with their severe economic problems.
The ministers noted that Japan has pledged to step up domestic consumption by increasing public investment. American officials said the policy should encourage Japan to import more, which would help reduce the country's soaring trade surplus.
The ministers also discussed foreign exchange markets, where the American and Japanese central banks intervened a week ago to push up the yen against the dollar. The ministers said they had "reaffirmed their commitment to cooperate closely in exchange markets, thus contributing to favorable conditions for stable exchange markets and economic recovery."
The seven called on the International Monetary Fund "to act expeditiously" to conclude arrangements by this spring that would allow Russia and other former Soviet republics to join the fund.
Saying they recognized the difficulties the republics face in adopting economic reforms, the ministers warned them not to default on their debt payments, which were lightened earlier this month. The ministers said the payments were a precondition for maintaining the republics' creditworthiness.

HEADLINE: Sudan Is Seen as Safe Base for Mideast Terror Groups

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The United States and other Western Governments are becoming increasingly alarmed by evidence that international terrorist organizations that once operated from Lebanon and Libya are now using the Sudan as a safe haven, foreign diplomats here say.
The Western nations also fear that the Islamic military Government formed here after a coup in 1989 is intent on exporting its brand of fundamentalism, threatening secular Governments in Egypt and other countries in the region, the diplomats say. The Sudan has been forging an increasingly close alliance with the Islamic Government of Iran. 
 The developments in the Sudan, which has cast its lot with the radical Arab states, come at a time of heightened concern over the growing power and appeal of Islamic fundamentalism across North Africa as Muslim populations become disillusioned with long-ruling, unresponsive and often corrupt Governments. That rise in influence was vividly illustrated last month in Algeria, where fundamentalists won resounding victories in free voting and were poised to take control of Parliament before the military cracked down and suspended the democratic process.
 
Visit by Iranian President
 The challenge posed by the Sudan was underlined after a visit to Khartoum last month by the Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, Western diplomats said. Iran agreed to grant military and economic assistance to the Sudan, thus extending to it the potential to not only consolidate its power at home but also to materially and morally promote Islamic groups elsewhere, the diplomats said.
In the last year, the Sudanese have accelerated the training of a paramilitary force of conscripted Government workers and university students, known as the Popular Defense Force. Officials acknowledge that it is modeled after and is receiving help from Iran's Revolutionary Guard.
As the Sudan hardens its Islamic rule at home, it is providing easy access, and apparently in some instances training installations, to international terrorist groups, the diplomats said.
They said the groups include the radical Palestinian organization of Abu Nidal, the Iranian-backed Party of God and Islamic Holy War. The Abu Nidal group has evidently been scaling back its operations in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, as Libya seeks to soften its image as a sponsor of terrorism. The other two groups, long linked with the kidnapping of Westerners in Lebanon, have seen their activities curtailed as the Syrian-allied Lebanese Government moves to extend control.
 
Warnings to Sudan Reported
 The United States and Britain have made "repeated" warnings to the Sudanese Government about the presence of the terrorists organizations here, the diplomats said.
The Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Robert G. Houdek, who visited the Sudan days before the Iranian President arrived, told senior members of the Sudanese Government that their country faced "grave" consequences if an international terrorist act could be traced to the Sudan, American officials said.
"Houdek told Hassan al-Turabi that there are continued reports of Sudan being used as an R and R place," an American official said, "and he cautioned Turabi that if Sudan was a facilitator of these terrorist groups then the actions of the terrorist groups would be a responsibility of Sudan."
Mr. Turabi, regarded as a leading intellectual force in the Islamic world, is the Secretary General of the National Islamic Front and described by Sudanese and Western officials as the de-facto head of the Government.
Implicit in Mr. Houdek's warning, in a written statement to the Government, was the threat that the Sudan would be added to Washington's list of states that support international terrorism, the official said. Countries on the terrorist list, all of which are denied United States economic aid or favorable terms of trade, are Libya, Iraq, Syria, Cuba, North Korea and Iran.
Diplomats in Khartoum say Iran appears to be extending its influence here to compensate for having lost ground in Lebanon; in addition, last year's military defeat of Iraq, an ally of the Sudan, has left a power vacuum here that Teheran seems eager to fill.
The largest country in Africa in land mass, the Sudan, with a population of about 25 million, was an ally of the United States until a coup in 1989 threw out the democratically elected, progressive Government of Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi; fundamentalists have since come to the fore in the current military regime headed by Gen. Omar Hassan al-Bashir. Washington cut all economic and military aid to the Sudan after the coup but last year spent $170 million on famine relief.
The Sudan declared itself an Islamic state in 1990 when General Bashir visited Iran and said the two countries shared a common duty to propagate Islam. The Sudanese sided with Iraq last year in the Persian Gulf war.
 
Worries About Nearby Nations
 Now, as the surge of Islamic fundamentalism in North Africa has been underscored in Algeria, American policy makers are worried about the Sudan's vow to spread fundamentalism to surrounding nations.
The Sudan is in a strategic position to export its Islamic revolution because of its borders with both Egypt and Libya and with six African countries, including Ethiopia, which has a large and impoverished Muslim population.
Egypt regards the Sudan as vital because the countries share then Nile River, and the High Dam of Aswan is only 150 miles north of the Sudanese border.
But the traditionally friendly Egyptian-Sudanese relationship has degenerated in the last year, with Cairo accusing the Sudan of supporting fundamentalism in Egypt. Just this month, the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, warned the Sudan to stop interfering in the internal affairs of Egypt. And Tunisia and the United Arab Emirates have withdrawn their Ambassadors from Khartoum, asserting that the Sudan was helping fundamentalists in their countries.
 
Denials From Official
 In an interview at his home here, Mr. Turabi denied that international terrorist groups were present in the Sudan. "We wouldn't know if an Abu Nidal element came into Sudan. But there is no office, official or unofficial," Mr. Turabi said. "There were a few Palestinians who were thrown out of the gulf who were not even engaged in political activities who came here." The Sudan was one of "two or three countries that allow Arabs to come in without a visa," he said.
An American official here said the terrorist presence had increased in the Sudan in the last six months as life had become more difficult for them in Lebanon and Libya.
"This is a safe haven of choice," the official said. "They can come and go as they please. They operate here with impunity. They are no longer welcome in Beirut, and there are signs Qaddafi is not happy to have them," he said, referring to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
The official said he did not have much hard data of what the terrorist organizations were doing in the Sudan. He added that although there was enough evidence to suggest there were training camps, he could not specify their locations or the number of men involved. But the official said he believed that there might be about "100" people he could classify as members of terrorist groups in the Sudan and that the number was likely to rise as Sudanese links with Iran were cemented.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Sudan At a Glance"
 
Geography: The Sudan is the largest country in Africa, covering 966,757 square miles, or about one-fourth the land area of the United States. The north is mostly desert, while the south is tropical.
 
People: In 1990, the estimated population was more that 25 million. Blacks are the largest ethnic group, at 52 percent of the population, concentrated in the southern half of the country. Arabs are the second largest group, at 39 percent, and live primarily in the north.
 
About 70 percent of the population is Sunni Muslim. The literacy rate is 20 percent.
 
Economy: Gross national product in 1988 was $8.5 billion. Consumer prices rose 66.3 percent in 1990.
 
Major industries are textiles and food processing. Major crops are gum arabic, cotton and sorghum. About 78 percent of the labor force works in agriculture.
 
History: The Sudan gained its independence from Britain and Egypt in 1956. Parliamentary democracy prevailed until 1969, when a civilian-led council took power and declared a socialist state. The socialist Government was overthrown in a 1985 military coup, and in 1986 elections were held for the first time in 18 years. The elected Govbernment was overthrown in another coup in 1989, when th current leader, Gen. Omar Hassan al-Bashir, came to power.
 
The north and south have been engaged in civil war since 1988.
 
(Source: 1992 World Almanac)

HEADLINE: Negotiators Expect Macy to File for Bankruptcy Protection Soon

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Participants in the negotiations to resuscitate R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that the retailer was almost certain to file for bankruptcy protection soon, possibly as early as Monday.
One of them said Macy had told some important creditors to expect a bankruptcy filing early next week. 
 Five people who took part in the talks said no new proposal for providing Macy with much-needed cash has replaced the $1 billion offer from Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman and chief executive of the Loews Corporation, which fell through late Friday when the parties could not agree on easing the terms of Macy's huge debt.
"It's almost impossible to put together another deal like the Loews offer with anything like the speed required at this point," one participant said. "Bankruptcy is really the only choice." Even if an interested rescuer suddenly emerged, the negotiators said, time has run out.
 
Merchandise Is Withheld
 Macy's banks have cut off its access to money, no one is accepting its credit and suppliers have shipped few goods to its subsidiaries, which include the I. Magnin and Bullock's department store chains, and several small specialty stores. Macy's New York-based flagship chain canceled a color advertising insert that was scheduled to appear in several big Sunday newspapers next weekend because it did not have the merchandise featured in the advertisements. Without a rescue, Macy must file for bankruptcy protection or risk be forced into involuntary bankruptcy because it cannot pay its suppliers or even meet its payroll.
"They're living literally hand to mouth," said one participant in the talks. "Cash that is coming in is barely enough to pay their daily operating expenses. They have no reserves."
A Macy spokesman declined yesterday to comment on the negotiations or the company's plans.
By voluntarily filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, Macy is almost certain to be able to borrow the cash it needs because debts incurred under court supervision would be first in line for repayment.
Suppliers, whose warehouses are holding back goods from the company until its financial condition becomes more certain, said yesterday that they wished the retailer would file for bankruptcy protection.
"Everyone has accepted there is going to be a bankruptcy, so let's just get on with it," said Bud Konheim, head of Nicole Miller Ltd., a mid-sized apparel manufacturer. "At this point they have zero other options because there are no more Tisches in the woods."
While the banks and insurance companies that lent Macy hundreds of millions of dollars generally hold valuable real estate as collateral, the many bondholders who helped finance the leveraged buyout of Macy in 1986 and later acquisitions are likely to suffer heavy losses. Those bonds are not backed by any collateral.
On Thursday, Mr. Tisch, whose family controls the Loews Corporation, proposed buying Macy for more than $1 billion and paying off its debt. But late Friday Loews abruptly announced that the talks broke off after it failed to reach an agreement with the Prudential Insurance Company of America, which holds an $811 million mortgage on about half of Macy's more than 140 department stores. Mr. Tisch wanted Prudential to agree to a lower interest rate than the mortgage calls for.
Some analysts said that the breakdown in the talks might be a sophisticated game of financial chicken between savvy companies and that Mr. Tisch might ultimately come back to the table.
As part of his plan, Mr. Tisch, through a Loews subsidiary, would have paid $740 million for Macy's publicly traded bonds and $80 million for virtually all of the equity. If the buyout deal had been completed, he would have then paid suppliers $200 million to $300 million.
With no deals to consider and none in sight, Macy lawyers and investment bankers were trying to put together a bankruptcy plan over the weekend. Remarkably, for a company of its size and sophistication, Macy is hurtling toward bankruptcy largely unprepared.
Lawyers and investment bankers are working feverishly to complete the necessary documents for a bankruptcy filing and as of yesterday Macy's representatives were still trying to put together a package of short-term financing for use after a bankruptcy filing -- to allow the retailer to continue to meet day-to-day expenses like utility bills, travel costs and payroll while a long-range reorganization is crafted.
Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's chairman and chief executive, was apparently so certain that the company would be saved from filing that he did not have the company's lawyers finish the temporary financing and bankruptcy documents. The talks for the financing were begun less than 10 days ago, even though a bankruptcy filing had been looming for months.
Several people close to the negotiations said they believed that Macy was desperately low on the cash and could no longer draw on a credit line that it had been using.
In a few months, Macy's situation has grown appreciably worse, as the nation's economic slump slowed consumer spending and the retailer's losses mounted. With its $3.6 billion in debt, Macy faces a regular series of multimillion-dollar interest payments, and it also is obligated to maintain certain levels of cash in the bank to qualify for its bank credit lines.
The Christmas shopping season, the most important season for retailers, was clearly a disappointment and left Macy short of its sales projections.
"Generally in these situations, the prudent course is to anticipate all possibilities and prepare for all eventualities, as unlikely as they may initially seem," said Harrison J. Goldin, a principal of Goldin Associates Inc., a financial consulting firm, and a former New York City Comptroller.
 
Some Talks to Continue
 With a bankruptcy filing almost certain, a host of large financial institutions that have been quietly negotiating to overhaul Macy's financial obligations will continue the discussions in bankruptcy court. They hope to get back much of the hundreds of millions that they invested in Macy.
The main bank group, led by Bankers Trust and Manufacturers Hanover, would be exposed to $700 million in debt after a bankruptcy filing, including a $420 million letter of credit that has not yet been drawn upon. Another bank group, led by the Swiss Bank Corporation, is owed about $560 million, has secured debt.
Prudential, the focus of Friday's negotiations with Mr. Tisch, is likely to try and get some interest on the $811 million mortgage it holds on Macy's stores. Although Prudential has fairly good collateral for its loans -- the stores -- like other creditors it will be hurt in a bankruptcy filing. At the very least, Prudential will not get the 12 percent interest that its mortgage calls for. In fact, it is not likely to get any interest on the note for several years.
In addition, the hundreds of individuals and institutions that bought Macy's high-yield bonds to finance the management-led buyout of the company in 1986 will become leading creditors in a bankruptcy proceeding.
Until now the bondholders have not organized, and have largely sat on the sidelines and watched as Macy renegotiated its bank credit lines 23 times and still failed to meet all its obligations. If the company does seek protection, analysts and those involved have said the bondholders will suffer the greatest losses because their debt is not backed by any collateral.
Altogether the bondholders hold roughly $1.3 billion of debt in three different classes of bonds that pay as much as 16.5 percent. The bonds, which sank to low levels before news of Mr. Tisch's offer, rebounded sharply once news of the deal was public. Some bonds that will come due in 1998 traded as high as 74 cents on the dollar after languishing at about 55 cents for many days before.
Prudential was one of the largest holders of Macy bonds along with many other life insurance companies and junk bond funds. It is unclear whether Prudential still holds any of the bonds.
Mr. Tisch was prepared to offer about 80 cents on the dollar for those bonds, people involved in the talks said. Now it is likely that those who hold the bonds will get substantially less after a settlement in bankruptcy court.
 
Expensive Pact With Insurer
 The rescue plan stumbled on Friday over Mr. Tisch's demand that Prudential grant better terms to Macy's on the $811 million mortgage. The Prudential debt is the largest of Macy's real estate-related debt and was very costly because of various provisions in the mortgage.
One person familiar with the terms of the mortgage said that even if the retailer had been able to find a lender to refinance the entire mortgage on better terms, the cost of buying Prudential out would have been close to $1 billion because of various agreements.
Prudential, whose loan is secured by the stores themselves, said it was not willing to cut the interest on the mortgage to a flat 9 percent from the present 12 percent, as Mr. Tisch wanted because it would have lost tens of millions of dollars in interest income. On the other hand, it is unlikely that the insurance giant could get even 9 percent interest on its loan if Macy's file for bankruptcy protection, although the principal is probably secure. In fact, it is not likely to get any interest on the notes while Macy's in bankruptcy. It is possible that the interest will be accrued and paid back after the company emerges from bankruptcy.
"We had many discussions with the Tisch organization and we were willing to bend and compromise to a certain point and beyond that it would not have been prudent for us," Frank McDougal, the president of the Prudential Mortgage Capital Company, said on Friday. Mr. McDougal said the company felt its principal was secure.
In addition, the bankruptcy court may allow Macy's to sell some stores to raise cash that could be used to reduce its debt, as the company had already planned to do. Although the stores that the company wants to sell are not the ones Prudential has as collateral for its loans, the overall effect could be to reduce the company's assets and its potential to fully repay all its debts.

HEADLINE: BUSH BUDGET SEEKS AID FOR CHILDREN AND END OF A TAX

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Sprinkling largess among diverse constituencies at the start of an election year, President Bush wants to repeal the luxury tax on yachts and will propose a substantial increase in the Federal budget for feeding and vaccinating poor children.
Confidential galley proofs of the budget, to be sent to Congress on Wednesday, show that Mr. Bush will also propose a doubling of Federal spending to control tuberculosis, as well as a public housing initiative to let tenants oust bad managers. 
 Administration officials describe repeal of the boat tax as a way to restore jobs lost in the maritime industry, and many Democrats support the proposal. Administration officials said they did not know if Mr. Bush would seek changes in the luxury taxes on other items like jewelry, furs, private aircraft and automobiles. Cadillac dealers are clamoring for repeal of the luxury tax on all items.
 
Criticism Overlooked
 The documents show Mr. Bush boasting that he would spend "$100 billion for children's programs, up 66 percent since 1989," the year he became President.
Though Mr. Bush now takes credit for the increase, he criticized appropriations for many of the same programs as excessive when they were approved by Congress. In this election year, Congress is likely to repeal the boat tax and to approve the extra money for children sought by Mr. Bush.
The coming week will be pivotal in Mr. Bush's Presidency. He has led people to expect that in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday and in his budget the next day he will unveil a coherent vision of the nation's future, a bold new health policy and an economic recovery plan to save millions of jobs, including his own.
With deadly outbreaks of tuberculosis reported in many states, Mr. Bush seeks $66 million for control of the disease in 1993, up from $32 million this year, the documents show.
 
For Once, Mitchell Agrees
 The boat tax proposal will be presented as part of Mr. Bush's campaign to promote economic growth and create jobs. The tax, enacted in 1990, was originally seen by Democrats as a way for the Government to extract revenue from people wealthy enough to buy boats costing more than $100,000.
But it adversely affected many craftsmen and artisans who lost jobs when boat sales slumped and boat builders went out of business. The 1990 law requires anyone who buys a new or imported boat with a retail price exceeding $100,000 to pay a 10 percent tax, formally known as a luxury tax, on the amount over $100,000. For a $300,000 boat, for example, the tax is $20,000.
The desirability of repealing the tax is one of the few economic questions on which President Bush agrees with Senator George J. Mitchell, the Democratic leader from Maine, a big boat-building state with a long coastline.
The boat tax could be seen as a parable of trickle-down economics. It "was slapped on there because people felt this is a way to get the rich guys," Mr. Bush said in August while on vacation in Maine. "What they forgot is, there's a lot of not-so-rich guys that build these boats."
 
Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
 Mr. Bush said then he feared that he might be criticized if he came out "in favor of relief for boats." But he insisted: "I'm talking jobs. I'm thinking of the people who are thrown out of work in these shipyards."
Likewise, Mr. Mitchell said on the Senate floor: "The welfare of luxury boat buyers is not our concern. Rather, our concern is the well-being of the many thousands of Americans who work in the boat manufacturing and sales industry."
At a Senate hearing in June, Kenneth W. Gideon, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy, said, "We do not support repeal of the luxury boat excise tax at this time." But since then, members of Congress and Administration officials say evidence of the tax's adverse effect on the boat industry has become clearer.
 
Where Doctors Are Scarce
 Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, which builds more yacht hulls than any other state, said the tax was supposed to raise $148 million over five years. But he said the cost far exceeds the benefits because the Government is losing income and payroll taxes and must pay unemployment compensation to workers laid off by boat builders. Many Democrats and some labor unions now support repeal of the boat tax.
Stung by Democratic charges that he neglected the home front while focusing on foreign affairs over the last three years, Mr. Bush will propose substantial increases in public health and child welfare programs.
These include childhood immunization (up 18 percent from last year, to $349 million); efforts to combat infant mortality (up 18 percent, to $9.4 billion); the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC (up 9 percent, to $2.8 billion), and community health centers (up 15 percent, to $684 million).
The $100 billion for children, as calculated by Mr. Bush, includes Social Security, Medicaid, public assistance and education programs.
Mr. Bush will seek a total of $120 million for the National Health Service Corps, which places doctors in rural areas and inner-city neighborhoods where physicians are in short supply. That represents an increase of 19 percent for the corps.
The corps' budget was slashed by the Reagan Administration, which predicted in 1981 that the problems of access to basic health care would be "virtually eliminated within the next few years due to growth in the nation's supply of physicians."
 
'Perestroika in Public Housing'
 Daniel R. Hawkins Jr., policy director for the National Association of Community Health Centers, said events over the last decade disproved that prediction. Mr. Hawkins said the $90 million increase for health centers sought by Mr. Bush would be the biggest rise in 15 years. The 550 health centers that receive money from the Federal Government serve six million people a year. Mr. Hawkins said that one million additional people could be served with the extra money.
Mr. Bush says his budget contains "the largest one-year increase ever proposed" for the WIC program, a rise of $240 million, and he says this would allow "full participation by eligible pregnant women and infants."
Edward M. Cooney, deputy director of the Food Research and Action Center, a research and advocacy group, said today that $100 million was needed just to cover the increase in prices for items in the food package for pregnant women and young children. He said the increase sought by Mr. Bush was "a step in the right direction, but terribly inadequate" to feed all those eligible. The program now serves 5.3 million of the 8.7 million people eligible, he said.
Mr. Bush's budget also proposes a "perestroika in public housing initiative." The name alludes to Soviet efforts at political and economic restructuring. Under the proposal, tenants of public housing could vote to transfer control of particularly shabby projects to new managers.
 
30 Percent of Units
 Alfred A. DelliBovi, Deputy Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said this proposal would let tenants replace managers who do not fix the elevators and do not provide adequate heat and security for the residents.
Robert Y. Nelson Jr., executive director of the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials, denounced the proposal, saying the decay of public housing results not from mismanagement, but from "a lack of Federal money and a lack of Federal attention."
Mr. DelliBovi said the proposal would apply to any local agency that was on a Federal list of "troubled public housing authorities" for more than three years. The list now contains 23 local agencies with about 30 percent of all public housing units. It includes housing authorities in Atlanta, Boston, Bridgeport, Conn., Camden, N.J., Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles, Newark, New Haven, New Orleans, Philadelphia and San Francisco.
Mr. DelliBovi said the New York City Housing Authority was not on the list because it was very well managed. "If you can do it in a difficult urban environment like New York, you can do it anywhere," he said.

HEADLINE: The 1992 Campaign: Republicans;
Bush Camp's Primary Fear: A Buchanan Moral Victory

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 25

 BODY:
Ron Christian, the tax collector in the town of Peterborough, southwest of here, is a George Bush man. He voted for Mr. Bush in the Republican Presidential primary four years ago and thinks he has "done a good job in the White House," especially in the Persian Gulf war.
"But I'd be interested in hearing what George is going to do for the economy in general and for jobs in New England in particular," he said on Friday as he waited for Barbara Bush to arrive for a campaign appearance. "He let the economy get away from him. It's important for him to come to New Hampshire to talk to us." 
 Voters like Mr. Christian trouble former Gov. Hugh Gregg, the Bush campaign's 74-year-old eminence grise, who is the father of the current Governor, Judd Gregg, the President's state campaign manager.
"There are a lot of people out there who are Bush people, who will be Bush people again in the fall, but who won't vote for him in the primary," the elder Mr. Gregg said. "They're fed up with professional politicians. Or they blame him for the economic troubles. Or they think he spends too much time on other countries' problems."
 
Buchanan as a Protest
 The candidacy of Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist and broadcaster, provides an ideal vehicle for a protest vote, and Mr. Gregg said that Mr. Buchanan "will do extremely well, not because of what he says but because of all the discontent and because they all know Pat from TV."
Judd Gregg is willing to concede Mr. Buchanan 30 percent of the vote, simply on the basis of the exuberant support of The Manchester Union Leader, the state's biggest and most idiosyncratic newspaper. Former President Richard M. Nixon says Mr. Buchanan, who worked for him as a White House speech writer, ought to get 40 percent. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, a conservative Republican who was here the other day to campaign for Mr. Bush, put Mr. Buchanan's probable vote even higher, at 45 percent.
All of those figures are part of the expectations game, as it has come to be known. The Bush forces do not want the impression to take hold that a strong but unsuccessful Buchanan showing constitutes a moral victory over the arrayed power of the White House and the state's Republican leaders. But there is no doubt that Mr. Buchanan has made striking progress here.
Tom Rath, a former State Attorney General who ran Senator Bob Dole's losing campaign against Mr. Bush in 1988, says the President needs to turn the challenger's argument on its head. Mr. Buchanan urges New Hampshire voters to "send a message" of discontent; Mr. Rath wants Mr. Bush to ask them to send a message of support in his battles with the Democrats in Congress on economic issues.
 
Bush Spurns Debate
 " 'I need your vote as a political mandate' -- that's the approach," Mr. Rath said, "because Congress is much less popular than he is."
Mr. Bush has been in New Hampshire once, apologizing for the state of the economy and promising to do better. He has ignored invitations to debate Mr. Buchanan, and he will return to the state, where pavement-pounding politics is a tradition, only twice more, on Feb. 12 and 15. Mr. Buchanan will be in New Hampshire six days out of seven between now and the primary, on Feb. 18.
For the most part, the job for Mr. Bush will have to be done by surrogates like Mrs. Bush, Mr. Gingrich, Vice President Dan Quayle and Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and by radio and television commercials. The first television advertisements went on the air this weekend, 30-second messages featuring the President declaring earnestly: "We've known each other for a long time. This state has gone through hell. I've seen the pain in people's eyes, and I'm determined to turn this state around."
 
Mrs. Bush's Comforting Words
 Mr. Bush and his aides are trying to reconnect. They are trying to attack the notion that he has forgotten New Hampshire in its hour of need after it propelled him toward the White House by giving him a much-needed victory in the 1988 primary.
Describing her husband as "a spectacular President" and admonishing those who have lost their jobs to "hang in there, do the right thing and don't panic," Mrs. Bush said in Peterborough: "I was and I am in awe of the way that he handled the gulf crisis and himself. The same man is handling the economic crisis -- with the same steady nerves. I assure you that you will get the same results."
But hard-hit people here want specifics, not just warm fuzzies.
Several voters interviewed in thelast few days said they would wait to see what Mr. Bush had to say in his much-ballyhooed State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, exactly three weeks before the primary. One of them, a Milford antique dealer, expressed the conviction that "unless he does something really surprising, really bold, people will let him have it."
Mr. Buchanan is trying to encourage that reaction. He predicted last week that the President's proposals would be "anemic and pathetic."
Governor Gregg said "it was a mistake" for Mr. Bush to accept higher taxes in a budget deal with Congress, and he conceded that the deal made the President's road here rockier.
"But that's history," he said. "What we have to do now is convince Republicans and independents -- the people who can vote in our primary -- that there is only one real Republican candidate for President. You may be unhappy about how things are going, probably are, but only one guy on the ballot can straighten it out."
 
Pushing a Wasted Vote
 Such comments are part of an effort to make New Hampshire Republicans believe that a vote for Mr. Buchanan is a wasted vote. For the moment, the message is implicit. But before the campaign is over, a member of the President's brain trust said, "You're going to see commercials that say, 'New Hampshire picks Presidents.Don't throw away your vote on someone who has no chance of being elected.' "
There are already radio commercials in which former Senator Gordon J. Humphrey and Senator Bob Smith extol Mr. Bush's conservative credentials, which Mr. Buchanan derides. "I fought side by side with this conservative President," Mr. Humphrey says.
In the end, Mr. Bush's greatest asset may be the organization that he and the Greggs, his longtime supporters, have been putting together and nurturing here since 1978. Despite a late start this time, the Bush forces have signed up coordinators in every one of the state's 300-odd towns and wards, and they have the support of most members of the Legislature, too.
Mr. Buchanan's supporters will turn out come snow or high water, politicians here say; the danger to Mr. Bush is that his less highly motivated backers will stay home, thus magnifying the impact of his challenger's vote. The Gregg organization should help to overcome that problem, as it did four years ago against the challenge of Mr. Dole.
Just to make sure that everything is working as expected, the campaign has planned what it calls a "Bush blitz" next weekend. Mr. Quayle will speak to hundreds of volunteers from all over the state, and they will then go door to door, trying to recruit undecided voters -- a major logistical exercise that demonstrates how seriously political professionals like the Greggs take Mr. Buchanan's challenge to Mr. Bush.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "What we have to do now is convince Republicans and independents -- the people who can vote in our primary -- that there is only one real Republican candidate for President," said Gov. Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, the President's state campaign manager. Governor Gregg, seen under umbrella, waited with Barbara Bush's entourage as she campaigned earlier this week in Dublin. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
