SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 28; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 733 words

HEADLINE: While Bridge Is Fixed, Businesses Waste Away

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
Arkady Osnis stood in his small shoe-repair shop in Kew Gardens, Queens, and rued the ruinous impact of the big project outside his door. "Business is 30 to 40 percent lower," he said, fretting about how much longer he could survive.
Across the street on the torn-up block of Lefferts Boulevard, Ruth and Aleta Vahlsing said that plunging patronage had already driven them to shut their gift and candy shop. The mother and daughter dolefully de-nuded their shelves and packed up picture frames, ceramics and other gift items. 
 The project so baneful to Mr. Osnis and the Vahlsings -- and to the two dozen other merchants on their block in a solid, middle-class Kew Gardens neighborhood -- is the city's rehabilitation of a deteriorated old bridge that carries Lefferts Boulevard over tracks of the Long Island Rail Road.
The top of the 180-foot-long bridge forms most of the block of Lefferts Boulevard from Austin Street to 83d Avenue. At street level, the block's unusual foundation is not readily apparent. One- and two-story buildings line both sides, with shops that sell food, clothing, newspapers and cosmetics and that launder clothes, cut hair and rent videos.
It is the kind of mercantile melange that adds texture as well as trade to many neighborhoods in the city.
"This block is like a little village," Arthur J. Cooperman, an area resident, said. "People who live here consider it a focal point of the community."
But the 83-year-old bridge is in dire need of overhaul, the New York City Transportation Department says. Since last June, when the agency began what it said would be a $2.9 million, 15-month job to replace the bridge's steel girders and deck beams and rebuild the concrete surface, the block has been transformed into a snarl of traffic barriers and chain-link fences.
Sidewalks have been scrunched to four-foot widths. Parking has been abolished. Cars and trucks squeeze through two temporary narrow lanes; the briefest pause knots traffic and prompts a symphony of honks.
In short, it is a stretch bothersome to negotiate and best to avoid, which is precisely what many people are doing. The result, the block's merchants say, is thattheir businesses are in peril, with four already closed.
Such straits are not unheard of in a city where renewal and regeneration is a theme. But lack of uniqueness does not lighten the bleakness for the Lefferts Boulevard business people.
Especially galling, some recently said, is that for nearly three months, from late October until mid-January, all major work on the project halted because of what the city says was a design error.
The mistake caused the new girders to be an inch too high and they had to be returned to the shop for adjustment, said Joseph DePlasco, a Transportation Department spokesman. The result, he said, is that the coveted return to normality will take three months longer than originally contemplated. It is now expected next December -- assuming no further snafus. This the shopkeepers are not assuming.
"How could they make the wrong measurement?" Mr. Osnis demanded, eyes wide with disbelief.
By relying on the bridge's original drawings, Mr. DePlasco said.
In Frank's Gourmet Deli, Frank Delenda, the owner, was skeptical of the entire project.
"This is a scam," he insisted. "Guys working on the job say they didn't have to do all this, that they only had to repair the concrete."
Not so, Mr. DePlasco replied. "The bridge was in a severe state of deterioration," he said.
Mr. Delenda ticked off the fatalities among merchants so far -- a florist, a women's clothing store, a manicurist and the Vahlsings' candy and gift shop -- and said, "I might be going too."
"Yesterday I took in $385 all day from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M.," he said. Before the bridge work, he said, he would gross $800 on a "very bad" day.
Merchants said the recession had hurt them slightly, but was not the reason for their plight. And although the Long Island Rail Road, the landlord on most of the block, has temporarily cut rents in half, the shopkeepers said this was not enough to matter.
The merchants are not the only ones pained by the prospect that as the bridge is restored, its street is de-stored.
Mr. Cooperman, the local resident, recalled his reaction when he recently passed the Vahlsings' place. "When I saw it was closed," he said of the longtime local fixture, "It was so sad."

The project began last June and was scheduled to take 15 months. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Year Later, Hellfighters Feel Forgotten

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
Like many other Harlem Hellfighters, Sgt. Joe Bradford has found that, one year later, his service in the Persian Gulf war with the famous New York Army National Guard unit holds little cachet with the public.
Mr. Bradford was a truck driver in New York before he was mobilized. His company relocated while he was away, so now he is now unemployed. Eight months ago he passed the postal exam to become a mail handler, but so far he has not heard a word. 
 "Angry is not the word to describe how I feel," said Mr. Bradford, 41 years old, a divorced father of four. "We weren't sitting on our thumbs over there. We did a damn good job. I'd think they would have given us a little more recognition than we've gotten."
There is a lot of talk like this these days at the 369th Regiment Armory, the base of the Harlem Hellfighters, a noted unit that dates to 1913. The Hellfighters helped to make history in the sands of Saudi Arabia, but many of its members now believe they have become forgotten casualties at home.
The scorecard of what happened to the Hellfighters after they returned home from eight months of service is familiar to others who served in n Desert Storm. Battalion officials said several of the 350 veterans lost their jobs, seven others lost out on job promotions, and two soldiers learned that their spouses had left them.
The armory -- an aging structure with high ceilings and shiny floors at Fifth Avenue and 142d Street, lined with photographs of the battalion's heroes -- is now a place where about 15 unemployed veterans have been given busy work. They are changing tires, fixing parts and painting military trucks.
Most of the members of the transportation unit based here are middle-aged bus drivers, police officers and Civil Service workers. Roughly one fourth are women. None suffered serious war-related injuries during war service.
One of the three companies that make up the Harlem Hellfighters, the 719th Transportation Company, had complained on the eve of the war that they were stripped of their vehicles and men and posted near the Iraqi border without adequate training. A Pentagon investigation found no irregularities.
Since the war, as veterans have tried to move on with their lives, that issue too has receded. "It was a concern but they've gotten over it," said Capt. Renwick Payne. "They did the jobs they had to do and returned."
In honor of their performance, the "forgotten soldiers"-- as they became known -- were presented with an award by the 101st Corps support group, to which they were assigned.
Many of the veterans marched in New York's homecoming parade last June and later in an African-American Day parade in Harlem. They were honored at City Hall. They were showered with awards, headlines and congratulatory speeches.
"Folks are still very much aware and proud that a piece of Harlem was in the war, and as the expression goes, 'Done Good,' " said the battalion commander, Lieut. Col. Francis W. Kairson Jr.
But for many veterans, the glow from the war has been replaced with the reality of everyday life and the knowledge that America has a short memory for their wartime efforts.
Dennis Holder, 21, remembers the blank looks of prospective employers as he went from one unemployment office to the next upon his return.
Only recently did he find employment. He works two part-time jobs, one counting and repairing ammunition in the armory and one preparing supermarket orders in a food warehouse.
"I figured since I was over there, I'd been making sacrifices for my country and I'd at least get a job," Mr. Holder said recently in the armory, as he helped move furniture. "It's been harder to find a job than ever. It upsets me sometimes but that's life."
Specialist Patricia Carden, 40, a truck driver at the armory, wishes the war's luster would shine on forever. Sergeant Carden, the mother of two grown children, said that some men thought she would be too fragile to do the work when she was mobilized for war, but she soon proved them wrong.
She said she was jubilant at the homecoming parade and flattered by the attention from friends and strangers. She was sent a silk scarf by a French woman who had heard her on a radio talk show.
Sergeant Bradford said he wanted to try to resurrect those good feelings. Last night he oversaw a Desert Storm disco at the armory, which he hopes will be an annual event. He sent out fliers for the disco and, yesterday, as he supervised arrangements for the party, he said he had sold about 175 tickets.
"It's something to look forward to, something to do," he said. "I don't want to sit around and bite my nails."

Specialist Patricia Carden prepared time sheets for the soldiers. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
MacPhail Isn't Fazed by the Championship Hype

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The last time a championship game was played at the Metrodome in Minneapolis, Andy MacPhail was sitting in the stands with a vested interest. He became especially ecstatic when Dan Gladden stepped on the plate with the only run in the 10-inning Game 7 of the World Series.
MacPhail, general manager of the Minnesota Twins, plans to be at the Metrodome today, but only as a curious observer. 
 "My wife wants to go," he said. "I've been to one Super Bowl, but she hasn't. It's like going to Times Square on New Year's Eve. You ought to do it once."
The Twins have won the World Series twice in the last five years, which gives MacPhail a different perspective on championship games than most people have. He doesn't need that special insight, though, to compare the World Series and the Super Bowl.
"It's a very, very different type of event," MacPhail said of the Super Bowl. "I have images of the World Series: tomahawk-chopping fans in Atlanta, hanky-waving fans in Minneapolis. When you have a game at a neutral site, the focus shifts from community and home team to corporate parties and hoopla. It's just a whole different culture. No doubt about it, baseball has it all over football in the post-season. With this, there's more action surrounding the game than the game itself. I can see that just looking out my window."
MacPhail did not spend all of his time looking out the window last week. He has a championship to defend, and he was busy trying to shore up the Twins' corps of starting pitchers. "A front office in baseball can get a lot more accomplished when attention is focused elsewhere," he said. "We've been trying to accomplish some things behind the scenes, but we haven't done it."
MacPhail said he had some interest in Scott Bankhead, but the injury-plagued pitcher, who became a free agent when the Seattle Mariners did not tender him a contract, signed with Cincinnati. MacPhail was also considering Eric King, who had a similar experience with Cleveland, "but we terminated that because the interest didn't seem to be there on his part."
The Twins lost out on Bankhead, MacPhail said, because they were reluctant to give him a major league contract, and the Reds did. "That was a risk we really didn't think was worth taking at this point, even though there is some potential on the upside," the general manager said. "We were surprised that the team that signed him did because they had enough pitching."
MacPhail said he also thought about Jim Deshaies and Doug Jones, but Jones signed with Houston and Deshaies was close to signing elsewhere. That leaves Bill Krueger and Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, he said.
"I would like to bring one of them in," he added.
Krueger poses an interesting question for the Twins. A free agent whom the Mariners have let go because of the uncertainty of their ownership, the left-hander had a disastrous performance against the Twins last season, allowing 15 runs and 21 hits in 10 innings for a 0-2 record and a 13.50 earned run average.
"Your staff sees him get hammered, and it's hard for them to generate enthuiasm for him," MacPhail said. But, he noted, subtract those numbers from his overall record, and he had an 11-6 mark with a 3.00 e.r.a.
MacPhail wants to add a veteran pitcher because Jack Morris (35 starts) has defected to Toronto and the Twins have let Allen Anderson (22) depart as a free agent. Kevin Tapani and Scott Erickson return from last year's rotation, Mark Guthrie will return to the rotation and a fourth starter will be selected from a group of younger or less established pitchers: David West, Willie Banks, Denny Neagle, Mike Trombley, Paul Abbott and Pat Mahomes.
The Twins would rather not take two from Column B, which leaves MacPhail rolling out and trying to sack a veteran.
 
The Northwest Mariners?
 The Japanese want to buy the Seattle Mariners, but major league officials don't want to sell to them. Jeff Smulyan, the Mariners' overwhelmed owner, wants to move the team to Florida, but major league officials want to keep the team in Seattle. Will Glasgow has a third option, but major league officials don't like that one either.
Glasgow, a Portland, Ore., lawyer whose thinking seems to be more solid than fanciful, has proposed turning the Mariners into a Northwest regional team. Under Glasgow's plan, the Cascadia Mariners, one possible name, would play 15 games each in Portland and Vancouver and the other 51 home games in Seattle.
"The impact would be to turn the Mariners into the fourth largest regional market," Glasgow said, noting that Seattle alone is No. 14 on the market list. "Regionalization could add $10 million to $20 million to the Mariners' revenue base and could make them one of the stronger franchises in baseball."
One of the Mariners' major economic problems is their almost-negligible local television revenue. By playing games in Portland and Vancouver, Glasgow said, that income would grow significantly because fans in those two cities and surrounding areas in Oregon and British Columbia would identify with the team and want to watch it.
Not only could Mariner road games be televised to those areas, but games played in Seattle could also be shown. Conversely, games played in Portland and Vancouver could be shown in Seattle without affecting attendance.
As another means of increasing revenue, Glasgow projected, the 15 games at Portland's 25,000-seat stadium would be sellouts, and because a limited number of games would be played, the ticket prices could be higher, perhaps double the range in Seattle. Vancouver has a 50,000-seat domed stadium.
Whatever drawbacks officials might see, the lawyer said, "none of the issues seem to be inherently insurmountable."
"You'd think they would have interest in strengthening the franchise and expanding the Mariners' revenue," he said.
 
Call 1-900-CONTRACT
 When four of the best pitchers in salary arbitration submitted figures between $4 million and $5 million, Al Harazin, the Mets' general manager, suggested their action had been part of an orchestrated deal. But if the players' agents and the Players Association conferred among themselves, it was an idea they learned from the Player Relations Committee and the general managers.
During the time the second free-agent collusion case was before the arbitrator, the players' lawyers learned that during arbitration time, management had been having weekly 26-club conference calls on which they discussed eligible players, offers, numbers to submit and settlements.
The union questioned the practice, but the clubs' lawyers noted that unlike its position on concerted action against free agents, the collective-bargaining agreement had no such provision about arbitration-eligible players.
Until then, some agents recalled, the union had not given them information on numbers other agents had submitted or were considering submitting. But in 1990, the union began sharing numbers. The clubs, meanwhile, have apparently stopped the weekly telephone sessions.
"In years past they had these 26-club conference calls, but we have not done it," said Charles O'Connor, general counsel for the Player Relations Committee. "This year, we have had smaller calls. What really takes place, both on the union and our side, is there are discussions regarding submission numbers. On both sides, the number requested is the number the player wants and the club wants, but there are attempts to get people to look at comparable players in terms of years and performance to maximize the opportunity to win."
 
The Olympic Connection
 Peter Ueberroth became baseball commissioner after heading the Los Angeles Olympics in 1984. George Steinbrenner chose a lifetime ban on his role as Yankees' managing partner rather than take a two-year suspension because he was concerned that a "suspension" would affect his position on the United States Olympic Committee. Now, somewhere in between those two extremes, Marty Appel becomes the latest official to travel between baseball and the Olympics.
Nearly 20 years ago, Appel was the second of nine men who have served as the Yankees' media-relations director during the Steinbrenner regime. More recently, he has been executive producer of local Yankees telecasts. Now, after 11 years with the local television station, he moves to the Olympics as public-relations director for the 1996 Summer Games in Atlanta.
There, he will be reunited with an Atlanta businessman, Ron Blomberg, a name from the Yankees' past. And he may, once in a while, even run into Steinbrenner, a name from their past, present and undoubtedly future.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
When Mantle Had to Battle for a Raise

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
WHILE the nation's economy dwindles, baseball's economy still soars upward.
For hitting 18 homers, driving in 66 runs and batting .259 for the Chicago White Sox last season, Dan Pasqua, once a Yankee outfielder, recently signed a three-year, $6 million contract. And in the first season of his three-year, $6 million contract, Franklin Stubbs of the Milwaukee Brewers batted .213, hit 11 homers and drove in 38 runs. 
 So much for the ratio of salary to performance when the fourth-violinist theory doesn't exist.
At a Frank Sinatra concert, he gets the big money. He's the attraction. He sells the tickets. The fourth violinist is happy with union scale. But in baseball, the fourth violinist still gets millions.
"It's unbelievable," Mickey Mantle was saying.
Mickey Mantle wasn't begrudging today's players their millions; he was just wishing he was wearing a Yankee uniform now. Consider that his 1960 pinstriped Yankee shirt was auctioned for $111,000 at Leland's last week. Consider that his uniform shirt with a 7 on the back is now worth more without him in it than it ever was with him in it.
Mantle's highest salary was $100,000, a plateau he didn't attain until 1963, his 13th season.
"And after they put me up to $100,000," he recalled, "I never asked for another raise."
At age 60, Mickey Mantle's job is being Mickey Mantle. He's a baseball icon. He gets top dollar at autograph shows. He gets stares and smiles and standing ovations. Last Wednesday, he was in his West 59th Street restaurant, promoting a new watch. Thursday night he was honored with Willie Mays and Duke Snider at the Baseball Assistance Team dinner at the Marriott Marquis.
He remembered coming here in January in other years, stopping at the Yankee offices on Fifth Avenue, only a long home run from where his restaurant is now. On those visits, he had to battle for a raise from George Weiss, the Yankee general manager through much of the center fielder's career. His struggle typified what life was like before free agency.
In his Triple Crown season in 1956, the 25-year-old slugger led the American League with a .353 average, 52 homers and 130 runs batted in: a troika that today's players only dream about.
"I wanted to double my salary from the $32,500 I made in 1956," he recalled. "But when I asked Weiss for $65,000, he told me I was too young to make that kind of money. Then he threatened to show my wife reports from private detectives he had gumshoe me and Billy Martin. He threatened to trade me to Cleveland for Herb Score and Rocky Colavito."
Weiss wouldn't budge, but Del Webb, then a Yankee co-owner, agreed to meet Mantle's price.
"Weiss never forgot," Mantle said. "After the 1957 season, he tried to cut me $5,000."
Mantle had batted .365 with 34 homers while driving in 94 runs. He eventually signed for $75,000 for 1958, a $10,000 raise. But when he batted .304 with 42 homers and 97 runs batted in, Weiss opened their 1959 negotiations by offering only $65,000, a $10,000 cut. Mantle demanded $85,000 and eventually accepted a token $2,000 raise to $77,000.
Over his first eight seasons, the Yankees had been in seven World Series, winning five. When the Yankees slipped to third place in 1959, Weiss pounced. His first offer called for a $17,000 cut and Mantle accepted a $10,000 slice to $67,000.
But after the 1960 season, Weiss retired from the Yankees before organizing the expansion Mets. By 1963, the Mick finally had his $100,000 contract, only to break his left foot in a tangle with a chain-link fence in Baltimore early that season. On his return, he hit his longest Yankee Stadium homer, off the facade below the right-field roof.
Win or lose after that, he never earned less than $100,000, or more for that matter.
But if the Mick were playing today, if he were a free agent after a Triple Crown season, if he were available to the highest bidder, if Bobby Bonilla was worth $29 million to the Mets over five years and if Danny Tartabull was worth $25.5 million to the Yankees over five years, how much would the Mick be worth?
At least $50 million over five years. And at that price, he'd be a bargain.
But this is now and that was then. Mickey Mantle must be satisfied with being an icon in an era when baseball owners still haven't realized that while proven attractions are worth whatever they can command, fourth violinists should be getting union scale.
"When I played, the players were dumb," the Mick said. "Now the owners are."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The baseball hero Mickey Mantle outside his New York restaurant. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The High Costs of Xenophobia

 BODY:
Japan-bashing has suddenly become a frenzy, at a terrible toll to America's best interests. In one short week: A Japanese offer to help Seattle keep major league baseball was doused with cold water by Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent. Los Angeles County canceled its order for Japanese mass-transit rail cars. And the town council of Greece, N.Y., voted not to buy a used Japanese dirt mover.
Everyone benefits from free and open international commerce. But while Japan's cars and electronic gear have been a boon to American consumers, its barriers to foreign products and investment are an endless frustration to Americans who want to do business there. 
 Washington and Japan have dueled over trade and investment for most of a decade. Except for a few distinct groups like auto workers, however, the friction has not gripped intense public emotion. The recession and election-year politics have clearly changed that.
Prolonged sluggishness in the U.S. economy, the upward creep of unemployment and a run of huge layoffs have made America job-conscious. Every Japanese car sold here, even if it's made in Ohio, has come to symbolize fewer American jobs. Politicians in Washington, Los Angeles and upstate New York see public resentment rising and react accordingly. In election campaigns it is always easier to blame foreign foes for problems than to admit one's own shortcomings.
As the nation's leader, President Bush set the tone with his crude emphasis on promoting jobs when he traveled to Tokyo this month with a legion of top-dollar C.E.O.'s. While the Speaker of Japan's lower house, Yoshio Sakurauchi, didn't help matters with his unwarranted scorn for "lazy" American workers last weekend, he can hardly be blamed for all that's happened since.
First, the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission reversed its decision to buy 87 mass-transit cars from the Sumitomo Corporation for $122 million, rather than from an American company for $5 million less. The wholly rational reason to pick Sumitomo was experience; it supplied the cars for the first phase of the county's new mass-transit system, on time and on budget.
Last week, faced with angry demands for more jobs in southern California, the commission scratched the Sumitomo deal and foolishly set out in a risky new direction; it's going to set up its own car plant and lease it to manufacturers. Does the county commission seriously believe it can succeed where American industry has long since been outpaced by Japan, Canada and Europe?
Meanwhile, in Seattle, local business interests -- led by Nintendo of America's president, a Seattle resident for 15 years -- offered to buy the Mariners baseball team for $100 million; Nintendo's Japanese owners would put up 60 percent. The Mariners' owner, who lives in Indianapolis, wants to sell and threatens to move the team out if he can't.
Business leaders and the state's leading politicians are behind the local offer, but the baseball commissioner clings to a xenophobic notion that major league owners should be exclusively North American, even though the Mariners' owner is a distant absentee, more than 2,000 miles away in the Midwest. If the team's next home is St. Petersburg, Fla., it will be Seattle's loss, not Nintendo's.
In Greece, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester, it's the same story with yet another twist. A used Komatsu excavator, made by the Komatsu Dresser Company, a U.S.-Japanese joint venture in Illinois, costs $15,000 less than the John Deere model. What's more, the Komatsu was made in America of mostly American parts, whereas the John Deere, with an American engine, was made in Japan. In upstate New York, labels apparently outweigh facts.
Los Angeles, Seattle and Greece -- three communities, each with its own concerns. But three rebuffs for Japan in a single week are no coincidence. It's an ominous sign that Americans, caught up in the misery of a short-term recession, are losing sight of the long-term benefits of foreign trade.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 454 words

HEADLINE: How the Japanese Learned to Drink Bourbon;
Corporate Complacency

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The outcome of the recent United States trade mission to Japan and the forceful statements of the American auto industry executives who participated recalls my experiences in the early 1960's at Forbes Inc. 
 As a project supervisor for automobile market research studies, I handled accounts of the Japanese International Trade Association and of the Ford Motor Company. Our study findings exploded certain treasured myths regarding the predominance of American technology and the expropriation of that technology by foreign manufacturers.
Nearly 35 years ago the Japanese approached Forbes Marketing Research (a Forbes Inc. subsidiary) to conduct a comprehensive yearlong study on the feasibility of expanding exports of their two- and four-wheeled vehicles to the United States. The study examined consumer satisfaction with Japanese, European and American vehicles in the California market, where the Japanese had begun to have some limited success; it outlined the American marketing profiles and the technology advances of British, German and Italian auto exporters, and analyzed the tariff and protectionist implications.
The Japanese trade officials were concerned also about anti-Japanese sentiment among the American public as well as about the quality image of Japanese manufacturing among young Americans, at whom marketing efforts would be aimed.
The study results were widely published in Japanese business journals of the early 1960's, but were not picked up by the American press. Among the key findings were:
* California consumer satisfaction was so positive that serious consideration of a national marketing approach was recommended.
* Most of the United States patents for new automotive technology issued in the 1950's and early 1960's were for developments made by British, German and Italian manufacturers, not by American manufacturers.
This new automotive technology was being tested on European Grand Prix circuits during a long period of U.S. hibernation in the areas of automotive research and development.
As part of the study, I interviewed several outspoken American automotive executives, including a plant production manager of the Chrysler Corporation, who told me: "You don't understand automotive economics and the taste for large American cars. The more metal you sell, the more profit you make."
American automotive executives and engineers may indeed not be stupid, as Lee Iacocca said recently in their defense, but a pattern of complacency, limited vision and inflexibility over the last 40 years has certainly contributed to their current crisis.
 
HAROLD S. FLEMING
New York, Jan. 12, 1992
 
The writer is a retired Foreign Service Officer.

HEADLINE: The 1992 Campaign: Democrats;
Candidates Court Jackson Supporters

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Six Democratic Presidential candidates met with the Rev. Jesse Jackson's National Rainbow Coalition today, hoping to tap the grass-roots support that fueled Mr. Jackson's own 1988 bid for the nomination.
But if any hoped to capture the whole rainbow, he was disappointed, as support was fragmented. All the candidates had a similar message but spent considerable time trying to demonstrate their differences, and that led to some prickly responses. 
 Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas was booed when he spoke in support of right-to-work laws. Edmund G. Brown Jr., former Governor of California, swiped at Mr. Clinton by calling for a moment of silence for a man whom the Governor allowed to be executed in Arkansas on Friday night. And Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska got enthusiastic applause for his national health care plan.
Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, outlined his tough-love economic message. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa captivated the audience with his unabashedly liberal oratory, and Eugene McCarthy, the former Senator from Wisconsin, told charming stories of his previous runs for President.
 
Thoughts on Candidates
 Among the roughly 500 delegates, there were those who said they liked the message of Mr. Brown but said they did not think he was electable. Others said they thought Mr. Clinton looked and sounded presidential but wondered if questions about his personal life could harm him in voters' eyes. Still others said they thought that Senator Kerrey, with his emphasis on health care and his personal attractiveness, looked like a winner.
But as Mr. Jackson pointed out, immediate support was not the reason for the forum. The coalition will not endorse any particular candidate, though Mr. Jackson said he would endorse a candidate at some point in the future.
"This is the broadest based forum the candidates can appear before," Mr. Jackson said. "Here you have mayors of big cities and small, women, Hispanics, gays, Native Americans asking the questions. These are the people who have to be energized and I think there has been a message gap in the debates. My sense is that people are looking for concrete plans."
 
Panel Questions Candidates
 Each of the candidates gave a short speech and was then questioned by a panel of labor, civic and education experts and officials.
The forum was held in an auditorium at the Omni Shoreham Hotel here.
Mr. Brown got a standing ovation for his support of statehood for the District of Columbia and his suggestion that Mr. Jackson would make a good running mate. But afterward several delegates who said they agreed with many of Mr. Brown's views expressed doubt that he could be elected.
"I like Brown's philosophy, but, really, who is going to vote for him?" said Mel Fallis, a vice president of marketing for American Visions magazine.
Mr. Clinton's presentation was upbeat and appeared to capture the audience's attention, until he ran into criticism for his positions on a middle-class tax cut, the death penalty and support for right-to-work laws.
Mr. Clinton defended his support for a tax cut for middle-class taxpayers, saying that only by expanding the middle class could the poor be helped. And he seemed to win the sympathy of the audience when he talked about his emotional turmoil when he decided to allow the execution of Rickey Ray Rector, a black mentally impaired murderer, to proceed.
Mr. Clinton, however, ran afoul of some members of the audience when he said he would not oppose right-to-work laws. He said that the issue was divisive and that it was one of the reasons that Democrats had not won recent Presidential elections. A handful of people stood up and booed and then walked out of the hall.
"He can forget about support from trade unionists," said Ron Richardson, vice president of the Hotel Employees Restaurant Employees International Union, who had asked the question.
Mr. Kerrey, who spoke about education, health care and his experience in the Vietnam War, appeared to win the most enthusiasm from the audience.
"His platform is more about my concerns," said Andre Thompson, from Glen Arden, Md., who said he was put off by Mr. Clinton's smooth delivery. "He's too plastic."
Mr. Tsongas gave his economic bootstrapping message, something that appealed to Christine Welch, a representative of the American Federation of Government Employees. "He's truthful," she said. "He's upfront."
Mr. Harkin lashed out at Republicans in general and President Bush in particular, promising that if he won the Democratic nomination he would not hold Mr. Bush's "feet to the fire" in the general election campaign.
"I'm going to put his feet in fire," he said, adding, "I'm going to make them accountable for the despair and the depression we have in the land."
Mr. Harkin also took Mr. Clinton to task on his record on issues like education, civil rights and employment. He said Mr. Kerrey was for health care, but "none of his employees have it."
By the end of his speech, some of the delegates were chanting the Senator's name.
Annette Rainwater of Detroit said she was leaning toward Senator Harkin but had not made up her mind.
"Something is missing, I don't know what," Ms. Rainwater said. "Maybe I'm looking for the excitement I had with Jesse. But when the dust settles, I think I'll be going with a winner."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Retail Space;
For Retailers, It's Space-Sale Season Hard-Put Landlords

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
FILA SPORTS, the high-priced Italian sports clothes company, just opened its first New York boutique, at 831 Madison Avenue near 69th Street, in the heart of designer row.
"We've always wanted to be associated with the likes of Ralph Lauren and Armani, but it took until now to find exactly the space we want," said Christine A. Massetani, advertising and promotions director at the company's American headquarters in Brisbane, Calif. 
 Morse Shoe, the Canton, Mass., company that owns Fayva shoe stores, just emerged from bankruptcy in December and already is looking to open some 25 stores in New York this year. "I'm mounting a full-court press to open new stores while landlords are still realistic about rents and terms," said Vincent Brown, Fayva's vice president of real estate.
For retailers, New York has become the ultimate space buyers' market. Rents are falling on every shopping thoroughfare. Landlords are wooing desirable tenants with longer rent-free periods in which to tailor the space to their needs before opening their doors. They are making available huge blocks of prime space, often vacated by banks, that make chains like the Gap or The Limited salivate. They are welcoming restaurants, cheese stores, discount houses -- all sorts of tenants that, in palmier days, were unwelcome for either hygienic or image reasons.
"There's no question landlords are taking tenants they wouldn't take before," said Ralph Friedman, vice president of Dakota Realty, a Manhattan brokerage.
One example is Cosmetics Plus, a discount cosmetics shop with a well-earned reputation for bargaining rents down. It recently moved into the prime space at 57th Street and Seventh Avenue opposite Carnegie Hall that formerly was occupied by a Barnes & Noble bookstore. Barnes & Noble also is a discounter but in the world of retail leasing, it ranks higher in prestige because it sells culture rather than lip gloss.
Eddie Bauer, known mainly as a mail-order clothing and sporting goods company, has opened stores on 58th Street and Madison Avenue and 45th Street and Third Avenue. Innovation Luggage is at 43d Street and Fifth Avenue, in space where Nynex once sold computers. The Gap, which declined to discuss its expansion strategies, is "bidding on every location around," said one broker.
All told, the commercial real estate depression has turned into the one bright spot in the glum retailing landscape. Solvent companies are getting into locations they could only dream about two or three years ago.
SHAKY retailers are scrounging for extra cash to take advantage of some of the best store availabilities and rent bargains in two decades. And money-losing retailers are playing out the corporate version of the beleaguered executive who comes home and kicks the dog: After mollifying their own bankers and shuddering at their anemic receipts, they are wringing concessions from their landlords.
According to Garrick-Aug Associates, the country's largest retail real estate broker, the retail vacancy rate in Manhattan is now about 10 percent. This means nearly 7 million square feet of space is available -- up 75 percent from the 4 million vacant square feet of just three years ago.
Not surprisingly, landlords, many of whom are deeply in debt, are growing increasingly desperate to keep old tenants and get new ones. Garrick-Aug says that by the middle of last year the gap between the average asking price for a square foot of retail space ($61) and actual rents ($41) -- the so-called negotiability factor -- had hit 32.7 percent. Even though those numbers include the lowest-rent side streets and East Village avenues, they indicate a pretty hefty dose of realistic pessimism in prime space, too.
"This is the best retail real estate market tenants have faced in 25 years," said Charles Aug, the firm's president. He should know: He just gave the 14+ Store in Union, N.J., which occupies space his firm owns, an 8 percent rent concession for the remaining two years of its lease. "They were a good tenant," he said. "I didn't want to lose them."
Industry insiders say such examples abound. The co-op at 25 West 13th Street owns two 5,000-square-foot stores fronting on 14th Street -- prime shopping territory for the two low-priced variety stores in occupancy. Three years ago the co-op planned to raise rents on the stores when their leases came due in September 1991. The stores were paying $18 a square foot and the co-op planned to raise this to more than $100. It settled for $50 -- and felt lucky at that.
"The days when a co-op could assume that retail rents will carry the entire operating cost of the building above are long gone," said James G. Samson, a partner in the Manhattan law firm Haas, Greenstein, Samson, Cohen & Gerstein and the co-op board's lawyer.
Like office buildings, residential co-ops and condominiums, once among the pickiest of landlords, are welcoming tenants that were once anathema. "Co-ops used to want stores that would attract buyers of apartments," said Neil Kreisel, president of the Kreisel Company, which manages co-ops and condominiums. "Now they want stores that generate revenues."
The 68-unit building at 300 West 108th Street is a prime example. It has a 2,500-square-foot restaurant as well as two small stores, about 400 square feet each, facing Broadway. About seven years ago the Indian Cafe signed a 15-year lease, complete with escalator clauses, for the big restaurant space. The small stores were occupied by a coffee shop and a newsstand-tobacco shop.
The cafe's rent was high enough to nearly make up the amount of revenues the co-op could take in from nonresidential sources and still qualify for favorable tax treatment under the Federal Tax Code's so-called 80/20 rule. The rule says that co-op shareholders can deduct mortgage interest payments and other expenses as if they were homeowners, provided the income the co-op gets from other sources, such as commercial rentals, remains less than 20 percent of total income. So the co-op, not happy about two restaurants, with their attendant smells and breeding grounds for vermin, did not renew the coffee shop's lease when it came due two years ago. The newsstand left on its own.
To avoid ongoing 80/20 problems, the co-op set out to sell the space to clean, prestigious tenants -- say, clothing boutiques.
ALL that has changed. The cafe, hurting along with the economy, has negotiated waivers of rent escalators, and the two small spaces are not attracting buyers.
"Even another restaurant is starting to look good," said Mr. Samson, the co-op's lawyer.
In a sense, the tug of war between landlords and retailers is a battle of invalids. Both industries are battling sales and profit figures that could depress even Pollyanna. And both sides are playing up their weaknesses as they jockey for position. Landlords point to their huge vacancy rates, their high property taxes, recalcitrant mortgage holders and other reasons that they would rather leave a store vacant -- or allow a good tenant to leave -- in hopes of getting a decent rent.
Retailers, however, point to their own numbers to persuade landlords that it's impossible to get blood from a stone. Holiday sales, traditionally as much as half of a retailer's annual profits, were poor for the third year in a row, falling 0.4 percent below 1990's Christmas season. Bankruptcies and closings have been widespread.
The industry is in deeper trouble than store numbers would indicate.
Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics data show there were 39,000 stores in the five boroughs in 1979, 38,700 10 years later and 38,300 in the first quarter of 1991. A decline, to be sure, but not a huge one.
Employment figures, however, paint a more somber picture. With shopper traffic so sparse and per-store sales low, stores are hiring fewer people, offering fewer services and paying less overtime. The New York State Department of Labor says there were 362,000 people employed in the retail trade in New York in November 1991 -- the most recent figures available. That's down just shy of 6 percent from 384,700 in November 1990 and more than 13 percent from the 417,600 retail jobs that existed in November 1987, the year best remembered for the October stock market crash but also the one in which local retail employment peaked.
"In two years we've all but wiped out the employment gains from the entire boom decade of the 1980's," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, who heads the Middle Atlantic regional office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics in Manhattan.
No one is predicting a big turnaround soon. The New York economy led the country in the economic downturn. According to Mr. Ehrenhalt, New York's fiscal woes began in October 1989, while the national recession usually is pegged to July 1990. The downturn has already cost New York 230,000 jobs.
Retailers, many of which were carrying huge debt loads, have been particularly hard hit. B. Altman's is gone, as is Gimbels; Macy's and Bloomingdales are in trouble.
A revived economy may not be the answer. Already, discount malls, shopper discount clubs and mail-order companies have siphoned buyers away from department stores and even from specialty stores. The department stores, meanwhile, are running sales on luxury goods, making deep inroads into sales at some of the luxury boutiques.
STILL, things are less bleak in the pricier sections of town -- Madison Avenue, say, or Fifth Avenue, where foreign labels are outnumbered only by foreign spenders. Japanese spend freely on Fifth Avenue, while Italian and German visitors tend to spread their wealth in Madison Avenue stores.
Faith Consuelo of Garrick-Aug says she just negotiated the highest per-square-foot rental ever on 55th Street just off Fifth Avenue. At a time when rents on the block, among the most prestigious in town, averaged $425 a square foot, she got close to $600 for a 2,000-square-foot storefront in the Coca-Cola building, across from the St. Regis hotel. The store houses Goldpfeil, the German luxury leather-goods store.
E. William Judson of Judson Realty, who negotiated Fila's Madison Avenue deal -- an aggregate $10 million lease over 10 years, for 2,400 square feet of selling space spread on two levels -- says there has been no let-up in calls from designers looking to open showcase stores on Madison Avenue.
"They'll still pay high rent on Madison, because they see a store there as good image advertising for their brands," he said.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A Long Ride on Tokyo's Turmoil

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The dismal performance of the Tokyo stock market -- especially while the rest of the world has rallied -- has been a pesky irritant to those money managers who have been positive on Japan. It has not been fashionable to be, as it is often put in the industry, "constructive" on Japan, but there are those who are.
 "I think about it every day," said Richard H. King, the manager of the Counsellors International Equity mutual fund, which is managed by Warburg, Pincus Counsellors Inc. in New York. "I look every day and wonder if the policy is right. I read conflicting views and wonder if the policy is right." 
He has plenty of reason to scratch his head. Despite reductions in interest rates and signs of moderating inflation, which in the United States have helped push the Dow Jones industrial average to record highs, the Japanese market is in decline.
 Last Tuesday, the market's blue chip index, the Nikkei 225, closed at 20,858.30, just 636 points, or 3 percent, above its lowest level since the market crashed after reaching a record high of 38,915.87 at the end of 1989.
 In two years this is a plunge of 46.4 percent. But, what is worse, the market seems unable to revive. It reached its post-1989 low, 20,221.86, on Oct. 1, 1990. Since then it has rallied rarely, only to falter. Its highest rebound, to 27,146.91, was in the afterglow of the allies' Persian Gulf victory in March. It last touched 25,000 on Nov. 1, 1991, and it has been downhill since.
 Another manager, who like Mr. King increased his exposure in Japan last year, is Michael Bullock, chief investment officer at Morgan Grenfell Asset Management in London. "I think we would all like to hit the timing right," he said. "But we know that is not possible."
 Has the Tokyo market's performance changed their minds? No, they are keeping their chins up. "The balance of the fundamentals show we at Counsellors are right to stay where we are," said Mr. King.
 Both are expecting that the decline in interest rates -- short-term rates dipped below 5 percent last week -- and further cuts by the Bank of Japan, will finally revive the market. Mr. Bullock also expects corporate earnings to begin to revive.
 "It has clearly taken longer for the market to respond than I had anticipated," he said. "But we are sticking with it and feel pretty confident the market will show a good return."
 But this does not mean that those who have bet on Japan are increasing their stakes. Mr. King said his purchases have stopped for now. The drop in the market, he said, has helped to reduce the Japanese share of his portfolio below last fall's level. At Morgan Grenfell, according to Ian Kelson, a director, "We are looking at the sell-off and asking whether we should buy more, or if it is too early to take advantage of it."
 All three said they had not been hounded by their clients, partially because their funds take a long-term view and the clients are aware of it. Another reason is that the performance of other stock markets in the portfolios has been good enough to bring home nice returns over all. In 1991, Counsellors had a gain of 20.6 percent in dollar terms.
 But riding out the turmoil is not pleasant. When Mr. King and Mr. Bullock were increasing their stakes in Tokyo last fall, the Nikkei 225 was at 23,000. At the end of October, it had moved up almost 9 percent to 25,000. But since November the market is off 16 percent, closing on Friday at 21,072.15.
 And both think that the months ahead could be rough because the technical factors that have prompted the recent decline are still hanging over the market. One is the huge supply of stock, as many corporations, which had invested billions of cash in so-called Tokkin stock funds that have been falling, sell out. Another worry is that a slide below 20,000, which would bring the market to its lowest levels since February 1987, would force many banks to sell stock to meet international capital adequacy standards, forcing the market even lower.
 "We could have a shock," cautioned Mr. King. "But if there is a shock, Japan has the capability for pump priming," he argued, to cushion the plunge. "Japan has room for both fiscal and monetary policy to be pretty aggressive if there is a downward spike."
 Deciding whether these managers are right about a recovery will take time. Yes, they may have bought in too soon. (Note, however, that Mr. King suggested in September that the market could fall another 10 percent, which is exactly what it has done.) But if the market does rebound, they will already have a good stake and the timing error could be easily forgotten.
 And there is the matter of the Tokyo bears. Michael Metz, chief market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company in New York, is negative about Japan. In mid-September, he warned that the market could drop to 20,000 in four to six weeks. He even said a plunge to 18,500 was possible.
 He was right about the direction, but like the others his timing was off a bit.
 "My philosophy is you cannot be right unless you risk being wrong," he said, pointing out his own timing mistake. "You are no use to people if you do not take a stand."

HEADLINE: Candidates Playing to Mood of Protectionism

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM with KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
With New Hampshire's economy on the rocks and few points of disagreement on other emotional issues like crime, race and abortion, the Democratic Presidential candidates are vying over who can deliver the harshest words and strongest promises about giving America a leg up in world economic competition.
What the candidates are offering in their commercials and on the stump is more emotion than logic, more oratory than substance. But they are exploiting the sense that many voters have that Americans are being treated unfairly in international trade, especially by the Japanese. 
 In fact, American exports have almost doubled in the last six years, and this country is running neck and neck with Germany for the position of the world's top exporter. Moreover, the most recent New York Times/CBS News Poll on the subject, taken in November, shows that 32 percent of Americans believe that the Japanese compete unfairly, a number significantly lower than the 47 percent who say that Americans tend to blame Japan improperly for the nation's own economic problems.
But economists and politicians alike agree that the protectionist movement has gained strength this election year because of the flagging economy and the loss of high-paying American manufacturing jobs in the automobile, steel and other industries to Japan and Europe, where markets are not as open as they are here.
Much of this may be no more than electioneering. After gaining office, every President since Herbert Hoover has taken basically a free-trade stance, although several have said they favored trade restrictions in their campaigns.
But now, of the main Democratic candidates, only Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, is vigorously opposed to new trade restrictions. But his language is as strident as that of the others. "Others just blame the Japanese," he declares in his latest commercial. "Paul Tsongas will beat them, the American way, by making quality come first again."
Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska make no bones about advocating stiffer trade barriers. "I'm proud to be accused of being a protectionist," Mr. Harkin often says.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas calibrates the problem in a way that lets him strike a middle course. About one-quarter of the problem, he says, is that the Japanese have unfair trade rules; the other three-quarters is that the United States does not work hard enough to "compete and win."
President Bush, who used sharp words of his own on his trip to Japan this month, purports to be a free-trader. His acid test will come in the spring, when restrictions against imported steel are due to expire just before the primary in Pennsylvania, where steel is a major industry. In 1988, when polls showed him trailing in the state just before the fall election, Mr. Bush advocated continuing those limits.
Among economists, the mainstream has supported free trade, but it may have wandered slightly. Some prominent experts are now arguing that the United States must change its policies to compete more aggressively with the Japanese and Europeans. One of these is Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., an economist and trade official in the Reagan Administration.
"They're playing football and we're playing baseball, and we're both playing by the rules," he said in an interview. "But football is a contact sport, a rougher game than baseball, and our guys are getting beat up."
To follow the issue, it is important to understand not only the politics but also the economic theory, the history of postwar international commerce and the way the United States and its allies now restrict trade.
 
Trade Issue Rouses
The Big Losers
 Over the years, no other issue has caused such dissonance between scholars and politicians as trade.
Since the time of Adam Smith more than two centuries ago, almost every Western economist has been trained that unfettered trade is the best policy. On paper, it is. If you tally all the economic benefits from free trade and all the benefits from protection, free trade generally comes out ahead.
But politics is fueled by votes, not theories, and it is a rare politician who has not at one time or another sought protection from international competition for constituents. That is because while many people may be helped a small amount by free trade, a few people can be hurt a great deal.
For example, if a country allows shoes to be imported from abroad, where they can be manufactured more cheaply than at home, almost all consumers will be better off because they will pay a few dollars less for their shoes. But the domestic shoe industry might fold. And the people who own or work for shoe companies could lose their livelihoods.
Not surprisingly, the big losers, not the small winners, are the people who base their votes on where the candidates stand on shoe imports. So politicians normally abide by what Charles L. Schultze, who was budget director for President Lyndon B. Johnson and chairman of President Jimmy Carter's Council of Economic Advisers, calls the principle of "do no direct harm."
 
Barriers Came Down
After World War II
 Whatever the economic and political theory, the United States became an industrial power in the late 19th and early 20th century by using tariffs and Government subsidies to shield its industries from foreign competition. But the bubble burst in the 1930's after the enactment of the infamous Smoot-Hawley law. High American tariffs precipitated retaliatory barriers from Europe. Trade and industry were crippled, the roar was wiped out of the 20's and the world tumbled into Depression.
Learning from mistakes, the United States and most of its industrial allies, including to some degree Japan, lowered trade barriers bit by bit from the end of World War II until the early 1970's. Then, in the 1970's, after the cartel of petroleum exporting countries caused oil prices to skyrocket, nation after nation began to erect trade walls as their economies contracted.
Early in the 1980's, largely because of the extraordinarily high value of the dollar, the United States began to run a serious trade deficit for the first time in more than a century. Trade restrictions here exploded. When the dollar is strong, imports are less costly and American exports are more expensive, which meant that important domestic industries like copper, steel and autos found themselves unable to compete.
The trade deficit peaked in 1987, at $152 billion. Then, the value of the dollar fell. The deficit was only $65 billion last year.
Exports led the comeback. The politicians rarely mention it, but the market in Japan for American manufactured goods grew faster than any other big market except Mexico, nearly doubling to $31 billion last year from $16 billion in 1987.
But imports from Japan also expanded, so the United States trade deficit with Japan shrank slowly. It was about $40 billion last year, down from $56 billion in 1987.
By contrast, the United States has turned around its trade deficit with Europe. Last year, the United States sold about $17 billion more in goods and services to the 12 nations of the European Community than it imported from those countries.
And American trade barriers have also been relaxed slightly. The share of United States imports subject to some kind of protection rose to 21 percent in 1984 from 8 percent in 1975, according to Gary C. Hufbauer, an economist at the Institute for International Economists. Now, he said, the figure is only 16 percent to 18 percent.
The World Bank calculates that the European Community restricts a slightly larger proportion of imports than the United States, while Japan protects about one-quarter of its imports.
 
Trading Countries Use
Many Types of Protection
 The United States has been the international leader in promoting free trade for more than 50 years. The Reagan and Bush Administrations struck free trade agreements with Canada and Israel, began negotiating a pact with Mexico and led the push for a reduction in trade barriers worldwide.
But the United States protects some of its own industries, especially agriculture. Ice cream imports, for example, are limited to less than one teaspoon per person each year. Sugar imports are capped at about a quarter of the nation's annual consumption, and grain and tobacco farmers are subsidized. The result is not only to keep out foreign agricultural products but to increase markedly what consumers pay for food.
Pressure to "Buy American" also seems to be growing. This week, responding to protests, the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission canceled a $122 million rail transit contract with Sumitomo, a Japanese company.
The United States also restricts foreign investment in its shipping, airline, radio, television and long-distance communications industries.
In Europe, through a system of import quotas, lavish export subsidies and purchases of extra production, farmers are protected to a much greater extent. This has caused considerable friction in international trade talks. The Europeans view their rules as much as a social policy as an economic one.
"I've been in your cities," a European agriculture official told an American reporter, "and I don't want our cities to get like that, crowded with all the people who have moved off the farms. We don't have plains and prairies and deserts like you. Our farms are our countryside."
European governments also often impose rules against buying from foreign suppliers and actively support direct subsidies to favored businesses, a practice generally avoided in the United States. Airbus Industrie was set up with billions of dollars in taxpayer money from Germany, France, Britain and Spain to compete with American aircraft manufacturers.
In Japan, rice imports are completely banned. Japan agreed in 1988 to cancel rigid limits on imported beef and oranges but replaced them with tariffs of more than 50 percent. "The price of sirloin steak in downtown Tokyo's $26 a pound," Senator Harkin complained in last Sunday's debate of Democratic Presidential candidates. "We could sell it for $4 or $5 a pound over there, but they won't let it in."
Japan's keiretsu -- loosely knit industrial and banking groups with sprawling interests -- buy mainly from within their group and keep out imports.
The Japanese Government bureaucracy and professional groups have other ways of blocking foreigners from offering services. Americans complain, for instance, that the dates when contract bids in Japan are due are not announced.
But some Japanese trade barriers are being lowered slowly. After three years of arm-twisting, Toys "R" Us was permitted last month to open its first store in Japan. The Japanese Government agreed during President Bush's recent visit to buy more large American computers and parts for automobiles.
 
Disagreements
On What to Do
 The Japanese argue that their trade advantage over the United States is based on their superior education, training and production, and most American politicians agree that improvement here is needed in those areas. Still, although the American economy is roughly twice as productive as the Japanese, politicians here from both parties find political mileage in harping on what they see as unfair advantages in the Japanese system.
"The two economies are simply incompatible," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, reflecting a pervasive view in Congress. "They are a society that is intensely focused on production and export, and we are focused on consumption and import."
But there are significant differences on how best to respond, and no single position is dominant.
The White House stance is that the United States should use its diplomacy to persuade Japan to change its ways. Mr. Bush's trip to Japan this month was basically a trade mission.
Many Democrats favor a form of industrial policy in which specific American industries are singled out for Government subsidies so they can become more competitive.
Beyond the florid oratory in New Hampshire, a consensus may be developing, at least in theory, about what American trade policy should be in the years ahead. Almost everyone agrees that the United States should make better use of what Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, calls "the juicy allure of American markets" to pry open markets elsewhere.
In addition, many economists as well as politicians are arguing that the Government should compensate communities, companies and workers damaged by imports, withhold subsidies to unproductive industries and offer some assistance to those that show the promise of being able to win a healthy share of world commerce. But who would decide, and how?
"I'm very skeptical," said Benjamin M. Friedman, a professor of political economy at Harvard, "that this could ever work in the American system."

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "America's Trade Balance," tracks U.S. trade surpluses and deficits with the rest of the world, with Western Europe and with Japan, 1981-1991* (1991, estimate) (Source: Commerce Dept.) (pg. 20)
 
Chart: "Ways That Nations Restrict Trade: A Glossary"
 
TARIFFS: Customs fees on imported products. For example, the U.S. imposes a tariff of $1.21 per kilogram (2.2 pounds) of cut or ground tobacco stems. Economists, who generally don't like import controls, tolerate tariffs because their cost is apparent to consumers and because they affect all sources of an import equally.
 
QUOTAS, BANS, AND VOLUNTARY RESTRAINT: Limits or prohibitions can be placed on imports. Particularly prevalant in trade in textile and apparel. Kurtas, knee-length tunics worn by many immigrants from north India, are allowed into the U. S. quota-free if they do not have collars; with collars, they are counted as shirts, and few can be imported. Also frequent in agriculture and in culture:
 
But the treaty that governs most world trade prohibits quotas or high tariffs on many products. Developed countries have increasingly turned to insisting that their trading partners "voluntarily" hold back. The U.S. just last month renewed such a voluntary restraint agreement on factory tool imports from Taiwan and Japan.
 
"BUY AMERICAN" (OR FRENCH OR ITALIAN): Governments exhort their citizens to buy fewer foreign products, or lean on foreign industries to import more.
 
Goverments tend to buy from domestic producers even when foreign companies produce a better or cheaper product. German public hospitals, for example, have trouble getting permission to buy American X-ray equipment.
 
SUBSIDIES: Nations often help domestic industries sell overseas by reimbursing producers part of their costs. The European Community pays $12 billion to farmers who agree to export food.
 
RULES AND REGULATIONS: While needed to protect workers and consumers, safety and quality standards are often used to close a country's markets, or to restrict the financial and legal services that foreign companies can offer.
 
The European Community is about to ban pine wood imports that have not been heated in a kiln until very dry. The E.C. says the purpose is to kill pine tree worms; the U.S., which has more forests than Europe, contends that there is no scientific basis for requiring the expensive process.
 
PRICE FIXING: The treaty governing most world trade allows countries to use to use tariffs to raise the prices of imported goods produced by subsidized industries.
 
A growing number of countries also impose tariffs if they feel that imported goods are being sold below cost, or "dumped." The United States imposed late last summer a dumping duty of 62.67 percent on imports of sophisticated screens for laptop and notebook computers from Japan.
 
LIMITING FOREIGN INVESTMENT: By restricting how much of a local business a foreign company can buy, or forbidding a foreign corporation to open a business, countries make it hard to distribute imports.
 
PIRACY: By allowing domestic industries to copy foreign books, computer programs, pharmaceuticals and videocassettes without asking permission or paying any royalties, countries can discourage costly imports.
 
Developing countries, led by India, China, Thailand, Nigeria and the former Soviet republics, engage in piracy more than developed countries because most of their citizens are very poor and their industries weak. (pg. 20)

HEADLINE: All About/Dealer Auto Repairs;
Turning a Source of Headaches Into a Source of Profits

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
For most car owners, there are few events that provoke greater anxiety than a trip to the dealer or local garage for service or repairs. A phone call from the service manager often means news of unforeseen and costly problems. Because drivers rely so much on their cars, a less-than-perfect repair can be a significant irritation.
Many service visits are less than perfect. Almost a third of all trips to the dealer for repairs require a repeat visit, according to J. D. Power & Associates, the automotive consulting firm. And some auto repairs are never done right. The Better Business Bureau says poor service for cars consistently rates as one of the top five consumer complaints. 
 Automobile dealers can no longer afford the reputation of having troubled service departments. As profit margins on new cars have dwindled and sales have dropped to their lowest levels in nearly a decade, dealers are relying on their parts and service departments for a growing share of profits -- 86 percent last year, according to the National Automobile Dealers Association, up from 11 percent in 1983.
This growing reliance on parts and service as major profit centers has forced dealers to focus more attention on these operations. They are also working hard to increase their 21 percent share of the $100 billion spent each year on parts and service by drivers of the nation's 187 million registered vehicles. In 1985, dealers had just 18 percent of the market, according to the Motor and Equipment Manufacturers Association.
Dealerships have made numerous changes in the way they do business to woo consumers who demand convenience and to accommodate the complexity of modern cars and trucks. "Service and parts are their survival," said W. C. Smith, who heads an automotive consulting firm in Laurel, Md.
The innovation and investment appear to be paying off. As dealers gain market share, largely at the expense of service stations, the quality of their operations is also improving. A J. D. Power survey states that repeat visits for repairs to dealers of all foreign and domestic makes dropped to 28 percent in 1991 from 46 percent in 1986. In a separate J. D. Power survey that asks whether dealers are doing a better job satisfying customers' service needs, 56 percent of consumers responded yes in 1991, up from 39 percent in 1986.
 
Impressing Customers
Free Cab Rides And Playgrounds
 Many dealerships have devised elaborate ways to build customer loyalty through added convenience. Given the competition from the growing ranks of specialty repair shops -- such as outlets that specialize in tune-ups and oil changes -- the industry has been forced to raise its standards, consultants say. "Dealers have to learn to impress, not just satisfy customers," said Mr. Smith.
To minimize the hassle of getting to work without their cars, customers at the eight Zimbrick dealerships in Madison, Wisc., are offered free cab rides to work after they drop off their cars in the morning. Although the monthly cab bill comes to $10,000, David S. Nathanson, Zimbrick's president, said the money is better spent than on other costs such as marketing. Regular dinners with the staff of the cab company provide feedback on customers' comments about the dealerships, Mr. Nathanson said..
Last year, Zimbrick's Honda dealership set up a stand-alone service center for basic repairs and maintenance work away from the showroom in a suburban area with a high concentration of Honda owners. At this satellite center, the dealership constructed an indoor playground for children and work cubicles for adults with telephones and free local calls. "We just want to make it as uninterruptive to the flow of daily activities as possible," said Mr. Nathanson. "We're in a very service-oriented economy."
Zimbrick and many other dealers offer car buyers regular service seminars in which customers learn about the service operation and their warranty coverage. And dealers have expanded their service hours to an average of 49 hours a week in 1991 from 42 hours a week in 1989, according to the National Automobile Dealers Association.
Some dealers and auto makers also try to impress with more subtle details. Infiniti and Lexus, the two top-rated brands in J. D. Power's most recent customer satisfaction survey, store their customers' service histories in a computer network that can be quickly accessed at any Lexus or Infiniti dealership nationwide.
At Sewell Village Cadillac in Dallas, the drain screens in the floor in the service area are chrome plated. At Sewell's Lexus dealership, the service manager has installed old-fashioned ceiling fans and hung prints on the wall.
 
 
The Mechanic of Yore
Now It's Computers And Technicians
 Fixing a car is no longer a job for mechanics; they are now referred to as technicians. The reason for the change is that many technicians require as much training in electronics and computers as they do in mechanics. "A technician now has to have the expertise of a radio or television repairman," said Fred Pirochta, repair facility division director of Michigan's automotive regulation bureau.
To help technicians with the increasingly difficult task of trouble-shooting, many auto makers have devised expensive computerized diagnostic tools for their dealers. Chrysler's diagnostic system, developed with the help of the International Business Machines Corporation, diagnoses problems, but also serves up repair procedures and contains technical libraries, diagrams and an electronic parts catalogue. Using a portable computer, data can be recorded during a test drive by a Chrysler technician, then fed into the main system back at the service bay for analysis. Some diagnostic systems enable technicians at the factory to hook into the dealer's computers to help diagnose a problem.
The cost of such advanced systems is one reason why dealership labor rates are higher than service stations' rates. Last year, labor rates at dealerships averaged $41.50 an hour across the United States, up from $25 an hour in 1984, according to the National Automobile Dealers Association. Service station rates averaged about $38 an hour last year.
To reduce the number of repeat visits for repairs on seven of its increasingly complex engines, the General Motors Corporation launched a program in October that calls for dealers to replace the engines rather than fix them on several models of 1992 cars and small trucks. G.M. pays for the replacement engines; the old engines are shipped to the factory, where they are either discarded or rebuilt and resold as used engines.
 
Stocking Up
The Cost of Keeping Parts on Hand
 Not only is the repair business labor intensive, it is capital intensive. In 1990, car dealers stocked an average of $200,000 worth of parts, according to the National Automobile Dealers Association. But dealerships employ different strategies for stocking parts.
At one extreme is Sewell Village Cadillac. It keeps more than $1 million worth of parts on hand. Carl Sewell, who owns six dealerships, said his goal is to fill more than 90 percent of parts orders from on-site inventory. Mr. Sewell said interrupting work for a part to be delivered costs the dealership $25 to $40. "Every time you're out of a part, it's very, very expensive," he said.
By contrast, Lexus dealers generally keep just $30,000 worth of parts in stock. One reason is that Lexus is a relatively new brand with fewer models. But it also needed a way to minimize the space required to store parts, so dealers could build in prime locations.
To minimize waiting times for customers, Lexus dealers stock a broad but shallow array of parts. When one is used, it is replaced by next-day delivery. Richard L. Chitty, corporate manager for parts, service and customer satisfaction for Lexus, said the delivery cost is a necessary expense to enable dealers to build compact dealerships.
 
 
 
SHOWS ON PEOPLE SKILLS OR TRANSAXLES
 For many years, the Chrysler Corporation kept its dealers current on technical information and other issues through electronic mail, phone calls and mailings. But the auto maker wanted a more efficient way to communicate the same message to everyone at the same time. The answer: its own television shows, on the Chrysler Dealer Network, or CDN.
For more than a year, Chrysler has been broadcasting roughly 90 minutes of new programming a week on topics that include service, like "Throttle cable adjustment on ZF transaxle."
It also broadcasts shows on sales, like "Hot Button: Brush up on your people skills. Learn how to find a customer's hot button and when to push it." Other shows are designed for dealership management.
Nearly all of the company's 5,000 U.S. dealers are equipped with monitors. A survey found that more than 90 percent of the targeted employees at the dealerships see the programs. James R. Abbott, service and parts director at Doug Griffith Chrysler-Plymouth in Baltimore, Md., said he tapes the programs for his service staff. "It immediately updates us with all the information," he said. "Before it was just hit or miss."
A number of dealers' suppliers advertise on the network, including computer companies and van conversion firms. A Chrysler spokesman said the goal of the network is to break even, a point it has not yet reached.
