HEADLINE: Well-Dressed Animals Keeping Sales High

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
SALES of clothing for men and women at the tonier stores may have fizzled this last holiday season, but at the K-Marts, Woolworths and Jamesway stores, sales of sporty sweaters and nappy raincoats for four-legged customers did especially well.
"Even when times are bad, people somehow keep buying for their children and their pets," said Robert Kastner, a manufacturer of dog sweaters, dog T-shirts and dog and cat beds. "People with pets, especially, find it emotionally satisfying to buy them something for the holidays." 
 Mr. Kastner, 62, the owner of Rotanis Pet Products in Ossining, said: "Ours is a volume business. We don't make canine mink coats or studded leather pet biker jackets, but we do make moderately priced, fashionable running clothes, sweaters, raincoats, jackets and beds."
Even in the smallest towns across the country today, he said, "People are very fashion conscious."
"What's fashionable in the human world is fashionable for pets," explained Mr. Kastner, who does his market research by walking through places like Bloomingdale's and Lord & Taylor, observing what people select for themselves.
 
A Huge Potential Market
 "Earth tones are in for sweaters," he reported. "Small floral patterns and paisley prints are big in home furnishings. The Victorian look is important for beds. We incorporate all the fashionable styles into our own line. I explore every department including housewares, for instance, where I examine kitchenware, and when I see a lot of pastels used, we use the same pastels for our dog beds."
Mr. Kastner's potential market is huge. The dog population in the United States stands at 50 million. Cats number 70 million. In a perfect world, every one of them would have a bed, Mr. Kastner said.
"Every creature needs a place to rest or nest, something to crawl into," he said. "A protected place to peer out from."
His business, in fact, began with beds.
"My dad, Albert Kastner, started a company in 1938 from his office in the Flatiron Building in Manhattan," Mr. Kastner said. "At the time, he was working as a manufacturer's rep for importers of bamboo and rattan products from Indonesia. In those days, bamboo and rattan were inexpensive materials, used a lot for tables and chairs. My dad thought, 'Why not make a bamboo basket to be used as a dog's bed?'
"He sold the W. T. Grant Company on the idea, and when he had its order he made arrangements with a supplier in Indonesia to have dog beds made in three sizes. The largest one, big enough for a good-sized Labrador. With a retail price starting at $1.98 to $2.98, they sold very well in the years from 1938 to 1941, when the war cut off all trade with Indonesia."
But by then, Mr. Kastner recalled, his father was convinced that a business catering to pets had a future.
"He rented a loft, and in those days Manhattan was full of jobbers and suppliers who were capable of making anything a manufacturer wanted," he said. "My dad designed a cushion with a back similar in shape to a dog's basket, had it made up and took it around to the department stores. Buyers liked it. Carson Pirie & Scott in Chicago gave him his first big order."
 
Starting Out on the Road
 Mr. Kastner said he worked for his father during summer vacations from high school and college. He recalled that he always assumed that he would go into the family business.
His father started him on the road, calling on customers. "I realized there was an opportunity to do some cross selling, so we expanded our line to include other pet products such as sweaters, coats and raincoats for dogs," he said. "We even tried some canine footwear -- rain boots -- I recall, but we discarded those quickly when we found that they made the dogs uncomfortable."
When asked why dogs need coats, sweaters and raincoats, Mr. Kastner said: "Because domesticity has changed their ability to adapt to the elements. Animals who live in heated homes get used to an even temperature. When it's below 40 degrees outside, they need the same protection from the cold that humans do."
Sweaters, designed and manufactured in the Ossining plant, outsell coats and raincoats by 5 to 1, he said.
"People tend to buy more than one sweater -- a whole wardrobe of sweaters for their pets," he said. "T-shirts, with such inscriptions as 'Fire Hydrant Inspector' are strictly for fun, but they sell surprisingly well."
T-shirts sell for $4.98. Sweaters retail at $5.98 to $7.98. Running suits are $6.98. The most expensive item made by the company is a brass dog's bed, which sells for $39.95.
 
<SC0>A Highly Competitive Field
 "Our operation is typical of most of the companies in the pet products industry," Mr. Kastner said. "Most of us are small manufacturers. Many of us represent the second generation of owners. It's a highly competitive industry but a fairly stable one for old-time companies."
In 1988 Mr. Kastner bought a building formerly occupied by the Cambridge Instruments Company in Ossining.
"We were pressed for space," he said. "Our volume has increased about four and a half times since the 1970's, and our sales are projected at over $4 million this year. We looked for space in New York City, but the building in Ossining with 55,000 square feet of space was enough for both our manufacturing facility and our office."
An additional draw is the labor supply, he said: "These Hudson River towns are such good sources for semiskilled local seamstresses. We employ about 30 of them in our plant."
Rotanis also has two resident models: Freddie, a black Labrador, and Chuckie, a mixed breed.
"Freddie was a stray who literally knocked on the door shortly after we got here looking for a handout," Mr. Kastner said. "Chuckie appeared on the scene a little bit later. They both live here and earn their keep modeling."
 
A Mail-Order Approach
 A large dog doll, a Dalmatian, made for Mr. Kastner by a sculptor friend of his, is used as a backup model.
Mr. Kastner, who lives in Manhattan, makes the reverse commute by train every day. "It's a very pleasant trip," he said, "never crowded. I like working in Westchester, but I can't see myself living here. I'd miss the noise and excitement of the city."
Jay Spear, a former commuter and now the owner of Quincy's Choice, a mail-order house in Dobbs Ferry, which sells quality products for the discerning dog, said he doesn't miss anything about Manhattan.
"My office is close to home so instead of a two-hour commute, I have a short walk."
Mr. Spear, who has always been fond of dogs, named his company for the family dog, Quincy, a golden retriever that appears frequently in the catalogue as a model.
 
'An Upbeat Business'
 "Our customers often send us pictures of their dogs, which we run in the catalogue. Not only is this an up-beat business, but it seems to be one that is recession proof," Mr. Spear said. "During the two years we've been in business, our volume has steadily increased."
Calling this past Christmas season a very good one, he added: "When it comes to pets, people make multiple purchases. They'll order goodies, four or five toys plus other accessories at one clip."
According to Mr. Spear, his catalogue offers items that can't be found elsewhere. "We only carry those products we consider safe, fun or functional," he said. "And that means no choke chains, no cages and no electronic collars. So we ferret out sources who will make us new and different items such as special toys."
All the products under consideration for the catalogue are first tried out on Quincy.
"He was especially fond of the ragg bones this year, and they proved to be excellent sellers," Mr. Spear said.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1236 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS: Georgia;
Loft-Living Southern Style, Catching On

BYLINE: By FORD RISLEY

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Thanks to an abundance of old warehouses and the arrival of new residents who have experience with loft living, Georgia has become home to a growing number of loft conversions.
"This is sort of a Southern-fried SoHo," said Bruce Gallman, one of the original developers of this city's Castleberry Hill, which has the state's largest concentration of loft apartments. 
 Georgia developments like Castleberry Hill differ perceptibly from New York's SoHo and other well-known loft districts. While they share the usual high ceilings, brick walls and abundance of windows, most lack the stores, restaurants and other amenities that help give a neighborhood a sense of community.
Conversions of scattered buildings around Atlanta have been going on since the late 60's, but Castleberry Hill did not emerge as a loft community until about three years ago.
Next to one of the main railroad lines, Castleberry Hill is a 10-block area of small warehouses interspersed with an occasional storefront. Within walking distance of downtown, it is bordered on the north by the Omni arena and on the south by Morehouse College. Most of the buildings still standing in the area, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places, were built between 1885 and 1925.
In 1983, Mr. Gallman and other local investors acquired a vacant 80-year-old warehouse and converted it into 16 loft apartments. Since then, small investors have been buying other buildings in the neighborhood and converting them to lofts either for their own use or to rent.
Castleberry Hill now has about 120 loft apartments that are home to more than 150 people. And the numbers are growing. Late in 1990 a nine-unit building that had been a mattress warehouse opened, and construction on 40 more units will begin this year.
Rick Skelton, president of SMP Properties, one of the developers behind the projects, said loft owners in Castleberry Hill have little trouble finding tenants. He estimates the vacancy rate at less than 5 percent.
"People are starting to move back downtown," he said. "Every strong city needs downtown living."
Mr. Skelton's former mattress factory was fully leased before the six-month conversion was completed. Units have 14-foot ceilings and pine flooring and average 1,750 square feet. Rents are $650 to $1,100 a month.
The growing interest in Castleberry Hill is reflected in rising prices. Five years ago, unrenovated property cost $5 to $6 a square foot, Mr. Skelton said; today it brings $12 to $15, while renovated buildings go for $40 to $45 a square foot.
Of about one million square feet of warehouse space in the area, less than half is now used for lofts, said Jim Schneider, a real estate broker who has sold several buildings in the area. Most tenants have an appreciation of history, he said. Castleberry Hill, he said, appeals to people who want to live close to downtown and need or want a lot of space.
Mr. Skelton and his group of investors paid $135,000 for their 24,000-square-foot building and spent $350,000 to renovate it.
Most Castleberry Hill loft space was taken at first by artists and craftsmen, who worked as well as lived in their apartments. Although many remain, the area has recently become home to an increasing number of professionals. Mr. Skelton's tenants include an architect, a physician, a public relations executive and several salesmen. Many had lived in lofts in other cities and wanted a similar life style in Atlanta, he said.
Established in the mid-1800's, Castleberry Hill was Atlanta's original industrial district. Warehouses used for cotton and other commodities were built alongside the railroad line that now divides the area from downtown's high-rise towers. After the Civil War, banks, saloons and grocers began moving into the area, according to local historians.
After the turn of the century, Castleberry Hill fell on hard times and became home to brothels and a gang known as the Snake Nation. Mangum Drive, one of the streets in Castleberry Hill, is named for the sheriff who helped run the gang out of the area.
Though Atlanta is the principal venue for loft-living, there are lofts in other cities, too. Savannah has loft apartments scattered throughout its historic district and riverfront area. Although the total number of lofts is still fairly small -- only a few more than two dozen -- it is growing steadily, said Dick Mopper, a real estate broker in the city.
"Interest certainly is growing," he said. "I think we're going to see more and more. There are a number of buildings that lend themselves to lofts."
Much of the interest comes from newcomers to the city who had lived in loft apartments elsewhere, Mr. Mopper said. Some are students at the Savannah College of Art and Design, a small school that attracts students from throughout the country.
Several smaller cities, Savannah among them, , have a bigger inventory than Atlanta of warehouses appropriate for use as lofts, said Pat Connell, a professor of architecture at Georgia Tech who specializes in historic preservation.
Augusta, Macon and Columbus, which now have only a few scattered loft projects, were centers for cotton manufacturing and their many large warehouses are easily converted into lofts. Atlanta, by contrast, had more of a service-based economy, .
"These places have an excellent inventory of buildings," Mr. Connell said. "There's a lot of potential for loft development."
Despite frequent comparisons to SoHo, loft projects in Atlanta and elsewhere in the state lack many of the characteristics of New York's famous residential district.
Except for Castleberry Hill, most of the loft developments in the state lack a sense of neighborhood identity. Castleberry Hill has a neighborhood association and an annual holiday arts festival. Pick-up basketball games are popular and there is a common area where residents gather for small parties.
But leaders in the community recognize that more is needed. Mr. Skelton said he and several others are trying to buy an abandoned railroad spur that runs behind several buildings to turn it into a park where community activities could be held.
The neighborhood also lacks the amenities and street activity found in loft areas in many communities, Mr. Gallman said.
A rapid transit station and a few sandwich shops and small restaurants are nearby, but most establishments close at dark. Finding any real nighttime activity means a trip downtown, residents say. And because there is very little downtown living, there are precious few stores -- such as groceries -- that cater to residents. The nearest such retail shopping is several miles away.
There are obstacles in the way of further loft conversions. Some lenders, for example, are wary of projects they still consider "pioneering," Mr. Skelton said, and the 1986 Tax Reform Act also eliminated some of the tax advantages for renovating historic buildings.
Probably the biggest stumbling block is the perception that Castleberry Hill has a serious crime problem. Although streets in the neighborhood often are dirty and the area attracts many homeless people, residents say crime is no worse than in many other parts of the city.
And Capt. W. F. Derrick of the Atlanta police said that crime had actually decreased in the area in the last year -- he did not provide numbers -- which he attributed to having a round-the-clock population.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bruce Galman, an early loft converter, in Castleberry Hill loft. (Alan Weiner for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1137 words

HEADLINE: UConn Marks 100 Years of Women

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
A CENTURY ago the president of Storrs Agricultural School, Benjamin Koons, felt so strongly about enrolling a student named I. Lee that he skirted the law and kept the admission secret from the school's trustees. The student's first name was Ida, but state law prohibited women students at the school. Mr. Koons did not accept fees from Miss Lee and could not give her academic credit, but she got her education.
Ida Lee Hale's obituary cited her as the first woman enrolled at the school that grew into the University of Connecticut. Researchers have found five other women who were also enrolled surreptitiously at the school during the 1891-92 academic year. The law was changed to allow women to enroll in 1892-93, and Ida Lee was officially accepted as a second-year student. 
 "The social values of that time were that women didn't need an education," said Dr. Cynthia H. Adams, a professor of allied health at the university. "They would just get married and have babies, and why did you need an education for that?"
 
Degrees in All Areas
 Dr. Adams, chairwoman of the 100 Years of Women At UConn celebration, said sexism permeated even the scientific community of the 19th century. Medical textbooks of the time said too much education would damage the uterus, she noted.
"As recently as the 1950's and 60's, when I was growing up, it was still not totally accepted that women should go to college," Dr. Adams said. "Now there's almost no area left where women haven't gotten a degree."
Dr. Regina Barreca, an associate professor of English at UConn and a member of the planning committee for the centennial celebration, said she hoped to see considerable progress in the next 100 years. But women have to proceed cautiously, she said.
"Women are really caught in a crossfire" between those who note how far they have come and others who point to the gaps that remain between women's progress and men's, Dr. Barreca said. "But I will say this, it's been real easy to find women who have made a difference at UConn."
She said that the university's administration had been enthusiastic in its support for the celebration, and that UConn's president, Dr. Harry J. Hartley, created something of a stir when he appointed her the institution's first woman convocation speaker when this academic year opened.
"There were men who were much taller and much older who had a lot more stuff hanging off their academic gowns who were really listening to what I had to say," Dr. Barreca said.
 
Encouraging Engineers
 Erling Murtha-Smith, a professor of civil engineering and a member of the committee, said women are still underrepresented in his discipline. There was one woman among 120 students in his graduating class in 1969 at the University of Leeds in England, he said, while at UConn today the proportion is up to 5 or 10 percent.
"We need to brief high school teachers and counselors, and even below that level, at junior high, to encourage the better math and science students to consider engineering," Dr. Murtha-Smith said. UConn has started such a program, he said.
The director of recreation and intramural sports at UConn, Patti A. Bostic, said that in athletics as well as academics women have been making gains, which she attributed not only to interest in women's sports but also to equal treatment of women's sports in the hierarchy of the university's athletic department.
She went to one women's basketball game recently that had 3,100 spectators, she said, and more than 1,700 season tickets for the women's games have been sold.
"That's outstanding for the first year they're selling season tickets, particularly considering that last year they didn't even charge to get into women's basketball games," said Ms. Bostic, who is also helping plan the centennial celebration.
Dr. Adams said that despite the strides that women have made in the academic world, only 2 of UConn's 12 trustees are women, the university has never had a woman president, few women hold administrative posts, and salaries are remain higher for men. She said, however, that Mr. Hartley's selection as president bodes well for women.
 
Finding Qualified Women
 "The attitude of President Hartley and his administration has been one of action rather than lip service," Dr. Adams said. "We bring things to his attention, and he fixes them.
"I've been at UConn 20 years, and there have been times I was the only woman on a committee. Or I have noticed there were no women on certain committees, and the explanation has always been there were no qualified women. President Hartley's solution has been to find the qualified women."
Men do not seem to have suffered any discrimination during the planning of the celebration. Dr. Murtha-Smith is the only man on the committee, aside from Dr. Hartley, who is an ex-officio member. But Dr. Murtha-Smith said he felt no awkwardness at the meetings.
"I don't feel like I've been treated, as the token male," he said. "I give my opinions, and they are accepted or rejected on merit alone."
Dr. Adams said one part of the celebration will be to honor the families of the six women pioneers at UConn, including Ida Lee Hale. Mrs. Hale owned the Hale House restaurant with her husband, Spencer Hale, the first man to grow peaches in Connecticut. She used her studies of nutrition to develop recipes using only peaches.
 
Largely Self-Supporting
 UConn has promised some financial assistance for the celebration, but Dr. Adams said much of it will be self-supporting, through sales of tickets to the main banquet in March and T-shirts with the UConn logo on the front and the 1905 and 1991 national champion women's basketball teams on the back.
These are some of the events planned for the spring term:
*An exhibit of portraits of 50 women important to UConn, taken by Pat Leavens, a graduate student in photography, will open at the Benton Museum on campus on Feb. 13 and run through March.
*A half-time show at the women's basketball game against the University of Pittsburgh at the Gampel Pavilion on Feb. 26 will honor some of the university's first women students and their families.
*An exhibit of archival UConn photos will open on March 4 in the walkway between the Legislative Office Building and the Capitol in Hartford. That evening, during the men's basketball game against Syracuse University at the Hartford Civic Center, a half-time show will honor the children of the original women students.
*At an awards banquet in Southington on March 26, 11 women who have made important contributions to UConn will be given medallions. Among them will be Rep. Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat of Hartford, and former state Representative Dorothy Goodwin of Mansfield, the first person to earn a Ph.D. in agricultural economics at UConn, in 1953.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 652 words

HEADLINE: Sack the Power Brokers

BYLINE: By Geoffrey Norman; Geoffrey Norman is author of "Sweetwater Ranch," a novel.

DATELINE: DORSET, Vt.

 BODY:
For fans who aren't trying to figure the spread and who don't live in the cities that claim the teams, the Super Bowl can be a problem: Three hours of not-so-good football (usually) preceded (always) by endless hype. Deciding which team to support has never been easy.
This year, it will be absurdly simple. For everyone living outside the Beltway, it is us versus them, baby. Them being the Redskins, the team from the nation's capital, which, if you didn't already know, is inside the Beltway. And full of insiders. 
 As TV commentators like to tell us, the Redskins are the only thing everyone in Washington can agree on. Everyone there loves them, knows all the words to their fight song and has had at least one drink with Billy Kilmer, a former Redskins quarterback.
Well, among those of us who don't live in Washington, there is one thing we can all agree on. We hate that city and all its works: B.C.C.I., the Keating Five, the Thomas hearings, the Gates hearings, a faltering economy.
Since we can't do anything to punish or even inconvenience our tormentors in Washington, we can take out our anger on the Redskins and pull for the Buffalo Bills. Maybe they can do to the Redskins on the gridiron what we want to do with term limitations but can't.
It's going to be hard. The Redskins have talent, some of it with the kind of seniority a Congressman would envy. They also have a coach, Joe Gibbs, with the discipline and intelligence of Richard Darman -- though Gibbs's record is much better than the President's budget director's.
The Redskins owner is Jack Kent Cooke, who always has a trophy politician or two in his box. As the Redskins savaged Detroit two weeks ago, Secretary of State James Baker looked on. Cooke has invited Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly of Washington and her husband to sit with him at the Super Bowl. Coincidentally, Cooke is negotiating with the city to build a new stadium for his team. There is discussion as to whether this constitutes a conflict of interest, or merely the appearance of a conflict of interest, a distinction that might be lost on most people outside the Beltway.
The late Edward Bennett Williams, Washington's archetypal power lawyer, was once part owner of the team. His clients included such Washington luminaries as Abe Fortas, Bobby Baker and Joe McCarthy. All of whom would have been Redskins fans.
The Redskins were the last team in the National Football League to integrate, even as Congress is the only Fortune 500-sized enterprise not covered by the Civil Rights Act or the Equal Employment Opportunity Act. Until recently, representatives were not even obliged to have money in the bank when they wrote a check.
Now all of this may seem like pure ad hominem and graceless ranting, but, what the hell, that's how just about all the powerful people in Washington got there in the first place. The city, remember, is also the home of the 30-second attack-video industry.
It has been a good, fat year for the Redskins. But then Washington is completely recession proof. Every year the Beltway insiders grow sleeker and more comfortable. Meanwhile, out in the beyond, in places like Detroit and Buffalo, people are hurting.
It will only feel good for a day but wouldn't it be fine to watch Jim Kelly, the Bills quarterback, cut up a defense with more specialists than the Pentagon has consultants? To see Cornelius Bennett, a linebacker, crush a Redskins back running the counter-trey, which is about as predictable as Congressional junkets and even harder to stop?
The smart money says it won't happen. A conspicuous exception is John Gotti, who said that he would bet on the Bills. But, then, he has his own reasons for holding a grudge against Washington. Anybody else who still has enough money to make a bet should probably go with the Redskins. The rest of us will be pulling for the Bills and vicarious vengeance.

HEADLINE: U.N.'S FUND CRISIS WORSENS AS ROLE IN SECURITY RISES

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 26

 BODY:
At a meeting here on Friday, President Bush and the leaders of the 14 other members of the Security Council are expected to call on the United Nations to play a growing role in preserving peace in trouble spots around the globe. But the organization finds itself facing a deepening financial crisis because many of these same member nations are not paying their share for the operations.
The United Nations has been called upon to mount 8 new peacekeeping operations since 1988. In its previous 43 years of existence, since its founding in 1945, there were 13 such operations. This year it is planning ambitious new operations in Cambodia and Yugoslavia involving a total of some 15,000 troops and police personnel. Those operations could double the organization's peacekeeping budget to more than $1 billion. 
 As a result the United States, which pays 30.38 percent of these bills under a formula assessing members according to their wealth, could see its assessment for peacekeeping rise from around $197 million last year to at least $300 million this year.
 
$377 Million Debt
 But no one here knows whether the members will pay the new assessments. The United States and other leading members already owe the United Nations hundreds of millions of dollars in unpaid peacekeeping fees. At the end of last year, member nations collectively owed $377 million in overdue peacekeeping assessments. While this debt was less than the record $444.1 million they owed at the end of 1989, the figure still represents the second-highest total on record.
The declaration that Mr. Bush and the others plan to issue this week is full of appeals to expand the organization's peacemaking role, but at present it offers no pledge to pay these unpaid bills. "The world's leaders are coming here to tell us to work harder," said a senior United Nations official who asked not to be identified. "But will they remember their checkbooks?"
 
China Is Paid Up
 The United States remains the biggest single delinquent on peacekeeping, owing $140.9 million at the end of last year.
Of the other four members with permanent Security Council seats, only China, which has the smallest share of the five, had paid its peacekeeping bills in full. Russia, which has taken over the debts and the Security Council seat of the former Soviet Union, owed $126.7 million for peacekeeping at the end of last year, while France owed $10.4 million and Britain $4 million.
Of other leading contributors to the United Nations peacekeeping budget, Germany has an unpaid assessment totaling $17 million, Ukraine owes $12.4 million, Poland $10 million and Italy $5 million.
In addition to unpaid peacekeeping charges, members owed $439.3 million to the organization's regular budget, again the second-highest figure on record, though slightly lower than their cumulative debts at the end of 1989.
These unpaid regular budget contributions worsen the budget crisis, officials say, by tightening the overall financial situation and making it harder to juggle funds between accounts.
 
U.S. Debt $739 Million
 Counting unpaid assessments for the regular budget, including the debt for this year, the United States' total debt now stands at $739.4 million. Not counting this year's assessment, the United States owed $407.3 million as of the end of last year.
These mounting debts have surprised and angered many top United Nations officials because the organization's peacekeeping role has been widely praised by governments and parliaments in recent years. In 1988 the United Nations was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for its peacekeeping efforts.
"It is a great irony," Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said before stepping down last month, "that the United Nations is on the brink of insolvency at the very time the world community has entrusted the organization with new and unprecedented responsibilities. It is the member states who must collectively bear the responsibility for this most unfortunate situation."
Sir Brian Urquhart, the former Under Secretary General in charge of peacekeeping, complained that peacekeeping operations have always been "run on a shoestring" and argued that governments must be prepared "to put adequate resources behind global and regional security systems."
 
Formula for Peacekeeping
 While countries are assessed contributions to the United Nations regular budget according to their wealth, peacekeeping contributions are divided differently, with the five permanent Security Council members paying relatively more because of their special responsibility under the Charter for preserving international security.
So, while the United States pays 25 percent of the regular budget, it pays 30.38 percent of the peacekeeping bills. Similarly, Russia pays 9.41 percent of the budget but 11.44 percent of the peacekeeping costs. The comparable shares for Britain are 5.02 and 6.10 percent; for France 6.oo and 7.29 percent; and for China 0.77 and 0.94 percent.
Calculating the cost of peacekeeping operations year by year is difficult, budget officials say, because the Security Council frequently mandates a force for a portion of a year or for a period bridging parts of two years. Start-up costs also usually increase expenses at the beginning of an operation.
 
Outlay for Cambodia
 But the cost of the new Cambodian peacekeeping operation is informally estimated at $750 million to $1 billion for the first full year. In that case, the United Nations must virtually take over the administration of the country as it organizes elections, in addition to sending troops and police forces.
Start-up costs will be particularly heavy because of the lack of basic infrastructure, like roads, bridges, airstrips and communications destroyed by years of civil war.
As a result, officials believe the United Nations could find itself spending $600 million to $700 million during the remainder of this year in Cambodia alone, assuming the operation gets fully under way by the start of the rainy season in May.
In addition the Security Council is considering sending a 10,000-member force into Yugoslavia to oversee the present fragile cease-fire at a cost estimated at $350 million to $400 million in a full year, bringing the total cost of both operations to about $1 billion. This would be double the roughly $500 million the United Nations spent last year on peacekeeping operations in Lebanon, the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights, Kuwait, Western Sahara, Angola, Central America and El Salvador.
 
2 Operations to End
 This year the cost of these seven operations will fall slightly with the Central American observer group's activity scheduled to end in April and the Angola operation scheduled to end in October.
But United Nations peacekeeping costs in El Salvador will rise sharply as its forces start overseeing the new truce and disarmament agreements there.
The United Nations also runs three peacekeeping operations which are not financed through the United Nations peacekeeping accounts.
One of them, the force deployed in Cyprus, costs about $ 31 million a year and is paid for by voluntary contributions from member states. But the United Nations truce observer mission based in Jerusalem and the observer mission on the India-Pakistan border, which together cost another $35 million a year, are paid from funds in the regular budget.

HEADLINE: 'Buy American': Remedy or Tunnel Vision?

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Intended or not, President Bush's trade mission to Japan has now stirred an emotional wave of "buy American" fervor across the recession-pocked land. But economists and trade experts say the movement is a dubious remedy for the underlying ills of the American economy.
Sentiments reached a peak last Wednesday, when the Los Angeles County Transportation Commission, after withering public attack, rescinded the $122 million contract it had issued to a Japanese company for new rail cars for a mass transit system. 
 The feelings are being echoed all across the country.
Like a number of companies that are giving their workers inducements to buy American cars, Dr. William Lippy, an ear surgeon in Warren, Ohio, has begun his own campaign, as he put it, to "jump-start America" by offering his 35 employees bonuses to buy used or new American cars by July 4.
In Edwardsville, Ill., Bill Chartrand is offering a 2-cent-a-gallon discount to drivers of American cars at his Fina gas station. "I didn't do it to punish foreign-car owners," said Mr. Chartrand, who drives a 1990 Chevrolet pickup. "I did it to reward the American car owner."
Here in Los Angeles, the City Council is considering a bill that would give American companies preferences in bidding for municipal contracts. The legislation would alter the City Charter, which currently requires Los Angeles to award its contracts to the lowest bidder.
But not everyone is angry at Japan.
John Bragg, a Tennessee state lawmaker who served on the negotiating team that lured Nissan to his state, does not think much of the buy-American movement. It's little more than "Japan bashing," he said, adding: "What it all is is politics and perception. The fact is, the British and Germans don't buy any American cars. We don't fuss with them."
And whether "buy American" gestures will do much good, even in the short run, is at the very least questionable, commerce experts say.
 
Would Tactic Backfire?
 Some fear a protectionist trade war that would depress American exports to Japan, including motion pictures, music recordings and apparel, three products that find a particularly lucrative market among the Japanese.
"We have to be careful, because whether people realize it or not we are joined at the hip with Japan here in Los Angeles," said Jack Kyser, chief economist at the Economic Development Corporation, a private group trying to stimulate a Southern California economy depressed by the slowdown in the nation's military spending.
Further, experts say, American consumers will be unwilling or unable to sustain any buy-American fervor for long, in part because many continue to believe in Japanese manufacturing superiority, but also because it is becoming increasingly difficult to say with certainty that one product is American, another Japanese. "A General Motors car can have more Japanese components than a Japanese car," said David B. Friedman, an expert on Japanese-American trade relations at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif.
 
The Lines Are Blurred
 Never was this kind of confusion better illustrated than last week in Greece, N.Y., a Rochester suburb, where the Town Board voted against buying a used Komatsu dirt excavator, the cheapest available alternative, in favor of an American-made excavator. Then the board learned that the Komatsu excavator had been made in the United States, and that a John Deere model under consideration had been made in Japan. Both were the products of American-Japanese joint ventures.
Indeed, numerous experts doubt that consumers can tell the difference anymore between American and foreign products. For example, Mitsubishi big-screen televisions sold in American showrooms are assembled in a factory in Santa Ana, Calif., from parts that are partly domestic, partly foreign, but with a crew of 687 American workers.
About 40 percent of the cars sold under Honda, Toyota,Nissan and other Japanese names are actually made in the United States. Workers at such plants in Smyrna, Tenn.; Marysville, Ohio, and Fremont, Calif., are concerned that the buy-American campaign will cost them jobs.
The confusion was apparent Friday afternoon outside Adray's, a discount appliance store in Los Angeles. Albert Williams, 66 years old, was loading two new Pioneer stereo speakers into his Oldsmobile Cutlass. "I can't say much about it, because I don't know where they're made," he said. "Pioneer's American, isn't it?" When told it was a Japanese product, he said, "It sounds American."
A few moments later, Basil W. Barnes emerged with a big Zenith television set, saying he had bought it rather than a Japanese-made Sony "to wave the flag a little." The Zenith Electronics Corporation of Glenview, Ill., is the only American-owned television maker. Zenith sets are assembled in Springfield, Mo., and Reynosa, Mexico. But by year's end, all operations will be transferred to Mexico, with a loss of 1,000 jobs in Springfield.
And Fernando C. Coto bought a Sony stereo system at Adray's without compunction. "I just think it's up to the Americans to make it better," he said. "Why should I buy something that's not as good?"
Consumer experts said this is the hard reality that the buy-American campaign will face. David Cross, an economist with the Futures Group, a consulting firm in Washington that specializes in consumer trends, said 25 to 30 percent of the typical consumer's budget went to imported products, directly or indirectly.
And reducing imports, he said, would have the effect of raising prices. "Price resistance in this recession has been extraordinary," he said. "So interest in buying American will collide with the fact that we do not have the money to do that. It's not like we can quickly retool and start producing everything we need domestically."
 
'Errors and Poor Judgment'
 There is paradox in the fact that the most recent buy-American campaign flared in California, a state whose economy is deeply entwined with that of Japan. Mr. Kyser said 600 Japanese companies maintained operations in Southern California, employing 58,000 workers, mostly Americans. He added that Japanese airlines were major purchaser of Boeing jets, whose bodies are made at a Northrop Corporation plant in suburban Hawthorne. And Japan is a big market for the two quintessential California products, motion pictures and recordings.
"There have been errors and poor judgment on both sides," Mr. Kyser said. "If this hysteria continues, it could be painful for Southern California."
But public officials have found themselves under enormous pressure to do something to save American jobs. This poses a predicament for officials of the Bay Area Rapid Transit system in San Francisco, who are taking bids for at least 50 new cars for an extension of the 20-year-old line serving San Francisco and the East Bay. The original cars were made by Rohr Industries of Chula Vista, Calif., but Rohr has since quit that business.
An American company and two Japanese consortiums bid. The American company, Morrison Knudsen Corporation of Boise, Idaho, lost the Los Angeles rail bid to the Japanese Sumitomo Corporation of America.
 
Can't Buy Inferior Cars
 The president of the BART board of directors, Wilfred Ussery, said he wanted to favor American companies. But he added: "We cannot buy a product that will downgrade our current system. No one will remember who made the cars in five years if they start breaking down. They'll just blame BART."
At the State Capitol in Sacramento, the Democratic leadership is pushing a bill that would give preference to California companies bidding on $6 billion worth of public works projects. The bill would allow California concerns to bid up to 10 percent higher than the low bid and still get the contract; require a minimum domestic content of at least 51 percent in raw materials, parts and equipment used in each project, and require that on each project at least half the workers be California residents of at least a year. Twenty-six other states already have such in-state bid preferences.
Across the country, companies, labor unions and individual citizens are taking their own grass-roots measures:
*In Grand Rapids, Mich., the Autodie Corporation, a tool and die maker, said it would use American-made supplies whenever possible as retaliation against a Japanese legislator's comments last week that American workers were lazy.
*The 2,500-member Michigan Association of Police, a union that represents police officers and security guards, said that it would try to negotiate a special bonus of 3 percent of an employee's salary to anyone who bought or leased an American car.
*In Alexandria, Va., Jane Crawford reported that business was brisk at her store, America, which sells flags, patriotic memorabilia and other products made entirely in the United States.
But there are also fears that the movement could be self-destructive. In Sparta, Tenn., near Nashville, 4,850 workers produce cars and trucks at the $1.2 billion plant built by the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A. The cars have a Japanese brand name but are built by Americans, using 150 American suppliers. Workers and local officials there are nervous. Mr. Bragg, the lawmaker from nearby Murfreesboro, said Nissan was a good corporate citizen and had generated thousands of Tennessee jobs.
Indeed, some Japanese-Americans see racist overtones in the buy-American movement.
 
'People Are Scared'
 "People are scared and frustrated about the economy, and they want to blame someone," said Mas Fukai, who was interned with his family in Arizona during World War II and is now a top aide to Kenneth Hahn, a Los Angeles County Supervisor.
"Lockheed moved to Georgia, and we're losing 20,000 jobs there," Mr. Fukai said. "Northrop is moving. The General Motors plant in Van Nuys is closing. Why isn't anyone bashing them? We're becoming a target. I'm being asked, 'What are you?' When I say I'm an American, they say, 'You know what I mean.' That has not surfaced since the 40's."
Dennis W. Hayashi, national director of the Japanese American Citizens League in San Francisco, said: "There is an underlying racial animus creeping into the dialogue. Some people don't want to see that the recession has many causes."
Mr. Friedman, of the Rand Corporation, said that the move to bolster domestic products and labor could ultimately be fruitful if localities take the long-term steps needed to build the kind of local industrial networks and ties that exist in Japan. Otherwise, he said, buying American is just "misplaced nationalism" that serves only to reward inefficiency. "One can imagine the worst outcome of this is that Americans will rally to save General Motors from 50 years of past follies."

HEADLINE: Bias Crimes Hold Steady, but Leave Many Scars

SERIES: Hatred Up Close: The Tension in New York -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Their encounters with hatred came as a mellow May day dissolved into evening.
A young black man and his Hispanic girlfriend were talking amicably in a restaurant in the Baychester section of the Bronx. According to a police synopsis, two white men began staring malevolently at them. After a while, one snidely challenged the black man, "What did you say, nigger?" The white man then punched him in the head and shoved his pregnant girlfriend. Before fleeing, the white men warned the black man that the next time they saw him they would kill him. 
 A young Italian man found bigotry scribbled in longhand. One morning last June, he was opening his plant store in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, when he discovered an anonymous note. It read, "Wop bastard, you will burn like your store."
For two young gay men in Forest Hills, Queens, the ear-splitting noise was too much. It was late on a September afternoon, and their neighbor's stereo was shaking the walls. The men wandered downstairs, rapped on their neighbor's door and asked him to lower the volume. The neighbor grew incensed and heckled them using a fusillade of anti-gay epithets.
Three displays of hatred, these cases joined the list of 540 bias crimes recorded last year by the police. There was nothing pretty about any of them, and some were especially abhorrent. But despite this roll of misdeeds against difference -- and a troubling spate of hate incidents in recent weeks -- police statistics show that the number of bias cases in New York City has remained fairly steady over the last four years.
Since as many as 11 of the 540 incidents may be reclassified by a police review panel, the number of bias cases in 1991 was virtually the same as the 527 logged in 1990 and beneath the peak of 550 in 1988. Statistics have been kept only since 1981.
The commander of the Police Department's Bias Incident Investigating Unit, Inspector William T. Wallace, points out that viewed from a historical perspective, bias crimes may well be falling. "People say, 'I don't remember it this bad,' " Inspector Wallace said. "How could they remember? We didn't count these crimes years ago. Why were there all those civil rights marches if things were so hunky-dory in the good old days? In all probability, there were more bias crimes 30 or 40 years ago."
On the other hand, advocacy groups for ethnic, religious and other minorities complain that the police counts underplay the frictions in the city. "I don't believe the police numbers represent reality," said Matt Foreman, executive director of the New York City Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project, who feels attacks on homosexuals are steadily rising. His group tallied more than six times as many offenses against gay people last year as the police listed.
 
Effects
Visible Results Appear Small
 Even small numbers of hate crimes reflect poorly on society. Still, an examination of the incidents reported last year indicates that many defy facile labels, mixed up as they often are in matters of turf and class and economic jealousy, and that most are less serious -- at least on the surface -- than the sprinkling that become encased in publicity.
All in all, last year's episodes varied enormously in severity, from the 140 incidents of phone calls and letters laced with slurs to the 11 swastikas painted on synagogues and homes of Jewish families to the 40 assaults on homosexuals to the three homicides, one of which seems certain to be reclassified.
Most of the 540 cases did not involve physical injury. The three murders and 146 assaults were 28 percent of the total. There are almost that many assaults every day in New York, and Inspector Wallace said that most of the bias-related ones resulted in minor cuts and bruises.
Nevertheless, victims say that bias crimes often wound the psyche more than the body and leave a residue of painful distrust and fitful dreams. And the sting is felt by whole groups of people of similar faith, race or sexual preference.
 
'My Son Had Nightmares'
 "You do not forget," said Yitzchak Bitton, who with his 12-year-old son was beaten by black teen-agers in Crown Heights last summer. "My son had nightmares about being attacked for months. When he's outside, he's always afraid, always scared. It's on his mind every minute when he walks the streets."
A gay man who spoke on the condition of anonymity said he carried a .38-caliber pistol while out alone at night ever since he and his companion were pummeled last October by four men in the West Village. "This has had such negative impacts on my life that I can't tell you," he said. "I'm really paranoid."
Every year seems to have one or two signature events that captivate the media, politicians and citizens and result in a flurry of retaliation and imitation. In 1991, two dramas in Brooklyn overshadowed the year.
In July, a real-estate office in Canarsie was firebombed for showing properties to blacks, touching off a wave of racial disturbances. In August in the Crown Heights section, Gavin Cato, a 7-year-old black child, was accidentally killed by a car driven by a Hasidic man who was part of a rabbi's motorcade. In a later melee involving bands of black youths, Yankel Rosenbaum, a 29-year-old Hasidic scholar, was stabbed to death.
 
Incidents Rose After Fire
 Before the firebombing, bias crimes tracked by the police in 1991 were running 23 percent below 1990. After the disturbances, incidents rose to more than 25 percent above the level for the same period in 1990. Twenty-one bias incidents plagued Crown Heights in just the three days after the deaths. The bias unit logged 79 bias cases in September -- the most in a single month since the unit was formed in December 1980 -- most of them anti-Semitic incidents. The previous high was 77, in October 1989 after the killing of a 16-year-old black youth, Yusuf K. Hawkins, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.
On the evening after the Crown Heights deaths, as the neighborhood's streets rocked with anger, Buruch Hoffinger was on the brink of safety. Hurrying home from his job at a book publisher, he was nearing his door when, he said, four black teen-agers spied him and shouted, "There's a Jew." Stones and a brick came flying at him. The brick opened a gash on his right temple. After he washed up, he called the police but, since he was unable to give a precise description, no arrests were made.
"I never felt comfortable for months after that," Mr. Hoffinger said. "I was boiling anger at the injustice and the stupidity of it all. I was attacked because I had a beard and wore a hat -- just that. I'll never be over it. I feel very sad. I feel bad that people don't know God. They don't know his unity. They don't know his love. They choose to live in a shanty rather than a mansion."
Immediately afterward, he gathered up a cache of stones and stashed them beneath his car seat. "If somebody threw rocks at me again," he said, "they would get a surprise."
The stones are still there. As they click against each other whenever he drives down the street, up wells the past.
 
Causes
War, TV Account Or New Neighbor
 Evildoing happens everywhere. Hate crimes, according to the bias unit, often spring up in neighborhoods in the throes of transformation and in poor areas, but, as Inspector Wallace said, "No neighborhood is exempt."
Last year, Brooklyn experienced 205 incidents, Manhattan had 132 (many of them attacks on homosexuals in Greenwich Village), Queens had 102, Staten Island had 61 and the Bronx, the borough with the highest murder rate, trailed with 40. The small number in the Bronx, Inspector Wallace says, may stem in part from a seeming reluctance by Hispanic immigrants and other residents to report crimes. Anti-bias groups say that many non-English-speaking residents in poor neighborhoods mistrust the police, feel that nothing will come of reporting crimes, and don't want to get involved.
The biggest percentage increase over 1990 -- a jump of more than 90 percent -- occurred on Staten Island. The reasons for the surge are cloudy, though Mr. Wallace said there were anti-Jewish and anti-Arab incidents during the Persian Gulf war.
Most of the Staten Island cases did not lead to physical injury, said Deputy Inspector William Calhoun, chief of detectives there. Many, he said, were insulting phone calls to Jews. "These are random calls where people want to say something clever for that night's fun," he said.
Most reported incidents appear to be crimes by the young against the young. The bias unit said that more than 60 percent of the criminals were under 20, as were an equal percentage of the victims. Hate crimes are often meant to be symbolic, and nearly 100 targets were edifices -- synagogues, churches, businesses and cemeteries.
Last July, for instance, four fires erupted at the Yeshiva Kerem Schlomo in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn. Three pentagrams and offensive scribblings like "Hail Satan" were discovered in the main service room and basement. The school had extensive damage. There have been no arrests.
Thus far, 183 arrests have been made in 1991's 540 cases, some of them multiple arrests in a single incident. Inspector Wallace said that arrests occurred in roughly 20 percent of the cases, and in another 5 percent or so victims changed their minds about pursuing a prosecution.
 
Underreporting Is Suspected
 Advocacy groups for minorities feel certain that as with rapes, only a small number of bias crimes are reported. Howard Ehrlich, director of research at the National Institute Against Prejudice and Violence, said that probably 80 percent of incidents are not reported, chiefly because victims feel nothing will be done. Asians, in particular, are said to be loath to report bias incidents, partly because of language and cultural barriers. The police logged only eight bias crimes against Chinese and Koreans last year. Many homosexuals, especially those more private about their lives, do not report incidents, nor do illegal immigrants.
The largest category of bias crimes last year involved race -- 247. Of those, 121 were aimed at blacks, 70 at whites, 38 at Hispanic people, 10 at East Indians, 6 at Chinese and 2 at Koreans. Far more often than not, they were unfair acts -- a group of four to several dozen against one or two victims.
Who knows what exactly set them off? Two Hispanic girls, one 17 and one 21, were standing at the corner of 208th Street and Hillside Avenue in Queens Village on an April afternoon when a group of nine black teen-agers -- eight women and one man -- came by. According to the police account, one of the blacks said, 'Oh, those white people. What are you looking at, white bitches?" The two girls were then roughed up and slightly injured.
Of the 178 crimes last year directed against religious conviction, all but six were against Jews. "It shows the scourge of anti-Semitism remains very much part of our society," said Michael Riff, associate director of the New York regional office of the Anti-Defamation League.
In May, a Holocaust survivor was featured in an article in The New York Post. Shortly afterward, the police said he said he got an anonymous letter in the mail laced with anti-Semitic remarks and threats.
There were 88 reported anti-gay crimes in 1991, down slightly from 1990, when a summerlong string of attacks caused reported cases to more than double to 101. Of the 88 last year, 40 were assaults, nearly a third of the total reported bias assaults.
 
Chances
Hate and Ill Luck Are Irrational Pair
 To a large extent, hate crimes do not follow a script, but are spontaneous attacks, touched off by the wrong person's running into the wrong people. Supporting this is the choice of weapons, often fists and feet or whatever might be lying on the street -- bottles, tree branches, fluorescent light bulbs. In May, a young gay man was walking down a Manhattan street when another man grabbed a placard and yelled at him, "I'm going to kill all you fags."
He missed. Others didn't.
Eric Torrez's date with hatred came just a short way from home. Toward midnight on an evening last March, the 30-year-old gay man was strolling home from a friend's place. As he neared his apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, he spotted four youths between the ages of 15 and 20. He knew them from the neighborhood and from the disparaging remarks they had made to him before.
He said they went up to him and, after a brief exchange, began pummeling him with their fists. As they did, he said, they chanted, "Beat the homo, beat the homo."
Mr. Torrez said he had a chipped tooth, a black eye and other bruises. He flagged down a patrol car. Eventually, three of the suspects were arrested and two were tried on charges of assault. One was acquitted and one received a 45-day jail term.
"I don't go out as much as I used to now," he said. "If I have to walk down that block, I do it in the daytime. If I see a group of young boys, I cross the street. I won't go into the crowd."
Next: Experts say the surge in bias crimes in New York City this month is actually a predictable phenomenon that has happened several times in recent years.

HEADLINE: In New York, State Prisoners Work or Else

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
New York State's prison system has quietly imposed one of the nation's toughest mandatory work policies, locking inmates who refuse work in their cells for 23 hours a day and then blackballing them when they come up for parole.
The new work policy was put in place over the last year when 1,071 inmates were locked in their cells until they agreed to work and another 267 had their privileges restricted, state correction officials said. 
 The officials also said lesser penalties are imposed on inmates who refused to enroll in education and vocational programs.
The tough new approach has raised concerns among prisoners' rights groups. But New York correction officials say it reflects their intent to achieve three objectives: force inmates to help pay the $25,000-a-year costs of imprisoning them, prepare them more effectively to hold jobs after their release, and counter a growing feeling among some segments of the public that prisons have become much too easy for inmates.
"I've been troubled for years by the public perception that inmates sit around all day watching TV or pumping iron while the average guy is trying hard to make ends meet," said Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, Commissioner of the State Department of Correctional Services. "We fully intend to change the perception of inmates getting a free ride."
"We have a basic responsibility to teach inmates how to read and write," he said in a telephone interview. "Just as important, inmates have the responsibility to help support the cost of their incarceration."
Many states including New Jersey and Connecticut, and the Federal prison system, have adopted stronger work policies. But New York's new mandatory requirements are regarded by correction experts as among the toughest in the nation, because of the severity of the penalties if inmates refuse to work, said George Camp, co-president of the Criminal Justice Institute, a private group that studies penal institutions. Most states with any penalties at all for refusing to work curtail privileges or time off for good behavior.
In New York, when inmates are locked up for refusing to work, they eat in their cells and are allowed out one hour a day for exercise.
Of New York's 58,155 state inmates, 27,967 are enrolled in work programs that vary from cleaning and painting jobs to making license plates, building office furniture and producing cleaning supplies. Another 19,577 are in education, vocational, and various treatment programs. There are 3,146 unemployed. The rest are involved in various other programs, in hospitals, or are restricted for reasons like security.
Robert Gangi, head of the Correctional Association of New York, a private organization that studies prison and criminal justice issues, is highly critical of the penalties used to force inmates to work: "It's Draconian," he said. "We don't treat animals in a zoo that way."
Mr. Gangi also contended that the state's new policies were "nothing more than a public relations effort to show how tough the state is going to be with inmates."
Law-enforcement groups, however, generally support the new push. Thomas Reppetto, the head of the Citzens Crime Commission, which describes itself as a private watchdog over criminal justice issues, said he favored the new approach. "It's a good idea to require inmates to work and pay their own way," he said.
 
Bringing Back Work Gangs
 Mr. Coughlin said a natural progression for his department's new emphasis on work would be the reinstitution of old-fashioned inmate work gangs that fell into public disfavor in the past.
Inmates now perform a limited number of tightly supervised outside work tasks, mostly in upstate rural areas where the public has become accustomed to their presence.
But Mr. Coughlin said he is preparing to expand the concept widely, organizing even more tightly supervised work gangs to clean up littered railroad lines and highways, the state's parks and beaches and even sections of New York's inner cities.
"They would be doing work that is not being done and which will not be done without them," he said, anticipating the promised opposition of public unions who view any outside work by inmates as an economic threat.
 
Important Factor in Parole
 Under a law approved by the Legislature in 1987, inmates can acquire an Earned Eligibility Certificate in return for participating successfully in education, vocation and work programs. The certificate strongly counts in an inmate's favor when applying for parole, and strongly against him when he lacks it.
David Ernst, a spokesman for the State Division of Parole, said inmates who appear for a parole hearing with the certificate have an 80 percent chance of being released, while the chances of inmates who do not have a certificate are reduced to 33 percent.
"The certificate is a powerful work incentive," Mr. Ernst said.
"Proof positive," said Commissioner Coughlin, "is that 67 percent of inmates are now gaining parole at their first hearing, compared with 60 percent before the eligibility certificate was introduced."
The idea of putting inmates to work began in New York 160 years ago at the state prison in Auburn. But the practice fell in disfavor in the late 19th century amid scandals involving the exploitation of convicts and later with the widespread revulsion at the cruelty and deprivation of Southern chain gangs.
 
Reducing Prison Costs
 In recent years, factories and workshops that produce far more than state license plates have been established at 15 prisons. It is on this manufacturing base that the department wants to superimpose a better trained inmate work force to reduce the costs of imprisonment at a time when prison budgets are being cut.
For example, inmates produce a complete line of office furniture, metal cabinets and cleaning supplies for state and local government agencies. They are also providing more services to the agencies and to nonprofit groups, jobs that include reconstruction, painting and upkeep.
For this they are paid 60 cents a day at the start and ultimately 65 cents an hour for a normal 40-hour workweek. Prisoners are required to enter educational and vocational programs before joining work programs.
In his State of the State message this month, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a wide variety of inmate work initiatives, including the establishment of a Prison Industries Corporation.
 
'Giving Something Back'
 "The Governor strongly supports that idea of inmates giving something back to the community," said Terry Lynam, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo.
The Federal Government is also encouraging inmates to work. Daniel Dunne, a spokesman for the United States Bureau of Prisons, said that if an inmate refuses to work he risks being confined to solitary, losing "good time" that otherwise would have been subtracted from his sentence, and any chance of entering an early work-release program.
James Stabile, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Corrections, which has 20,000 inmates, said inmates are not required to work. But if they refuse, he said they lose "good time" credit and any chance at early work-release.
William Flower, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Correction, which has about 9,500 inmates, said that if an inmate declines work, his refusal is referred unfavorably to parole officials. But he said that the department does not have enough jobs to put most inmates to work and that many prisoners consequently "lay up" all day without performing any tasks.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Drama at Macy's
R. H. Macy's lawyers and investment bankers worked to assemble the financing package that the retailer needs if it files for bankruptcy protection, as expected. The arrangements were expected to be completed by today, and several participants reiterated their belief that a filing was imminent. If a filing is made, a judge will settle the fate of lenders, bondholders, suppliers and the company itself, but the stores will operate as usual. [Page D1.]
What went wrong at Macy's? The problems of the retailer, like those of many companies in bankruptcy, stem from the billions of dollars borrowed to enable its managers to buy the company from stockholders. News Analysis. [A1.]
Tremors emanating from the shaky foundation of Macy's parent company are being felt by shoppers on 34th Street. [D1.]
 
Companies 
 Customers seeking greater speed and reliability in their computer storage systems have been turning to EMC, which beat Storage Technology to the market by 15 months. [D1.]
Compaq is introducing the first computers of its Eckhard Pfeiffer era, two notebook models with several new features. [D1.]
 
The Economy
Americans are on the move again after two years of reduced travel, producing an unexpected spurt in bookings for cruise ships, hotels and airlines in recent weeks. [A1.]
Provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act took effect, requiring businesses to give equal access to millions of disabled Americans. [A1.]
The President's trade mission to Japan has stirred an emotional wave of "buy American" fervor. But economists and trade experts say the movement is a dubious remedy for the economy's underlying ills. [A1.]
President Bush and the Democrats seem intent on trying to outdo each other in proposing tax cuts. But many economists say that in the long run the nation needs higher taxes, which would help lift the paltry U.S. savings rate. [D1.]
 
International
Russia's Fuel and Energy Minister said his Government would push for practices that prevent Western oil companies from earning too big a return on their investments. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
When Hearst snapped up the editor in chief of British Vogue to head Harper's Bazaar, it sent a shiver through the fiercely competitive world of fashion magazines. [D1.]
Political access has given The Washington Times its own genuine, if limited, place in the capital's rich media mix. But The Times remains a very expensive and unsuccessful business. [D6.]
A new Jewish magazine hopes to get off to a running start by turning some of the nation's top charitable donors into instant subscribers. But the plan has drawn complaints. [D6.]
The three networks have quietly sought concessions to head off larger losses in the two years remaining on their contract with the N.F.L. Their losses have collectively exceeded $200 million during the first two years. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
It took CBS until Friday to sell the last of the available ad spots for the Super Bowl, a consequence of a fundamental change in advertisers' planning ability. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

Traders of Treasury securities seem to have few quarrels with the sweeping market changes proposed by the Government. Some say there is widespread recognition that many of the proposals are sound. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D5.]
Dole's stock languished after the company reported disappointing third-quarter earnings. Last week, shareholders got a more pleasant surprise. Market Place. [D4.]
