HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Kerrey Moves to Reinvigorate Campaign

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Senator Bob Kerrey has not been having as much fun running for President as he thought he would.
Asked why not, as he sat the other night drinking a draft beer and eating popcorn in an airport bar in Houston, the Democrat from Nebraska offered his whimsical smile and replied, "Cosmic forces." 
 Later, he elaborated. "I mean that there are many things I don't control," he said. "I'm just saying that I don't believe that there are people in the heavens who are doing anything other than laughing at times at my foolishness."
Welcome to the first Presidential campaign with an air of Pirandello, an absurdist adventure marked by ironic detachment, existential angst, black humor and, believe it or not, a vow of celibacy.
 
How to Catch Up
 "Cosmic Bob," as the Senator is known in political circles because of his offbeat style, has been trying to figure out a way to catch up with "Slick Willie," as Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas is known for his smooth patter.
With a more focused attitude and a new campaign team, Mr. Kerrey is hoping to make the most of the fresh attention that will come his way as Mr. Clinton struggles with questions about his personal life. Although Mr. Kerrey's strategists have been careful not to gloat for the record over the rival camp's stumble, they are clearly eager to profit from the fact that the Democratic race once again seems fluid.
Hailed early by the press as a 48-year-old combination of Sir Lancelot and James Dean, Mr. Kerrey faded through the fall with flat performances, a vague agenda, except for his health insurance plan, and an overreliance on his war record. Faced with a renewed opportunity, Mr. Kerrey's response so far is not to offer the missing details of how he would govern but to try to persuade Democrats that details are a trivial pursuit and that he is not their man unless they want to make a leap of faith.
 
'You've Got to Fight for It'
 "I am not a bookkeeper," he said, in an interview in Washington last week, referring to Mr. Clinton's promotion of himself as a seasoned manager with an economic plan. "I am not a person who has any desire to come forward and say, 'Here's a cabinet full of smooth-moving drawers.'
"I'm going to try to drive out the idea that this is just about nominating someone who's electable. You either are or you are not in politics because you want to change the world. I do not, in a very personal way, believe that good all by itself conquers evil. You've got to fight for it."
Mr. Kerrey is trying to make a virtue of vagueness, arguing that his status as a work in progress, an unfinished politician, could be a strength as President.
He said he carried with him a book by Albert Schweitzer that explained why it was good not to have all the answers. "Schweitzer says that real learning doesn't occur unless you are in an attitude of humility," Mr. Kerrey said. "And that's extremely difficult as a politician.
 
Shines in Small Settings
 By the standards of modern campaigning, Mr. Kerry can be amiable and witty in small settings. On a trip to Berlin in northern New Hampshire, he charmed hard-boiled reporters by talking excitedly about how his motel bed featured the "Magic Fingers" massage machine and asking an aide to come up and check out the shaking bed.
Mr. Kerrey was asked what he did for fun outside of politics with a warning that Michael S. Dukakis had answered the question, "Black mulch," speaking of fertilizing his tomato plants. Mr. Kerrey replied with a twinkle: "Black Mulch. I have some of their albums."
While he affects the sing-song Kennedy cadences in speeches, Mr. Kerrey has not shown the potent charisma of John F. Kennedy, which Democrats seek like the Holy Grail. At one of Mr. Kerrey's appearances a large number of Dartmouth students left a less-than-scintillating session early to go to a screening of "J. F. K."
Mr. Kerrey often seems more like wry observer than eager candidate. With large blue eyes and a lightbulb-shaped head that give him the look of a bemused extraterrestial, he continues to maintain an unusual Jamesian distance from his campaign.
Even on an unscheduled stop at an American Legion Post in Manchester last week, surrounded by admiring Vietnam veterans who greeted him as "a brother," Mr. Kerrey did not seem to fit into the scene easily. With a military cap perched on his head and a beer, Mr. Kerrey chatted rather awkwardly with some of the men around the bar.
 
Learning How to Shout
 He asked Bill Genesee, 38 years old, who was describing his job at the Raytheon Corporation making missiles, "When you walk past sheet metal, wouldn't you like to get out and bang it?"
Stung by criticism that he was too diffident, Mr. Kerrey has been trying to convey urgency by adding a life-and-death message to his speeches and speaking in a louder voice.
"People would come up and say, 'You just don't seem to want this badly enough, because you're not shouting at us,' " So now I'm given to shouting, and it's not my favorite voice," he said.
Mr. Kerrey's aides tend to watch him nervously, knowing that he sometimes says things that are more Brecht than boilerplate.
In response to a question about Sidney Blumenthal's New Republic cover articles on "The Politics of Self: Bob Kerrey's Shallow Campaign" and "The Anointed, Bill Clinton, Party Favorite," Mr. Kerrey laughingly suggested that he would like to "loosen one of his teeth," a move that he told others would wipe away Mr. Blumenthal's "preppy little smile."
 
'Close to the Edge'
 "He does skate close to the edge," a strategist for Mr. Kerrey, Michael McCurry, said. "But sometimes I think he says things that provoke reactions just to remind himself that he's not a conventional politician, to remind himself, 'If you're not careful, you're going to wind up like Bill Clinton.' "
Mr. Kerrey's strategists see his problem as how to convince people that he is different but reassure them that he is not too different. People may snicker at Vice President Dan Quayle's reading Paul Johnson's "Modern Times," a history of the 20th century, for three years, according to what he and his aides tell reporters. But it may also make voters nervous when Mr. Kerrey says one of his favorite books is Walker Percy's "Moviegoer," an anthem of alienation about a Korean War veteran out of touch with the rest of America.
Mr. Kerrey agrees that sometimes his aides are right when they warn him with the "time out" hand signal. "I can keep a little line on the reel," he said. "I don't need to put it all out there."
Mr. Kerrey presents his character, shaped by war and wounds, as the reason why voters should put faith in his leadership.
As a candidate, John F. Kennedy let Red Fay and other aides brag about his war record as a fighter, while he discreetly avoided the topic. But Mr. Kerrey still begins speeches with lines like this one to an A.F.L.-C.I.O. meeting in Austin last week: "Let me start off by saying that in spite of the fact that I left a little of myself over in Vietnam, there's a hell of a lot left to be able to drive George Bush and Danforth Quayle out of that White House."
Mr. Kerrey suggested that some reporters who had criticized him for talking too much about his war record were "feeling this enormous guilt themselves, because they didn't do anything" in the war.
He said he did not mind that many men in his generation chose to avoid going to war. "It doesn't bother me deeply," he said. "But when there's dishonesty, it does. When Quayle first had his trouble in 1988, I defended him. But when he asserted that he got into the National Guard in order to go to Vietnam, he lost me completely. That was a lie. He didn't get into the Guard in order to get in Vietnam.
"But what I do object to is now when they come and give this golden reason for why they really wanted to go to Vietnam. Bill Clinton does that a little. I mean, come on, there were a lot of us who didn't want to go to Vietnam."
In speeches, Mr. Kerrey obliquely scores Mr. Clinton for making "personal responsibility" a campaign theme, implying that his own nine months in a Navy hospital in Philadelphia learning how to walk again imbued him with moral superiority. "I understand the nature of personal responsibility," he tells audiences. "I'm the one, since I was injured, that had to learn how to walk, learn how to run, how to do the things I wanted to do."
In conversations with friends, he denigrates Mr. Clinton as lacking conscience, complaining that the Governor of Arkansas had made too many political compromises trying to make everyone happy.
"I have learned the necessity of developing a conscience and of letting that conscience speak to you," Mr. Kerrey said. "The ground for my campaign isn't a position paper or a policy institute. The ground is my conscience."
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kerrey had a tiff after Mr. Clinton had made a commercial criticizing Mr. Kerrey for voting for the Congressional pay raise. Mr. Kerrey noted that Mr. Clinton had the perquisites of the Governor's office. Mr. Clinton shot back that Mr. Kerrey, too, had "lived in the Governor's mansion."
"There were a lot of stories written about it," Mr. Clinton.
Privately, Mr. Kerrey was furious at Mr. Clinton's apparent reference to his relationship with Debra Winger, the actress. He told people that he was single and free to do as he pleased and that Mr. Clinton had a nerve mentioning it.
 
Decision Not to Date
 Even before reports about an extramarital affair by Mr. Clinton, Mr. Kerrey said he had decided that he could not date during his campaign, even though he had been divorced from his wife, Beverly Defnall, for 14 years. They had been married for four years.
He said he believed that in a political season when voters quickly sketched in portraits he could not take the risk. "People do not know who Bob Kerrey is, and I don't want them to be reading stories about who it is that I'm dating and trying to figure out who I am," he said.
Although Mr. Kerrey would like to present himself as the candidate of conscience, the politician who embodies the idealism and skepticism of the 60's and who hates expediency and trade-offs, that message keeps running into sharp questions about own values, business practices and conflicting positions.
At the St. Paul's Academy in Concord, N.H., Mr. Kerrey received a bristling reception from students who wanted to know how he could emphasize national health insurance when the part-time workers in his restaurant chain did not have health insurance.
On "Meet the Press" on NBC News Mr. Kerrey delivered a stumbling response on abortion, as he tried to explain that his switch from opponent to proponent.
 
Questions on Death Penalty
 In 1982 Mr. Kerrey said in a letter to Nebraska State Senator Bernice Labedz that he believed "the unborn to be human life and entitled to all the protections the state can legally offer for the preservation of life."
He added that the "death and destruction of young men that I led in battle" in Vietnam had helped shape his decision.
But on Saturday, Mr. Kerrey was asked about the death penalty by former Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton, now an executive in Harlem. Mr. Sutton, at a candidates' forum sponsored by the Rainbow Coalition in Washington, asked how Mr. Kerrey could support the death penalty, in light of the fact that he had talked about seeing young men die in Vietnam and that "so many people who are poor are not given the opportunity to have proper representation."
"Death is final, isn't it?" Mr. Sutton asked Mr. Kerrey in just the sort of question that the candidate of existential angst might have enjoyed in a different setting.

HEADLINE: In Pittsburgh, Laid-Off Workers to Cook Up Civic Pride Along With Bread

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
Here in Steel Town, which lost 100,000 manufacturing jobs over the last decade, the start of a new bakery is being heralded with as much hoopla as a new sports team. Workers are preparing to brand the city's north side with the bakery's neon sign, 14 feet high, 136 feet long and visible from the moon. It will say, "City Pride Bakery: The Bakery With a Heart."
Experts say City Pride is the nation's first start-up of a major manufacturing company intended to be owned in full eventually by its employees, almost all of whom are being hired from welfare rolls and long-term unemployment lines. Many of its workers hadlost their old jobs when the city's last commercial bakery closed in 1989 and organized to obtain government loans and private investments to establish the $9 million company. 
 "What City Pride is doing is very, very unusual," said Corey Rosen, executive director of the National Center for Employee Ownership, a nonprofit research organization in Oakland, Calif. Although there are about 10,000 employee-owned companies, he said he knew of no other case where laid-off workers built a major new factory after an old one had closed.
City Pride is also unusual in its intent to provide jobs to people who need them the most in Pittsburgh. And the bakery plans to offer high school courses, free child care and subsidized lunches to its unionized worker-owners. When a group of City Pride's investors and workers gathered to talk about the company's mission, the hotel meeting room overflowed with idealism, spiritual talk and visions of a humanitarian workplace.
 
'A Sense of Ownership'
 "We're going to take responsibility for teaching people to purge themselves of the lack of hope that they have had for so long," said Daniel R. Curtis, City Pride's president. "We're going to give them a sense of ownership."
The bakery, scheduled to open in March, may also create a model for other cities struggling to hold onto manufacturing jobs and factories.
"I would love to do this in Detroit, Atlanta or New York," said Mr. Curtis, 58 years old, who has spent 35 years in the bakery business. "How could any supermarket chain in the country turn down a quality product, competitively priced, that helps the community?"
At least one chain agrees. Even before the bakery had an oven, it had a customer in Giant Eagle Supermarkets. The chain, the largest in the Pittsburgh area with over 100 stores, sells nearly half of the $102 million worth of bread sold annually here, and nearly half that bread is sold under the store's own label.
Dissatisfied with its out-of-state bakeries, Giant Eagle has agreed to give its private-label business to City Pride, which promised to provide a wider range of breads at a lower cost. With that commitment, City Pride instantly obtained more than twice as much business as it needed to turn a profit.
"We had the opportunity to bring jobs and a commercial bakery back to Pittsburgh," said Joseph R. Faccenda, the senior vice president of Giant Eagle, a privately held company. "And it gives us the opportunity to expand the variety of bakery products we can offer at lower prices under our own Giant Eagle label."
The Penn Traffic Company, which has 90 convenience stores and supermarkets in the area, has also agreed to buy City Pride bread. And over the past year, a volunteer sales force led by the unemployed bakery workers obtained verbal bread orders from hundreds of neighborhood groceries, pizza shops, hospitals, university cafeterias and Pittsburgh's public schools.
City Pride also plans to distribute frozen bakery products nationally and internationally, and the company estimates that first-year sales of $37 million could eventually grow to more than $100 million a year.
City Pride's primary marketing strategy -- to provide local supermarkets with fresh bread in the store's own wrapper -- fits into two national trends in the food business. Supermarkets are trying to increase profits and build customer loyalty by stocking shelves with their own private-label brands. Sales of private-label products last year grew by 6 percent, nearly twice as fast as overall supermarket sales, according to Information Resources Inc., a Chicago market research firm.
But while the demand for private-label bread is increasing, the wholesale bakery industry is consolidating. The number of commercial bakeries has shrunk from 3,000 in 1972 to fewer than 500 highly automated plants today. With fewer bakeries, serving stores from greater distances, supermarket owners say, the bakery industry is less able to meet the need for custom breads.
Pittsburgh got caught up in the industry consolidation when its sole commercial bakery, Braun Baking, was purchased by Continental Baking Company and later on, in 1984, Continental was bought by Ralston-Purina. Continental has since closed about 20 plants, including Braun.
City, county and state agencies tried to keep the bakery in town and its 110 workers employed by offering Continental a package of benefits, including a low-rent lease on a new factory, reduced utility charges and real estate taxes. The company rejected the offer and now ships bread to Pittsburgh from its bakeries in Columbus and Akron, Ohio.
"When the laid-off workers saw that Continental rejected that offer, they said, 'Why can't we get the same deal?' and, to some degree, they got it," said Tom Croft, executive director of the Steel Valley Authority, a local economic development organization that, along with the bakers' union and the city's Urban Redevelopment Authority, coordinated the City Pride project.
 
From Laid Off to Lobbyists
 The laid-off Braun workers became lobbyists, obtaining public commitments that now total $2.6 million. The largest ones include $500,000 in Federal grants for job training, $1.1 million in state loans and grants and $560,000 in loans from the city and the county.
"The reason we got this far is that 62 of us stuck together and kept pushing the project along," said Joseph P. Zajac, a former Braun employee who has lead the workers' effort to establish a new bakery.
The group of workers hired Mr. Curtis, who suggested that the new company make private-label bread. The workers also had to find a management team, develop a business plan and obtain lots of private investment. Church groups, from far and near, were among the earliest to invest, providing a total of $315,000, while more than a dozen business and individual investors, including Pittsburgh's major banks, have invested about $6.5 million.
The bakery will start off with about 100 employees -- including about 40 from the plant that closed -- who will own 10 percent of the business. The number of employees is expected to increase to 300 over the next five years, by which time the workers would be in a position to buy the remainder of the company from the private investors.
While construction workers are completing City Pride's new building and assembling its 120-foot-long ovens, the company's search for new business continues. "People in Pittsburgh are very loyal and you get the feeling that people want the bakery to do very well," said Ralph A. Angel, City Pride's marketing director.
Mr. Angel is an example of City Pride's desire to employ those who have had difficulty in finding jobs. Mr. Angel, who is 41 years old, was blinded in a car accident and, for two years before being hired by City Pride, had been unable to find full-time work. He makes his pitch to potential customers accompanied by a seeing-eye German shepherd named Otto.
"He is the best salesman any bakery could have," Mr. Angel said.

It is intended to be owned by its employees, most of whom are being hired from welfare rolls and unemployment lines. Workers at City Pride readied an oven rack for the bakery, which is scheduled to open in March. (Terry Clark for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fast Data-Storage Systems Are EMC's Big Opportunity
BYL>By JOHN MARKOFF

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOPKINTON, Mass.

 BODY:
For more than a year the computer industry has been eagerly anticipating a ground-breaking new product code-named Iceberg from Storage Technology Inc., the disk-drive maker.
The new system will chain together dozens of small disk drives like a team of huskies pulling a sled, to give them greater speed and more reliability in storing data. But it is not due out until the second half of this year. Storage Technology will formally announce the system on Jan. 28. 
 In the meantime, customers hungering for greater speed and reliability in their computer storage systems are increasingly turning to the EMC Corporation. The upstart high-technology company, based here, began offering a similar product 15 months ago. And customers are giving it enthusiastic reviews.
"It's a big money saver," said Philip Balcom, manager of information services planning and technology at J. I. Case, the Racine, Wis., maker of tractors and industrial equipment.
Purchases by Case and others have helped push EMC's revenues to $232 million in 1991, from $171 million in 1990. The company has said it expects to report fourth-quarter 1991 earnings of about $4.5 million, up from $3.3 million a year earlier. Several analysts have named the company's shares their 1992 stock pick of the year. The share price has jumped from $6 in September to a close of $13.75 on Friday. Last week, EMC announced a $44 million agreement with the Unisys Corporation to permit the mainframe computer maker to market EMC's disk drives.
"We have to pinch ourselves sometimes," said Michael L. Schoonover, who head's EMC's manufacturing operations. "Many of us have neighbors who have lost their homes." A notable exception to most of the battered New England economy, EMC employs more than 1,100 workers and has openings for 60 more jobs.
EMC provides a striking example of how a small American company, with careful strategic planning and attention to manufacturing detail, can succeed by finding profitable high-technology niches with huge growth potential.
 
Making Its Mark in Memory
 EMC found its spot in the market by adding a huge number of computer memory chips to an array of disk drives for storing data. Modern computers typically have several different kinds of memory or storage. Chip memory is generally high speed, but data vanishes when power is switched off. Magnetic disk memory is slower, but stores data permanently.
EMC combines both kinds of memory to get higher performance with greater reliability. The memory contained on chips in its system acts as a special high-speed buffer between the computer and the disk. During operation, software stores information in the buffer and can retrieve it much more quickly than if it must come directly from the slower magnetic disks. Furthermore, because the system uses groups of disks, the failure of one disk is not fatal because other disks fill in for the damaged one, increasing overall reliability.
"There is no doubt that disk arrays will be a very attractive market in the coming years," said Van Brady, a stock market analyst at Presidio Management in San Francisco.
 
Users Include Banks and Airlines
 Customers requiring such performance include businesses that must maintain and continually draw upon vast data bases of information, like banks and airlines. Indeed, the companies to which EMC shipped 325 of its Symettrix arrays so far include Security Pacific and Delta Air Lines.
Still, within the computer industry, EMC remains all but invisible in an environment still governed almost entirely by an older technology of disk drives pioneered by I.B.M.
"We sometimes call the Symettrix our Stealth disk drive," said Michael Ruettgers, EMC's chief executive. Mr. Ruettgers was a manager at the Raytheon Company and worked on the Patriot missile project before entering the computer industry. He worked at several computer companies and two years ago joined EMC, which was founded in the early 1980's as a maker of memory boards and later expanded into disk drives.
The disk drive business is growing at more than 25 percent a year as large corporations rely increasingly on huge corporate data centers in running their businesses. Moreover, I.B.M. still controls more than 60 percent of the business. But its large expensive drives are coming under attack from the arrays of inexpensive personal-computer-sized drives sold by EMC, among others.
In making only a few big drives for each mainframe, the International Business Machines Corporation has found that its costs of producing disks have remained relatively high. EMC, on the other hand, is buying small disks off the shelf from manufacturers that produce them for personal computers and work stations; combined into arrays, the drives can work with a mainframe.
Currently, disk array technology -- known as Redundant Arrays of Independent Disks, or RAID -- is being offered principally by I.B.M.'s competitors as a higher-performance alternative to I.B.M.'s larger drives. But that is certain to change. Already the Compaq Computer Corporation has sold thousands of simple arrays for its server systems that act as data libraries on business networks of desktop computers.
I.B.M. is not expected to introduce its own disk arrays for the commercial market until 1994, and its Japanese competitors Hitachi and Fujitsu appear to be waiting for I.B.M. before offering their own compatible versions. But I.B.M. has already introduced its first array product for the scientific computing market, and Ray AbuZayyad, who heads the computer maker's disk drive businesssaid last year that his division was looking closely at array technology.
For the moment, EMC customers express satisfaction.
Mr. Balcom said that J. I. Case had originally considered EMC as something of a gamble, but the company put some of its applications on the system and saw a significant speedup.
"A lot of people have apprehension about not going with I.B.M.," he said. "We went out there and talked for a whole day before we decided to go with EMC."
Not only has the EMC system made faster work of such tasks as tracking inventory and sending electronic mail, Mr. Balcom said, but the added capabilities have enabled Case to delay buying an I.B.M. 3090 mainframe -- a potential $10 million to $20 million outlay -- by at least six months.

Scott Emus and Mary Fahy installed a controller board in one of EMC's Symettrix disk array systems. (Jim Bourg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Who (and What) Decides How City Budget Rates

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
WHEN Mayor David N. Dinkins delivered his State of the City address earlier this month, one sentence in the 18th paragraph finally inspired his audience to spontaneous applause: "Bond ratings are important," Mr. Dinkins declared, "but we are judged against a higher standard."
Surprisingly, perhaps, some bond raters agree. 
 "The need for public safety, adequate sanitation, maintenance of the municipal infrastructure, education of our children and safety nets to assist those truly in need are clearly priorities that put a bond rating in its proper perspective," Richard P. Larkin, a managing director of Standard & Poor's, acknowledged after the Mayor's speech. "There may be situations and needs so great that a city or state's bond rating may suffer as a result of the fiscal actions or increased debt issuance necessary to respond. For investors, this may seem heretical."
Before Mr. Dinkins makes public his four-year financial plan for New York City this week, his ritual pilgrimage to brief rating analysts demonstrates just how important he believes bond ratings are -- regardless of whether other standards against which his budget will be judged are higher.
State and local jurisdictions sell bonds to raise money for public works and other long-term projects. How much interest the market demands is determined, in part, by the risk judgments expressed publicly by private agencies like Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service.
Credit is derived from the Latin, to believe. A rating represents the degree of faith in a borrower's ability to pay its debts. A rating may lag behind prices imposed by market forces, which better reflect investor confidence. A minor rating change may be largely irrelevant when interest rates are as low as today's. A rating may reflect economic conditions beyond any official's control. A plunge to junk-bond levels, though, could legally preclude some institutions from investing -- curtailing or even cutting off a government's access to credit.
But a credit rating is just one variable in the political equation that defines spending priorities. Getting the highest credit rating is not necessarily a desirable goal in itself.
"Most bond raters don't live in the city," Stanley Hill, who heads the largest municipal employee union, complained the other day. "They just see numbers. But I look at kids not getting educated, a crumbling infrastructure."
The government's balancing is akin to a consumer's decision to postpone paying a credit-card bill after making the judgment that the bill for rent or electricity or medicine or tuition or a well-deserved vacation is more pressing -- even if it means being slapped with an interest penalty the next month. The choice is clearer when the consumer is warned to stop charging or when the card is about to be revoked.
"Maybe comptrollers shouldn't say it," said Edward V. Regan, the State Comptroller, "but if you got down to a choice of shutting down all emergency rooms and closing the parks or letting an AA rating fall, then obviously you would let the rating fall." He said the city and the state still had plenty of latitude to impose less painful economies. He also said higher interest costs that result from a rating decline can mean less money left for hospitals and parks.
"When the Mayor says there's more to life than bond ratings, I sympathize with him," said Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created in 1975 to borrow on behalf of a city shunned by the credit markets. "It's a perfectly acceptable public policy to say, 'I can do more for the people of the city and state and instead of a AA rating I'll have an A-minus, as long as I'm sure I can stabilize it there.' The terrible thing is that nobody knows where the brink is until after they've gone over it."
New York State may be perilously close. Its general-obligation bonds were downgraded by Standard & Poor's this month to the second lowest of any state except Massachusetts.
New York City's rating may depend on whether Mr. Dinkins's financial plan credibly answers the raters' inevitable questions: Does the budget depend too much on deficit financing? (A proposal to pay off Municipal Assistance Corporation debt with city borrowing might cost more in interest since the city's credit rating is lower than the M.A.C.'s). Are proposed services affordable for the duration of outstanding bonds? Does the budget represent a cohesive vision?
Without investor confidence, "all the rhetoric in the world will not accomplish the goals and priorities of elected officials," Mr. Larkin of Standard & Poor's warned. Yet, while the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, predicted that any downgrade would be devastating, the taxpayers who get the bill for government borrowing and even many investors do not live by the agencies' ratings alone.
"If you don't make the cuts they want, they have trouble with your budget," Mr. Michael said. "If you do, they may have trouble with your city."

HEADLINE: Democrats See Support for Capital Gains Tax Cut

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said today that Democrats in Congress could support a cut in the capital gains tax if it was part of a generally "fair and progressive tax package."
Mr. Mitchell's comment, on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," was the second signal this weekend that Democrats might not go all-out in attacking such a proposal as proof of Republican commitment to helping the rich, the traditional Democratic accusation. 
 On Saturday, the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said on the Cable News Network, "We have never objected to a consideration of a reduction in capital gains taxes if it was part of a balanced and fair tax package."
President Bush made a reduction in the capital gains tax rate a centerpiece of his economic plans in 1989 and 1990, but that proposal hampered negotiations with Congress over the budget. On the insistence of Congressional Republicans, Mr. Bush abandoned his push at the end of the 1990 discussions; some Democrats had favored a cut, but Mr. Mitchell and others were agreeable only if it was accompanied by an income tax increase in the upper brackets.
Under the 1986 tax law, earnings from capital gains, which are profits from sales of assets like stocks or houses, are taxed at the same rate as ordinary income, with higher rates for people with higher incomes. Before 1986, capital gains had traditionally been taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income.
Just how much of a reduction below those rates Mr. Bush will propose in his State of the Union Message and his budget is uncertain, but Republican conservatives in Congress have been demanding that he ask for a big cut. Mr. Foley said it was possible that Congress might vote for "some moderate reduction."
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, said that the real success of Mr. Bush's proposals would depend not only on what he asked for but also on the President's determination to press Congress for action after the speech on Tuesday night. In previous years, most of the proposals made in the State of the Union Messages and Presidential budgets have been largely ignored in Congress -- and by the Administration, too -- in subsequent months.
"He's going to have to follow up," Mr. Dole said on the CBS News program. "He's going to have to put the heat on Congress. I don't say he ought to be confrontational Tuesday night, but he ought to tell Congress, tell the American people, 'This is what we need to do.' "
 
Repeal of Plane Tax Is Seen
 Mr. Dole also predicted a tax cut even closer to his heart, or to that of his constituents in Kansas, than reduction in the capital gains tax rate. After a newspaper report today that Mr. Bush would seek repeal of the luxury tax on pleasure boats costing more than $100,000, Mr. Dole said the President would also seek repeal of the tax on private airplanes.
Two of the nation's largest manufacturers of private aircraft, Beech and Cessna, are in Kansas. Mr. Dole, 68 years old, announced Saturday that he would run for re-election this fall, ending months of speculation that he might retire next January after 32 years in Congress.
The tax on private planes applies to 10 percent of their cost over $250,000. Like the tax on boats, which applies to 10 percent of the price over $100,000, it was imposed as part of the 1990 budget agreement largely to show that higher-income taxpayers would be affected by that pact.
 
Repeal on Cars, Too?
 Mr. Dole also predicted that Congress "may go even further than that before it's over."
"Congress may decide to take it off of automobiles, furs and jewelry," he said. For automobiles, the 10 percent tax affects that part of their purchase price that exceeds $30,000; for furs and jewelry, the floor is $10,000.

HEADLINE: In the Aisles, Shoppers Voice Dismay

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
Evie Wollman, 76 years old, was in the furniture department on the ninth floor of Macy's Herald Square store yesterday. "I would like to buy a couple of chairs," she said, adding, in a note of potential impulse that is sweet music to retailers everywhere, "and maybe some sheets."
As newspapers and radio and television stations reported that bankruptcy proceedings to protect R. H. Macy & Company from its creditors were imminent, Mrs. Wollman -- "nee Bender," she said -- had come from the Bronx to go shopping with her friend, Ida Rubinstein. And though their trip to 34th Street could not be described as a pilgrimage exactly, both women had memories of the store that recalled better days. 
 Mrs. Wollman said she bought her bedroom set in Macy's more than 40 years ago. Mrs. Rubinstein said she was still using the original Waring blender that she bought at Macy's, "it must be 50 years ago."
Bankruptcy probably will not close the place; indeed, the only difference customers are likely to see is that there will be more merchandise on the shelves because suppliers, assured of being paid, will return to regular deliveries of goods. But there is no question that the tremors emanating from the company's shaky foundation were felt on 34th Street, one more reminder of the vulnerability brought on by tough economic times.
Recalling the many other department stores that have failed, Mrs. Wollman said that if Macy's went under, it would be "one of the worst things that could possibly happen," adding: "They took away Gimbel's. They took away B. Altman's. And there's nothing replacing these landmarks."
She followed this with a general lament about the economy, concluding, "These are sad days we're living through."
A trip through the store yesterday brought out considerable anecdotal evidence that to many of its customers and employees, Macy's is not just any store. People spoke of its troubles with expressions of loyalty, anger, disappointment, resignation, nostalgia -- in much the same way that they speak about New York these days.
In the fifth-floor electronics department, George Simmonds and his 10-year-old son, Jason, were watching a Paul Simon performance on a 46-inch television screen. The Simmondses, who live in Manhattan, were merely sightseeing in the store -- electronics is Jason's favorite department -- after picking up some ribs in one of the food emporiums in Macy's Cellar.
"I'm always in Macy's," Mr. Simmonds said. "We can't afford to lose it. They ought to make a big pitch to the public to send in what they owe. If they made such an appeal to their customers, I'd certainly be one of them."
Mr. Simmonds also expressed fear that the collapse of the bid by Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of the Lowes Corporation as well as CBS, to take over the company would lead to Japanese investors' stepping into the breach. And he said he was angry with the Prudential Insurance Company of America for not going along with Mr. Tisch's request to reduce the interest on the mortgages it holds on Macy's stores.
"If Prudential were my insurance company, I'd pull out," Mr. Simmonds said. "That's how strongly I feel about showing support for this store."
At The Patio, a lunch counter on the eighth floor, Joe and Laura Patrina stopped to eat. They had just returned from London and Vienna, they said, where CNN had been reporting Macy's troubles. "The Europeans are really upset," Mr. Patrina said. "To them, Macy's is an institution, as strong an image as Mickey Mouse."
The Patrinas, who live in Manhattan, are furnishing a new apartment, and they came to Macy's, Mr. Patrina said, "to show support for the store." He added: "We had X amount of things to buy. We thought we might as well buy them here."
Not surprisingly, on the other side of the sales counters, where livelihoods are at stake, reactions were infused with pragmatism. Al Behmoiras, 20, who works in gift wrap on the eighth floor, said he was more worried for his father, who had worked for the store for 45 years, than for himself. "They're saying if they cut back, they're going to fire a lot of managers," Mr. Behmoiras said. "He's 62 years old. Where's he gonna go?"
In men's furnishings on the ground floor, one salesmen said business had never been better. "We had a great year," said the salesman, who insisted on anonymity. "We made a lot of money on commission."
Another salesman walked over. "One lady came in," he said, 'She was really upset. 'Is it true? Is Macy's going to close?' I told her no and she said, 'Thank God.' "
The first salesman said he had been working at Macy's 30 years. "We love it here," he said. "We make good money. We've been able to buy homes. We do well. We're a family. We'll survive."
He was then joined by two co-workers in a chorus of the Patti LaBelle song, "We Will Survive," their hands placed over their hearts. They were not pledging allegiance to Macy, however; they were just hiding their name tags.

HEADLINE: President's Message Expected to Lay Out Plans for a 'New Domestic Order'

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
In his State of the Union Message, President Bush is expected to challenge Congress to action on the economy without criticizing or directly confronting the Democrats, as well as to seek to define a "new domestic order" to go with his "new world order," Administration officials said today.
As Mr. Bush worked today on a draft of the address, which he will deliver on Tuesday, the officials and Republican strategists said the White House was still debating philosophy and tactics. 
 It was not clear, they said, how far Mr. Bush is prepared to go in offering a distinctly new course for the second term he will seek in November or whether he would stick to his months-old argument that he has offered a solid set of proposals for economic growth and that if Congress would simply enact them, with some modest changes, the recession would end.
"Everyone agrees that Bush has to lay out a sense of what the next five years will be like," an Administration official said today. "The big debate remains how much he is going to acknowledge, implicitly or explicitly, that the program needs to be different from what it's been in the previous three years."
On "This Week" on ABC News this morning, the new White House chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, acknowledged that the Administration's domestic policy making had to be reorganized and strengthened. But he signaled that the Administration still viewed its problems primarily as a matter of public relations and that Mr. Bush saw nothing wrong with his economic policies.
The thematic framework of Mr. Bush's speech emerged as the President worked through the weekend on his address. Officials cautioned that the President, who was working with Mr. Skinner and his campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, could still make important changes.
 
'Forum to Begin an Effort'
 Clearly concerned that public expectations for the speech were too high after weeks of being presented by the White House and the campaign as the defining moment of Mr. Bush's Presidency, Mr. Skinner sought today to lower those hopes.
"What the State of the Union allows us to do," he said, "is to articulate to the American people George Bush's 1992 domestic programs for this country, and it will be a forum to begin an effort, to put some good programs in place, to work with Congress, to get these good programs into law."
Administration officials said today that the White House recognized that the speech had to be more than that.
The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" that the speech might "be the political Super Bowl for Bush."
An official said the speech "tries to lay out not just a program for this year, but also some sense of the next five years."
"One of the themes," he said, "at least at this point, is that we've had a great victory in foreign policy with the end of the cold war and that it's a new world in foreign policy. Now we need to move toward a new world in domestic policy."
Another official said there was still a debate between Mr. Bush's advisers about how strongly Mr. Bush's speech should strike that theme. Some advisers, primarily on the right flank, believe that there should be a clear change of direction, he said.
"Then," the official said, "there are those who say we need better communications, better procedures, but that basically we have to explain why we've done a good job and, perhaps, some retooling."
Although Mr. Skinner did not comment on the contents of the speech, he seemed to suggest that radical changes in policy were not needed, attributing the economic problems in part to reductions in military spending and referring to "a normal transition and a normal cycle."
A Republican strategist said, "The danger is you could end up with the worst of both worlds, which is a lot of apologizing about the current situation, which implies that we're to blame for it, but no strong message of new policies or changes in policy."
Administration officials said Mr. Bush appeared to have ended the debate that broke out last week over whether he should aggressively confront the Democrats in Congress, as many Republicans have suggested, or try to take a more statesmanlike approach in hopes of winning Democratic cooperation in enacting growth measures.
"Basically the speech is a split-the-difference exercise," one official said today. "The President will try to be challenging to Congress, urging them to pass his programs, and then lay the groundwork for criticizing them later on if they don't come through."
On television this morning, Mr. Skinner said that Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, would take the additional responsibility of coordinating all aspects of White House communications. Officials said Mr. Fitzwater could conduct daily meetings and counsel Mr. Bush on short-term press tactics and long-term communications strategy.
But the officials added that Mr. Fitzwater would not formally assume the post of director of communications, made famous under President Ronald Reagan by Michael K. Deaver. Soon after he took office Mr. Skinner asked Mr. Fitzwater to take on those functions, but Mr. Fitzwater suggested that the Administration look outside for a full-time "image czar," officials said.
The job was offered to Thomas C. Griscom, communications director at the end of the Reagan years, and James H. Lake, a campaign aide for Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush. When they declined, Mr. Skinner turned back to Mr. Fitzwater, officials said.
Mr. Skinner has also been looking for a "heavyweight" figure to supervise domestic policy, a move widely seen as an attempt to reduce the powers of Richard G. Darman, the budget director.
Officials said that Mr. Skinner had approached Clayton Yeutter, the former Agriculture Secretary who is chairman of the Republican National Committee, but that it seemed unlikely he would take the job. The officials said Mr. Yeutter wanted full control of the Domestic Policy Council and the Economic Policy Council and to have real policy-making authority given to those panels, which Mr. Darman has relegated to largely consultative roles.

HEADLINE: Lift Taxes? Economists Vote Yes

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
As President Bush and Congressional Democrats seek to outdo each other in proposing tax cuts to stimulate the economy, many economists say that what the nation needs in the long run is exactly the opposite.
Higher taxes, these economists say, are needed to prevent America's competitiveness from slipping further by providing money for improving schools, beefing up research and development and modernizing highways, railroads and airports. 
 A tax increase is also needed, they say, to reduce a runaway Federal budget deficit that has caused the United States to focus far more on spending for current purposes than on long-term investment to strengthen the nation's productivity. By reducing the deficit, higher taxes would push up the nation's paltry savings rate, an action that economists say is crucial because savings provide the money to finance further investments to increase competitiveness.
 
2 Views on Tax Cuts
 "In the long term, the country needs tax increases, not tax cuts," said Charles L. Schultze, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Jimmy Carter. "When I look at all these proposals, I am adamantly convinced that whatever they do should not involve any kind of permanent tax cut."
Of the 24 industrial nations in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the United States is tied for last place with Greece in how much taxes it raises as a percentage of its annual economic output.
Mr. Bush and the Democrats say tax cuts are not just politically sound but are also good economics. And indeed their economic advisers tell them that fiscal stimulus is just what the ailing economy needs right now.
 
President's Proposals
 So in his State of the Union speech on Tuesday, President Bush is expected to announce various tax proposals, including a tax credit for first-time home buyers, lower capital gains taxes, an increase in the personal exemption for families with children, a tax credit to help low-income families afford health insurance and an end to the "luxury tax" on expensive boats.
But some economists have doubts about this approach. "In terms of policy, what is needed to make the next 6 to 12 months better is not what you need to do to make the next 6 to 12 years better," said Robert Solow, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a recipient of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics.
He and others agree that Americans will need to provide more tax dollars if the country wants to shore up its competitive position against Japan and other countries.
"I don't think any tax increase is indicated at this time, but I don't have any hesitation to increase taxes longer term for public investment," said Robert Eisner, an economics professor at Northwestern University.
 
Agreement on Savings Rate
 If the often-fractious community of economists has reached a consensus about anything, it is that the nation's low savings rate is a principal reason for the decline in America's competitiveness.
The United States savings rate -- the combination of household savings, such business savings as increased retained earnings, and local, state and Federal budget surpluses -- is less than half of Japan's savings rate.
Economists are constantly telling Washington's politicians that cutting the nation's yawning $352 billion budget deficit would be an important way to improve America's savings rate -- and ultimately increase investment. And many economists say this deficit cutting also points to raising taxes over the long term.
"The long-run need of the country is for investment in the broadest possible sense," Mr. Solow said. "That means investment in plant and equipment, investment in technology, and investment in human capital such as training and education."
He said he supported some temporary tax cuts to power the stalled economy, but he added that he unequivocally backed tax increases over the longer term.
 
Conservatives' Position
 Many conservative economists say no tax increases will be needed to pare the budget deficit; they say cutting spending will do the trick. And many supply-side economists support permanent tax cuts, saying this will fuel investment.
"We want to have permanent tax- rate relief, which would lower the cost of capital and lower the cost of labor for employers," said Lawrence Kudlow, a Reagan Administration economist who works with the investment firm Bear, Stearns & Company. "This will have a very positive long-run effect and will improve the economy's long-run potential to grow."
But as the Reagan era recedes, leaving behind a mountain of debt, more and more economists say the supply-side tax cuts of the 1980's have hurt investment by unduly fueling consumption and causing a plunge in savings.
According to the O.E.C.D., the taxes raised at the Federal, state and local levels in the United States, including Social Security taxes, represented 31.8 percent of gross domestic product in 1989, the most recent year for which comparative figures are available. That compares with 46.5 percent in France in 1989, 44.6 percent in Germany, 39.7 percent in Britain and 33.3 percent in Japan.
One reason that American taxes are lower is that health care is financed with tax revenues in many other industrial nations, although that is offset in part by the United States' spending a proportionally higher amount on the military.
"Americans are hardly overtaxed by the standards of Europe," said Benjamin Friedman, an economics professor at Harvard University. He suggested that the nation's peace dividend, resulting from the end of the cold war, might be large enough to furnish enough money for deficit reduction and public investment so that taxes would not have to be raised.
"If that's not true, then we would need to pay more in taxes," Professor Friedman said.
Economists point to a mountain of statistics they say give clues why America's competitiveness has stumbled. According to one study, America's net investment in infrastructure like roads and airports represented just three-tenths of 1 percent of its gross domestic product in the 1980's. In comparison, Japan's net investment was 5.7 percent of G.D.P. during that period and Germany's was 3.7 percent.
 
Research and Development
 And a study by the National Science Foundation found that America's nonmilitary research and development spending, although higher in absolute terms, represented 2 percent of G.D.P. compared with 2.9 percent for Japan and 2.6 percent for Germany. America was also behind in government spending on nonmilitary research and development.
Considering how the income of the average American worker has stagnated over the last two decades, it is understandable why so many Americans cry for tax cuts. In addition, in recent decades Americans have manifested a strong antipathy to big, activist government.
Besides, many Americans hate taxes because they feel little direct benefit from them, since so much of their money goes to the military, the poor or to interest payments on the nation's debt. Perhaps one reason Europeans complain far less than Americans do about their higher tax rates is that Europeans feel more concrete benefits from their taxes: the state usually covers the cost of health care and higher education.
'There is another aspect to this," Professor Solow said. "A lot of people feel that as soon as the U.S. Congress raises taxes, it spends and it spends wastefully. President Reagan once spoke of tax reduction as taking the Congress's allowance away, as if Congress were children spending the money at a candy store."
 
$300 Billion Proposal
 Professor Solow suggests that if America wants to increase its competitiveness and living standards, it should spend about $300 billion more of the gross domestic product each year to finance education, new plants and equipment, and other investments in the future.
Economists like Mr. Solow are saying that if Americans are seeking to insure that their children live better than they do, they must learn to consume less, meaning live less well, and to save and invest more.
If Mr. Solow were running for Congress, such a "live worse now in order to live better in 10 years" platform would probably leave him on the wrong end of an electoral landslide. Indeed, politicians certainly remember what happened to Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate, after he said in his 1984 campaign that he would raise taxes.
It is easy for professors to pontificate about the importance of raising taxes. Perhaps their biggest frustration is that they cannot find some magical economic formula to make politicians in Washington worry as much about the state of the union in November 2002 as in November 1992.

HEADLINE: Travel Industry Is Experiencing A Sudden Surge

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
After two years of reduced travel, Americans are on the move again, producing an unexpected spurt in bookings for cruise ships, hotels and airlines in recent weeks.
Trans-Atlantic flights are on the rise, travel industry executives say, and tour operators, who just a month ago were bemoaning a slowdown in bookings for Hawaii, now report an upsurge of fresh business. Airlines that until recently were unsure whether to add flights to Florida and other warm-weather destinations now say they will, and so far this month almost 1,400 flight attendants have been recalled -- the largest number since May 1990. 
 "Our phones are ringing off the hooks," said Ron Letterman, the president of the Carlson Travel Network's 1,000 travel agencies, which are in all 50 states. "International travel is up 15 percent this year over the same time last year, and business travel is up an average of 6 to 7 percent. Travel to the Caribbean and Hawaii has been very strong lately."
Resorts at some national parks and ski resorts also say business is looking better.
At the Mammoth Springs Hotel in Yellowstone National Park, for example, occupancy reached 75 percent from mid-December to mid-January, compared with 61 percent in the corresponding period last year, said Steve Tedder, a vice president of TW Recreational Services Inc., which is in charge of lodging at the park.
At Taos Ski Valley in New Mexico, "bookings are up 25 percent since Jan. 1," from the same period last year, said Chris Stagg, vice president of marketing. Most visitors are from Southern California, he said, but many are from New York, Chicago, Texas and New Mexico.
At Universal Studios Florida in Orlando, a record number of visitors came in the week between Christmas and New Year's Day, and attendance remains strong.
"We were up more than 15 percent over our previous record week last July," said Randy Garfield, the executive vice president of marketing. Attendance this month, he said "is running about 30 percent ahead of our projections."
In 1990, travel was a $328 billion industry in the United States and its territories, according to a recent study by the United States Travel Data Center, a nonprofit center for travel and tourism research. That figure equaled 6.5 percent of the gross national product. But the last two years have been difficult, with the Persian Gulf war and the nation's economic slump keeping many people at home.
While most predictions were that 1992 would be only lackluster, the recent spurt in bookings has many travel industry executives holding their breath, hoping the elusive recovery in business and leisure travel may finally be under way.
Even hotels and airlines, which were devastated by the recession and the gulf war, are showing improvement -- modest improvement, but few officials in either industry expected much of any improvement.
 
Demand Plus Discounts
 Industry executives say much of the recent increase in business reflects pent-up demand, fueled by generous industrywide discounts. The surge in bookings is unlikely to continue, they say, unless the overall economy turns around.
Nowhere is the travel business better than at the cruise lines.
Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines, which is based in Miami, received a record 115,000 calls from travel agents in the first week of the year, a company spokesman said, nearly twice the level of the first week of last year. Last January was especially bleak for the travel industry, because of the outbreak of the gulf war.
The 115,000 recent calls resulted in 95,000 bookings, another record.
"We added 17 percent capacity this year but this month we gained 40 percent in call volumes," the spokesman said. "So that means the demand isn't just because we have more berths available."
 
Cruise Line Breaks Record
 Carnival Cruises Lines, which is the industry leader and is also based in Miami, booked 65,000 passengers between Jan. 6 and 12, most for winter and spring cruises, said Tim Gallagher, Carnival's director of public relations. "By Jan. 9 we broke our previous record of 46,200, and our bookings have continued very strong since," he said.
Carnival's bookings are particularly striking because it markets its cruises to the masses, not the wealthy, and its potential customers are among those most vulnerable to a weakened economy.
At the Holland America Line, which is owned by Carnival, Juli Chase, a spokeswoman, said, "Our bookings for Alaska are running 12 percent higher than any previous month in our history."
 
People Didn't Travel in '91
 Two weeks ago, the American Hotel and Motel Association said in a report that for the fourth consecutive month the hotel industry "continued to show growth in several key indicators, making it clear that a slow but steady rebound from the effects of the recession is indeed under way." The occupancy rate grew 1.4 percentage points in November (the last month for which nationwide figures are available) to 56.2 percent, from November 1990, and some hoteliers say the situation appears to be improving.
"We don't have the December or January figures yet," said Mark Lomanno, research manager of Smith Travel Research, which compiles the figures for the American Hotel and Motel Association, "but I think the results will be very positive. There seems to be pent-up demand from people who didn't travel last year."
This apparent improvement follows on the heels of estimates by Coopers & Lybrand that the occupancy rate will rise only 3.3 percentage points this year. Most of the increase in occupancy is expected from spring through fall.
Airline passenger traffic increased 3.6 percent in December, the last month for which statistics are available, according to the Air Transport Association of America. The increase was largely unexpected, and except for a minuscule six-tenths of 1 percent increase in October, it was the only monthly gain in passenger traffic in 1991.
While American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines -- the strongest United States carriers -- had traffic increases, so did several smaller, weaker airlines.
 
Gains by Weaker Airlines
 America West Airlines, for example, posted a 15 percent increase in miles flown by paying passengers last month, compared with December 1990, while Northwest Airlines gained 11.6 percent over that period.
Trans World Airlines flew 9.1 percent more revenue passenger miles in December than in December 1990. And, in part because of an array of discounts this winter, "we're projecting an 11 percent increase in revenue passenger miles in January, compared with January of last year," said Don Fleming, the carrier's director of public relations.
Continental Airlines flew 11.2 percent more revenue passenger miles last month than in December 1990, and its load factor -- percentage of seats that are filled -- this month is running well above that of the corresponding period last year (60 percent compared with 55 percent).

HEADLINE: Jukebox Economics;
Are Lyrics and the Economy in Tune?

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Harold Zullow can flash the kind of I-told-you-so grin that Alan Greenspan of the Federal Reserve Board or Louis Rukeyser of "Wall Street Week" can only dream of. Mr. Zullow forecast the recession in May 1990, months before the Government says it began. All he did was to listen to the songs on Billboard magazine's Hot 100 chart.
"I was sorry to see that in fact we had a recession," said Mr. Zullow, a research fellow in social psychiatry at Columbia University's School of Public Health. "I don't really think of myself as a prophet of doom." 
 Nor is he a pie-chart-in-the-sky optimist, nor the kind of person who graphs the correlation between every eighth-of-an-inch rise (or fall) in hemlines and every eighth-of-a-point rise (or fall) in the stock market. There is, he says, nothing frivolous about what he does.
In contrast to researchers who extrapolate trendy tidbits from the Consumer Price Index, Mr. Zullow studied 40 years' worth of popular songs, from "Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing" in 1955 to the 1963 hit "Puff the Magic Dragon," to "Killing Me Softly With His Song" in 1973, to the 1990 blockbuster "Nothing Compares 2 U."
Mr. Zullow has not been around for 40 years -- he is only 30 -- but he and his research team studied hundreds of all-but-forgotten lyrics from libraries. They also evaluated 1,820 Time magazine cover stories as another yardstick of consumer confidence. He concluded that just when the economy seemed to be, pardon the expression, humming along nicely, song lyrics turned pessimistic. This is the tipoff that it's time to sell off the stock portfolio and lock in the certificate-of-deposit interest rates.
"Then, while the economy's doing very badly, popular culture turns more optimistic," Mr. Zullow said. "Songs are more optimistic during a recession than they are just before the recession."
 
Seven Choruses of Doom
 This has held true, he said, for the seven major recessions since World War II: 1958, 1960-61, 1970, 1974-75, 1980, 1981-82 and the one that began in July 1990. His research indicates that the pessimistic songs were issued a year before the economy turned sour and the optimistic ones a year before things started to get better.
"The outlook in songs and other popular culture may be contagious, reinforcing cheer or gloom in people," he said. "I am not suggesting that the songs make people more pessimistic and therefore less likely to spend. But they may tap into our collective fears, which color how we act in the world. The songs may reinforce and spread pessimism."
But since reinforcement takes time, Mr. Zullow not only kept score on musical scores in 1989 and 1990, he also kept news clippings.
"I was collecting articles on polls of economists who said the economy would continue to expand into 1993, knowing that down the road if my prediction came true, people would say things were already getting bad and people knew it," he said. "But really, people didn't know it at the time, or they weren't saying it if they knew it."
It is almost enough to make one wonder what would happen if economists spent more time on lyrics and less time on tiresome statistics. Economics could lose its reputation as the dismal science.
 
Bad Tunes Rising
 Mr. Zullow, whose findings have been published in scholarly journals like American Psychologist and The Journal of Economic Psychology, developed his own methodology, using seven-point rating scales. He analyzed 1,344 songs and rated them for "rumination about bad events" and "pessimistic explanatory style." This led him to conclude that "pessimistic rumination in popular songs predicts decreased economic growth, with a one- to two-year lead."
In 1989, he found, 89 percent of the Fine Young Cannibals' song "Good Thing" was rumination about something bad, starting with the opening line, "The one good thing in my life has gone away."
George Michael's "Praying for Time," issued in 1990, also got an 89 percent rumination rating with lines like "These are the days of the beggars and the choosers" and "It's hard to love, there's so much to hate, hanging on to hope when there is no hope to speak of."
Turning the clock back to 1969 and Creedance Clearwater Revival's "Bad Moon Rising." Mr. Zullow found that 19 of the 24 lines in the song, or 79.2 percent, were negative rumination ("I fear rivers overflowing. I hear the voice of rage and ruin.")
That was only one of several dark songs in the prerecession year of 1969. Among the others: the Marvin Gaye hit "I Heard It Through the Grapevine" (the line "not much longer would you be mine" rated high on the pessimism scale) and "In the Year 2525," about the end of the world.
What a difference a few years makes. "In 1988," he said, "I noticed there had been some pessimism preceding the stock market crash of '87 and in the months following, which turned much more optimistic in the summer of '88. All of a sudden, we had songs like 'Don't Worry, Be Happy,' which George Bush made his campaign theme."
What is he predicting now? The lyrics from the first half of 1991 were cheerier, like Gloria Estefan's record of "Coming Out of the Dark." But he said he could not tell whether that was a sign the country was coming out of the recession.
"The optimism still isn't very strong," he said. "The rumination component about how much these song lyrics are focusing on bad events shows a striking change. You saw a lot of songs in '91 like Paula Abdul's 'Promise of a New Day' and I forget who did this one, 'I Adore Me Amor.' On that basis, you'd expect to see an improvement in consumer spirits. The unusual thing is Wall Street's spirits have picked up before consumers' spirits."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Clients Demand Flexibility For Their Media Purchases

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
NOT too many years ago, anyone who suggested that an advertiser would be able to buy a commercial during a Super Bowl as late as two days before the game would have been dismissed as someone who played too much football without a helmet. Yet for Super Bowl XXVI, which CBS broadcast yesterday, no one was surprised that it took the network until Friday to sell the last of the 56 available 30-second spots.
The difference between then and now is a fundamental change in the ability of advertisers to plan ahead. As a result of two years of economic uncertainties, no company wants to make commitments as extravagant as a Super Bowl buy -- at $800,000 to $850,000 for each commercial -- as far as several months in advance. Across a broad range of product categories, like beer, cars, soft drinks, air travel and credit cards, rapidly changing market conditions make flexibility far more highly prized than having an annual media plan locked in by Jan. 1. 
 "It would be easily solved if you could just plan conservatively," said Dan Fox, executive vice president of Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago. "Instead, we constantly revise and update and adjust."
"There has been a real increase in how close this agency's management stays to the numbers," he added. For instance, late last year, when "one large client announced it was making all of its 1992 budget cuts now," he continued, "our response was, 'No, you're not; you're just making the first of your 1992 cuts now.' "
The creativity that agencies are expected to bring to the production of ads now must also be demonstrated in the planning process, said Ron Burns, chief executive of J. Walter Thompson North America in New York. Three-year and one-year strategic plans, he said, are being supplemented by what are termed "rolling plans," which offer clients alternatives for whatever vagaries they might encounter over shorter periods of time.
All that is greatly changing how media companies operate, too, particularly in making their annual estimates of revenues and costs based on forthcoming business volume.
"In forecasting 1992, a crystal ball could come in real handy," said Elizabeth P. Valk, publisher of Time magazine in New York. "It's so hard to know, in this economy, what the base line is."
The main difficulty, she added, is that the information her sales executives are able to obtain from advertisers and their agencies is "a less and less accurate reflection of what's to come." For example, "if orders are down 5 percent, we keep asking ourselves, 'Will that make up for itself?' " If not, more aggressive ad sales efforts must be undertaken to sell the number of pages anticipated for that issue.
"Getting the whole year's schedule in one fell swoop -- you don't see much of that anymore," she continued, almost sighing.
Yet rather than pine for Time's times past, the news magazine is reconfiguring itself for today's realities. Since "the marketplace is telling us it's unable to give us a commitment," said Brian O'Leary, Time's production director, the magazine in August reduced the close for four-color ad pages -- the deadline for them to be on hand before publication -- to four weeks from seven.
The words "planning ahead" are likely to remain an unrealistic term until the economic recovery begins.
"All of this comes down to how good are you at knowing what's going on at your client," said Mr. Fox at Foote, Cone, "not what they're telling the press."

HEADLINE: Grapefruit Month in Congress

 BODY:
Forget the economy, health care and other weighty issues. Representatives Andy Ireland and Tom Lewis of Florida are busily buttonholing colleagues to have February declared "National Grapefruit Month." That might please the state's citrus growers, but why does Congress waste its time on empty commemorations?
A new compilation in the Congressional Record shows that nearly one-third of the new laws passed by Congress last year named a day, week, month or decade to celebrate. Whether the cause is National Mushroom Month or National Country Music Month, each bill requires lining up the co-sponsorship and signatures of a majority of members of both chambers. That eats up a hefty portion of staff time. And for what? A clutter of forgettable occasions, many pandering to special interests. 
 Representative Dave McCurdy, Democrat of Oklahoma, and Sherwood Boehlert, Republican of New York, propose turning over the designating chore to a commemorative commission, modeled on the one that decides on commemorative stamps. The day Congress took such a step would be Congressional Common Sense Day.

HEADLINE: If Frogs Had Wings

 BODY:
President Bush went to New Hampshire the other day to tell voters that he cares about their economic distress. But when asked whether he would agree to further extend last year's extension of unemployment insurance benefits, he dismissed the question curtly: "If a frog had wings, he wouldn't hit his tail on the ground -- too hypothetical."
There's nothing hypothetical about the determination of Congressional Democrats to add still more weeks to the 13 to 20 extra weeks of insurance payments that were added last fall. The House Ways and Means Committee is scheduled to vote on a 13-week extension Tuesday, just hours before Mr. Bush's State of the Union Address. The Senate Finance Committee plans hearings for Wednesday. 
 For workers who have been unemployed since last spring, payments will start running out next month, on the eve of the New Hampshire primary. And Mr. Bush, who twice vetoed last year's extension, is suddenly of different mind than when he talked about frogs 11 days ago. According to Administration insiders, he's ready to consider a further extension after all.
Whether his change of heart means he cares about New Hampshire's distress, or just its votes, is unclear. What's clear is that a flip response shows no care at all.
