HEADLINE: Kazakhs Seek a Level Capitalist Road

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALMA-ATA, Kazakhstan, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Quietly, while the other republics of the fallen Soviet empire are raging with the politics of recrimination, this critical new nation linking Russia and the newly independent Asian states is employing a different drummer in its attempted march to the free market.
He is Dr. Chan Young Bang, a 55-year-old American economist from the University of San Francisco, who has already achieved notable progress in the privatization of 40 percent of this capital's housing stock while the parliaments of other republics are still mostly agonizing over the alien notion of private ownership. 
 This week, Dr. Bang, who was born in Seoul, South Korea, took over the despairing precincts of the Communist Party Higher School to turn it into an academy to train free-market bankers, economists, managers and lawyers he finds so lacking in all the post-Communist reforms.
 
A 74-Year-Old Failure
 "I share your indignation," he told a gray-haired Marxist professor who was flabbergasted at his pink slip and demanded to know why capitalism is not working yet. "But to change the ideological attitude you have is very difficult; it hampers economic reform," he told the complaining professor in very simple, determined tones that pointed out that the Marxists had 74 years to fail, while the capitalists are in their first month.
Such are the bracingly authoritarian ways of Kazakhstan, the second largest of the old empire's new nations in territory and richness of mineral resources. It is the overlooked giant in the post-Communist equation, a nation where a pragmatic counterpoise of the Muslim-rooted Kazakh majority and the large Russian minority has thus far prevented wasteful tangents of nationalism, with more time to study the new arts of making money.
 
Hints of Nostalgia
 These are not coming easy, with problems far outweighing progress. Some business executives even speak in mock fondness for the old Communist business monolith now that they must brave the brushfire commerce wars smoldering among the foundling nations that survived the Soviet Union.
As it is across the former union, the old Communist economy is grinding down here to 60 percent production levels and worse, and unemployment has become starkly obvious as useless state factories lay off workers by the hundreds. Prices are expected to rise more than sevenfold this year, and the accelerating inflation has produced little more than fresh shock and cynicism.
While Kazakhstan seems ahead of other republics in privatization, it still has ended state ties at fewer than 5 percent of the enterprises -- about 50 businesses in this city, employing 15,000 workers who have realized up to 18,000 rubles each in share holdings at their converted workplaces. As in Russia and elsewhere, the Parliament, caught in old Soviet incantations about the Motherland, still balks at the truly private farm ownership that is so critically needed.
"Now, most workers are hesitating to allow auctions of their factories for privatization, because they know new private managers will demand harder work and efficiency and they could lose their jobs," said Hykyenov Sapapgaly, the chairman of the Kazakhstan property conversion committee, an ambitious factory welder who has learned to wend his way through the local party jungle.
But deep change is occurring quietly all about this capital's tree-lined snowscape. The magnificent city steam baths, once crowded and no longer low priced, are now a plutocrat's enclave of lavish hot marble and idle attendants grateful to deliver, for the equivalent of $1.50, a world-class massage and the Russian equivalent of have-a-nice-day.
Airliners, once ludicrously priced as low as mass transit and always packed, now take off half empty against the snowcapped mountain backdrop of the Chinese border. A seat to Moscow, 1,500 miles to the northwest, costs an average month's factory pay.
"Russia has just announced an end to all trade restrictions with us, and that's the first good news in a long time," said Nurzha Alimukhamedov, a partner in one of the new free-enterprise companies that are by far the best touch of optimism to be found here.
 
'There's No Stopping Us'
 "Don't worry, we are making progress and there is no stopping us," said the 32-year-old businessman, a nouveau millionaire in rubles, grinning in his ramshackle office that is the heart of a burgeoning furniture making and retail chain.
"Oh no, the remnants of Communism are still pretty suffocating," said his 33-year-old partner, Vladimir Zdorovizov. He described how long entrenched bureaucrats are cravenly behaving the old way in fighting the plans of Dr. Bang to privatize their empire. Business executives say most state administrators are working to get a personal leg up on the first entrepreneurial profits to be made, particularly in monopolizing state real estate.
As master planner, Dr. Bang is well aware of this, having been visiting this and other Soviet republics for 15 years; he still jumped at the job of resident reformer a year ago when it was offered. Currently he is worried about the effects of the price-liberalization policy that Kazakhstan had to follow (prematurely, he stresses) after giant Russia introduced it on Jan. 2.
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia deserves credit for pressing for the free market in such a harrowing time, Dr. Bang says, but deserves criticism as well for not having gotten a handle yet on the companion need of liberalized prices: privatizing the old state production monopoly and seeding competitive manufacturing of more goods.
 
Russia Is the Engine
 The key to all the other republics' reform hopes, radical or not, Dr. Bang stresses, is that the overshadowing Russian republic "has to put its house in order." Russia must very quickly push state enterprises into private conversion, he said, and end the government deficits and open-ended ruble printing.
"Yeltsin sometimes can be an unreliable, unguided missile," Dr. Bang complained. "As you see, 98 percent of the enterprises in Russia are still owned by the state. With this, price increases of themselves will not induce a positive response from state enterprises," because state managers have no personal incentive to change.
To get something of value quickly into the hands of ordinary people, Dr. Bang conceived the housing privatization scheme now under way: an equity system in which tenants are accorded retroactive "down payments" based on their years of residency, work and family size. Two of five apartments have been converted in this city of 1.2 million residents, he said.
Significantly, Dr. Bang did this by winning the support of Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the republic's former Communist leader who is attracting increasing Western attention as a skilled transition politician trying to push independence forward by braiding some free-market democracy to this vast land's autocratic traditions.
With Kazahhstan having only 17 million people in comparison with Russia's 149 million and Ukraine's 53 million, Mr. Nazarbayev has skillfully used the republic's quarter interest in the Soviet nuclear weapons club for political prestige. He has pledged disarmament but declined to ship Kazakh missiles for storage in President Yeltsin's Russia. At the same time, he keeps cross-border ties strong between the two nations, with six million Russians here and 850,000 Kazakhs there.
Mr. Nazarbayev suffered little for having hesitated a day in denouncing last August's Kremlin coup. Rather, he rushed into the post-Communist era by getting popularly elected with a minimum of opposition and pushing ahead with a huge new capitalist deal to have the Chevron Corporation develop lucrative oil fields.
Thus far, Kazakhstan's social stability stands out in comparison with the growing unease and political infighting of Russia and Ukraine, the restless giants of the shaky new Commonwealth of Independent States. A nationalist movement is just now noticeable here, but Mr. Nazarbayev appears trusted by the majorities of both Kazakhs and Russians, at least until the economy withers further.
"We do not have a lot of time," he said, hurrying through a dim corridor of Marxism's defunct academia. "Within two years, there'll be fresh stagnation, and then big social unrest, unless positive and very radical change can happen."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the growth of capitalism in Kazakhstan misattributed the final quotation. It was Dr. Chan Young Bang, an American adviser to the Government, who said: "We do not have a lot of time. Within two years there'll be fresh stagnation, and then big social unrest, unless positive and very radical change can happen."

HEADLINE: Kazakhs Seek a Level Capitalist Road

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALMA-ATA, Kazakhstan, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Quietly, while the other republics of the fallen Soviet empire are raging with the politics of recrimination, this critical new nation linking Russia and the newly independent Asian states is employing a different drummer in its attempted march to the free market.
He is Dr. Chan Young Bang, a 55-year-old American economist from the University of San Francisco, who has already achieved notable progress in the privatization of 40 percent of this capital's housing stock while the parliaments of other republics are still mostly agonizing over the alien notion of private ownership. 
 This week, Dr. Bang, who was born in Seoul, South Korea, took over the despairing precincts of the Communist Party Higher School to turn it into an academy to train free-market bankers, economists, managers and lawyers he finds so lacking in all the post-Communist reforms.
 
A 74-Year-Old Failure
 "I share your indignation," he told a gray-haired Marxist professor who was flabbergasted at his pink slip and demanded to know why capitalism is not working yet. "But to change the ideological attitude you have is very difficult; it hampers economic reform," he told the complaining professor in very simple, determined tones that pointed out that the Marxists had 74 years to fail, while the capitalists are in their first month.
Such are the bracingly authoritarian ways of Kazakhstan, the second largest of the old empire's new nations in territory and richness of mineral resources. It is the overlooked giant in the post-Communist equation, a nation where a pragmatic counterpoise of the Muslim-rooted Kazakh majority and the large Russian minority has thus far prevented wasteful tangents of nationalism, with more time to study the new arts of making money.
 
Hints of Nostalgia
 These are not coming easy, with problems far outweighing progress. Some business executives even speak in mock fondness for the old Communist business monolith now that they must brave the brushfire commerce wars smoldering among the foundling nations that survived the Soviet Union.
As it is across the former union, the old Communist economy is grinding down here to 60 percent production levels and worse, and unemployment has become starkly obvious as useless state factories lay off workers by the hundreds. Prices are expected to rise more than sevenfold this year, and the accelerating inflation has produced little more than fresh shock and cynicism.
While Kazakhstan seems ahead of other republics in privatization, it still has ended state ties at fewer than 5 percent of the enterprises -- about 50 businesses in this city, employing 15,000 workers who have realized up to 18,000 rubles each in share holdings at their converted workplaces. As in Russia and elsewhere, the Parliament, caught in old Soviet incantations about the Motherland, still balks at the truly private farm ownership that is so critically needed.
"Now, most workers are hesitating to allow auctions of their factories for privatization, because they know new private managers will demand harder work and efficiency and they could lose their jobs," said Hykyenov Sapapgaly, the chairman of the Kazakhstan property conversion committee, an ambitious factory welder who has learned to wend his way through the local party jungle.
But deep change is occurring quietly all about this capital's tree-lined snowscape. The magnificent city steam baths, once crowded and no longer low priced, are now a plutocrat's enclave of lavish hot marble and idle attendants grateful to deliver, for the equivalent of $1.50, a world-class massage and the Russian equivalent of have-a-nice-day.
Airliners, once ludicrously priced as low as mass transit and always packed, now take off half empty against the snowcapped mountain backdrop of the Chinese border. A seat to Moscow, 1,500 miles to the northwest, costs an average month's factory pay.
"Russia has just announced an end to all trade restrictions with us, and that's the first good news in a long time," said Nurzha Alimukhamedov, a partner in one of the new free-enterprise companies that are by far the best touch of optimism to be found here.
 
'There's No Stopping Us'
 "Don't worry, we are making progress and there is no stopping us," said the 32-year-old businessman, a nouveau millionaire in rubles, grinning in his ramshackle office that is the heart of a burgeoning furniture making and retail chain.
"Oh no, the remnants of Communism are still pretty suffocating," said his 33-year-old partner, Vladimir Zdorovizov. He described how long entrenched bureaucrats are cravenly behaving the old way in fighting the plans of Dr. Bang to privatize their empire. Business executives say most state administrators are working to get a personal leg up on the first entrepreneurial profits to be made, particularly in monopolizing state real estate.
As master planner, Dr. Bang is well aware of this, having been visiting this and other Soviet republics for 15 years; he still jumped at the job of resident reformer a year ago when it was offered. Currently he is worried about the effects of the price-liberalization policy that Kazakhstan had to follow (prematurely, he stresses) after giant Russia introduced it on Jan. 2.
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia deserves credit for pressing for the free market in such a harrowing time, Dr. Bang says, but deserves criticism as well for not having gotten a handle yet on the companion need of liberalized prices: privatizing the old state production monopoly and seeding competitive manufacturing of more goods.
 
Russia Is the Engine
 The key to all the other republics' reform hopes, radical or not, Dr. Bang stresses, is that the overshadowing Russian republic "has to put its house in order." Russia must very quickly push state enterprises into private conversion, he said, and end the government deficits and open-ended ruble printing.
"Yeltsin sometimes can be an unreliable, unguided missile," Dr. Bang complained. "As you see, 98 percent of the enterprises in Russia are still owned by the state. With this, price increases of themselves will not induce a positive response from state enterprises," because state managers have no personal incentive to change.
To get something of value quickly into the hands of ordinary people, Dr. Bang conceived the housing privatization scheme now under way: an equity system in which tenants are accorded retroactive "down payments" based on their years of residency, work and family size. Two of five apartments have been converted in this city of 1.2 million residents, he said.
Significantly, Dr. Bang did this by winning the support of Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the republic's former Communist leader who is attracting increasing Western attention as a skilled transition politician trying to push independence forward by braiding some free-market democracy to this vast land's autocratic traditions.
With Kazahhstan having only 17 million people in comparison with Russia's 149 million and Ukraine's 53 million, Mr. Nazarbayev has skillfully used the republic's quarter interest in the Soviet nuclear weapons club for political prestige. He has pledged disarmament but declined to ship Kazakh missiles for storage in President Yeltsin's Russia. At the same time, he keeps cross-border ties strong between the two nations, with six million Russians here and 850,000 Kazakhs there.
Mr. Nazarbayev suffered little for having hesitated a day in denouncing last August's Kremlin coup. Rather, he rushed into the post-Communist era by getting popularly elected with a minimum of opposition and pushing ahead with a huge new capitalist deal to have the Chevron Corporation develop lucrative oil fields.
Thus far, Kazakhstan's social stability stands out in comparison with the growing unease and political infighting of Russia and Ukraine, the restless giants of the shaky new Commonwealth of Independent States. A nationalist movement is just now noticeable here, but Mr. Nazarbayev appears trusted by the majorities of both Kazakhs and Russians, at least until the economy withers further.
"We do not have a lot of time," he said, hurrying through a dim corridor of Marxism's defunct academia. "Within two years, there'll be fresh stagnation, and then big social unrest, unless positive and very radical change can happen."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Firms Relatively Quiet on Treasury Proposals

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
After decades of doing business pretty much on their own, executives and traders at firms that buy and sell Treasury securities seem to have relatively few quarrels with the sweeping market changes proposed last week by the Government.
In part, the subdued reaction stems from a realization that further changes, beyond those announced in the immediate aftermath of the Salomon Brothers bidding scandal, were bound to come. But many traders say there is also widespread recognition that many of the proposed changes are sound ones. 
 "Ninety-five percent of this is great," said one government securities trader, who insisted on not being identified. "I'm just concerned that the remaining 5 percent could be detrimental."
 
Participants' Main Concern
 Market participants said their main concern about the Government proposals involved the new uniform-price, open-auction system that the Treasury is considering to replace the multiple-price, sealed-bid auction that has been in place since the mid-1970's.
Among the legislative recommendations is one that would require the time-sequenced reporting of trades to regulators -- otherwise known as an audit trail. At the moment the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Board oppose this proposal, while the Securities and Exchange Commission favors it. If those differences are ironed out, market participants would undoubtedly contest it.
For the moment, the notion of tinkering with the auction system, one that the Treasury acknowleges has worked well despite the recent abuses, was the one that provoked the most discussion among traders and dealers.
"The auction proposal is an interesting idea that needs additional study," said Richard M. Kelly, chairman and chief executive of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a primary dealer in government securities.
 
Worries About Liquidity
 Mr. Kelly and others are concerned that by giving investors an incentive to participate directly in the auction process rather than through primary dealers, liquidity in the market for new Treasury issues prior to their sale -- the so-called when-issued market -- could dry up, making efficient price discovery of the securities more difficult and potentially raising the Treasury's borrowing costs.
"Under the new system, customers may decide it is to their advantage to buy at the auction rather than deal in the when-issued market," Mr. Kelly said. "I am skeptical that will lead to lower borrowing costs."
A less liquid when-issued market might be detrimental to the Treasury because it might not accurately reflect the real prices of the securities. Moreover, the Treasury has said it plans to use the when-issued price as an initial benchmark at the auction. It will be months before it can be determined whether that method of setting the initial bid is workable.
 
Current System to Continue
 Until sometime late this year or early in 1993, when the auction process is fully automated, the current bidding system will remain in place. And sealed-bid auctions will continue for a time after that, market participants said, as the proposed new system is tested and debated.
Indeed, there are signs that changes announced last fall to open up bidding under current rules are having an impact.
At a Congressional hearing following release of the report detailing the changes, Jerome H. Powell, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Domestic Finance, said that since the changes were announced in October, an additional 40 firms had bid for clients at auctions, and that "10 or fewer" had bid directly.
Other aspects of the report were of less concern. Dealers voiced little or no objection, for example, to the Treasury's headline-grabbing commitment to provide additional amounts of a security to the market in order to minimize the chances that any firm could "squeeze" an issue, as Salomon Brothers did last spring.
 
Little Real Change Seen
 In large part, market participants were fairly indifferent to the pledge because they realize that for a variety of reasons the Treasury is unlikely to take such a step often, perhaps never.
Indeed, in the report detailing the actual and proposed changes, only three instances of such acute, protracted shortages were identified. Two occurred last spring, the product of Salomon's illegal bidding tactics. The third took place in February 1986.
Similarly, primary dealers were reluctant to criticize the decision to democratize what had been a tightly knit group of authorized securities dealers. Even with greater competition, the changes stand to benefit large firms.
As part of opening up the system, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which is charged with designating primary dealers, is eliminating the requirement that each primary dealer make at least 1 percent of all customer trades in the secondary market.
 
Maybe Less Democratic
 "To firms who make markets in government securities as a major business this is a positive, because it will eliminate an artificial requirement that forced marginal players who wanted to be primary dealers to underprice their services," said Louis v. B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. "By eliminating the minimum-share requirement, the New York Fed is allowing dealers to set bid/ask spreads at levels where they can make money."
Moreover, the recognition of more and more primary dealers -- beyond the 38 that now carry that designation -- may over time force the New York Fed, which conducts its open-market operations through primary dealers, to telescope those activities through a small group of firms it knows well.
"It will be some time before the number of primary dealers expands much, but as the numbers grow the Fed is likely to return to a much smaller, more informal group of market contacts," Mr. Crandall added. "Ironically, what is being described as a more democratic system may effectively work in the opposite direction."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 30, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The Credit Markets column in Business Day on Monday referred incorrectly to bidding activity by Salomon Brothers at Treasury note auctions last April and May where "squeezes" occurred. Salomon's bidding at the April auction has not been questioned by regulators. In a report last week, the Government said the squeeze in May appeared to have been caused by large awards of the securities to Salomon and some of its customers, but it has not been established whether that squeeze resulted from wrongdoing by Salomon.

HEADLINE: Hands Off the Economy

BYLINE: By David A. Stockman; David A. Stockman, White House budget director from 1981 to 1985, is a partner at the Blackstone Group.

 BODY:
The stock market has lurched into overdrive, betting that the Federal Reserve's shift to low interest rates means that an economic rebound is just months away. But unlike the speculators who face perhaps 50-50 odds, President Bush in his State of the Union Address tomorrow is expected to make a wager that arguably has a 100 percent chance of being wrong.
Recession year "borrow and stimulate" packages have a habit of missing the present and haunting the future. And in the present circumstances, the case against the grab bag of stimulants for housing, investment and the middle-class consumer that the President is expected to announce is especially compelling. 
 Unfortunately, if Mr. Bush had not been so reluctant to raise taxes early in his term when the economy was healthy, his current risky prescription would not be necessary. But when he finally moved his lips in November 1990, he wound up imposing a major tax increase just as the bottom was dropping out of the economy. Ironically, the right-wingers who thwarted him then now compound their felony by loudly pressing for unadulterated pump priming.
If Wall Street is correct, however, and we are at the turning point of an ordinary business cycle, the Federal Reserve's 4 percent money market rates will spark business activity long before the House Ways and Means Committee even takes roll call.
Arousing Congress from its usual stupor in order to ignite the fiscal afterburners would thus be doubly tragic. By eliciting a Capitol Hill bidding war to include a stimulant for every constituency with a name, the Administration will not only expand the short-term deficit but also risk squandering the prospective post-cold war fiscal windfall.
After all, financing national security during the cold war took more than 6 percent of the gross national product. Surely in this new era of ruble rubble, defense can eventually be financed on just 3 percent of G.N.P.
Thus, a normal recovery could mean a strong revenue rebound, a reversal of the $100 billion-a-year savings and loan bailout and a decent chance to harvest the peace dividend. What could ruin this golden opportunity to rid the nation of the curse of mega-deficits, however, is the fiscal stampede the Administration is about to launch.
There remains the more likely prospect that instead of a downturn in the ordinary business cycle, we are in the middle of national balance sheet shock. In the 1980's we raised the collective debt of the economy from $4 billion to $11 billion -- and its percentage of G.N.P. rose to an unprecedented 200 percent.
Could the drop in nominal growth indicators like housing prices, lending, spending and wages to anemic 2 to 4 percent rates -- levels not seen since the 1950's -- mean that a genuine debt deflation is under way? If so, hitting the fiscal accelerator after the Federal Reserve has launched its high-octane money policy could prove highly hazardous.
Why? Because economic recovery may turn on restoring financial confidence, not consumer spending.
Our balance sheet problem involves not just an excess of debt, but, more important, a surfeit of assets. The debt side of the balance sheet, however ugly and distended, is backward-looking -- a measure of recklessness during the 1980's. Likewise, the mushrooming defaults weigh more heavily on current wealth than on future production.
It is the abundance of household and business fixed assets that really threaten recovery. Cars, VCR's, wardrobes, office buildings, hotel rooms, airplanes and retail floor space, overbought in yesterday's debt spree, must now inevitably become oversold and underproduced. The former brings a markdown in value and confidence, the latter an extended hiatus in business activity and employment.
Perhaps the public's flaccid shopping behavior represents as much an exhaustion of need as it does anxiety about the value of its principal collateral and the flow of income needed to service its debts.
On the business side, banks, brokerage houses, insurance and real estate companies acquired personal computers, modular furniture and square footage like there was no tomorrow. This sector, with a base of only 17 percent of real G.N.P. in 1980, accounted for an astounding $450 billion or 50 percent of the real growth in the nation's capital stock through 1989. Could the lack of orders at I.B.M., Compaq and the office furniture makers signal an overabundance of fixed assets and a long, flat spell ahead?
If we are in balance sheet shock that holds down business expansion until the fixed-asset surplus can be marked down and slowly absorbed, the financial markets will likely soon go into cardiac arrest. Confidence will ebb to the vanishing point. In this case, a renewed exercise in fiscal pump priming that would send the Federal deficit soaring toward half a trillion dollars will have many effects. Stimulating an economic recovery will not be among them.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 1, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday misstated the rise in the collective debt of the U.S. economy in the 1980's. The debt rose to $11 trillion from $4 trillion.

HEADLINE: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Players;
Onetime Insider Adapts To Low-Key Campaign

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RAYMOND, N.H., Jan. 22

 BODY:
Peggy Connolly, once a consummate Washington insider as spokeswoman for the Democratic National Campaign Committee, left the capital in 1988 right after George Bush's election. She said she believed that a Democrat would not be elected President until the year 2000.
But today, Ms. Connolly, 36 years old, is press secretary to Paul E. Tsongas, former Senator from Massachusetts, who is seeking the Democratic nomination. Mr. Tsongas was the first Democrat to challenge President Bush. 
 "I had been frustrated with Washington and with the Democrats who were afraid to take risks and refused to be critical of Reagan," said Ms. Connolly, who had returned to her hometown, Westford, Mass., to care for her father. "They were fearful of the polls, which said that he was enjoying this tremendous popularity. But the polls said people liked Reagan, but they didn't like his policies. And it was frustrating to me that the Democrats wouldn't tie those two things together."
Ms. Connolly said Mr. Tsongas's announcement in April did just that. "I picked up The Boston Globe one day, and it said this guy was really gutsy to say that George Bush has to be challenged," she recalled.
She joined the campaign on April 7, 1991, but said she was unprepared for Mr. Tsongas's low-key strategy, which incorporated none of the smooth packaging and image making that she had been used to. The Potomac point of view did not dissipate easily, she said, particularly in the summer, when Mr. Tsongas received little press attention and Ms. Connolly felt responsible.
"I would come in and tell Paul that he was losing ground in the eyes of the national media, and he would reassure me that everything was going to be fine," Ms. Connolly recalled. "He would offer me the perspective of his past political campaigns, saying this was nothing compared to his Senate race. He's never demanded headlines or national columns. It's a whole new experience."
She is respected by journalists for her candid responses, conceding that her candidate lacks dazzle even while pushing his positive points.
Ms. Connolly said she "fell into politics" when she went to Washington shortly after graduating from Northeastern University in Boston in 1982.
Occasionally, her Washington instincts get the upper hand. She has tried to lessen Mr. Tsongas's use of chalkboards and flip charts to explain his economic plan because they make him look more professorial then Presidential, but she conceded that she had not been entirely successful.
Ms. Connolly is the youngest of six children in the family of a machinist in Westford, 10 miles west of Mr. Tsongas's hometown, Lowell. She worked as a reporter at The Lowell Sun, but did not meet Mr. Tsongas until she became his press secretary.
Like any good press secretary, she said she was sure Mr. Tsongas would win. "I believe in following your political gut," she said. "After all, in the office pool in 1988, I was the only one who chose Dan Quayle as Vice President."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 5, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 27 about Peggy Connolly, press secretary for the Presidential campaign of Paul E. Tsongas and former spokeswoman for the Democratic National Campaign Committee, misstated her age. She is 34.

GOTTI TRIAL: PLEA TO THE JUDGE
Prosecutors in John Gotti's racketeering trial urged the judge to limit the defense's ability to cross-examine three former high-ranking mob figures about murders they had committed, saying that grisly details about the murders would inflame the jury. DINKINS TAXI PLAN: CAN IT WORK?
As he seeks to bring order to the city's fragmented taxi industry, Mayor Dinkins's motive is clear. He would like all New Yorkers to have the same quality of cab service -- particularly the right to hail a taxi on the street -- that people enjoy in central Manhattan. But it remains unclear whether he can obtain approval for his plan, and whether it will actually bring better service. News Analysis, B3.

In what is believed to be the first test of a new Federal law protecting the rights of the disabled, a group of advocates filed suit against the Empire State Building, demanding that its owners make the observation deck accessible to people in wheelchairs. B3.

On the two issues that most affect business decisions to move -- cost and safety -- New York is significantly worse off than five years ago, a survey of business leaders has found. B3.

Our Towns B5

 BODY:

The Macy's Bankruptcy
R. H. Macy & Co. filed for bankruptcy protection, finally admitting defeat in its bruising battle with creditors and the economy. [Page A1.] 
 Add Macy's to the list of leveraged buyouts gone bad, but successes are also numerous. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's chairman, tried everything, but in the end, there was nothing he could do. [D6.]
Macy's will not alter its marketing efforts significantly, advertising executives say. [D6.]
Macy's will have its day in court in front of one of the favorite judges of lawyers for bankrupt clients, Burton R. Lifland. [D7.]
The filing came just a week before Federated Department Stores is expected to emerge from bankruptcy protection. [D7.]
 
Companies
General Motors Acceptance agreed to refund tens of millions of dollars to hundreds of thousands of homeowners who were allegedly forced to pay excessive amounts into escrow accounts. [D1.]
Leading Edge notified its dealers that it accidentally shipped as many as 500 personal computers with a potent virus. [D1.]

General Motors plans to close its "factory of the future" in Saginaw, Mich., in August. [D4.]
Alan Fortunoff is putting his family's business on the line with plans to build a shopping center on Long Island. [B5.]
 
The Economy
Employers' health-care costs rose 12.1 percent nationwide, to $3,605 per employee last year, according to a survey. [D2.]
Orders for U.S.-made machine tools tumbled to a four-year low last year as depressed auto sales battered the industry. [D8.]
The Supreme Court limited the ability of union organizers to go onto an employer's property to distribute literature. [A13.]
A complaint about the Empire State Building draws attention to businesses' legal obligation to the handicapped. [B3.]
 
International

HEADLINE: Dow Edges Up 7.83 and Closes at 3,240.61

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with blue chips posting small gains while the broader market was weak. Many cautious investors moved to the sidelines in anticipation of the President's State of the Union Message tonight.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.83 points to finish at 3,240.61, but all the other leading indexes wound up with losses. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was noticeably down from previous sessions, with nearly 191 million shares traded, compared with 214.6 million on Friday. Gaining issues held a slim lead over losers, 890 to 831, as the Big Board composite slipped 0.23, to 228.94.
Anthony Ludovici, senior vice president and senior investment analyst with Tucker Anthony, described the trading as lackluster, with investors trekking to the sidelines before tonight's message.
Mr. Ludovici noted that automobiles were one of the strong spots in the market, with weakness still apparent in pharmaceuticals. This is "an indication that there is still rotation into cyclicals, a group geared to the economy," Mr. Ludovici said. "Even in a lackluster market, it explains why the Dow was up while the market was down. The key market indicator is made up of a number of cyclicals."
Noting past moves by the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low, which would translate into renewed economic strength, some analysts were high on auto stocks. Chrysler rose 1 1/2, to 15; Ford Motor, 1, to 32 3/4, and General Motors, 1 3/8, to 34 1/8.
Paper stocks like Scott Paper, up 2 3/8, to 40; Boise Cascade, up 1/4, to 23 1/8, and International Paper, up 1 5/8, to 74 3/8, also benefited from the move to cyclicals, Mr. Ludovici said.
Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks slipped 0.49, to 414.99, while the American Stock Exchange composite was off 0.94, to 412.48. The Nasdaq composite was down 3.68, to 621.00, and the Russell 2,000 was off 0.36, to 205.06.
The moderate gains in early trading were aided by strong futures prices, a firm bond market and some carry-over from gains overseas.
Premark International, the manufacturer of Tupperware and food equipment products, jumped 5 1/4, to 46 7/8, after the company reported higher-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings of $1.48 a share, because of the surprisingly strong showing in its domestic food-equipment business and lower tax rates. Jay Freedman, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, said Wall Street had expected Premark to report earnings of $1.05 a share.
As generous as investors have been to better-than-expected results, they have been equally unforgiving when earnings have not matched expectations, traders noted. Commodore International served as a reminder yesterday, falling 2 3/8, to 16 5/8, after second-quarter earnings did not exceed expectations.
Mentor Graphics , which produces and services electronic design automation systems, was up 5/8, to 18 1/4, as Laura Conigliaro, an analyst with Prudential Securities, raised her rating on the company to "buy" from "hold." She cited the completion of the company's 8.0 design automation software last year, which will allow Mentor to concentrate on the release of related software products than can be used on more work stations. This month, Mentor said it would make the 8.0 software, already compatible with Sun Microsystems work stations, compatible with certain I.B.M., NEC and Sony equipment.
Among the biggest percentage gainers on the Big Board was MGM-Pathe, which rose to 3 1/4, from 2 1/4. Credit Lyonnais, which last month gained control of the Hollywood studio, said it would welcome a good offer but was in no hurry to sell the studio.

HEADLINE: Health Costs Up 12.1% Last Year, a Study Says

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Employers' health-care costs rose by 12.1 percent nationwide, to $3,605 per employee last year, or about four times as fast as overall living costs, according to a survey released yesterday. What is more, analysts said the annual increase in 1992 would be higher.
Health costs in 1991 were the highest in the Middle Atlantic States, averaging $4,066 an employee, and were the second highest in New England, at $3,918, followed by $3,659 on the West Coast, $3,546 in the Midwest, $3,412 in the South Atlantic States, and $3,262 in the Mountain States. 
 Costs were the lowest in the South Central region, at $3,256. The coverage included medical and dental plans and health maintenance organizations.
 
Factors Affecting Some Rates
 John Erb, a principal in New York with the A. Foster Higgins consulting firm, said in commenting on the annual survey that some of the reasons for the higher costs in the Northeast were government-set hospital rates in New York and New Jersey that barred employers from negotiating discounts; the high prevalence of unions resisting efforts to make workers pay more of their medical bills; more state-required types of coverage, like podiatry, and higher regional living costs.
He also said the averages reflected the severe recession in the Northeast.
"Typically, younger, healthier people get laid off, leaving an older work force," Mr. Erb said. Older workers on average have higher medical expenses.
Kenneth Sperling, a health-care consultant in Rowayton, Conn., with Hewitt Associates, said hospitals and doctors in the Northeast had long been more resistant to health maintenance organizations and employer-discount networks than other regions.
The resistance is softening, he said, because many medical "providers are afraid that if they don't get control of health-care costs, the Federal Government will move in, and they will be worse off." He added, "Most likely, everybody would be paid according to a Medicare fee schedule in a price-regulated system."
 
'Fee for Service' Costs
 Nationwide, medical costs in traditional "fee for service" plans, which pay medical providers for each service performed, rose by 13 percent, to $3,573, down from 20 percent the year before, as more employers required workers to pay more of their own bills, the Foster Higgins survey showed.
Mr. Erb said the 13 percent level would probably not be repeated; trends show the rise will again be about 20 percent this year because the basic causes of medical-cost inflation have not been controlled.
H.M.O. and discount health plan rates have been rising at a slower pace, 12 percent to 14 percent, in the last few years.
Mr. Sperling of Hewitt said a survey of 12 large insurance companies had shown fee-for-service rates rising by 22 percent for 1992 and H.M.O. rates up by 13.6 percent.
 
10.7% Rise Expected
 Federal economists estimate that national spending for medical care will increase by 10.7 percent this year, to $817 billion, or 14 percent of the gross national product.
Foster Higgins said about two-thirds of the employers surveyed in its study were offering to pay for health maintenance organizations. A third of their employees had joined. H.M.O. participation was lowest in the Middle Atlantic States, at 24 percent, and in New England, at 31 percent. In the West, an H.M.O. stronghold, 41 percent were members.
Foster Higgins said 2,409 private and government employers responded to their survey. Half had 500 or more employees and half had fewer than that.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Plans New Taxes And Job Cuts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins will propose more big cuts in spending for long-term construction projects, new taxes on gasoline and automobiles, higher income taxes on commuters and a four-year freeze in property tax rates when he presents his preliminary budget for New York City on Thursday, city officials said yesterday.
The Mayor must present a plan for closing a $1.8 billion gap in the $29 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1. He must also show how he proposes to keep the budget balanced over the next four years, in hopes of winning support for a $1 billion bond deal with the Municipal Assistance Corporation to ease the pain of spending and service cuts. 
 Final details are still being ironed out, but city officials said last night that the plan would call for cutting a total of about 20,000 full-time jobs by mid-1996 from the 220,000 that were on the city payroll in June, mostly through attrition. That is about 4,000 more jobs than were to be eliminated in the city's most recent plans, which fiscal monitors faulted as inadequate.
 
New Revenues Sought
 The capital budget, which finances building projects through the sale of long-term bonds, would be cut $3.7 billion over four years, to $8.5 billion, to save money on bond repayments that were projected to swallow one-fifth of city tax revenues by 1996. Officials said the proposal would produce perhaps only $5 million in savings next year, growing to $250 million a year by 1996. They said that the Mayor would keep his pledge to speed up capital spending to boost the economy in the next 18 months, though construction industry representatives said the cuts would still be devastating.
But even as the administration proposes the capital cuts, it will seek new revenue sources, including a nickel-a-gallon gasoline tax and a 1 percent tax on the value of automobiles, to finance a new bridge maintenance authority. Those taxes have been proposed unsuccessfully in the past, and will face an uphill battle in the State Legislature, which has toyed with raising gas taxes to help balance the state budget.
The Mayor will also face a fight with the Legislature over his proposal to increase the city income tax on commuters, an idea always hotly resisted by powerful suburban lawmakers. But in a twist that it hopes will gain support in Albany, City Hall proposes to relieve suburban New York counties of some of the taxes they now pay to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. In other words, only commuters from New Jersey and Connecticut would ultimately bear the income tax increase.
 
Property-Tax Freeze
 The administration will propose raising the rate for commuters who are wage earners to .75 percent, from .45 percent, and for self-employed commuters to .95 percent, from .65 percent.
Mr. Dinkins had earlier pledged a two-year freeze in property-tax rates, but he will now extend that to four years, aides said, under continuing pressure from the City Council and the real-estate lobby. He will make up the difference by proposing to extend permanently a three-year surcharge on the city personal income tax that was imposed last year. That would keep the top income tax rate at 4.46 percent.
Some of the capital budget cuts would simply delay projects not scheduled to start for several years. But they come on top of $2.9 billion in capital cuts already made in the last year, and would postpone indefinitely some projects that had been scheduled to begin soon, including a 1,000 bed jail on Staten Island that local residents have vigorously opposed. The cuts would also delay for at least four years the building of a dozen schools and major school repairs.
The administration has proposed the cuts under pressure from bond-rating agencies, which have threatened to lower the city's bond rating because of concern about the burdens on the budget. City officials said they decided it was better to choose where to cut now, rather than risk losing ready access to the bond market and thus further reducing their options.
In a statement explaining the capital spending cuts, the Mayor said spending for bridge reconstruction, courts, libraries and cultural institutions would remain untouched, as would water and sewer projects, which are backed by separate bonds.
But Frank McArdle, managing director of the General Contractors Association, a trade group for the heavy construction industry, said the proposed cuts would cost the industry between 21,000 and 35,000 jobs in the next four years, depending on what projects are eliminated.
"I can't believe that this mayor is proposing to do this at a time when the City of New York has super-high unemployment in the construction industry and at a time when the city can get bargain basement prices for the work," he said. The association estimates that about half of all construction workers in the city are out of work.
 
Garbage Fees Considered
 First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the administration was especially concerned about not damaging the economy further, and that was why it has proposed most of the cuts for the third and fourth years of the plan. He said the plan was not inflexible, and that the city would continue to explore other revenue sources -- including new fees for garbage collection that could finance sanitation projects -- and to lobby for more Federal construction money.
Mr. Steisel said the city had decided to delay jail construction because new efforts to speed court processing and send more inmates to state jails, together with a drop in felony arrests, had relieved presssure on city cells that had been bursting at the seams. If new needs develop, he said, the city could quickly erect inflatable units on the Staten Island site.
Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island, a bitter opponent of the jail, praised the delay, but attacked a proposed 80 percent cut in capital spending for ferries that serve his borough.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profits Fall For ARCO And Phillips

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 27

 BODY:
ARCO and the Phillips Petroleum Company reported sharply lower earnings today for the fourth quarter, steeper declines than oil companies with broader international operations like Exxon, Mobil and Texaco have reported.
The Unocal Corporation, which like ARCO and Phillips Petroleum operates primarily in the United States, reported a small loss for the quarter. 
 ARCO said net income fell 52.7 percent; Phillips Petroleum reported a decline of 66.7 percent for the quarter, and Unocal said it lost $16 million.
Lower prices for crude oil and natural gas, weak demand for refined products in the United States and one-time charges against earnings contributed to lower earnings at ARCO and Phillips Petroleum. Unocal said its loss resulted from special charges against earnings.
C. J. Silas, chairman and chief executive of Phillips Petroleum, said, "We haven't seen any upturn in the economy as far as our operations are concerned."
Following are details from the three companies' earnings reports:
 
ARCO
 ARCO, the nation's eighth-largest oil company, said its net income fell to $268 million, or $1.67 a share, from $566 million, or $3.45 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. Revenues fell 15.9 percent, to $4.83 billion from $5.74 billion.
The company, based in Los Angeles, said earnings from drilling and production activities plunged to $197 million in the quarter, from $553 million in the period a year ago. But other business segments reported profits close to the totals a year ago.
Profits in refining and marketing slipped to $48 million, from $54 million, but rose from pipeline and other transportation activities to $65 million, from $58 million, and in chemicals to $67 million, from $63 million. A gasoline pricing war on the West Coast, ARCO's primary retailing area, eased in the recent quarter.
For the year, ARCO's earnings fell 64.7 percent, to $709 million, or $4.39 a share, from $2.01 billion, or $12.15 a share. ARCO took a $295 million charge against earnings in the third quarter when it announced layoffs and operating cutbacks because of anticipated low natural gas prices.
Without the charge, ARCO's 1991 profits would have been roughly $1 billion, or $6.21 a share. Revenues for 1991 fell 3.5 percent, to $18.16 billion from $18.81 billion. The company's average price for crude, which ARCO produces mainly from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay region, slipped to $12.93 a barrel in 1991 from $16.56 in 1990.
ARCO's share price rose 25 cents today, to $108, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Phillips Petroleum
 Phillips Petroleum, the nation's 10th-largest oil company, said its net income was $79 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $237 million, or 92 cents a share. Revenue for the company, based in Bartlesville, Okla., fell 24.1 percent, to $3.37 billion from $4.44 billion.
If several special items were excluded from the two reporting periods, like the gain of $256 million in the recent quarter from property insurance payments related to a fatal 1989 explosion at its Houston chemical complex, net income would have fallen further, to $48 million from $294 million.
Most of the one-time gains in the recent quarter were offset by a $244 million write-down of the company's stake in the Point Arguello field off the California coast, where production has been limited by local and state regulators.
For the year, net income fell 66.9 percent, to $258 million from $779 million. Revenues declined 5.2 percent, to $13.26 billion from $13.98 billion.
The company's share price fell 12.5 cents today, to $24.25, in trading on the Big Board.
 
Unocal
 The company's $16 million loss in the quarter compares with net income of $38 million, or 16 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Revenue for the Los Angeles-based company fell 18 percent, to $2.77 billion from $3.38 billion.
Excluding special charges, net income would have been $31 million, or 13 cents a share, in the recent quarter, compared with $111 million, or 47 cents a share, in the period a year ago. The charges in the recent quarter included $62 million for canceled or scaled-back projects at the Los Angeles refinery and a chemical plant near Sacramento, Calif.
Earnings from exploration and production fell to $105 million, from $222 million in the period a year ago. But refining profits improved, to $50 million from $17 million. Average prices for total crude sales fell to $16.33 a barrel, from $26.26 a barrel in the final quarter of 1990.
For the year, earnings plunged 89.8 percent, to $73 million, or 31 cents a share, from $401 million, or $1.71 a share. Revenues slipped 7.7 percent, to $10.90 billion from $11.81 billion.
Unocal's share price fell 50 cents today, to $22.625, in trading on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Killing Casts a Rare Light On Gay Life in Suburbia

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH BELLMORE, L.I., Jan. 24

 BODY:
Nobody at Pal Joey's wanted to talk much about Henry Marquez, the dark-haired Texas dreamer who loved old cars, country music and Hamptons beaches. At the gay bar, where one would expect outrage at a gay-bashing episode that the police said led to Mr. Marquez's death, the silence instead ran cold, immutable and deep.
The attack on Mr. Marquez at a parking lot near Pal Joey's last month has thrown an unwelcome spotlight on gay life in the suburbs, a shadowy world between the pride, bravado and activism of Christopher Street in Manhattan and the exuberant summer retreats on Fire Island and the Hamptons. 
 Gay-rights advocates say gay life on Long Island is often muted by half truths meant to protect double lives. Many gay men and women here are married and have children, and, like many suburbanites, moved to Long Island to escape the anxieties of urban life.
While bias incidents have become a rallying cry for gay-rights groups in New York City, they remain largely a topic of hushed conversation here and have gone all but unreported to the police, gay-rights advocates say.
"A lot of people move to Long Island because they want to get away from things in general," said Ted Oneto, director of the Long Island Act Up, a group involved in AIDS issues. "To be confronted on a hard-core issue, a lot of them turn their backs."
 
Confronting Apathy
 To be sure, the death of Mr. Marquez, a 26-year-old customs agent, has roused many gay residents of Long Island. They are angered by the Nassau County District Attorney's decision to charge Mr. Esposito with manslaughter instead of murder.
But these attempts to organize say more about the community's weakness than its solidarity. A protest Thursday morning at the Nassau County Courthouse drew less than a dozen people, and a weekend vigil in North Bellmore began at the railroad station, in part to accommodate people coming from New York City.
"In terms of solidarity, it's the ostrich effect," said James Darragh, a philosophy professor and journalist in Old Westbury who is gay.
 
Few Reported Attacks
 The Nassau County police say there were four reported incidents of anti-gay bias in 1991, the same number in 1990, and five in 1989. The Suffolk County Police anti-bias unit counted nine gay-bashing incidents last year, up from four in each of the two previous years. But few people, including the chief of Suffolk County's anti-bias unit, Detective Sgt. Joseph Zito, believe the figures give an accurate measure of insults and attacks against gay people on Long Island.
One part of the problem is New York State law, which does not prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, and leaves gay people open to losing jobs and housing, said Sandy Rapp, political director of the East End Gay Organization and author of "God's Country," a book on gay civil rights.
"When you have a group for whom civil rights protections are not in place," Ms. Rapp said, "they are unlikely to report an incident in which they are identified as being gay."
But the difficulty in reporting an attack usually extends beyond the legal and economic risks. If the details of the attack leak out, it can also lead to the victim being ostracized.
"The suburbs, and especially Long Island, like to perceive themselves as a homogeneous group," said a salesman who knew Mr. Marquez and asked that his name not be used. "Everyone wants to be with their own kind. And when somebody's different, they really hold it against you."
A friend of Mr. Darragh, who did not want to be identified, said he was attacked at a gay bar in Suffolk last year. Divorced and living with his parents, who still display his wedding picture in the living room, the man could not bring himself to tell them he had been lured out of a gay bar and assaulted. It was two days before he was able to return home.
In that time, he replayed the attack in his mind: the teen-ager who asked if he was gay, and then blocked the door back into the bar; the bar patrons hearing his cries and coming outside to help; friends of his attacker running over from the gas station next door, swinging golf clubs; the bar owner calling his customers inside and locking the door, and the horrifying realization that one man had mistakenly been locked out and was being beaten.
For hours, the man grappled with whether to press charges, fearful of word spreading that he had been in a gay bar. Others were equally ambivalent about pressing charges: The owner of the bar wanted to report it, the man who had been locked out and battered with golf clubs did not.
After the attack, the victim felt singled out, identifiable as gay. He found himself thinking: "They're after me. They hate me. I was a white male, I was accepted, and now I feel I'm the lowest-class person."
The fear of being unmasked apparently prevailed the night Mr. Marquez died. Then, two men taunted people and used a car to run them down in the parking lot near Pal Joey's, a popular cruising spot for gay men, an hour and half before they struck Mr. Marquez. One man jumped for cover behind a phone booth. And Mr. Marquez was escaping the men when he jumped in his car and they hunted him down, ramming his car into a tree.
But nobody called for help that night. When one witness, a gay man, called the police days later, he did so after much soul searching, and used a public telephone, a friend of his said.
"It was lucky for us two of the witnesses were not gay," said Sgt. William Cocks, of the Nassau County homicide unit. The police arrested a 29-year-old unemployed handyman, Angelo Esposito, in the killing.
In a strange way, Mr. Marquez might have understood the reticence of the witnesses. "If Henry had survived this," one of his friends said, "I don't think he would be thrilled to be the center of all this controversy. If he had survived, he probably wouldn't have reported it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angelo Esposito, who has been charged with manslaughter in an alleged gay-bashing attack in North Bellmore, L.I.

HEADLINE: Hammer-and-Sickle Falls Out of Fashion in Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Drawing back from a 70-year effort to bring Marx to Brazil's masses, the Brazilian Communist Party has voted to drop the hammer and sickle as its symbol and to change its name to the Popular Socialist Party.
The party, which is stressing democracy and socialism, abandoned its name Sunday night in a raucous congress marked by egg-throwing and name-calling. Last fall, as a struggle over the party's future deepened, reform leaders took out a 10-year patent on the party's old name to prevent others from using it, and orthodox members retaliated by breaking into party offices and carrying to safety portraits of Marx, Engels and Lenin. 
 As the insults of "Czarist" and "Stalinist" faded away from the weekend congress, the end of the Communist Party marked the end of Brazil's oldest political party. During most of this century, the party, the largest Communist organization in Latin America before it was eclipsed by Cuba's, exerted a powerful influence over Brazilian intellectual life but also became an obsession for American diplomats stationed here, beginning in the 1920's.
 
Impetus for a Coup
 Paulo Sergio Pinheiro, a visiting scholar at Columbia University who recently finished a history of the party, said that during the 1960's, diplomatic cables analyzing the party left here for Washington at the rate of once a week.
Legal only for nine years since it was organized in 1922, the Communist Party won attention in 1935 for attempting a left-wing military uprising. In an electoral high-water mark, the party won 10 percent of the national vote in Brazil's 1945 presidential election.
"Fear of the Communists' growing influence was one of the great rationales for the United States support of a 1964 military coup," said Thomas E. Skidmore, a Brown University historian who has written several books on Brazilian political history.
During the military government, which lasted until 1985, about 6,000 party members were arrested and many were tortured and killed, according to Francisco Almeida, a longtime militant who is leader of the new party.
But after legalization in 1985, the party suffered from competition from the Workers' Party, which is not Marxist, and from the collapse of the Soviet Union. Anatoly Smirnov, former head of the International Department of the Soviet Communist Party, disclosed this month that from 1973 to 1987, the Soviet party had paid the Brazilian party a yearly subsidy of $300,000.
Wielding influence beyond its numbers, party membership included members of Brazil's small intellectual elite -- journalists, architects, musicians, filmmakers and novelists.
Noting the party's influence in promoting economic nationalism, Mr. Skidmore said, "For many Brazilians in the 1930's, 1940's and 1950's, their contact with the party defined their politics in later life."
Today, a Marxist-Leninist splinter group is led by Oscar Niemeyer, the 84-year-old architect of Brazil's interior capital, Brasilia.
 
Is Communism Dead? 'Baloney'
 "All this talk that Communism is dead is baloney," Mr. Niemeyer was quoted as saying today in O Globo newspaper. Last August, the architect hailed the coup attempt in the Soviet Union. Last week, he defended the execution of a saboteur in Cuba.
"Cuba is the last trenchline for democracy, and Fidel is loved by his people," said Mr. Niemeyer, referring to President Fidel Castro. Last month, after 46 years as a militant, Mr. Niemeyer reluctantly resigned from the Brazilian Communist Party and signed a membership card for the new group, called simply the Communist Party.
Foreseeing a split last fall, leaders of the Brazilian Communist Party formally filed for a 10-year patent on their name and on their symbols.
"It's like any other trademark," said Mr. Almeida, general secretary of what was registered today as the Popular Socialist Party. "When Esso started calling itself Exxon, it took preventive measures."

HEADLINE: Disney Earnings Up by 22%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif., Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company said today that its profits improved 22 percent in the most recent quarter, as several lucrative movies compensated for weak attendance at the company's theme parks.
Disney said earnings for the quarter that ended on Dec. 31 rose to $208.1 million, or $1.56 a share, from $170.4 million, or $1.28 a share, a year earlier. 
 Revenues rose 30 percent to $1.94 billion, from $1.49 billion.
It was the first time in more than a year that the entertainment company posted higher earnings for a quarter, as Disney theme parks have suffered the effects of the recession.
Disney also said its board raised the company's quarterly dividend 20 percent, to 21 cents a share from 17.5 cents.
The company credited the results for the latest quarter to a strong performance from its film business, led by the hit animated movie "Beauty and the Beast" and the videocassette release of the classic "Fantasia." "Beauty and the Beast" has grossed $99.2 million at box offices in the United States.
Before the earnings were announced, Disney stock closed today at $132.50, up 62.5 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

HEADLINE: In the Retail Desert, Fortunoff Is Planting a Mall on L.I.

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 27

 BODY:
Macy's, 47th Street Photo and other big-name retailers are in various stages of bankruptcy, but Alan Fortunoff is undaunted. He is putting his family's housewares and jewelry business on the line with plans to build a $194 million shopping center here.
Standing in the middle of 69 acres of barren blacktop in the heart of Nassau County, Mr. Fortunoff envisioned a mall that will employ more than 3,000 people and, by his estimate, pump $352 million annually into the depressed local economy. 
 "When we moved out here from Brooklyn in 1964, people told us we shouldn't go out to the suburbs." Mr. Fortunoff said. "We'd been operating in Brooklyn for 42 years, and a lot of our advice from well-wishers and bankers was, 'Stay put, don't risk it.' "
And now, 28 years later, he's doing it again. "And this time, financing is not so easy to find," he said. "Things have changed. But it's time again for renewal."
 
A Basement Headquarters
 Since the Fortunoffs opened their business in a small shop on Livonia Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn in 1922, it has grown into a chain with estimated 1991 sales of $360 million and stores in Wayne, Woodbridge and Paramus, N.J., one on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan and one here on the building site, where Mr. Fortunoff has his headquarters in a basement office filled with pictures of his family, including his six children and two grandchildren.
"As a private, family-owned business, we personally guarantee our debt," Mr. Fortunoff said. "And unlike some public corporations, we are not free to walk away from our debt." Mr. Fortunoff declined to say how much the family was borrowing for the project, but said he was dealing with a consortium of banks, including National Westminster, Citibank and First Fidelity.
Mr. Fortunoff said he was "well aware of the risks" he was taking with the expansion of his store here and construction of the mall, to be called the Long Island Galleria. The plan includes a 971,500-square-foot mall featuring a renovated Fortunoff, two other major retailers and approximately 100 specialty shops. In addition, there will be a 401,600-square-foot warehouse store for the Price Club, one of the fastest-growing retail chains in the nation. No other stores are as yet committed to the mall.
Kim Walin, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers, said that because Fortunoff as a private company is not required reveal its finances, there was no quick way to assess the risks of the mall venture. However, she said Fortunoff's situation was entirely different from that of Macy's, which filed for bankruptcy protection today because of debt problems.
"Macy's is a highly leveraged situation in which the critical problem was made worse by low cash flow," she said. "Fortunoff would not have the same kinds of problems."
Initially, Mr. Fortunoff planned an upscale mall with Neiman Marcus as an anchor. But the deal fell through in late 1990 after the recession took hold. "Here we were, disappointed, then Sol Price appeared in March of 1991," Mr. Fortunoff said. "And after I paid a visit to some of his Price Clubs and did some research, my mind opened up to a whole new range of possibilities."
Price Club limits its inventory to 3,000 items, all well-advertised national brands that are popular with consumers who buy in bulk at only a 10 percent markup after paying an annual $25 membership fee.
The change from upscale stores, like Neiman Marcus, to the Price Club, has pleased some area residents.
"If we're going to get more stores, we want to be sure they're ones we can use," said Shelley Lotenberg, who for the last 11 years has been an active leader of a civic association in Salisbury, a residential area east of Fortunoff. Until recently she was an opponent of the mall.
"We're now for it because Fortunoff has agreed to scale it down and implement many of our recommendations," she said.
More support for the project has come from a coalition of regional business and labor organizations, including 100 Black Men of Nassau-Suffolk, the Long Island Hispanic Chamber of Commerce and the Long Island Forum for Technology.
"It's the right project for the right time," said James D. Rice, president of 100 Black Men, who said the mall would provide badly needed jobs for the island's minority community.
Paul Amoruso, managing partner of Oxford and Simpson, a commercial real-estate adviser in Jericho, L.I., said, "The advent of the Price Club was a good match for Fortunoff." He said that the real risk for Mr. Fortunoff was to do nothing with his property.
Construction is to begin this spring, if the final zoning permits are granted by the Town of Hempstead, which is to hold a hearing on the project on Tuesday.
Mr. Fortunoff estimates the Galleria will employ 3,540 permanent, full-time employees with an annual payroll of $97 million. He expects the mall to directly generate $40.8 million in annual sales-tax revenue and at least $7 million in property-tax revenue. Nassau County alone would receive $25.5 million as its share of the sales-tax revenue.
It was a sharp decline in sales-tax revenues that forced the Nassau County government earlier this month to cut spending and schedule the layoff of more than 3,000 county employees.

HEADLINE: THE MACY'S BANKRUPTCY;
Reality Spoiled Merchant's Dream

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Edward S. Finkelstein tried everything to avoid bankruptcy -- catchy advertising, sales, cajoling suppliers, tapping his circle of wealthy friends to stump up more cash. But in the end, there was nothing the 66-year-old chairman of R. H. Macy & Company, who was once hailed as a marketing miracle worker, could do to keep his debt-laden empire afloat.
A man known as brilliant, thin-skinned and at home with hyperbole, Mr. Finkelstein (the last syllable is pronounced STEEN) repeatedly made optimistic predictions for Macy -- and repeatedly fell short of those goals. "Finkelstein really believed his own rhetoric," said one investment banker familiar with the company. 
 The recession and the slump in consumer spending clearly magnified the problems at Macy, but its cash squeeze was largely a creation of Mr. Finkelstein's vision and strategy.
 
A Burdensome Debt
 The $3.5 billion buyout that Mr. Finkelstein led in 1986 placed a considerable burden on the company. Yet, according to analysts, the real mistake was stretching to pay $1.1 billion to buy the I. Magnin and Bullock's department store chains in 1988. That deal increased the amount of cash Macy had to generate simply to make the interest payments on its debt, and it came just as the economy was softening.
"That was Macy's major strategic blunder," said Louis W. Stern, a professor of marketing at Northwestern University's graduate school of management. "It just killed them."
The 1988 purchase was championed by Mr. Finkelstein against the initial objections of at least one influential board member, Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of the Loews Corporation and of CBS Inc., one person familiar with the board room debate said. A corporate conservative of the old school, chary of taking on debt and pessimistic about the economic outlook, Mr. Tisch apparently thought that Mr. Finkelstein's expansion plans were overly ambitious.
When Mr. Finkelstein prevailed, the deal went through, and Macy, saddled with debt and high interest costs, was irrevocably headed for financial trouble.
 
A Rescue Falters
 Last week, Mr. Tisch emerged as Macy's last hope against bankruptcy with a $1 billion bid to purchase the company. But his offer required significant concessions from creditors, and when the Prudential Insurance Company of America declined to go along, the offer foundered.
The first real warning sign of trouble at Macy was its disappointing Christmas season of 1989. Mr. Finkelstein and his staff had misjudged the consumer mood, ordering far more goods than were purchased, leaving the stores with a surplus of costly inventory. The cost of maintaining the inventory reduced Macy's cash flow, the lifeblood a leveraged-buyout company needs to pay its banks.
It became a familiar pattern, retail analysts say. Mr. Finkelstein would declare a recovery in store traffic to be imminent, goods were ordered based on that optimism, and the sales season would be a disappointment.
To be sure, Mr. Finkelstein was not alone in underestimating the depth of the consumer recession, especially in the Northeast. "Macy's made some mistakes, but the retail industry has generally been very weak," said Meredith Adler, an analyst for the First Boston Corporation. "And nobody really predicted that it was going to be this bad."
 
Well-Trodden Path
 Macy is merely the latest big retailer to seek refuge from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy law, following a path forged by Federated, Allied, Ames and others. The financial rationale for the leveraged buyouts in retailing was that stores generate a great deal of cash to pay off loans. Besides, real estate values were racing ahead in the 1980's and retail chains owned valuable properties, which served as collateral for all the loans.
In addition, the payoff for the insiders looked handsome. For example, the lowest level of participation in the 1986 buyout for the 300-strong Macy management team was $75,000. The projected payback for a $75,000 investment, when Macy was expected to be sold to the public sometime in the 1990's, was $1.5 million -- a twentyfold return. Mr. Finkelstein, who invested $4.4 million, would have received $88 million if that calculation proved accurate.
Instead, analysts say, the initial investors are likely to get less than a dime for each dollar they put up.
Chapter 11 bankruptcy tends to favor existing management, giving them court protection from creditors while they try to reorganize the company. So Mr. Finkelstein, who was paid $1.1 million in salary and other cash compensation last year, should remain at the helm for the foreseeable future. One son, Daniel, runs Macy's California stores; another son, Mitchell, runs the company's Hong Kong buying office.
 
Praise From Analyst
 Mr. Finkelstein may have failed to sustain the debt-financed corporate giant he built, but he still remains highly respected as a retailer. "He's a great merchant," said Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant and former Macy's manager.
Since he joined Macy in 1948, after earning an M.B.A. from Harvard, Mr. Finkelstein has shown a flair for marketing. In the early 1970's, he overhauled the merchandising and image of Macy's California, to have the chain cater to a more affluent and stylish clientele. One innovation was establishing the basement of Macy's San Francisco store as a cheery mart filled with the latest in housewares and renamed the Cellar.
Later, he was promoted back to New York and engineered an even more impressive overhaul of Macy's once-drab flagship store on 34th Street.
"If he had stuck with what he knows best -- style-picking -- he would go down as one of the great retailers of our time instead of taking Macy's into bankruptcy court," said Alan Millstein, editor of Fashion Network Report, a retail newsletter.

HEADLINE: New York City Slips in Survey on Why Businesses Leave

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
On the two issues that most affect business decisions to relocate, New York City's performance is significantly worse than it was five years ago, a survey of city business leaders has found.
When asked to rate 15 considerations that might affect a company's location, 74.9 percent of those interviewed cited the overall cost of conducting business and 60.6 percent cited citywide security as extremely important. Of those choosing these two issues, more than 80 percent said they thought New York was worse off now than it was five years ago. 
 The survey, whose results were released on Sunday, was done by Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, for the New York City Partnership, a trade group that represents large companies.
The accounting firm interviewed 299 top executives drawn randomly and in equal proportions from Dun & Bradstreet's list of small, medium and large companies based in the city in six industries: financial services, manufacturing, business services, health care, tourism and media.
 
An Emerging Concern
 Ronald K. Shelp, president of the Partnership, said public security has only recently emerged as such a prime area of concern. In a more limited survey of his organization's members in 1987-1988, the issue did not rank as one of the top issues.
Only two other factors in the latest survey were considered extremely important -- proximity to markets and clients, and accessibility of land, air and water transportation -- and on those issues New York scored fairly well compared with five years ago. Despite all the criticisms of the city's fiscal problems by the business community, only 38 percent of those surveyed cited that issue as extremely important in making decisions about where to locate their operations.
The executives interviewed found many good things to say about a New York City location. Almost 70 percent, for instance, said they thought the quality of the upper-level work force was the same as or better than competing cities. About 60 percent said the same of midlevel employees, compared with 43 percent who felt that way about entry-level workers.
Of those who said telecommunications was extremely important to their companies, 93 percent said New York had either stayed the same or improved in the five years.
As for what the government could do to help keep corporate operations in the city, actions considered extremely important were reducing business taxes, improving citywide security, cutting red tape and improving public education.
