HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Commercials Offer a Fairly Ho-hum Bowl

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Super Bowl XXVI may have turned out super for the Washington Redskins, but as for the commercials, it was a Satisfactory Bowl, maybe merely an Adequate Bowl, at best.
Compared with some Super Sundays of yore, the audacious, attention-at-any-cost creativity seemed noticeably absent from the 27 or so minutes of extravagantly expensive spots that cost a record $850,000 for each 30 seconds. 
 Instead of producing a blockbuster like Apple Computer's anti-Orwellian "1984," Chiat/Day/Mojo Inc. delivered a disappointing series of spots for Reebok International Ltd. The five commercials teased viewers with the prospect of a duel between two American decathletes, only to disclose later that the contest must await the Summer Olympics.
Instead of creating a captivating catch phrase like "You got the right one baby, uh-huh," which BBDO Worldwide unveiled for Diet Pepsi during last year's Super Bowl, the agency brought forth the somewhat dated clunker "Gotta have it," for Pepsi-Cola, recalling the instant gratification of the 1980's.
Then there was the parade of advertisers like Advil, Gillette, Kellogg, Sudafed and U S Sprint which presented their everyday fare.
"It was like only a few people dressed up for the prom," said Nina DiSesa, executive vice president and executive creative director at J. Walter Thompson Chicago, "and the rest came in their casual clothes."
Ms. DiSesa was one of four advertising executives around the country who were asked to critique the commercials that almost two dozen advertisers bought during CBS's telecast of the game. In their comments yesterday, they singled out some commercials for harsh castigation or effusive praise. And some, they noted, like Pepsi's and McDonald's changing slogans, made marketing news. But their overall response echoed Peggy Lee: "Is that all there is?"
Relative to past Super Sundays, "it was kind of subdued," said Anita K. Hersh, president and chief operating officer of Lister Butler Inc., a corporate identity and image consulting company in New York. "Except for a few highlights, it was recession advertising -- no luxury, no glitz."
Asked about the Reebok spots, Jeff Atlas, chairman of Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre in San Francisco, replied, "I guess I'll see them at the Olympics, but I don't want to."
The executives also disapproved of a spot from Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Pacific for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A., celebrating the workers at the company's Georgetown, Ky., plant, who build the Toyota Camry.
While the spot was timely in the wake of strained American-Japanese relations, "it's already old news," said Joey Reiman, chairman and chief executive of Babbit & Reiman Advertising Inc. in Atlanta, because "people are going to buy quality," regardless of where a car is made. (As part of its continuing "Putting quality on the road" campaign, by McCann-Erickson, General Motors ran three spots telling consumers that G.M. had "heard your demands" for quality.)
The ad critics were also lukewarm about three commercials, from Leo Burnett U.S.A., for the Seven-Up Company, which paired the red Spot character in recent campaigns for 7Up and Diet 7Up with the brands' famous "uncola" slogan.
"Three un-commercials," Mr. Reiman said. "They talked about Diet Pepsi and Diet Coke more than about Diet 7Up, so they didn't sell the product."
Still, Ms. DiSesa put it, "The worst commercial was better than the halftime show." In fact, the halftime entertainment was such a bore -- a salute to snow -- that CBS pulled national ads from the show fearing, correctly as it turned out, that viewers were switching to a stunt on the Fox network.
Of the ad highlights, one was a 60-second Nike commercial by Wieden & Kennedy Inc., called "Hare Jordan/ Air Jordan," that teamed an animated Bugs Bunny with a live Michael Jordan in a wacky basketball game against four miscreants.
"I hate saying, 'They do it again,' but they did," Mr. Atlas said, referring to the Nike slogan, "Just do it." The spot finished first in USA Today's fourth annual Ad Meter survey, in which 60 residents of the Detroit area were asked to rate the ads they liked and disliked.
There was also the reappearance of an old favorite: the arty, yet hard-selling, Master Lock commercial. For the third consecutive year, Cramer-Krasselt ran a 30-second spot in which opera music was played over shots of thieves who tried, and failed, to destroy Master Lock locks.
And, blessedly, for the first time since Super Bowl XXIII in 1989, viewers were spared the Bud Bowl, a goofy scrimmage between tiny animated bottles of Budweiser and Bud Light beers.
Though a Bud Bowl IV score was announced -- for the record, Budweiser beat Bud Light, 27-24 -- two spots by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles ignored the action in favor of showing a mishap-plagued consumer searching for a Bud Bowl sweepstakes ticket.
The bottles might not be gone for good, though. Tom Sharbaugh, vice president of Budweiser brands at Anheuser-Busch Inc., said yesterday that, yes, Bud Bowl would make a comeback next January.
Make-believe football games seemed much on the mind of Anheuser's executives. In another spot for Budweiser, $1.8 million was spent on animating pieces of paper to a compelling illusion of football players of the past and present playing a lightning-fast game atop a bar.
The advertising executives enjoyed two commercials by Burnett for the McDonald's Corporation, which replaced the fast-food chain's two most recent slogans, "McDonald's today" and "Food, folks & fun," with a plain-talking theme: "What you want is what you get."
The McDonald's spots "focused on basic values and touched an emotional chord," Ms. Hersh said. Ms. DiSesa echoed her approval: "I know I was being manipulated, but sometimes, if you're manipulated well, you don't mind."
It appeared that CBS was wise to manipulate the ad lineup during halftime. Overnight ratings from A. C. Nielsen showed that the Fox stunt, a live episode of its "In Living Color" series, sponsored by Frito-Lay's Doritos tortilla chips, attracted a strong 18.3 rating and a 27 share, compared with a 33.2 rating and 49 share for the halftime show. (The game itself in the overnight ratings drew a 40.4 rating and a 60 share.)
Each rating point represented 431,151 households in 25 markets; the share is the percentage of homes with televisions tuned in to the program.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Steady in a Light Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in slow trading yesterday, as credit market participants marked time before a number of important events are played out over the next week to 10 days.
Specifically, traders pointed to this evening's State of the Union Message, the confirmation hearings for the Federal Reserve chairnan, Alan Greenspan, on Wednesday -- a day when preliminary estimates of fourth-quarter economic growth are also expected -- and next week's announcement from the Treasury about the size and confirguation of its quarterly refunding auctions. 
 "All of these topics are prompting lots of speculation," said a government securities trader, who insisted on anonymity. "But it is not the kind of speculation people are willing to act on. It is the kind that puts people on the sidelines."
 
Few Surprises Expected
 Analysts and traders said that despite the nervousness about the sort of fiscal policy package that ultimately might emerge from Washington, President Bush's speech, the official kickoff of budget negotiations, was not likely to include many surprises.
"I don't think Bush's speech should evoke dramatic reactions, because the important parts have already been leaked to the press," said Samuel D. Kahan, the chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago. "If he comes across appearing to be strong, then one can characterize the address as being successful."
Estimates of how the economy performed in the fourth quarter vary widely, but most Wall Street analysts project that the gross domestic product probably expanded slightly in the last three months of the year.
"It will be interesting to see what happens with the fiscal policy debate after this number prints," said Michael J. Moran, the chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc., "because I think most people in Congress expect the number to be negative."
Mr. Moran said he expected the report to show that the economy expanded by eight-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter.
 
8% Bonds at 7.72%
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late in the day at a price of 103 1/4, down by an eighth of a point, to yield 7.72 percent, compared with 7.70 percent late on Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 3/4 late yesterday, down by 3/32 , to yield 7.24 percent. The 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 977/32 , up by 1/32 , to yield 6.88 percent. And the 4 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9914/32 , down by 2/32 , to yield 5.17 percent.
Rates on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills rose slightly at the weekly auction.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.84 percent, up from an average rate of 3.78 percent a week ago.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 3.93 percent, compared with an average rate of 3.84 percent at last week's auction.
 
Pfizer Note Sale
 Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a $250 million offering of five-year notes from Pfizer Inc.
The 6.50 percent securities were priced at $99.37, to yield 6.65 percent, 25 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 1/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
Lazard Freres & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated AAA by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
A bid from an investor group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company won a $250 million offering of first and refunding mortgage bonds issued by the Philadelphia Electric Company.
The securities, which mature in 1999, were reoffered with a 7.50 percent coupon at a price of $99.50, to yield 7.593 percnet, or 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
 
Citicorp Pricing Due
 The corporate market was also talking about an offering of $150 million in 10-year securities from Citicorp, which is expected to be priced today.
Among commercial banks, Citicorp is the largest issuer of corporate debt. But given its recent problems, the company has been absent from the market for some time.

HEADLINE: Kia, of Korea, Plans to Sell Vehicles in U.S

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Kia Motors Corporation of South Korea said today that it would develop a dealer network in the United States to start selling subcompact cars and small sport-utility vehicles in 1993.
Kia, which is South Korea's No. 2 auto maker, after Hyundai, makes the Festiva subcompact distributed by Ford in the United States. Kia also announced that W. Gregory Warner, a former Hyundai Motor America executive, would oversee the North American project as chief operating officer. Mr. Warner, who is 48 years old, has been a consultant to Kia since November.
 
Quality Called Imperative
 Kia faces many challenges in the American market as it takes aim at sedan buyers whose choices include the acclaimed Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla models. Hyundai entered the American market in the late 1980's with a very strong start, but sales suffered after quality problems arose. In contrast, the Festiva made by Kia received a high reliability rating in the Consumer Reports 1991 car guide. 
 Mr. Warner said Kia would succeed with value and contemporary styling. He declined to specify prices.
Thomas Dukes, an auto industry analyst with J. D. Power & Associates, said Kia could not afford any missteps on quality, given Hyundai's past problems. "They'll need some serious customer satisfaction right out of the chute," he said.
Kia displayed its two American-bound models at the Tokyo Auto Show last fall. The designs of the sedan and sport-utility vehicle are more rounded and distinctive than competing models, and the vehicles do not resemble the Festiva. The sport-utility's powerplant will be unusual for its class: a 2-liter, 16-valve engine with dual overhead camshafts.
Kia will offer the sedan in 1993 and the sport-utility in 1994, starting on the East and West Coasts. Kia is also considering a convertible version of the sedan. Mr. Warner declined to disclose Kia's sales projections, saying only that it planned to sell 10,000 cars in the final six months of 1993.
 
 
Production Will Double
 In South Korea, Kia will double its current production capacity to roughly a million vehicles by 1995, and some analysts have said the move into the United States is necessary to support that expansion.
Kia has eight staff members at its North American office in Irvine, Calif. By the end of the year, the staff will grow to 130, Mr. Warner said.
Mr. Warner started his auto industry career at Ford as a marketing analyst. He joined Toyota in 1971 as product planning manager and handled several assignments before he moved to Hyundai in 1985. At Hyundai, which he left in 1990, he was executive vice president and chief operating officer.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices of Soybeans in Skid; Energy Products Higher

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Soybean futures skidded today on news of much-needed rain over Brazil's soybean fields, while strong demand and possible OPEC production cuts lifted energy prices.
 Weekend rains in Brazil, a formidable competitor in soybean production, are expected to enhance the developing Brazilian crop and weighed on futures in the United States. 
 "Until we see that pattern change, it will be hard to get people excited about soybeans," a floor broker said.
 Brisk farmer-to-elevator selling through the Midwest late Friday and over the weekend further depressed soybean values.
 March soybeans on the Chicago Board of Trade tumbled 4.75 cents, to $5.76 3/4 a bushel, by the closing bell.
 
Corn Sales Seen
 News early in the session that Russia and the other Commonwealth of Independent States could buy more United States corn this week on the heels of last week's purchase buoyed Chicago corn prices early. However, farmers brought an ample supply of corn to market Friday and over the weekend, which undermined futures prices today.
 March corn fell 1.75 cents, to $2.62 a bushel, by the close.
 Wheat futures rallied early on news of a sale to the commonwealth, but relinquished early gains to finish mixed.
 March, July, September and December reached contract highs in the early going when local short-covering lifted prices. The jump touched off buy orders, sending wheat for March delivery to its lifetime high of $4.42 3/4 a bushel before closing 2 cents higher at $4.39 1/4 a bushel.
 In New York, strong demand for heating oil and reduced production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries quietly buoyed energy futures.
 Prices rose early on a Middle East Economic Survey report that said voluntary cuts by OPEC members may point to more serious action to balance supply and demand at the Feb. 12 meeting.
 "Strength in heating oil is picking up the market, which is otherwise pretty quiet," said a Refco broker, Victor Yu.
 March crude oil gained 36 cents, to $19.36 a barrel, at the New York Mercantile Exchange. February heating oil climbed 0.69 cent, to 55.39 cents a gallon, and February gasoline rose 1.16 cents, to 54.85 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Machine-Tool Orders at a 4-Year Low in '91

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools tumbled to a four-year low last year as depressed automobile sales battered the industry, a trade group said in a report released yesterday.
But the Association for Manufacturing Technology said machine-tool orders surged in December, and analysts predicted that the manufacturing sector would rebound in 1992. 
 In its report, the trade group, based in McLean, Va., said machine-tool orders for 1991 totaled $2.64 billion, down by 11 percent from 1990 and the lowest total since $2.12 billion in 1987.
 
December Orders Up 46%
 But in December, new orders for machine tools rose to $336.85 million, a 46 percent increase from the previous month and up by 13.9 percent from $295.8 million in December 1990.
"We're closing out 1991 on a positive note," said Albert Moore, the organization's president.
Machine tools are used to cut and form parts for automobiles, airplanes and other durable goods, products expected to last at least three years. Although a relatively small industry, its performance is watched by economists as a guide to the general health of manufacturing.
Tool companies rely on the auto industry for 30 percent to 40 percent of their business. The squeeze in the automobile market, which has led car makers to cut back on production, has taken its toll on tool orders.
After a dismal 1991, analysts expect machine-tool orders to rise 8 percent to 30 percent this year.
"I think they're going to be right because when you're down as low as $2.6 billion, there's not much room to go down further," an industry spokesman said yesterday.
Even a 30 percent increase in orders would still leave the industry below 1990 levels, he noted.
 
Shipments Down 19%
 Shipments of machine tools, reflecting the lower orders, fell by 19 percent, to $2.77 billion last year, the lowest since shipments of $2.40 billion in 1988.
But December shipments totaled $282.3 million, up by 22.6 percent from a month earlier, but off by 19.5 percent from $350.5 million in December 1990, the association said.
Orders for export rose by 19.8 percent, to $58.10 million in December, from $48.5 million in November and were up by 36.9 percent from $42.45 million in December 1990.
Export shipments grew by 33.3 percent, to $46.2 million in December from $34.6 million in November, but the figure still represented a decline of 27.1 percent from $63.3 million in December 1990.
The group said the December order backlog was $1.43 billion, up from November's $1.38 billion. The December 1990 backlog was $1.47 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Sharp Gains; Group of 7 Meeting Is Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply yesterday against other leading currencies after a meeting of the major industrial nations over the weekend failed to indicate a preference on exchange rates.
Finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations met near New York City but failed to say in their closing communique what moves they would like exchange rates to take. 
 Some traders had expected the meeting would seek to promote a stronger yen to help reduce Japan's bulging trade surplus and to help the United States' economic recovery.
"There was zero output from the meeting" on exchange rates, Jerry Egan, chief currency dealer at Bank of Boston in Boston, said, "and that removed one bit of tarnish against the dollar."
He said it now appeared the market would try to test how high the dollar would be allowed to go against the yen.
"There will be some tentative testing for the top to see where the tolerance of the central banks will be," he said.
The dollar finished at 125.23 yen in New York, up from 123.53 yen late Friday. It had been quoted earlier in London at 125.35 yen. It finished in Tokyo at 124.57 yen, the same as late Friday.
Mr. Egan said there were also some sharp moves by the dollar against the German mark, which he attributed mainly to traders' jockeying to establish positions in advance of President Bush's delivery of his State of the Union Message tonight.
The dollar finished at 1.6105 German marks in New York, up from 1.5950 late Friday.
The dollar was also strong against the British pound. The pound fell to $1.7825 in New York, from $1.7955 late Friday. In London, the pound fell to $1.7770, from $1.8070 late Friday.
Dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.4300 Swiss francs, up from 1.4165; 5.4840 French francs, up from 5.4375; 1,2009.25 Italian lire, up from 1.200.50, and 1.17325 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16965.
In the precious metals market, gold for current delivery rose 40 cents an ounce, to $354.80, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid of $354.80 an ounce, up 30 cents from Friday's late bid.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Schooling Engineers in Environment

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
TOMORROW'S engineers -- and today's as well -- must be grounded in environmental science, says Dr. George S. Ansell, president of the Colorado School of Mines, in Golden, Colo. Two reasons he cited were the growing contamination of the environment and the need for a broader education to assure jobs.
"Our graduates have been getting jobs and with little trouble," he said in an interview last week. He contrasted that to the situation at many universities whose engineering graduates have difficulty finding jobs in the current market. He thinks that a requirement since 1984 that every student at the School of Mines take at least one course in environmental science is a helpful start. 
 Some of the engineers, physicists, computer scientists or geologists who receive their bachelor of science degrees at the school do more than take one course in the field. About 20 percent take a minor in environmental science, which requires about 18 hours of credits. In fact, the environmental science minor has become the school's most popular elective minor, Dr. Ansell said.
The department of environmental science was decreed by the trustees of the school, many of them active in the mining and other industrial areas, in 1981. That was three years before Dr. Ansell, a former professor and dean of the engineering school at Rennselaer Polytechnic Institute, became president.
By 1984, the department of environmental science, one of the first in the nation, had one or two professors. Today it has 10 full-time professors and a half-dozen adjunct professors. The adjunct professors are typically nonacademics who work in the environmental field or professors who specialize in other fields at the school, like hydrology.
The Colorado School of Mines, one of the oldest engineering schools in the country, has 2,700 students, of which a third are working for graduate degrees. Currently 168 students are enrolled in the master's program in the environmental science department. It has become the school's largest graduate program.
Dr. Ansell cited a recent study by the University of California at Los Angeles that found 83 percent of college freshmen nationwide wanted to make a positive contribution to the environment and 21 percent wanted to work on environmental issues.
Environmental science is such a complex area that the school has come up with the following definition to help students understand the field: "The study of how physical, chemical and biological processes cause the movement and transformation of substances in natural systems and how these processes can be controlled to achieve desired effects within a structure of economic, legal and political constraints."
The political aspects have become especially significant, Dr. Ansell noted, because of current issues like exploration for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and possible revision of the Mining Law of 1872.
One interesting dispute involves the so-called brown cloud over Denver, which Dr. Ansell described as the product of "winter thermal invasions trapping airborne particulates in the Denver Basin."
Some groups blamed the local utility's coal-fired power plants and demanded that coal be replaced with natural gas. But the utility, a coal company and coal miners appealed to the state to intervene, and a study determined that most of the problem was caused by internal combustion engines.
With problems like these facing engineers, the school, one of the few master's programs in environmental science, offers two specialties. Dr. Ansell described one as "an environmental master of business administration degree" with a strong technical base. Students who select this track tend to become project managers in environment management, working for corporations or in the public sector.
The second track produces what Dr. Ansell calls environmental technologists who might focus on and monitor the movement of contaminants or waste management.
All the graduate students take a core program of 18 hours in courses like the natural environment, environmental law, environmental pollution, treatment of water and wastes and experimental design and data analysis.

HEADLINE: Home-Resale Rate Rises

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The rate of sales of existing homes rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in December, a real estate trade group said today. It was the third gain in a row, and analysts called it a further confirmation of a modest housing revival.
Still, sales of previously owned homes fell to a six-year low in 1991, and most economists expect this year's rebound to be restrained. 
 "There's certainly no expectation that there is going to be a real surge," said Daryl Delano of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass.
But any increase in sales would be welcome after the decline of three-tenths of 1 percent last year, when sales dropped to 3.287 million units, according to figures compiled by the National Association of Realtors. That was the smallest total since 3.214 million units were sold in 1985.
Regionally, sales were mixed in December and for the year. They were up in the Northeast and the West at the end of the year, but down in the South and the Midwest. The Northeast and the Midwest posted annual gains, while the South and the West recorded losses.
Existing-home sales were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.34 million units in December, the association said. They had jumped 4.7 percent in November and 1.3 percent in October.
Sales jumped 10 percent in December in the Northeast, to 550,000 units at an annual rate, and 1.3 percent, to 529,000 units, for the year.
In the West, sales also rose, up 3.8 percent, to a 550,000-unit rate, but were five-tenths of 1 percent below the 554,000 units sold a year earlier.
Sales in the Midwest fell 2.2 percent in December to a rate of 920,000 units. For 1991, however, they rose 1.1 percent, to 902,000 units.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Moonlighting In Moscow

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
A CARDIOLOGIST sees private patients to supplement his salary from a full-time hospital job, which pays him only 2,000 rubles a month, or $10. An office worker, who could afford to buy a small car two years ago, now cruises the streets in it, picking up taxi fares -- a growing freelance activity. And a woman sells plastic bags for 3 rubles apiece to shoppers leaving a high-priced farmer's market with fresh food in their arms. She had purchased the bags for less than half that price by standing in line at a state store.
Everywhere in the commonwealth, people are hustling for extra income to survive. "Poverty is the normal state of living in our country today," said Lev Timoteyev, an economist and writer. But "poverty" has a different, broader meaning here than in the United States. The word in America suggests slum-living, joblessness, school dropouts and a high crime rate. Here, poverty is a result of prices that have tripled or more for everyone, while wages have only doubled at best. It is as if an American family earning $40,000 suddenly had that reduced to $30,000 -- or maybe $25,000. 
 While government statistics in the United States offer authoritative reports on the relationship of prices to income, here such data are lacking and the subject of much guesswork. The most informed estimates probably come from Goskomstat, the old Soviet statistics agency that is now in the hands of the Russian Federation but still collecting data from all the republics.
Ilena Fravola, a cost-of-living expert at Gaskomstat, says the average monthly outlay for food and other essentials has risen to roughly 1,300 rubles for an individual, with people in the countryside getting by on as little as 400 to 500 rubles and Moscovites averaging 1,800 rubles. Before price ceilings were lifted on Jan. 2, living costs across the commonwealth averaged 340 rubles.
On the income side, the average jobholder now earns 800 to 1,000 rubles a month for a 40-hour week, Gaskomstat estimates. Those sums include not only wages and bonuses but also transfer payments, such as free meals on the job and state subsidies for children and maternity leave. The total is up from 300 to 400 rubles last fall.
Clearly, the average family budget is way out of balance, even allowing for the extended family tradition in which the elderly live with their children and grandchildren, and the earnings of every working family member are pooled, including the pensioner's meager 342 rubles a month.
The shortfall in family incomes raises two questions. First, why has the public accepted this plunge into poverty without widespread protests? Russians themselves suggest that they have not yet felt the consequences of their sudden setback, in part because families stockpiled food and other goods in anticipation of the upsurge in prices, and these dwindling stores still cushion their lives.
The second question is, what people can do to increase their incomes and save themselves from prolonged poverty. Is everyone -- like the cardiologist, the freelance taxi driver, the woman selling shopping bags or the numerous hucksters in Moscow's subway stations -- becoming sidelines entrepreneurs? These off-the-book activities are on the rise, but they are not the major source of extra income. In a land of jobholders, taking a second job is more common than trying to strike out on one's own.
Some 2.5 million people moonlighted in 1990, averaging 180 rubles a month in additional earnings, mostly from second jobs in the expanding private sector, says Viktor Barbashov, deputy director of Gaskomstat's division of labor statistics. And he says these numbers probably increased significantly in 1991.
Another popular activity is dubbed small enterprise. "A large organization surrounds itself with small, private companies that give people a chance to make money," said Abel G. Aganbegyan, director of the Academy of the National Economy in Russia. Mr. Aganbegyan, for example, permitted an entrepreneurial colleague to convert the academy's printing operation last year into a private publishing company, one that now subcontracts its services to the academy.
With the department's 20 employees as partners, the new company leased the academy's offset press, computers and other machinery. The lease payments have counted toward purchase of the equipment. And the new publishing house's personnel, working more efficiently than in the past, receive higher salaries from their enterprise than the state-financed academy would have been allowed to pay them, Mr. Aganbegyan said.
Poverty apparently is forcing many people not into rebellion, but into trying to live by their wits and by extra work. Or, as Aleksei E. Titkov, chairman of the Center for Humanitarian Studies, put it: "We used to talk about politics and social issues. Now we talk all the time about how to do business and make money."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Science Desk

LENGTH: 1724 words

HEADLINE: Shamans and Scientists Seek Cures in Plants

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
FOR ages, traditional remedies derived from plants were the primary form of medical care for the world's people, and for three-quarters of the global population they still are.
But in the United States, medical researchers have generally been lukewarm at best about investigating the undeniable curative properties of plants. This is not just a prejudice in favor of modern medicine; isolating specific plant compounds can be a difficult technical task. 
 That attitude is now changing. The chemical interaction of plant and animal compounds is better understood, robots are now available that can screen plant samples around the clock, and researchers are turning increasingly to plants in their search for cures to the worst maladies of our time, including AIDS, cancer and heart disease. The problem now is that the plants are disappearing, victims of tropical deforestation, faster than they can be investigated for their medical value.
Alarmed at the prospect, an improbable alliance has come riding to the rescue. It is made up of conservationists, pharmaceutical companies, academic scientists, traditional healers and the governments and entrepreneurs of developing countries. Although often suspicious of each other in the past, they are joining forces in the belief that tropical forests are vital to all their long-term interests and are worth more if preserved as economic assets than cut down for farmland.
The spearhead of this crusade is a pair of ingenious efforts to exploit the forests on behalf of medicine. The plans were described at a symposium last week at Rockefeller University in Manhattan. The gathering was organized jointly by the Rain Forest Alliance, a nonprofit conservation organization, and the New York Botanical Garden's Institute of Economic Botany.
In one project, a Costa Rican research institute is prospecting for promising plants, microorganisms and insects to be screened for medical use by Merck & Company, the world's largest drug company. Merck, in turn, is supporting the prospecting effort financially and will share any resulting profits with Costa Rica.
The Costa Rican Government, which has set aside 25 percent of its land as forest preserves, will use the royalties and some of the initial payments to support its conservation efforts.
In the second enterprise, a small California company called Shaman Pharmaceuticals is tapping the expertise of traditional healers -- shamans, or medicine men -- in various parts of the tropics. Shaman, less than two years old, says it already appears to have made its first big "hit."
The company has isolated a compound from a medicinal plant in South America that it says is active against the influenza and herpes viruses. Shaman has filed a patent, and the drug is well into clinical trials. If it or other drugs ultimately generate profits, the company intends to promote conservation of the forests by channeling some of its profits back to the localities whose medicine men provided the key plants.
The theory behind both ventures is that everybody wins: the world gets new drugs, the pharmaceutical companies earn profits, and people in the tropics are justly compensated for their "intellectual property" and their collection efforts. In this way, the local people are encouraged to protect the source of the compensation and the forests are preserved, and thus able to fulfill vital ecological and environmental functions like stabilizing the planet's climate.
"It's out of the realm of an academic exercise now," Dr. Michael Balick, director of the Institute of Economic Botany, said of the concept. "You've got people whose lives depend on using the rain forest, and whose cultural traditions depend on having it available, and people whose businesses depend on new chemicals all sitting down to discuss these issues."
Chemical prospecting and intellectual property rights "are terms I'd never heard of," Richard Deertrack, tribal administrator in the Office of the War Chief at Taos Pueblo, N.M., and an herbalist who collects medicinal plants, told conferees as last week's meeting was ending. But by then, although he expressed concern that the rights and sensitivities of indigenous peoples be respected, he had heard enough to commend Merck and Shaman Pharmaceuticals.
The discovery in the 1930's of the curare plant, which provides a muscle relaxant, stimulated drug researchers' interest in plants for a time, as did the discovery in the 1960's that the rosy periwinkle could be used to treat childhood leukemia and Hodgkin's disease.
But more recently, although the National Institutes of Health was screening plants for medical use, the prevailing attitude in commercial laboratories was that "plant research was old-fashioned or even flaky," Christina Findeisen, a management consultant to the pharmaceutical industry, said at the meeting.
With increasing knowledge about the chemical mechanisms through which plant compounds act on disease, and especially with the advent of rapid, high-capacity, automated screening equipment, interest has revived and many drug companies are gearing up for plant research. Some have contracted with academic botanical gardens to obtain plant samples.
 
Discovery in India
 Reports by researchers at the symposium emphasized the potential of drugs derived from plants. In India, researchers have derived a compound from the native guggal tree that shows great promise in lowering levels of cholesterol and other harmful blood fats without side effects. Early in their research, they drew on a 2,500-year-old Sanskrit medical text. SmithKline Beecham Pharmaceuticals has isolated a drug from a tree found in China and India that shows promise in attacking lung and ovarian cancers.
Rather than hoping to find a fully minted, fully effective and complete "blockbuster" drug as a result of plant studies, Ms. Findeisen said, researchers have scaled down their expectations and are instead hoping to find compounds that, while not necessarily fully effective by themselves, provide the basis for a more rapid synthesis of a workable drug. In search of these compounds to help counter major diseases of this age, "we look anywhere -- absolutely anywhere," said Dr. Lynn Caporale, Merck's director of scientific evaluation.
But half or more of the world's plant species are in the tropical forests, and those forests are being lost to deforestation at a rate of nearly 55,000 square miles a year, an area about the size of Florida, experts on biological diversity say. The forests are often cut and burned to create agricultural fields, which are abandoned as their soils are depleted. The deforestation is causing widespread extinction of plants and other organisms, most scientists who study the problem say.
Just the possibility of extinction can inhibit drug companies in prospecting for useful plants, since discovery can take years and disappearance of the resource cannot be risked. "The concept of rain-forest destruction actually reduces our incentive to go and screen plants," Dr. Steven Brewer, a chemist with the Monsanto Company, told the conference.
 
An Economic Incentive
 The solution, according to the emerging new concept of tropical forest conservation, is to emphasize the value of the forest as a long-term, sustainable economic resource, and to give local people an economic stake in its preservation.
Dr. Balick, working in Belize with "bush masters," or native professionals who collect the plants that shamans use in their ministrations, has studied the plants' economic value. The plants are sold in urban markets as part of the primary health-care system.
In a study to be published soon, he found that a bush master earns 2 to 10 times the income of a farmer, suggesting that plant-gathering is an attractive alternative to farming and to the deforestation that often goes along with it.
In Costa Rica, the National Institute of Biodiversity, a nonprofit research organization established by the Government, is engaging local people familiar with the forests and paying them to be "para-taxonomists." Their function is to learn the forests and the plants and provide information on which the institute will base its collection of plant samples for Merck researchers, said Dr. Ana Sittenfield, the institute's coordinator of research and development.
Under the institute's two-year agreement with Merck, which both parties expect to be renewed, the institute will supply a limited number of plant samples to be screened for medical use. In return, Merck will pay the institute $1 million to support the sampling, train workers and help Costa Rica support its forest conservation efforts. Merck will also pay royalties to the institute on any drug products discovered as a result of the collaboration.
"The real key is that the benefits are going to be returned to conservation," said Dr. Walter Reid of the World Resources Institute, an expert on forests and biological diversity. "That's what's unique."
Shaman Pharmaceuticals' venture is based on the proposition that working with traditional medicine men, rather than screening plants randomly for useful drugs, can speed the process of discovery.
"We are driven exclusively by ethnobotany," which is the study of how traditional people use plants, said Lisa Conte, the company's president.
 
Value of Concept
 She said the ethnobotany strategy enabled the company in only 18 months to isolate from a medicinal plant in South America the compound that it says is active against a number of viruses, including those of the flu and herpes.
Early clinical trials have been encouraging, she said, and second-stage trials are about to begin. Some of whatever profits the company eventually makes will be channeled back to the tropical regions in an attempt to foster conservation. The money is to flow through a nonprofit foundation, the Healing Forest Conservancy, set up by the company when it was organized.
Much depends on whether, in fact, any of this leads in a reasonable time to a real, live treatment for an important ailment.
"I can't tell you how I look forward to the first positive hit," said Dr. Caporale of Merck.
"Once we have that first successful compound," Dr. Balick said of the over-all conservation concept, "this whole thing will fall into place."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Don Antonio Cook, a Mayan herb gatherer, preparing a medicinal herb for a traditional therapist in San Antonio, in western Belize. (Michael J. Balik/New York Botanical Garden) (pg. C1)
 
Chart: "Finding Drugs in the Rain Forest"
 Scientists with diverse roles might take these steps in seeking out plants used as medicines, analyzing medicinal components and finally manufacturing or synthesizing drugs based on them:

STAGE 1: ESTABLISHING FOLK HISTORY
 The ethnobotanist goes where the plants grow and interviews a shaman, or traditional healer, about their use. Specimens are collected and other shamans confirm the information.

STAGE 2: ESTABLISHING TENTATIVE IDENTIFICATION
 The ethnobotanist and the field botanist make a very careful collection of the plants, identifying collection site, presumed genus and species, date of collection, etc. The expertise of the field botanist is needed to distinguish species since closely related species can appear to be identical to the untrained eye.

STAGE 3: BLIND SCREENING FOR ACTIVITY
 Consulting with the field botanist, the pharmacologist dries the plant the same way the shaman does. The aim is to detect and define the effects produced by the plant and the toxic potential of the drug; a blind animal testing program is set up.

STAGE 4: ABSOLUTE PLANT IDENTIFICATION
 The taxonomist independently confirms the plant's identity so more authentic plant material can be collected by the field botanist.

STAGE 5: DISCOVERING THE ACTIVE INGREDIENT
 The chemist isolates and extracts the active ingredient, figures out the potency, molecular weight, etc., and consults with the pharmacologist so actions of the drug can be understood.

STAGE 6: CLASSIC PHARMACOLOGICAL EVALUATION
 Chemists and pharmacologists find out if the drug has a unique activity.

STAGE 7: CLASSIC STRUCTURE DETERMINATION
 Chemists find out if the drug's molecule is unique and can be synthesized.

STAGE 8: THE ATTEMPT TO SECURE A PATENT
 Chemists and pharmacologists prepare a patent application. (Adapted from The Journal of Ethnopharmacology) (pg. C9)

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 1; Science Desk; Medical Science Page

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Drug-Resistant TB Makes U.S. Rethink Elimination Program

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
LESS than three years after Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, set 2010 as the target for eliminating tuberculosis in the United States, the resurgent disease is out of control in this country.
As Dr. Sullivan and his lieutenants confront the problem, far more is at stake than upsetting an arbitrary deadline. The goal itself is in jeopardy because the disease has to be controlled before it can be eliminated. 
 Several of the new outbreaks have been caused by deadly strains of bacteria that are resistant to most tuberculosis drugs. If further outbreaks occur, surely there will be more drug-resistant bacteria, and it will only be a matter of time before they supplant the susceptible strains as the most common form of tuberculosis.
Some needs to bring the disease under control are clear and urgent: new antibiotics to combat drug-resistant tuberculosis and stronger public health programs, especially efforts to treat all patients until they stop spreading the tuberculosis bacilli, which are dispersed through the air from coughing.
But some experts are wondering whether more extreme measures are needed, like recreating tuberculosis sanitariums, particularly for those who develop drug-resistant tuberculosis. Experts are also asking for a review of the legal measures to forcibly treat people who refuse to complete prescribed courses of therapy.
Because tuberculosis is largely linked to poverty, many middle-class or wealthy people dismiss it as a disease they do not have to worry about. But tuberculosis can strike the affluent. For example, the diagnosis of tuberculosis was made too late to save the life of Eleanor Roosevelt, the former First Lady who died of tuberculosis in 1962.
Without effective measures, the dread scourge of earlier this century will return to eat away the lungs, kidneys and other tissues to kill large numbers of Americans, many of them in the prime of life.
The new threat from tuberculosis is the latest example of a classic problem in the control of infectious diseases. As such diseases come close to disappearing, apathy develops. Legislators slash public health budgets, an action that usually proves to be false economy.
It is now clear that in the 1970's, the public, government officials and even health professionals became overconfident about the drop in reported cases of tuberculosis that had been continuing since the 1950's.
After all, treatment for tuberculosis was completely effective, although the cure was not quick. But many patients did not complete the full course of drug treatment because the workers who supervised such therapy were laid off. Incomplete therapy fosters the development of drug-resistant strains, and when such patients returned to the community they spread drug-resistant tuberculosis to others. The resistant nature of such infections often went unrecognized because most laboratories did not test bacteria isolated from tuberculosis patients for susceptibility to drugs.
In recent decades nearly all the tuberculosis sanitariums in this country, which numbered more than 500 in the 1930's, closed. Now tuberculosis patients are treated in community hospitals and released after doctors decide they are no longer contagious.
But the spread of tuberculosis has occurred within hospitals. One reason is the delay in diagnosing cases. Another is that most hospitals did not spend the money to meet requirements to install adequate ventilation to stop tuberculosis bacteria from spreading through the air.
Health departments were slow to recognize that they had not dealt adequately with the old problems of tuberculosis and to recognize the new ones because control programs were cut or abandoned.
Instead of continuing to decline, the number of tuberculosis cases rose. About 28,000 cases occurred from 1984 to 1990, well beyond the total Federal health officials had expected. Nevertheless, the Federal goal still seemed attainable because the cases were thought to be caused by strains susceptible to standard antibiotics.
But since 1989, when Dr. Sullivan announced the target to eliminate tuberculosis, drug-resistant tuberculosis has spread in at least 17 states. Dr. William L. Roper, director of the national Centers for Disease Control here, said doctors "are surely less confident now than we were two or so years ago" that they will cure an individual patient of tuberculosis.
In some outbreaks of drug-resistant tuberculosis, death rates have exceeded 80 percent. It is not clear whether the death rate was so high because of delay in recognizing and treating the resistant form of the disease, because the new strains were deadlier than previous ones or because the patients were debilitated by AIDS.
But even when patients with drug-resistant tuberculosis end up in the hands of the top experts like Dr. Michael D. Iseman of the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine in Denver, the cure rate is only 50 percent.
The loss of confidence extends to preventing latent infections from progressing to active tuberculosis. There is a 10 percent chance of such progression in a lifetime.
When an individual's skin test turns from negative to positive, indicating that he has recently become infected, doctors usually prescribe a drug called isoniazid.
But now Federal health officials say they do not know whether any drug will prevent development of active tuberculosis in someone latently infected with drug-resistant strains.
Federal officials advise health workers caring for tuberculosis patients to wear air-tight masks known as particulate respirators to filter out tuberculosis bacilli. But most hospitals do not make the respirators available because of their cost and controversy over their effectiveness.
And some experts, like Dr. Iseman and Dr. Lee B. Reichman, the president-elect of the American Lung Association in New York, say they do not wear masks, largely because they believe masks impede communication with patients.
If a tuberculosis patient coughs in his presence, Dr. Reichman said, he turns his head away and holds his breath. Dr. Reichman, who is head of chest diseases at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark, said he wears a mask only when putting a tube into the windpipe in a procedure known as a bronchoscopy. Because such a procedure makes a patient cough, anyone with active tuberculosis could breathe the bacilli directly into a doctor's face.
Most doctors who wear masks use the standard surgical type. But that type of mask allows air to circulate through the edges and it did not protect Dr. Kenneth R. Ong, Deputy Commissioner of Health in New York City. He said he became infected in late 1990 as an infectious-disease specialist caring for tuberculosis patients. Dr. Ong said he took isoniazid in the hope that he had caught the form of the disease that is susceptible to drugs. But he believes he almost surely is latently infected with a drug-resistant strain.
Another important concern is the threat of spreading tuberculosis to patients, health care workers and visitors in hospitals where ventilation is inadequate.
Experts are now debating whether all hospitals should care for tuberculosis patients and whether such patients should be cared for only in special wings in certain hospitals or sanitariums dedicated to care of the disease. Although it would be uneconomical for every city to have a tuberculosis sanitarium, sharing regional centers could be cost-effective.
One of the most lucrative areas of drug manufacturing is the development of new antibiotics to combat microbes that have become resistant to older drugs. But in a strange way, the drive to eliminate tuberculosis may have been counterproductive to developing new anti-tuberculosis drugs.
"What's the incentive to develop new drugs when manufacturers hear about the impending demise of a disease and think there will be no market in the United States?" asked Dr. Michael Osterholm, the Minnesota state epidemiologist.
Manufacturers do know that a need exists for new antibiotics elsewhere in the world where tuberculosis is a leading killer. But the drug companies also know that there is little potential profit because such countries are poor.
Spread of drug-resistant tuberculosis has made it far more difficult to eliminate the disease. "It adds complications at a time when we don't need any more problems but when we need some solutions," Dr. Roper said.
Dr. Roper is still confident that tuberculosis can be eliminated. But he said, "The jury is out as to how long it is going to take us to do what needs to be done."

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Science Desk; The Environment Page

LENGTH: 1525 words

HEADLINE: Experts Say Logging Of Vast Siberian Forest Could Foster Warming

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
THE forests of the Amazon and other tropical regions have been getting attention for some time, and understandably so. They are home to a disproportionate share of the world's living species, they absorb huge amounts of atmospheric carbon dioxide that would otherwise exert a big heating effect on the earth's climate and they are rapidly being destroyed.
Less well known is the vast stretch of fir, larch, spruce and pine that girdles the continents at far northern latitudes and is known as the taiga. The word is derived from the Russian, appropriately enough since the Siberian part of the taiga is the largest forest in the world, far larger than the Brazilian Amazon. At more than two million square miles, it would cover the entire continental United States excepting Alaska. Like the tropical forests, it is a major absorber of atmospheric carbon dioxide. 
 Now, with Russia economically devastated and hungry for hard currency as it converts to a market economy, environmentalists are raising fears that joint ventures between the Russians and American, Japanese or Korean timber companies could lead to extensive deforestation of the Siberian taiga. This, the environmentalists warn, could contribute significantly to global warming.
If carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases continue to build up in the atmosphere at the present rate, the earth's average surface temperature will rise by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit in the next century with possibly catastrophic results, many scientists predict. The rate of buildup would presumably increase if Siberia were deforested.
The possibility is raised in an article in the current issue of the British journal Nature by Dr. Armin Rosencranz and Antony Scott of the Pacific Energy and Resources Center in Sausalito, Calif., a nonprofit environmental research and education center that works with Russian environmentalists to defend the Siberian forests.
The forests "have a large role to play in mitigating global warming," they wrote, emphasizing that this "must be communicated to the negotiators of international agreements" aimed at limiting or reversing the buildup of carbon dioxide.
Negotiators from 130 countries are to meet in New York next month in the fourth of five sessions aimed at producing a binding international convention on the control of heat-trapping gases. Participants say the session is crucial, since there is not much time left before the scheduled signing of the pact in June in Rio de Janeiro, and the United States and other industrial nations differ over whether to set specific targets for limiting carbon dioxide emissions. Less attention has been given to the important role of deforestation in global warming, and particularly to the role of the taiga.
Some forestry experts question whether large-scale logging will ever catch on in Siberia, given its inaccessibility, generally high costs and a short growing season for the regeneration of trees.
But the pressures of economic survival in the former Soviet Union, and particularly in hard-pressed Siberia, are causing Russians to "look to natural resources for conversion into cash, and people in the United States, the West and Korea and Japan are waiting to use these natural resources," Dr. Rosencranz, the president of the Pacific Energy and Resources Center, said in an interview.
He and Mr. Scott noted in the Nature article that the recent completion of a new Siberian railway helps make expansion of the timber industry possible. Thousands of people sent to Siberia to work on the railway are now jobless, they wrote, adding to the pressure to speed up development of other industries, like timber.
The article asserted that the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation and the Weyerhaeuser Company, three American timber giants, have begun negotiations to cut Siberian forests. Any agreements, the authors wrote, "will almost certainly increase the rate of logging." Weyerhaeuser, said Dr. Rosencranz, has built a large loading dock near Khabarovsk, a major Siberian city.
The authors wrote also that Hyundai Inc., the South Korean conglomerate, "is said to have contracted to log roughly half a million acres" in eastern Siberia and that C. Itoh and Company, a Japanese concern, had already begun harvesting trees there.
S. S. Chae, senior executive vice president of Hyundai Resources Development Company Ltd. of Seoul, confirmed that his company had entered into a joint venture to log the half-million acres and that the company was considering expanding its Siberian operations.
C. Itoh imported 100,000 cubic meters of softwood logs from Siberia last year and has also invested in a "small-scale sawmill" in Siberia, said Yoshiharu Matsumoto, a spokesman for the company in Tokyo.
Georgia-Pacific representatives have been to Siberia to investigate the long-term potential of the timber resource, but the company has not begun any joint-venture negotiations, said Sheila Weidman, a company spokeswoman. With 50 percent of the world's inventory of softwood, she said, Siberia could in time be a major competitor on the world market.
But roads, railroads and other infrastructure necessary to develop Siberian forestry are insufficient, and the convertibility of the ruble is still a big question, she pointed out. For these reasons, she said, Georgia-Pacific sees the Siberian forests "as a possible opportunity well into the future but is not considering it in the short term at all."
Similarly, Louisiana-Pacific has looked at the Siberian forests but has no present plans to exploit them, said Barry Lacter, a spokesman at the company headquarters in Portland, Ore.
Weyerhaeuser has "explored the feasibility" of logging operations in territory of Khabarovsk, in eastern Siberia, and has considered how to ship wood out of the territory, said Scott Marshall, a spokesman in Tacoma, Wash. While "we're not doing anything yet," he said, it is possible the company will enter Siberia in the next 5 to 10 years. "Certainly," he said, "there is a likelihood that someone will.
Despite interest from timber companies, "it's hard to see much happening in the next decade" in Siberian timbering, said Dr. Roger Sedjo, an expert in world forests at Resources for the Future, an independent research organization in Washington.
Dr. Rosencranz and Mr. Scott acknowledge that short-term prospects for investment in Siberian timber might not be good because of economics, transporation difficulties, red tape, non-convertibility of the ruble and especially political instability and doubt about who will own and control the forests. But they insist that it is essential to insure that "the allure of hard currency and modern technology does not outweigh the long-term health of the forests."
 
Difference With Tropics
 While recognizing the possibility of both local and global environmental damage, Dr. Sedjo pointed out some important differences between the taiga and tropical forests. In the tropics, he said, deforestation proceeds mostly because forests are being converted to agriculture and other forms of development in a region where population pressures are acute.
By contrast, he said, unoccupied timberlands regenerate. In fact, he said, there has been a net gain in forest acreage in the heavily logged temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. Moreover, he said, trees converted to wood products like houses and furniture do not release carbon dioxide to the atmosphere as tropical forests do when they are burned. It is even likely, he said, that regenerating forests would remove more carbon dioxide from the atmosphere than the mature ones they replace, since young, growing trees absorb the gas at a higher rate.
Dr. Rosencranz and Mr. Scott argue that regeneration would be slow in Siberia because the growing season is so short, and that clear-cutting -- the most economical way to log -- would cause erosion. This, they fear, would further inhibit regeneration and destroy aquatic ecosystems on which native Siberian people depend for fish they eat.
While regeneration does take longer in the far north, said Mr. Marshall of Weyerhaeuser, it has been done successfully in the taiga of Canada and Scandinavia for decades. Moreover, he said, some parts of Siberia are warmer and more favorable for tree growth than others.
Dr. Sedjo said that Siberian logging operations would be among the costliest in the world, despite the new railway. Subsidies by the Russian or local governments, unlikely in the present economic climate, might overcome the timber companies' cost objections, he said. Successful efforts in the United States and elsewhere to prohibit logging on conservation grounds could also drive up the world price of wood, he said, making Siberian logging more attractive.
But, he said, large increases in Siberian timber production "may never occur."
To whatever degree the Siberian forests are exploited, Dr. Rosencranz and Mr. Scott wrote, they ought to be exploited in a sound way so that the resource itself, "an economic, climatic and wilderness resource of global significance," is preserved.

HEADLINE: President Puts Final Touches On State of Union Message

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
President Bush today began final preparations for his State of the Union Message to Congress on Tuesday night, reviewing final drafts of the speech and delivering the first of two dress-rehearsal readings to aides in a theater in the East Wing of the White House.
Mr. Bush's recitation signaled the end of a gantlet through which speechwriters and advisers have alternately dashed and staggered, nights and weekends, for almost a month. 
 State of the Union speeches are always pressure-packed, the aides said in interviews, but the one on Tuesday night, billed by Bush aides as a linchpin of his re-election strategy, is triply so.
"I think it's fair enough for people to look for a lot out of this speech in terms of him moving to the next stage" of his campaign, which is to present a program for economic recovery, Charles R. Black Jr., a top Bush campaign adviser, said last Thursday.
 
Final Flourishes
 Today Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, tried to minimize the hyperbole. He said the President's speech would "have a great deal of meat in it," but added, "I think if expectations tomorrow are reasonable, the President will meet them."
Several of the President's aides stayed at the White House this weekend to apply final flourishes to what is essentially a finished speech. The White House director of speechwriting, Tony Snow, said he expected the President's speech to run 45 minutes to an hour, including interruptions for applause.
That is longer than most State of the Union speeches. Mr. Bush's first two ran 35 minutes and 47 minutes, respectively, and both were artificially lengthened by outbreaks of patriotic fervor over successful wars in Panama and the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Snow said Tuesday's speech would "be carried by its substance," not by any high-flying oratory.
Mr. Bush's aides say he has put an unusual amount of personal effort into this speech. By this weekend, he had reviewed eight drafts of the address, cobbled in countless meetings and position papers since December.
 
Month of Planning
 Serious planning for the address began about a month ago, shortly after Mr. Bush named Samuel K. Skinner as his new chief of staff and appointed a 1992 campaign team headed by his chief pollster and political strategist, Robert M. Teeter. Those two, with Mr. Bush, the budget director, Richard G. Darman, and the White House communications director, David F. Demarest Jr., have regularly chewed over the tone and content of the speech since then in a series of informal meetings.
Mr. Bush also has solicited advice from fellow politicians, friends and what one adviser called "John Q. Public," but it was unclear what ordinary citizens he had spoken with.
Actual drafting of the address began about 10 days ago, and the first copy was delivered last Wednesday, aides said. Mr. Bush has since begun weighing in, sometimes "quite dramatically," with specific changes and suggestions, said one of several aides who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The President can and does rewrite lines and whole paragraphs of the speech to suit his tastes. "But he also will just sit back and say, 'Here are some thoughts and reflections,' and we'll just listen," one aide said. That aide said Mr. Bush "actually is a very good writer."
Mr. Bush enters the House of Representatives on Tuesday with a built-in handicap: State of the Union addresses, even ones ballyhooed like this one, are virtually dictated by their roles in politics to be forgettable.
The speech must trumpet a list of White House accomplishments, real and imagined, as well as an equally improbable list of proposals for the nation's future greatness.
"In a State of the Union, you're trying to put an enormous amount of substance together with a great amount of style," said Chriss Winston, who was White House director of speechwriting until last March, when she left to spend more time with her child. "So when you look back on it, there are very few States of the Union that anyone could quote from. It has not been an address that goes down in the annals of speechmaking."

HEADLINE: Court Shifts California's Political Lines

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In a move that alters the political landscape of California, the State Supreme Court today imposed a new redistricting plan that is widely expected to accelerate Republican gains in the largest state. Political experts say Republicans could take control of the state's huge Congressional delegation this year and possibly both houses of the State Legislature within two to four years.
The plan ignored existing district lines, thereby putting many powerful incumbents in both Congress and the Legislature in the difficult position of either running against other incumbents or moving to less reliable districts. 
 With the new map, powerful Democrats in Congress like Vic Fazio of Sacramento and Anthony C. Beilenson of Los Angeles face tough re-election fights, as does the powerful President Pro Tempore of the State Senate, David A. Roberti of Los Angeles.
Together with a ballot measure passed in 1990 that limits the terms of members in the State Senate and Assembly, the plan promises the most confusing, competitive and costly election year in California memory. Politicians are scrambling ferociously for new seats.
 
'Dramatic Turnover' Expected
 "We'll see some dramatic turnover in the next two election cycles," said John B. Emerson, a Democratic political strategist who is Chief Deputy City Attorney of Los Angeles. "This will be an enormously expensive fund-raising year as previously safe incumbents will have to fight for their lives."
The current Congressional delegation consists of 26 Democrats and 19 Republicans. While the election is more than nine months off, the Republicans are generally expected to win four or five of the new seats and possibly three or four of the redrawn districts. That could give them 27 seats, a majority of the 52 in the new delegation.
The plan was drawn up by a special panel of three retired judges appointed by the State Supreme Court, six of whose seven members were appointed by Republican governors. The court took control of the contentious reapportionment process late last year after Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, vetoed a plan devised by the Democratic-controlled Legislature.
Ten years ago, districts were gerrymendered under a Democratic plan that largely protected incumbents of both parties.
This time the panel ignored incumbents, trying to keep districts compact and avoiding the grotesquely gerrymandered districts of the past. It tried to keep "communities of interest" together and follow county lines and geographical barriers like mountains in drawing lines, while also adhering to the Federal Voting Rights Act, which requires that minority-dominated districts be created where possible.
 
Plan Challenged in Court
 Democratic incumbents in Congress and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund are challenging the plan in Federal District Court in San Francisco, saying it fails to set up enough minority districts.
But the incumbents seemed resigned to running under the new districts. Two weeks ago, Mr. Beilenson, who has represented Beverly Hills, Westwood and other parts of the liberal West Side of Los Angeles for 16 years, announced that he was moving his residence over the mountains to the more politically conservative San Fernando Valley rather than run against his friend, Representative Henry A. Waxman, in a new 29th District that runs from near downtown to Santa Monica.
"It was very painful to me because either way I'd lose enormous number of constituents I care about personally," Mr. Beilenson said today in a telephone interview from Washington. Registration in his new district, the 24th, is 45 percent Democratic and 45 percent Republican, making it marginal for a Democrat since Republicans are generally more loyal to the party. He said the court plan was poorly drawn in terms of keeping communities of interest together.
The plan is a blow to the powerful Democratic political machine run by Mr. Waxman and Representative Howard L. Berman, who represent the affluent, heavily Jewish West Side.
 
'Level Playing Field'
 "This gives us a level playing field -- we've been running uphill for 10 years," said Dan Schnur, a spokesman for Governor Wilson, of the new plan.
Both Democratic and Republican experts agreed that Republicans would take the lion's share of the seven new seats California won after the 1990 census. Over the decade the state's population grew by 26 percent, to nearly 30 million people, but the bulk of the growth was not in the liberal Los Angeles and San Francisco areas but in more conservative areas like the Central Valley and Riverside and San Bernardino Counties.
"For the first time in my history, we've got a good shot at it, if not this year in two more years," said David Knatcal, spokesman for the California Republican Party.
But Bob Mulholland, political director of the California Democratic Party, said that given the state's economic troubles and disaffection with Governor Wilson, the Democrats would maintain a majority, albeit a thinner one.
The court-approved plan is vulnerable mainly on the ground that it fails to establish enough minority districts. Currently California has three representatives in Congress who are Mexican-American and three blacks.
Jonathan H. Steinberg, a lawyer representing the Democratic incumbents in Congress, said that by keeping districts compact the panel had produced a gerrymander that favored whites. He said cohesive Hispanic populations on the East Side of Los Angeles and the Coachella Valley and Imperial Valleys were broken up unnecessarily. Hispanic people make up 26 percent of California's population but a much smaller percentage of the electorate.
In its 6-to-1 ruling, written by Chief Justice Malcolm Lucas, the Supreme Court found that the plan conformed to Federal law.
But in his lone dissent, Justice Stanley Mosk, complained that the panel of retired judges had abolished four existing districts in Los Angeles County and placed four incumbents into one district, the new 29th. "That all four members were Democrats arouses understandable suspicion as to objectivity," he wrote, adding this amounted to "reverse gerrymandering."
Now that the ruling is out, Mr. Steinberg said he expected to push forward on the Federal challenge, which is based also on discrepancies in the size of districts.
But with a Feb. 18 deadline for candidates to file their notices of intent to run, many experts said they believed the court plan would likely stand at least for the 1992 election.

HEADLINE: The 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
For the Front-Runners, Crucial Days Are Here

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Jan. 27

 BODY:
Pace-setters often fade in the stretch. It happens to horses, and it happens to politicians. So this week, which should show something about the staying power of the presumed front-runners in the New Hampshire primary, could turn out to be highly significant.
Neither President Bush nor Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas is likely to find the going easy. Mr. Bush must somehow manage, in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, to convince the intensely provincial people here that he has a concrete program to pull their state out of recession. Mr. Clinton must somehow recover his balance after being staggered by allegations of marital infidelity last week. 
 For the President, the task is making hard-hit voters believe that he, a man born to privilege, rich most of his life, understands their plight.
Bush supporters in the state are fretful, and they do not hide it. "I'm very, very nervous about him putting all his eggs in one basket," said Tom Rath, a former State Attorney General who has been active in the Bush campaign. "Suppose he gives the greatest speech of his life. The next day, the guy in Laconia or Nashua still doesn't have a job. He's still hurting."
Challenged here by Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, limited in what he can propose by lack of resources and obliged to take his stand weeks before the vote here, Mr. Bush has his work cut out.
On Wednesday, only a few hours after his speech, the President will announce his budget, which is expected to exceed $1.5 trillion, and the Government is expected to make public a new set of statistics showing that the economy, after starting to recover last spring and summer, stalled again last fall. The figures will give fresh ammunition to those who argue that Mr. Bush mishandled the economy.
And all week long, Mr. Buchanan will be on the streets of the state, while Mr. Bush is absent. The President will not be here again for two weeks, campaigning solely through radio and television advertisements and surrogate speakers.
For Mr. Clinton, the stakes are even higher. As he said in his interview on the CBS News program "60 Minutes" Sunday evening, this week should demonstrate whether he will be able to resume discussion of the economic and social issues from which he was diverted by accusations that he had carried on a 12-year affair with Gennifer Flowers, a former nightclub singer.
That will depend on the voters and on the reporters covering him, whom the Governor accused of playing "a game of gotcha" at his expense. When accusations of sexual impropriety surfaced four years ago during former Senator Gary Hart's Presidential campaign, reporters hounded Mr. Hart with questions on that subject alone, contributing to his decision to withdraw from the race because he could no longer get his message across.
Mr. Clinton forcefully denied he had an affair with Ms. Flowers, but refused to deny having an affair with anyone, saying he had had rocky passages in his marriage and allowing the public to draw its own conclusions.
A telephone survey last week, after the accusations had been publicized by Star, a supermarket tabloid, showed Mr. Clinton sagging badly in New Hampshire. It said he had fallen into a tie with former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who had been trailing by 25 percentage points.
Several polls have shown that about 15 percent of American voters say they would not back someone who had had an extramarital affair. The figure is even higher in the South, where the primaries on March 3 and 10, in which Mr. Clinton has been favored, are concentrated.
Much will depend on whether Mr. Clinton can avoid additional damage. Mr. Tsongas, dismissed until recently as a Bruce Babbitt -- straight-talking but not salable -- has been winning plaudits in the last few days and might then be a beneficiary, or Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska.
It is still possible, politicians here say, that people will believe Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary. Some may vote for him because they resent the role of news organizations in spreading the accusations, which have not yet been substantiated. If he wins -- and with five candidates in the Democratic primary, he might need only 35 percent or 40 percent of the vote -- he might be strengthened enough to put his drive back on course.
