HEADLINE: In a Speech, President Returns to Religious Themes

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Reviving social and religious themes that are seldom heard in his oratory except in election years, President Bush today called for voluntary prayer in schools, pledged to curtail "the decline of the American family" and cited the teachings of Jesus Christ as the moral force behind the Persian Gulf war.
"Obviously no country can claim a special place in God's heart," Mr. Bush said in an address to the National Religious Broadcasters, a group of Christian radio and television station officials. "Yet we are better as a people because He has a special place in ours." 
 Mr. Bush's appearance before the broadcasters has been an annual event. But the timing of today's speech allowed the President to emphasize his commitment to conservative social issues on the day before his State of the Union Message, which is expected to be dominated by more pressing economic concerns.
 
Reviving Old Notions
 Some of the notions that Mr. Bush touched on today were mainstays of the more ideological Reagan years. But they have received scant attention from Mr. Bush since the 1988 campaign, when the economy was going strong and Mr. Bush was free to campaign on prayer in public schools and the Pledge of Allegiance, issues that he used to portray his opponent, Michael S. Dukakis, as cold in spirit and unpatriotic.
Mr. Bush even spoke today, although euphemistically, of abortion, an issue that he seldom raises except in remarks that are intended to reassure a conservative audience like today's enthusiastic crowd, which gave him two standing ovations.
Saying he wanted to speak about "values," and not give a partisan address, Mr. Bush said: "The first value is not simply American, but universal. And I refer to the sanctity of life. I will stand on the side of choosing life."
At moments like today's speech to the religious broadcasters, Mr. Bush's demeanor changes markedly from his usual campaign and Presidential appearances. He is far more emotional than is his normal style. In Atlanta last year, Mr. Bush cried as he spoke to the Southern Baptist Convention about praying before he ordered the ground attack on Iraqi forces in Kuwait.
 
Biblical Blandishments
 The President, who is an Episcopalian, seemed to tailor his syntax to the audience today, using words like "unto" and citing the Bible. He even used it at one point to convey the impression that he is committed to fair foreign-trade practices.
"The Bible reminds us, by thy works shall ye know them," Mr. Bush said. "What we must do is give working Americans that level playing field to keep us as rich in goods as we have been blessed in spirit."
The President commended the broadcasters for their support of the war to drive Iraq from Kuwait. "I want to thank you for helping America, as Christ ordained, to be a light unto the world," said Mr. Bush.
The President renewed his call for a Constitutional amendment allowing organized prayer in public schools, calling prayer "the ultimate value that sustains America."
"In Sunday school, children learn that God is everywhere, but in public school, they find that He's absent from class," said Mr. Bush.
The school-prayer amendment is one of six changes to the Constitution that Mr. Bush has gone on the record as supporting since the 1988 campaign. He also favors an anti-abortion amendment, a balanced-budget amendment, a line-item-veto amendment, an amendment requiring the recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in schools and an amendment setting limits on terms in Federal elected office.
White House officials say Mr. Bush strongly backs each of these amendments. But he has done nothing to start the process that might lead to their enactment and they are not a staple of the President's oratorical diet.
In today's speech, Mr. Bush spoke at length about what he said was a threat to American family values from crime, drugs and racism.
"We need a nation closer to the Waltons than the Simpsons," Mr. Bush said, "an America that rejects the incivility, the tide of incivility, and the tide of intolerance."

HEADLINE: Afraid and Hurt, Young Turn to Clinics

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 27

 BODY:
The girl had just turned 13 and complained of acne when she came to the adolescent medicine clinic at Oakland Children's Hospital last week.
But blemishes were the least of her problems. 
 Under the gentle but insistent questioning of doctors and social workers, she disclosed her secrets: She had been molested by a neighborhood drug dealer, was afraid she was pregnant or infected with venereal disease and even more frightened that her assailant would retaliate if she turned him in.
Her harrowing story, told as rap music played in the background, is unexceptional at this inner city clinic where adolescents come with sore throats, twisted ankles and asthma and then reveal that they have been raped, beaten or shot; that they are pregnant, suicidal or hungry.
The clinic director, Dr. Barbara Staggers, a 38-year-old pediatrician, is one of a growing number of adolescent medicine specialists. In many big cities, such doctors run clinics like this one, at a medical school, a childrens' hospital, or even affiliated with an inner city high school.
 
Searching for Love
 The young people at Dr. Staggers's clinic describe their situations in the matter-of-fact tones students use to discuss extra math homework and not a compendium of urban plagues. But they cling to the doctors and counselors, returning day after day to the storefront clinic, down the street from the shuttered Pussycat Theater and several blocks from the main hospital, saying that what they most wish for is more time with an adult who loves them.
"To just function takes everything they have," said Dr. Staggers, who dispenses condoms, medical advice and hugs in equal measure to 5,000 youngsters a year, most of them poor and only a few of them living with both their parents. "We need to say to them over and over, 'This shouldn't be happening to you.' "
Young people like these have been the subject of dozens of national studies, learned reports and civic jeremiads in recent months, all deploring the conditions of life for many of the 64 million children of America, particularly the 13 million who are poor.
Teen-age rape and pregancy, child abuse and juvenile crime are all on the rise, government officials, child welfare advocates and scholars agree. But most alarming of all is the threefold increase in homicide and suicide rates among teen-agers in the last 30 years, which experts say signals the depth of their despair about the future.
"What we're seeing is the complete destruction of the social environment for these kids," said Dr. Joyce Lashof, a professor of public health at the University of California at Berkeley and the new president of the American Public Health Association. "Economic opportunity, stable relationships, housing, safety at school, hope for the future: Everything that makes up living has kind of disappeared for them."
These teen-agers troop through Dr. Staggers's clinic at the rate of about 20 a day, and all but a very few have horrendous stories to tell. But they do not disclose their problems easily or quickly.
Instead, pediatricians, social workers and peer counselors, most of them raised in the inner city, spend hours alternating diverting patter and probing questions about what is going on in the youngsters' lives.
 
Coaxing the Answers
 "Since I last saw you, have you had sex with anyone?" Dr. Staggers asks one girl who recently had an abortion and now has a new boyfriend. "Did you guys use protection? Good for you! Can we clone you?"
"What did you eat yesterday?" she asks a frail 12-year-old in sour smelling clothes, whose mother recently returned home from a prison term. "Any green stuff? Any meat?"
"Do you remember how many places you've lived in the last year?" she asks a 13-year-old who nightly wets her bed at a group foster home. "Can you count them? Do you understand that this is happening because of all the stuff that's going on in your life and that there is nothing wrong inside of you?"
"Who you staying with?" she asks another youngster who has richochetted between relatives and foster homes because her mother is an addict. "With your granny now? Are you guys getting along? Is she pulling your leash too tight?"
"What's your neighborhood like these days -- pretty rowdy?" she asks a 13-year-old boy whose block is the scene of frequent shootings. "Anything awful happen to any of your friends? Anybody been shot or stabbed lately?"
 
The Truth Comes Out
 Once Dr. Staggers and her colleagues find a conversational wedge, the dam bursts and sorrows flood forth.
"The foundation these kids are standing on is like glass," said Michael James, a counselor at the clinic. "Real hard, real smooth. But if something hits it, it shatters."
As at most adolescent clinics, health care is not defined as medicine alone. A routine visit takes more than an hour, with three-quarters of the teen-agers, referred by doctors or word of mouth, also talking to social workers, psychologists or peer conselors. The care is overwhelmingly state-supported, either because the youngsters are poor or because they are covered under so-called sensitive-service laws, common across the country, which protect the confidentiality of children seeking advise about pregnancy, drugs and the like.
The girls, without exception, talk about sex, much of it abusive or dangerous. The boys talk about weapons, which are unavoidable on the streets where they live. All of them say they are afraid of random gunfire and AIDS, legitimate concerns in these neighborhoods. Many say they do not expect to live to adulthood.
To survive "you got to stay out of peoples' way," explained a 13-year-old boy with the build of a linebacker, who was recently at a birthday party where a friend was shot. "Somebody can walk up to you and put a gun to your head. It's kind of rowdy."
 
Teen-Ager Asks 'Why Us?'
 Only a few of these teen-agers know their fathers and some have lost their mothers, as well -- to drugs, alcohol or prison. One such teen-ager, now 17, was sent to her first foster home at the age of 2, tried prostitution at 14, has been frequently raped, robbed and beaten, and sometimes wonders "what can I do to make myself die?"
"Why us?" she wailed the other day, as Dr. Staggers cradled her in her arms and promised both moral support and medicine for her latest vaginal infection. "Why are the blacks losing their mommas?"
The girl, with meticulously braided hair and almond-shaped eyes, had turned to alcohol for forgetfulness and to abusive men for attention.
"The only reason I drink so much is I be so hurt," she said. "I used to go home with no pants all the time."
But too many unwanted pregnancies and venereal diseases had persuaded her to mend her ways. "I can't trust nobody, no more, no more," she cried. "In '92 that's my goal. Not to trust nobody else, not ever."
Dr. Staggers shushed her. "We care about you," she said. "We love you. You can always come here."
Even the children with parents are often on their own, or worse. One heavy-set blonde, with thick purple eyeshadow, confessed to Dr. Staggers that she had tried to overdose on decongestants because of persistent beatings from her mother. Once not too long ago, the girl struck back, and wound up locked up in juvenile hall, labeled an "out of control youth" because she tried to defend herself.
"I'm tired of dealing with it," she said last week, describing her suicide attempt. "I thought it was the easy way out."
Dr. Staggers asked her "to do me a favor next time: Call."
She went on: "We can't replace you. We can't help you if you're dead."
Lonely and unsupported, these children cast about for comfort, which for the girls often means perilous sex.
"It's a good feeling to be loved, talked to nice, held," said Jamata Gray, a 20-year-old counselor, who served time in juvenile hall for selling drugs and was a teen-aged mother. "If your boyfriend is the only one to give that to you, you'll get it from him."
Sometimes the sex is an unintended byproduct of the need for shelter, as it was for a homeless 15-year-old who was offered a bed one wintry night by a group of men who then raped her. "She went back the next night, so the cops said she had provoked them," said Glenester Irvin, a social worker. "But it was 32 degrees. You've got to understand that she didn't have anyplace else to go."
 
A Role for Gangs
 In addition to sex, gangs fill the unmet needs of her patients, Dr. Staggers said.
"They get money, food, shelter, support, lots of the things they need to survive," she said. "You can't just say 'Don't do it,' when you can offer them no substitute for this highly structured social organization."
A variation on this theme is the attraction of a psychiatric hospital for one teen-aged patient, who makes frequent, although half-hearted, suicide attempts. She is homeless, often hungry and so far behind in school that graduation seems impossible.
"She sees the hospital as as a place to be taken care of, have three meals a day and her own bed," said Cleo Rice-Hodge, a social worker. "That's a sad commentary."
Among children between the ages of 15 and 19, homicide is the No. 2 cause of death, behind motor vehicle accidents, and suicide is No. 3. Overwhelmingly, it is black males who get killed, usually with a firearm, and white youngsters, both male and female, who kill themselves.
Either way, Dr. Staggers said: "I don't like picking up bodies. But I do like the fact that it has gotten so dramatic, so out of hand, so embarrassing to this country, that it can no longer be ignored."
 
Mixed Messages
 In the world in which these children live, Dr. Staggers and her colleagues say, they are bombarded with mixed messages, told that certain behavior is bad at the same time that is glorified in film, fashion and music. "Everything they see is sex and guns, sex and guns," Dr. Staggers said.
These teen-agers also struggle with the undertow of peer pressure, which can take deadly form in neighborhoods that are rife with guns and drugs.
"You want to be out having fun, not stuck in the house," said Ms. Gray, who said she sold drugs as a teen-ager to support the 13 siblings she was raising because her mother was an addict. "Somebody says, 'Let's go get a gun.' If you don't do it, they think you're a punk. You don't want to be looked down at, disrespected."
Dr. Staggers filled out charts and mused on the suffering of these children one recent night before heading home to fix dinner for her 6-year-old son. Darkness pressed against the clinic windows, the teen-agers had scattered and Vivaldi had replaced rap.
"I don't know who's worse off," Dr. Staggers said, comparing the children who survive to the ones who don't. "When you're dead, you're dead. You don't experience any more pain. But we've got the walking dead here. We've got the zombies."

HEADLINE: 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bad News for Bush as Poll Shows National Gloom

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
In his State of the Union Message tonight, President Bush will address a nation that is gloomier than it has been in 13 years, more disapproving of his Presidency than ever and increasingly willing to try a Democrat in the White House, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The survey suggests that Mr. Bush's speech at 9 o'clock tonight may be the most important of his Presidency. He is facing a discontented and volatile electorate that on a variety of issues is willing to give the opposition party the benefit of the doubt. 
 Seventy-three percent of those polled see the country as being in worse shape today than it was five years ago, a crucial measure of the national mood that has not been this grim since the days of "malaise" under Jimmy Carter when the figure was 63 percent.
 
Giving Democrats a Chance
 The public tends to think a Democratic President would do a better job on improving schools, helping the middle class, assuring national health care and even ending the recession, the poll found.
Sixty percent in the telephone survey of 1,281 adults nationwide say it is time to give a Democrat a chance as President, but Republican strategists note that an idealized generic nominee is likely to fare far better in polls than an actual one.
Support for Mr. Bush continues to erode, with just 43 percent saying they approve of his performance as President, an astonishing drop of 45 points since his popularity rating reached 88 percent, a historic peak, after the Persian Gulf war.
Perhaps most tellingly, the public has even lost confidence in Mr. Bush's handling of foreign policy, long his strong suit in the polls. In the latest survey, conducted Wednesday through Saturday, 46 percent approved of his conduct of foreign policy, while 46 percent disapproved. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
On the eve of his speech, Mr. Bush took an opportunity today to bolster his standing among the religious right. Addressing Christian radio and television station officials, he called for voluntary prayer in schools and cited the teachings of Jesus as the moral force behind the Persian Gulf war. Earlier, he reviewed final drafts of his State of the Union Message and staged a dress rehearsal of it before aides in a White House theater. [Page A17.]
While the poll outlines extraordinary opportunity for the Democrats, it is just that. The survey shows that less than a month before the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 18 only one Democrat, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, has broken from the pack in the race for the Presidential nomination.
Among those who said they were likely to vote in the Democratic primaries nationwide, Mr. Clinton's support has jumped to 22 percent, from 5 percent in October. The Governor is currently trying to steady his campaign in the face of accusations in a supermarket tabloid that he committed adultery.
Presidential approval ratings at this stage of a campaign are not a reliable indicator of a President's chances on Election Day. Two recent Presidents had ratings in the Gallup polls similar to Mr. Bush's in January of their re-election year: Gerald R. Ford, who went on to lose, though narrowly, and Richard M. Nixon, who stood at 46 percent approval at the beginning of 1972, and won 49 states that November against George S. McGovern.
Charles R. Black Jr., a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, said that the Democratic race was "in its embryonic stages" and that any predictions about the strength of the party's eventual nominee were highly premature.
The economy is clearly driving political attitudes now and profoundly changing the zeitgeist of the 1980's. Seventy-eight percent of those polled say the economy is in bad shape, and only 9 percent say they think it is improving.
Even with a burdensome Federal deficit, the survey suggests that the public is in the mood for a more active Federal Government engaged in some basic pump-priming. Sixty-five percent said they favored more Federal spending to create jobs; 74 percent favored more spending to improve education, and 74 percent said they would spend more to provide affordable health care to all Americans.
 
Paying for Health Insurance
 The idea of national health insurance has clearly caught fire: 65 percent said they would favor a system financed through taxes. Fifty-three percent said they would be willing to pay $1,000 a year more in Federal taxes to cover it, if that freed them from other medical costs.
The public voiced a clear preference on the best way to jump start the economy: 59 percent said the Federal Government should spend more and try to create jobs, while 28 percent said that tax cuts were the way to go.
The public seemed to have only modest expectations about what a tax cut for the middle class could do for the economy. Asked what kind of effect a tax cut of $400 or $500 would have, 11 percent said it would a major effect in ending the recession, 34 percent said small and 49 percent said it would make no difference.
Still, the middle class -- and 75 percent of those polled said they considered themselves part of it -- feels a clear sense of grievance. When asked who had suffered most from the policies of the Federal Government in the past decade, 46 percent said the poor and 43 percent said the middle class. When asked who had most benefited, 82 percent said the rich.
 
An Edge for Democrats
 Moreover, the Democrats' efforts to cast themselves as the champions of the middle class are paying off. Fifty-nine percent of the respondents said a Democratic President would be more likely to care about the needs of the middle class, while 25 percent said Mr. Bush would.
That was just part of the edge that the public gives to an idealized Democrat when asked who could do a better job on several issues. Forty-six percent said a Democratic President would be more likely to improve education, as against 31 percent who cited Mr. Bush. Sixty-one percent said a Democratic President would be more likely to make health care available to all, as against 19 percent who cited Mr. Bush.
Forty-two percent of the respondents said they thought a Democratic President would do a better job dealing with the abortion issue, while 32 percent cited Mr. Bush.
Perhaps most worrisome to Mr. Bush, 45 percent said a Democratic President would be most likely to end the recession, as against 32 percent who cited the incumbent.
Mr. Bush was given the edge in two categories in the poll: protecting family values and seeing to it that the United States is respected by other countries.
The poll shows public attitudes toward Japan changing remarkably fast, reflecting the debate surrounding Mr. Bush's recent trade mission there. The number of Americans who say the Japanese look down on them has risen 24 points in two months, to 67 percent from 43 percent in November.
A majority of Americans -- 56 percent -- say they favor protecting American industries and jobs by limiting imports, while 38 percent said they backed free trade that would make available good products at low price regardless of where they were made.
And Mr. Bush's effort to cast his Japanese trip as a mission for jobs clearly backfired. Sixty-three percent said the trip was a failure; 19 percent judged it a success.
But the results in the current poll were not all bad for Mr. Bush. Seventy-one percent of the public disapproves of the way Congress is doing its job, suggesting that Mr. Bush's Congress-bashing will fall on receptive ears.
But the overall mood of the public was a striking change from that in the expansive 1980's. It was measured by questions asking people to rate the present state of national affairs on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 the worst and 10 the best. They were asked to do the same for the state of affairs five years ago and five years in the future.
Over all, the respondents gave an average rating to the present of 4.63, lower than any measure taken by The New York Times/CBS News Poll since it began asking the question in November 1979. Reflecting little optimism, they gave the future a rating of 4.97. But looking back five years, they saw a better time, and gave it a rating of 6.54.
Looking at the Democratic Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton was first at 22 percent, followed by former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California at 13 percent, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts at 10 percent, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska at 9 percent and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa at 4 percent.

How the Survey Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 22 to 25 with 1,281 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for either Democratic primary voters or Republican primary voters.
For the question that asked respondents to rate on a scale of 1 to 10 the way things are going in the United States, the margin of sampling error was plus or minus 0.11; that is, in 19 cases out of 20 a mean rating of 4.63 on that scale would be no lower than 4.52 and no higher than 4.74. For means based on smaller subgroups, the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin, Out of Sight Again, Prompts Anxiety and Rumor

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 27

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia made another characteristically abrupt retreat from public life today, this time stirring a sense of mystery and diplomatic risk on the eve of the Middle East conference here of leading nations whose economic aid he has been courting.
Mr. Yeltsin has canceled all meetings for two days and left Moscow to focus on domestic problems and a coming foreign mission, according to the office of the Russian President, who has previously disappeared on sudden restorative retreats that caused world anxiety about the stability of this troubled nation and its leader. 
 Aside from any perceived slight to the conference officials, his unexpected departure to an undisclosed location heightened the focus on Mr. Yeltsin's executive style and resiliency as he prepared to depart later this week for another trip to the United States.
He will be intent on reassuring the world, at the United Nations and in a White House visit, that Russia deserves moral and economic support as it tries to lead the republics of the fallen Soviet Union in a new Commonwealth of Independent States.
Mr. Yeltsin's chief aides have said they prefer to sacrifice parts of his busy agenda occasionally to see him better prepared for important missions. But the tactic invariably proves unsettling in this crisis-bedeviled land and in the world's stock markets.
Mr. Yeltsin, who received mixed personal reviews in two previous visits to the United States, will resume his Kremlin schedule on Wednesday and meet with Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d, the President's office said.
"Circumstances arose which required his departure from Moscow," his spokesman, Pavel Voshchanov, said, again denying speculation that Mr. Yeltsin might be seriously ill from heart disease or alcohol abuse. "These rumors are absolutely foolish and are being circulated by those who do not want Yeltsin to be Russian President."
His agenda has lately been heavy with the pressures of trying to create a free-market economy from the ashes of Communism. The first step, switching to free-floating consumer prices after 74 years of drastically suppressed prices through state subsidies, has incurred the public wrath and loss of personal popularity that Mr. Yeltsin predicted when he ordered the change on Jan. 2 as an unavoidable necessity.
His other major headache has been in trying to encourage enough economic and military cooperation among republics in the new commonwealth to win some early credit and aid from overseas. Nationalist-minded Ukraine has been confronting Mr. Yeltsin with complaints about the severity and suddenness of his free-market plans and with demands for a substantial part of former Soviet Army and Navy units for building a separate military force.
In again secluding himself, Mr. Yeltsin left his domestic constituency once more speculating on the personality and staying power of their broad-shouldered, mercurial leader, who proved strong enough to stand up to old Communist Party enemies in August and deliver Mikhail S. Gorbachev from a Kremlin coup. The last thing needed by Mr. Yeltsin is another bout of personality scrutiny and increased doubts about his fitness by the world at large.
Although his initial visit to Washington was marred by press charges of buffoonery and bibulousness, Mr. Yeltsin's second visit after his heroic role in the failed coup reflected more favor and respect. One concern that has been omnipresent but rarely mentioned in his public scheduling has been personal security. The Russian President, who admits to concern about vengeful party hard-liners, is sometimes protected by portable shields in public.
Among his canceled appointments today was a meeting with Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe of Japan, whose economic aid Mr. Yeltsin has been seeking. The Interfax news agency said Russian Foreign Ministry officials were insisting that his decision to miss the meeting and head out of the city was mainly because of other pressing issues and not frustration at Japan's linking of foreign aid to regaining four Kurile Islands that were seized by the Soviets at the end of World War II.
 
A Day's Rest Ordered
 In testing the social trauma of his price liberalizations, Mr. Yeltsin undertook an ambitious tour of the Russian provinces this month and was then ordered to take a day's rest by his doctors, with his office insisting that he suffered fatigue but no serious ailment.
In a previous sudden disappearance, his aides said that although Mr. Yeltsin needed treatment for a "minor" heart disorder, he was in good physical condition. The Russian President, who is 60 years old, had previously suffered a back ailment that caused him to withdraw for a while from public life. That established something of a now familiar habit of encouraging a sense of mystery that he might then dispel upon returning with a flourish to deal with a pressing issue.
In some of his most recent tours on state and commonwealth business, members of the Soviet press entourage have said Mr. Yeltsin seemed to be heavily imbibing alcohol at times. His aides have repeatedly rejected such talk. Mr. Yeltsin himself, strapping and ebullient, has been the best defense against such rumors as he often puts in long public days wrangling with Parliament and traveling the republic.
"He is in good health," insisted his spokesman, Mr. Voshchanov. "He's in more than good health. He is in excellent sports condition," the official added, referring to Mr. Yeltsin's playing tennis and volleyball as often as time permits.
 
Absence Is Criticized
 Mr. Yeltsin had not been expected to play an active role in the two-day Middle East peace conference opening here on Tuesday, a meeting conducted at the foreign ministers' level. But some of those arriving for the conference remarked on a certain crudity of timing in the Russian leader's announcement that he must suddenly leave Moscow. They noted as well his missed opportunity to extend a personal early welcome of some sort in the interests of the glaring economic needs of Russia and the other commonwealth members that have been lobbying for extensive foreign aid from many of the nations represented here.
After Mr. Gorbachev resigned as the Soviet President, Russian officials insisted that Mr. Yeltsin would offer the same sort of support and enthusiasm for the conference as did Mr. Gorbachev, its chief proponent. It has been obvious, though, that Mr. Yeltsin has neither the global wanderlust of Mr. Gorbachev nor a cornucopia of diplomatic concessions to offer in return for foreign aid, since considerable ground had already been yielded in disarmament agreements with Washington.
Still, apart from the focus on Mr. Yeltsin's decision to stay out of the Kremlin for the next two days, the arriving American delegation was according considerable credit to the Russian President and the leaders of the three other former Soviet nuclear republics -- Belarus, Ukraine and Kazakhstan -- for carrying out the disarmament treaties.

HEADLINE: Florio's Budget Plan Charts Collision Course With G.O.P.

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Florio administration unveiled a budget today that counts on a turnaround in the economy, a substantial reduction in state payments for pensions, and as-yet-unapproved Federal Medicaid payments to bring it into balance. It also counts on sales tax revenues that the Republicans, who control both houses of the Legislature, have vowed to cut.
The precariously balanced budget is the largest in state history at $15.7 billion -- actually more than $16 billion if an unappropriated buffer of about $300 million is included. It relies heavily on a new formula that would cut state pension contributions and increase the amount to be paid from the investment income of the pension funds.
 
No Drop in Sales Tax
 
 The new formula is used by about half the states, according to the State Treasurer, Samuel Crane, who said the old formula forced the state to shoulder more than its fair share of pension costs while revenues from pension fund investments went disproportionately back into the funds instead of being paid to retirees. The new formula would not affect the size of the pensions themselves.
As expected in the wake of still-smoldering outrage over a $2.8 billion tax increase rushed through the Legislature 19 months ago, the budget includes no additional taxes.
But neither does it include any reduction in projected sales-tax revenues, which means that it does not take into account a promise by the new, veto-proof Republican majority to roll back the one-cent increase in state sales taxes that was part of the 1990 package. The Republicans wrested control of the Legislature from the Democrats who passed the increase by riding a tide of anger over it.
And with the ink barely dry on the proposed budget, a pledge of bipartisan cooperation on the part of the Republican majority that took office last week quickly evaporated.
In a strongly worded message sent to Gov. Jim Florio as the budget was being released, the new Republican Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco of Scotch Plains, vowed that the Senate would not act on any budget proposal that did not include a tax cut.
"I am amazed that Governor Florio is not including a tax cut in his budget message," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "Less than three months ago, the people of New Jersey sent an overwhelming message that they wanted tax relief. It is simply not good enough to tout a budget that leaves record tax increases in place.
"I will not post for a vote in the Senate any budget that does not include meaningful tax relief."
As Senate President, Mr. DiFrancesco has the authority to bring the matter to a vote or bottle it up. His challenge foreshadowed a renewal of the partisan infighting that brought legislation to a virtual halt in the final days of the lame-duck Democratic majority.
Then, rather than pushing for a tax cut, the Republicans did all they could to forestall one. Even though they had campaigned unceasingly against the tax increase, they boycotted legislative sessions in which the Democrats, stunned and angered by their shattering defeat, turned the tables by offering bills to repeal every penny of the $2.8 billion increase, a move that would have left the Republicans desperate for a way to replace the lost revenues.
Since the election, the Republicans have maintained that they never intended to roll back all the taxes, just the one-percentage-point increase in the sales tax to 7 percent, which produced $590 million in revenue.
The Democratic move to roll back the taxes died when even some Democrats declined to engage in such fiscal brinkmanship, leaving the Republicans to mount their charge against taxes again.
Governor Florio is to deliver his budget message to the Legislature Tuesday afternoon, and Republican leaders like Mr. DiFrancesco have vowed to grill administration department heads at length on where they intend to spend money and where cuts can be made. Mr. DiFrancesco has gone so far as to threaten to subpoena department heads to testify if the administration is reluctant to allow them to appear.
"I will not hesitate to draw upon the subpoena powers of the Senate as our committee system conducts its detailed analysis of government programs," Mr. DiFrancesco said. The threat was similar to one issued by the former Democratic Assembly Speaker, Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne, when the Republicans boycotted sessions to frustrate the Democrats' threat to roll back the whole tax package. Mr. Doria said he had authority to send marshals to dragoon recalcitrant legislators back into the chamber. He did not do it.
But while politics dictated talk of tax cuts, fiscal realities demanded that officials find ways to balance a new budget with revenues that are stagnant and show no signs of turning upward despite optimistic predictions.
 
'Modest-Growth' Budget
 In the proposal outlined today, Mr. Crane proposed balancing the "modest-growth" budget for the fiscal year 1993, which begins July 1, with a combination of actuarial revisions in the pension system, requests to the Federal Government for more Medicaid reimbursements, some broad but modest cuts in departmental budgets and prayers for an upswing in the economy.
The budget calls for an increase of $1 billion over the budget for the 1992 fiscal year, to $15.7 billion from $14.7 billion.
Although there is an increase in the overall budget, it promises no new taxes, $425 million more in aid to school districts, subsidies to New Jersey Transit to avoid fare increases, and stabilization of tuition at New Jersey's public colleges and universities to keep increases at or below 4.5 percent. It would also keep the homestead property tax rebate program, a pet of Governor Florio's, intact and fully funded at $685 million.
To raise the money to do all that without a tax increase, the budget counts on cutting operating expenditures in 14 of the state's 19 departments by modest amounts ranging from a tenth of 1 percent to eight-tenths of 1 percent. The agencies for which some growth is planned are Corrections, Military and Veterans Affairs, Law and Public Safety and the Department of the Public Advocate, which polices utility rates and brings suits in the public interest.
The budget also counts on increases of about 5 percent in collections of sales, income and corporate taxes, based on predictions that the economy will significantly grow.
There are two major fiscal changes in the new budget. One is a revaluation of the pension system, which would allow the state to reduce its outlay for pension costs by about $700 million.
This would be accomplished by an actuarial revision in the way the value of pension funds is counted. The new method would use the true, or market, value of the pension, which would let the state increase the amount of pension costs that could be assessed against investment income, thereby decreasing the state's contribution.
Mr. Crane said this could be accomplished without in any way endangering the fiscal health of the state's pension funds, which have a current market value of $29 billion.
While not specifically endorsing the pension fund revaluation as a budget-balancing device, legislative Republicans seemed receptive. Mr. DiFrancesco, for example, said he was pleased that the administration was "exploring all avenues in an effort to solve the fiscal crisis."

HEADLINE: These Tax Cuts Stunt Growth

 BODY:
To judge by advance leaks to reporters, the "growth" tax cuts that President Bush will announce in his State of the Union address tonight and his budget tomorrow will promote precious little growth. Taken individually, they range from inconsequential to destructive. Taken together, they would put billions into undeserving pockets -- and wreck the tax code.
Economic recovery cannot be bought with a mishmash of political handouts. What the economy does need is a swift kick, most easily delivered by a temporary tax cut that doesn't drain away revenues once the economy recovers. For the long term, the economy needs a tax code that favors saving over consumption. Perhaps there's more to the Bush plan than has been leaked, but otherwise, it won't do much to hasten recovery or reform. 
 Mr. Bush reportedly plans to propose tax breaks for middle-class families, capital gains, corporate investment, first-time home buyers and retirement savings. Most of these ideas fail on the merits. In combination, they're worse.
Middle-Class Relief. The President wants to increase personal exemptions, perhaps targeted to children. This idea is triply flawed:
 The tax cuts would be permanent, robbing Congress of revenues desperately needed for infrastructure, children and research.
 Higher exemptions are unfair because they would be worth twice as much to richer families than to families in lower tax brackets.
 The proposal is mistargeted. Middle-class families are suffering because their wages haven't been rising, not because their taxes have been rising. Sluggish wages are a problem of productivity that can only be solved by more investment.
What kind of growth can be expected from a plan that has so much wrong with it?
Retirement Subsidies. Mr. Bush wants to give rich families a tax break on retirement savings already available to low-income families. Properly targeted, and financed, subsidies for savings might be good policy. But Mr. Bush's idea is a gimmick, rigged to produce a deceptive bulge in revenues in the short run -- while creating a huge budget hemorrhage in 5 or 10 years.
At that point, Congress will have to cut back public programs, including investment.
Real Estate Giveaways. Apparently Mr. Bush believes America can reclaim its technological lead by building housing. He proposes to bring back wasteful tax shelters for investors in real estate, the most tax-subsidized industry. He's also expected to propose a subsidy for first-time home buyers. When economists say the U.S. needs more investment, they mean in education, telecommunications, research. Not houses.
Corporate Investment. Here, finally, Mr. Bush seems to be on track. Higher subsidies for corporate investment could promote growth. But even here there's a catch.
He's also reportedly going to propose new subsidies for saving. Putting both ideas together, the President apparently wants corporations to borrow money from tax-subsidized retirement funds in order to make tax-subsidized investments. That's a double subsidy, which could well encourage corporations to buy $100 machines that produce only $90 worth of output.
The error of simultaneously subsidizing savings and investment dramatizes the folly of piecemeal tax reform. That's why Mr. Bush would do better by pledging temporary tax cuts tonight and calling for an expert commission on long-term tax reform to report back to Congress after the November election.
Mr. Bush is likely to propose more than this list of misconceived tax cuts tonight, if only to rehearse his ill-advised capital gains cut. But unless there are some notable surprises, the tax package in his larger program looks perverse: In the name of growth, it would stunt growth.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Clinton Couple

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The Clinton couple of Arkansas have presented to the American public a gift and a testing opportunity.
The gift is that they treated us as adults. The opportunity is for us to act that way. 
 They spoke as individuals but it was as the couple that grew from two personalities that they were most effective -- united without losing separateness and supportive without mawkishness.
In the appearance that "60 Minutes" handled so well they put the responsibility for passing judgment on the Governor's conduct and deciding its consequences where it belonged -- not on the press but on themselves and the American voter.
For themselves, they made it plain that it was up to the Clintons as wife, husband and couple to decide whether whatever happened in their married life that saddened them could and should be repaired. They had made the decision that what gladdened them was more important -- and do not intend to allow anybody else to have a role in their choice.
To the public, which they recognize does have the right to decide the Governor's political future on whatever grounds seem just to the voters, they said there was no 12-year affair -- and that the rest, if there is any, is their own business to deal with. Vote for the Governor if that position satisfies you, said the Clinton couple, do not if you think more should be squeezed out of us.
I think that for now many American voters will accept that position of the Clintons -- particularly his supporters and those of us still considering all options. But "for now" is the easy part.
Suppose some other woman makes a charge of infidelity. It will be printed, or aired.
There is no one such thing as "the American press" but a collection of wildly varying presses. They do their jobs according to the tastes of their editors and owners, and readers. (Here I want to give myself the pleasure of congratulating the editors of The New York Times, in whose decisions I had no part, for playing the news story exactly right. They reported the episode, because to ignore it entirely would have been journalistically pretentious. But they kept the reports conspicuously brief. Disdain for the poison-pen press and its emulators leapt deliciously from the page.)
The poison-pen press, like The Star, Spy and others, exists for three reasons. First, enough Americans will pay for journalistic garbage; it's a market economy out there.
Second: Enough editors, publishers and writers are willing -- eager -- to make whores of themselves to pro duce salable nastiness. Their reward is to be noticed -- worth more to them than the cash fee for their services.
And sadly, there are enough mainstream "journalists" and publishers who through fear or admiration give the nasties the publicity and social acceptance they need to get attention for their poison product.
I can think of only two ways to put the vermin of the printed and electronic press out of business. One would be to rewrite in practice or law the Constitution they so demean; forget it, that would give them too much pleasure and notice. The other is to stop buying the garbage publications and click off garbage programs. Easy, and results guaranteed.
Until then, any new charge against Mr. Clinton will find a buyer. Now the difficult part: Suppose it has some portion of truth. I raise the theoretical possibility not through any knowledge but because the Clinton couple straightforwardly said thus far and no further about sexual questions and because the "gotchas" are hard at work to trap them.
If so, what then? Will we condemn the Governor without a trial? More important, will we demand a trial at all -- the print and TV sexual examination that is the monument to American immaturity and prurience?
I know there are voters who do believe that a President should have what they consider a spotless sexual history. Personally the only candidate for public office I would automatically disqualify on sexual grounds would be a rapist or a virgin.
But we can at least treasure the hope that Americans would be fed up with the slavering inquisition on politicians' sexual history and say to hell with that and the torturers. That would be a thank-you card worthy of the gift from the Clinton couple -- the presumption that Americans have achieved adulthood, at last.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Before Much Longer

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
"Welcome, election fans, to 'Meet the Adulterer,' the Emmy-Award-winning news show that lets Presidential candidates tell their own revolting stories of squalid and sordid conduct with models, actresses, bimbos and --"
"Hold it right there, fella. I categorically deny ever having had a relationship with a bimbo. What's more, even if I had, under no circumstances would I ever refer to any woman by a viciously sexist word like 'bimbo.' I am here to tell America candidly and entertainingly about adultery and me, not to be smeared as a sexist." 
 "Just a minute, Governor --"
"What's more, I am not a governor. Don't you even bother to find out who your guests are?"
"We do indeed, sir, and we know you are a Presidential candidate with a squalid, sordid, entertaining story of adultery in your background. Having to confess to a nationwide television audience must make you feel deeply ashamed."
"Not deeply, no. If she'd been one of those women who got rich off tax breaks handed out by Reagan-Bush trickle-down economics, you can bet I'd be deeply ashamed. But she wasn't. What's more, she was a woman who had never accepted a single welfare check either."
"You are saying --"
"She was middle-class."
"So the shame you feel is not deep shame?"
"Moderate shame is the way to describe it. Middle-of-the-road shame."
"You are aware, I suppose, of the allegations made by certain newspapers available at the supermarket?"
"You mean the vile accusation that I committed this adultery despite having heard the woman speak passionately at a hotel bar against a national health-care program? That is a despicable concoction which I categorically --"
"Don't change the subject, Mr. Candidate. You know the allegations I'm talking about: The grocery papers say your adultery story is a complete fabrication, that in fact you have never in your life engaged in hanky-panky --"
"That is a damnable lie which I categorically --"
"-- that with all the other candidates getting great TV exposure on shows like Emmy-Award-winning 'Meet the Adulterer,' you were afraid Americans wouldn't notice you were even running --"
"A lie which I categorically --"
"-- or worse, that they'd think you were a dull old homebody."
"I categorically deny being a dull old homebody."
"In that case, sir, you will want to give our viewers the kind of details the other candidates have provided so we can judge their credibility."
"No names. I will not reveal any names."
"Because of some quaint, old-fashioned philosophy about gentlemen not telling?"
"Now listen here, fella: I told you once I'm here to talk adultery. Why do you try to smear me by alleging I'm a gentleman?"
"You deny you're a gentleman?"
"Sordid detail is my game; let's get to it."
"All right, first the question we ask every candidate: Did you or did you not at any time before, during or after the illicit congress tell your adulterous partner you loved her?"
"Never. At some time during the proceedings, however, I definitely remember saying, 'Ma'am, I heard you tell those folks at the hotel bar that the present white-collar unemployment rate is a disgrace to this country, and I loved every word of it.' "
"Answer the question: Was that remark made before, during or after the illicit congress?"
"During. It must have been during. I'd never make a remark that personal to a woman before, and afterward the only possible thing to say is, 'I still respect you.' "
"Do you expect America to believe you didn't take advantage of that moment to tell your feminine friend your program for world peace?"
"Absolutely not. All I did was offer her a stick of chewing gum, then peeled one for myself, and we both chewed hopefully."
"Hopefully? What were you hoping?"
"I was hoping if the grocery press got this story they wouldn't get it wrong and say we'd had a smoke because if there's one thing the American voter won't stand for, it's a smoker."

HEADLINE: New York City Schools Can't Afford Any More Budget Cuts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was appointed to the New York City Board of Education on July 1, 1990 -- a little more than 19 months ago. It was an exciting time for me. After all, it was a predominantly new board -- five new members out of seven, mostly women, significant Latino representation for the first time in the history of the board, an outspoken Republican member, a Parent-Teacher Association activist and generally a good mix of committed people who wanted to change the school system so that all of our students could succeed 
 In addition, the Board of Education boasted a new Schools Chancellor in Joseph A. Fernandez, who was making sweeping changes to a system that James Gill called a "lumbering dinosaur." I had big hopes for the New York City schools. After all, we had an education President in Washington, a Governor in Albany who spoke reverently about the Decade of the Child and a New York City Mayor who had dedicated his administration to children.
What could possibly go wrong?
We all know what went wrong -- a sagging economy and the necessity for tough decisions.
Our public officials had to establish priorities -- and, unfortunately, the priority rating that we all thought would be accorded to education never materialized.
Since I took office, since this new dynamic Board of Education became a reality in July 1990, we have been forced to cut and cut and cut again. Thanks to the sacrifices our employees have made, and thanks to the creativity and hard work of the board, and of the Chancellor, we have been able at least to hold our ground.
But now the state and the city are talking about more cuts to education, cuts that would set education back immeasurably, far surpassing the pain we felt in the 1970's, from which our schools have yet to recover.
We must say no to the savaging of the school system. Our schools and our children deserve to be held in the same high regard as the Police Department, which has escaped budget cuts because of its high priority.
Not until all of the public officials who talk about their commitment to children begin to finance our children's education, will our students enjoy the bright future I envisioned for them when I became a board member.
 
CAROL A. GRESSER
Brooklyn, Jan. 15, 1992

HEADLINE: MACY'S ASKS COURT TO PROVIDE SHIELD AGAINST CREDITORS

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
R. H. Macy & Company, the proud retail business whose executives confidently took on billions in debt in the late 1980's, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, finally admitting defeat in its bruising battle with creditors and the deteriorating economy.
At a brief noontime meeting, the company's board voted unanimously to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Several board members, including Laurence A. Tisch, whose Loews Corporation had tried to prop up Macy with a $1 billion buyout plan, participated by telephone. 
 The decision puts another one of the nation's largest and best-known retailing chains into the humbling position of seeking court protection to keep its creditors at bay. It also leaves another group of suppliers and investors with little to show for their faith and scant hopes of getting all their money back.
 
 
'Best for Macy's Future'
 In bankruptcy, Macy's will conduct business as usual at its flagship store on 34th Street in Manhattan, as well as at its 250 other Macy's, Bullock's and I. Magnin department stores and small specialty chains throughout the country. The protection of bankruptcy court puts Macy's creditors on hold until its executives can draw up a plan to give the company a more manageable balance between its cash flow and costs. That will allow Macy to reduce its $3.6 billion debt load significantly and restore its balance sheet so that it can meet its obligations without resorting to the borrowing it has used to keep its business going over the last year.
"We worked day and night to find a suitable solution and ultimately came to the conclusion that filing for Chapter 11 was best for Macy's future," Edward S. Finkelstein, Macy's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement issued yesterday. "I am convinced that beginning this rehabilitative process is the best way to protect our valuable franchise."
 
Tisch Plan Fell Through
 The Chemical Banking Corporation and Bankers Trust Company are providing $600 million in short-term financing that Macy will use to pay for merchandise, utility bills, wages and salaries for its 69,500 employees and other operating expenses.
The filing became all but inevitable when the Tisch plan fell through late Friday. With nothing but bankruptcy on the table late Saturday afternoon, Macy's executives left their offices and let the company's lawyers and investment bankers take over the assembling of legal documents and financing needed to file for bankruptcy.
Under the first step in the bankruptcy proceeding, Macy will ask Judge Burton R. Lifland for permission to make pension and payroll payments, retain lawyers and accountants and use current bank accounts.
The "debtor in possession" financing provided by Chemical Bank and Bankers Trust will not be available for 15 days. In the meantime, the judge will arrange interim financing.
The papers filed by Macy's lawyers yesterday with the Federal Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York show the company has $4.9 billion in assets and $5.3 billion in liabilities.
A panoply of bondholders, banks, building contractors and garment manufacturers are Macy's largest unsecured creditors. The biggest are Macy's junk bondholders, who are collectively owed $1.6 billion. The next largest are Alexander & Alexander, an insurance company that Macy's owes $6.3 million, and Kraus-Anderson Construction of Minneapolis, which is owed $1.6 million.
Although the law gives Macy up to 120 days to formulate a plan for getting its business back into working order and 60 more days to seek its creditors' approval for the plan, judges often extend those periods.
"We estimate that this will be not longer than a two-year process, and that the bondholders will receive about 60 cents on the dollar at the conclusion," said Jack Hersch, an analyst who follows bankrupt companies for Lehman Brothers. "We would also expect to see Macy emerge with a far healthier balance sheet."
 
Fate of Management
 Bankruptcy law favors keeping the management team in place if possible, and since Mr. Finkelstein, Mark S. Handler, the company's president and chief operating officer, and many of the top managers are highly regarded merchants, they are likely to keep their offices on the 13th floor of Macy's flagship store.
But bankruptcy will likely force them to focus more than ever on the financial side of their business. "They belong to the old school of the retailing business, which attends to the merchandising assortment but not the business fundamentals," said Kurt Barnard, a retail consultant. "They may be somewhat uncomfortable with the financial requirements of bankruptcy."
The fate of Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade and the other promotional events it sponsors rests in Judge Lifland's hands, and few analysts could imagine that the judge would want to be remembered as the villain who put those institutions to death. A Macy's spokesman said that the company would try to demonstrate that the parade and other Macy events contribute to the company's franchise.
Founded in 1858 by Rowland Hussey Macy, a Nantucket whaler whose previous six attempts at retailing failed miserably, Macy's built an empire and a reputation for department store merchandising that has been copied by many competitors. But no amount of merchandising magic was able to overcome a recession and the debt Macy took on in the late 1980's.
Macy borrowed heavily to go private in a $3.5 billion management buyout in 1986 and then it added more debt when it bought the two West Coast chains, Bullock's and I. Magnin, for $1.1 billion in 1988.
The buyout gave Mr. Finkelstein and the other executives a bigger stake in the company, but they are now likely to lose almost all of their original investment.
A report by Raz Kafri, David Teolis and Jack Hersch of Lehman Brothers estimates that holders of Macy's common shares -- company officers, managers and directors -- can only expect to recoup 2 percent of their investments after bankruptcy.
The preferred stockholders, a group including subsidiaries of the General Electric Corporation and Loews, are likely to get only 8 percent of the value of their shares, the analysts estimate.
Several apparel manufacturers said yesterday that they were relieved Macy had filed for bankruptcy protection. Many have delayed shipments to Macy because they were afraid they would not get paid if the retailer filed for bankruptcy.
Those suppliers who are due payments from I. Magnin and Bullock's are likely to be paid in full after the company emerges from bankruptcy. But analysts at Lehman Brothers said those manufacturers who are owed money by Macy's department stores may only get 55 cents on the dollar, because of a provision in the original buyout agreement.
"This was something they needed to do for a long time," said Morris Marmalstein, chairman of the Warren Group, a collection of dress manufacturing companies.
Mr. Marmalstein said he had made partial shipments to Macy during the last month but would now ship everything the company ordered.
It was Macy's inability to pay manufacturers like Mr. Marmalstein that forced it to take the bankruptcy step.
Macy's desperate situation became apparent when the company told its suppliers it would be two weeks late with payments due on Jan. 10. The terms of its revolving credit line required Macy to keep its borrowing below $150 million for 30 consecutive days, and it could not satisfy that requirement and pay the companies that make the merchandise sold in its stores.
Macy's, which rang up $6.7 billion of sales during its fiscal year ended Aug. 3, 1991, was strapped for cash.
Yesterday's court papers described the 1991 holiday selling season as "the Christmas that never came."
During the next two weeks, Sir Run Run Shaw, a Hong Kong investor in Macy's, offered to give the company a $250 million loan that would allow it to pay its bills. But Macy's institutional lenders, whose loans to the retailer are backed by its stores and inventory, refused to share that collateral with Sir Run Run and the deal fell through.
The same banks and insurance companies that had seemed so willing to renegotiate and waive the restrictions on Macy's loans in December suddenly seemed to get cold feet.
 
Pattern Held True
 That seemed to hold true last week when Mr. Tisch, chairman and chief executive of Loews and a big Macy shareholder, proposed that Loews buy the company for more than $1 billion.
When the board assembled on Friday afternoon to consider the Tisch proposal, the only other option on the table was bankruptcy, an option Mr. Finkelstein had vowed to avoid since late 1989 when Macy's losses began mounting and the specter of bankruptcy first emerged.
The meeting was somber and sad, even before word came that Loews and the Prudential Insurance Company of America had failed to agree on new terms to refinance the $811 million mortgage the insurer held on dozens of Macy's stores. With no plan to vote on, the board decided to meet yesterday on a bankruptcy filing.
On Saturday, analysts and consultants speculated Prudential would buckle to pressure and return to the table. But Mr. Tisch flew to Minneapolis early Sunday for the Super Bowl, and Prudential never returned to the bargaining table.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Win or Lose, Buyouts Do It Big

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The bankruptcy filing of R. H. Macy & Company represents yet another leveraged buyout gone bad. But while the list of leveraged failures is long, the list of leveraged successes is also substantial.
Safeway, the supermarket chain; Duracell, the battery maker; American Medical International, which owns hospitals, and RJR Nabisco, the largest leveraged buyout ever, have succeeded despite the huge debts they took on. Among the companies that went from buyout to bankruptcy are Federated Department Stores, the parent of Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus; Jim Walter, a leading home builder; Southland, the owner of the 7-Eleven stores, and Interco, a shoe and furniture company.
 
Mitigating Factors
 Luck played a part in which group a company ended up in. It is not Macy's fault that the economy entered a prolonged period of weakness just as the company needed to improve cash flow. But there is also the matter of timing, and of the rising optimism through much of the 1980's. In general, leveraged purchases in the last years of the decade were made at much higher prices than those earlier in the decade. It was not impossible to make a good deal in 1987, but it was highly unlikely. 
 The Gibson Greetings deal, one of the first big leveraged buyout successes and one that caught the eye of Wall Street when it provided huge profits to investors, was in fact a rather conservative one when it was done in 1981. Its financial statements showed it had cash flow more than twice what would be needed to meet its interest obligations, even if business did not improve.
But from 1986 on, many junk bond issues, most of them intended to pay for acquisitions, had financial statements that showed the company was not taking in enough money to meet its projected interest payments, according to a study by Barrie Wigmore of Goldman, Sachs & Company. It was assumed that business would improve, and in some cases that subsidiaries would be sold off, at a fast enough rate to allow the company to meet its obligations.
The highly leveraged companies left over from that credit expansion have now been broadly divided by lenders and investors into two groups. In the first group, deemed successful, the companies have been able to go public by selling stock if they wished. Many have also been able to refinance their debt, taking advantage of lower interest rates.
It is the second group that has suffered as lenders have refused to make new loans. Part of Macy's debt is a 12 percent mortgage on at least 70 of the retailer's stores, owed to the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Mortgage rates for creditworthy customers are now far lower, but Macy cannot get the lower rates. Prudential refused last week to cut the interest rate on the mortgage, citing its obligations to policyholders, which led Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of Loews and CBS and a Macy director, to withdraw an offer to refinance the company.
In that regard, Macy is like an unemployed homeowner with a 12 percent mortgage. The homeowner can no longer meet interest payments, and because he is out of work cannot persuade a bank to refinance his mortgage at lower rates. His employed neighbor, who can afford higher payments, will be able to get a new loan from the bank at a lower rate.
There is nothing mysterious about the basic structure of a leveraged buyout. A company is purchased, as in any buyout, although in a leveraged deal virtually all the money is borrowed. As in any buyout, the eventual success or failure depends largely on whether the future operations of the company are profitable enough to justify the price paid. A difference is that the more leverage is used, the less room there is for error in forecasting.
A key factor in separating the winners from the losers is whether a company had dependable cash flows. RJR Nabisco succeeded in part because smokers kept buying cigarettes as prices were raised. "Highly cyclical companies are terrible candidates for an LBO," said Artur Raviv, a finance professor at Northwestern University. He pointed to the bankruptcy of the USG Group, the former U.S. Gypsum, a company heavily dependent on home construction.
But some cyclical buyouts worked, reflecting lower purchase prices and perhaps better luck. "One of the great successes of the 1980's was Cain Chemical," said James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer and a harsh critic of many buyouts.
Macy itself might by now have been deemed a winner had it gone through just one highly leveraged transaction, rather than two. The first deal was in 1986, when Macy went private in a $3.5 billion buyout led by its management. It had a large amount of debt but also an operating cushion so large that in the fiscal year ended Aug. 1, 1987, the first after the buyout, cash flow was enough to cover all interest expenses, plus capital spending -- with $54 million left over.
Then came the 1988 bidding war for Federated Department Stores, fought by Macy and the Campeau Corporation, controlled by Robert Campeau, a Canadian financier. As the price escalated, some people said that whoever won would be paying too much. That did not quell the frenzy, and in the end, a deal was struck. Campeau won most of the company but Macy got what it most coveted, the California-based Bullock's and I. Magnin chains, for $1.1 billion.
It took less than a year for Campeau to fail, and its stores, which include Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, went through bankruptcy proceedings in a pattern that is likely to be repeated with Macy. The stores remained open, but the owners changed. It is likely that Macy creditors, from bondholders to banks, will end up owning most of the stock in a reorganized Macy. Current shareholders will see their stakes sharply reduced, and perhaps eliminated.
In late 1990 and early 1991, those shareholders were willing to step up and make new investments, giving Macy the money to buy back some bonds at greatly reduced prices. This year, after another 12 months of poor results, they were not willing to invest any more.
As the Federated debacle was unfolding, Macy's chairman, Edward S. Finkelstein, liked to emphasize that his company, unlike Campeau, was run by merchandisers who understood retailing. But his financiers underestimated the degree to which cash flow could suffer if consumers turned cautious.
"Taking note that the consumer led us out of the recession in 1982, investment bankers and investors embraced the belief that consumer-oriented LBO's would show sufficient growth to meet aggressive debt schedules," said Mariel Clemensen, the director of high-yield bond research at Lehman Brothers. "But the consumer is in no position to lead us out of the current recession."
That fact, as much as any overpaying, helps to explain why Macy is now in bankruptcy.

R.H. MACY & CO.
 Currently operating more than 251 stores, including the I. Magnin and Bullock's chains, Macy sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. Most of the debts stemmed from Macy's $3.5 billion leveraged buyout by management in 1986 and subsequent $1.1 billion purchase of I. Magnin and Bullock's.
 
FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES
 The operator of 140 stores including the Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Lazarus chains, Federated failed to pay interest on loans after Campeau Corp. of Canada bought the company in 1988 for $6.6 billion. Federated filed for Chapter 11 protection in January 1990 along with Allied Stores Corp. They are expected to emerge from bankruptcy in mid-February.
 
ALLIED STORES
 Currently operating 82 stores, including the Bon Marche and Stern's, Allied failed to make interest payments after Campaeu Corp. bought it for $3.4 billion in 1986. Allied filed for Chapter 11 in January 1990 along with Federated.
 
CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES
 Carter Hawley Hale currently operates 88 stores, including Broadway and Emporium chains based in California. It failed to make payments on $1.3 billion in debt from 1987 restructuring undertaken to fend off takeover bid by Limited Inc. It filed for Chapter 11 in February 1991.
 
REVCO D.S.
 The 1,141 unit drugstore chain, currently operating in 10 states, was unable to make interest payments on debt from $1.25 billion leveraged buyout in 1986. It filed for Chapter 11 in July 1988. Creditors have failed to approve a reorganization plan. Rival drugstore retailer Jack Eckerd Corp. has offered to buy Revco for $925 million.
 
AMES DEPARTMENT STORES
 Ames, a discount chain operating 371 stores in 15 states, was unable to handle debt after buying the Zayre discount store chain for $788 million in 1988. It filed for Chapter 11 in April 1990 and hopes to emerge from Chapter 11 this year.
 
HILLS DEPARTMENT STORES
 Currently operating 154 stores in 12 states, Hills was unable to handle remaining debt from $637 million leveraged buyout in 1985. It filed for Chapter 11 in February 1991. (Source: Associated Press)
