SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1480 words

HEADLINE: ARAB-ISRAEL ON REGIONAL ISSUES START IN MOSCOW

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 28

 BODY:
A Middle East conference opened here today, with Israel for the first time sitting down for talks on regional cooperation with Saudi Arabia and the other Arab gulf countries, but the meeting was overshadowed by the Palestinians' absence.
The Palestinian spokeswoman, Hanan Ashrawi, said the Palestinians were barred from the conference by the United States and Russia, who objected to the presence of Palestinians from East Jerusalem and from outside the West Bank and Gaza Strip. 
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said it was the Palestinians who had refused to come according to the terms set out in the invitation, and he added that he was "disappointed" that they had missed yet another opportunity to advance their cause.
 
A Lot of New Faces
 The opening day of the conference was full of unusual scenes and contradictory emotions. The setting of the meeting was bizarre: 24 countries gathered in food-strapped Moscow in the dead of winter -- in the same Hall of Columns where the Stalin show trials were conducted in 1938 -- to discuss regional development of the Mideast.
The discussions themselves seemed to combine some strikingly dramatic signs that the age-old Arab-Israeli conflict was thawing -- and some very strained speeches that suggested it might not be changing much after all.
 
'Who Would Have Imagined?'
 Today's high point may have come when the co-chairmen, Mr. Baker and the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, gaveled the conference to order and looked out to see sitting before them around a rectangular table a lot of people who have never sat together before: Russians and Americans co-sponsoring a peace conference, the foreign ministers of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait sitting alongside Israelis, and China and Japan for the first time joining Mideast peace talks. China's Deputy Foreign Minister, Yang Fuchang, went out of his way to walk across the room and warmly embrace Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy.
"Look around you, ladies and gentlemen, at the parties who are gathered at this table," Secretary Baker told his fellow delegates. "Who would have imagined even five years ago that the United States would launch a new partnership with a democratizing Russia?"
The American and Russian co-sponsors envisaged this two-day conference as a vehicle to open a dialogue between Israel and the wider circle of Arab countries -- Tunisia, Mauritania, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Oman, Kuwait, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates -- about regional problems like arms control, water, the environment, refugees and economic development.
Algeria and Yemen had planned to attend but did not show up once it became apparent the Palestinians were not coming. The Syrians and Lebanese had never planned to attend the meeting and urged the other Arabs to join them, but they would not.
The hope of the co-sponsors is that if Israel can be drawn into negotiations with the wider Arab world, this will demonstrate to the Israeli public the potential for real acceptance around the region and therefore make Israel more willing to trade land for peace with Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and the Palestinians in their separate negotiations, which were started in Madrid and are being dealt with separately from this conference.
When the United States and the Soviet Union invited Arabs and Israelis to open direct peace talks in Madrid last October, the invitation included plans for a multinational conference that would follow two weeks later. It was also envisaged that it would be held in Moscow, but because of several technical problems it was delayed.
In the meantime, the direct talks begun in Madrid between Israel and Jordan, Israel and Syria, Israel and Lebanon, and Israel and the Palestinians were followed up by two rounds in Washington, one in December and one in mid-January.
 
Moderation and Stubbornness
 Today's session was confined to 10-minute speeches by each country, and the Arab delegates made it immediately clear that they had no intention of engaging in any serious regional cooperation with Israel until the Palestinians were brought into the process and Israel agreed to trade land for peace with its immediate neighbors.
Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, Saud al-Faisal, like all the Arabs present, gave a low-key, relatively moderate speech. He nevertheless captured the mood of the Arab delegations when he declared that no matter what statements were made here today, "We cannot make or attain specific progress if Arab lands continue to be occupied and the Palestinian people continue to be deprived of their right of self-determination."
The speech by the Israeli Foreign Minister, Mr. Levy, was also generally conciliatory, but made clear that Israel viewed regional cooperation with the Arab world as something that could and should progress independently of talks over territory with Israel's immediate neighbors.
 
Levy, Alone
 None of the Arab ministers, save for Egypt, applauded Mr. Levy's speech, or spoke with him. The standoffishness was symbolized by Maj. Gen. Amram Mitzna, Chief of Planning for the Israeli Army and a member of the Israeli delegation, who was taking photographs with his Instamatic camera of Jordanians seated next to him, but was too uncertain to speak to them.
The chilly atmosphere between Arabs and Israelis was inadvertantly summed up by Mr. Yang. Trying to express the idea that no one should expect progress overnight, he said: "As the Chinese saying goes, 'It takes more than one cold day for the river to freeze three feet deep.' "
 
Who Is a 'Palestinian'?
 The dispute that kept the Palestinians away is likely to bedevil this conference, as well as the separate Arab-Israeli negotiations.
The Palestinians insist that their delegation be made up of a cross-section of their community: Palestinians from East Jerusalem, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, and from the refugee diaspora abroad. The Israelis insisted, and the United States and Russia backed them up, that the rules of the Madrid conference applied here, and therefore the only Palestinians with whom Israelis have to negotiate are Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza.
The Palestinians countered that just because they had made a pragmatic compromise in Madrid, accepting Israel's terms in order to begin separate talks on Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, that did not mean that at this conference to discuss broader regional questions, they should make the same compromise.
 
A Compromise Rejected, Twice
 Mrs. Ashrawi, the Palestinian spokeswoman, said during a news conference outside the conference hall: "We wanted to address the world and speak out on behalf of all the Palestinians people, but unfortunately we were excluded."
At the eleventh hour, Mr. Baker offered the Palestinians a deal: He added refugees to the list of regional issues to be discussed in the working-group negotiations, which are to be set up tomorrow, and said the United States would back the Palestinians' demand to send diaspora representatives to such a session. The Palestinians said this was not enough.
Mr. Levy immediately rejected this proposal, too, saying: "If those whose participation we object to do arrive and if this runs counter to the agreement, they will meet by themselves."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Protests Among Arabs
 BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 28 (Special to The New York Times) -- Syria condemned the talks in Moscow today, thousands of Palestinians in Lebanon went on strike demanding a boycott of the conference and pro-Iranian Muslim fundamentalists staged sit-ins at mosques here to oppose what they termed "the negotiations of capitulation."
The Syrian Information Minister, Mohammed Salman, said in an interview published in the Beirut daily Al Sharq that the talks would only play into Israel's hands. "How can there be discussions on regional issues when no progress had been achieved at bilateral negotiations," he asked.
Israel also announced that it was sending reinforcements to what it calls its security zone in southern Lebanon to head off what an army spokesman described as "terrorist attacks" and possible violence by guerrillas of the Iranian-sponsored Party of God.
Fundamentalist soldiers of the "Islamic Resistance Movement," led by the Party of God, killed one Israeli soldier and wounded another in a raid inside the zone last Sunday.
Clerics who lead the Party of God told worshipers at a mosque in the Bir al Abed quarter in Beirut's southern suburbs that holy war "against Israel and America must be stepped up." Sheikh Abbas Musawi, the party's general secretary, said Israel and the United States would use the talks "to tighten their hegemony over the Arab and Islamic worlds."
In Palestinian refugee districts in Lebanon, marchers protested and shops and schools were closed.

GRAPHIC: Photos: As the Middle East peace talks got under way yesterday in Moscow, David Levy, left, the Israeli Foreign Minister, sat near Kamal Abu Jaber, at left center, the Jordanian Foreign Minister. (pg. A1); Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister David Levy of Israel greeting each other as the Middle East peace talks got under way. At the right was Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia. (pg. A8) (Reuters)
 
Chart: "The Process So Far"
 
ROUND 1: MADRID
 
Dates: Oct. 30-Nov. 3, 1991
 
Taking part: Seionr officials of Israel, Lebanon, Syria and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. Sponsored by the United States and the Soviet Union.
 
Purpose: Get the process started.
 
The parties met together for the first time, thanks to compromises on the format and on the makeup of the joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. Talks between Israel and Lebanon and Israel and the Jordanian-Palestinian delegation were cordial, but those between Israel and Syria quickly bogged down.
 
ROUNDS 2 AND 3: WASHINGTON
 
Dates: Dec. 10-19, 1991 and Jan. 13-16, 1992
 
Taking part: Same parties as in Madrid.
 
Purpose: One-on-one talks on substantive issues.
 
The Israelis arrived nearly a week late in December, saying they had not been fully consulted on the dates. Talks between Israel and the Palestinians could not get past arguments over procedure, and the Israelis went home again after 10 futile days. When talks were to resume in January, it was the Arabs who came a week late, waiting until after a United Nations vote to censure Israel for expelling a group of Palestinians. This time the Israelis and Palestinians managed to agree on procedure but made little progress on substantive issues.
 
ROUND 4: MOSCOW
 
Dates: Began yesterday.
 
Taking part: Israel, Jordan, eight other Arab governments, Turkey, the European Community, China, Japan and other nations, but not Syria, Lebanon or the Palestinians.
 
Purpose: Multinational discussion of regional issues.
 
The conference was originally to take place shortly after Madrid, but was delayed. The Palestinians wanted to include delegates from East Jerusalem and from outside the West Bank and Gaza. When the co-sponsors, Russia and the United States, would not agree, the Palestinians decided not to attend the talks.

LENGTH: 1696 words

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION;
Transcript of Democratic Reply by House Speaker

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Following is the transcript of remarks last night by Thomas S. Foley, the House Speaker, for the Democratic response to the State of the Union Message, as recorded by The New York Times.
My fellow Americans:
Tonight I speak for the Democratic Party. But I also speak for working families and the middle class; for those who worked hard to move ahead, but now find themselves falling behind; for so many of strength and spirit and skill who watch with increasing uncertainty as so many of their hopes have been threatened. 
 This should be America's high noon.
But instead, after winning both a war in the Persian Gulf a year ago and the historic struggle of the last half century against Communism, we face an ominous, persistent recession which reminds us anew of President Kennedy's warning that "this nation cannot be strong abroad if it is weak at home."
At home in America today, thousands wait on a frozen morning outside a hotel in Chicago for just a chance to apply for a job, no matter what the work or wages.
At home in America today, the largest auto maker in the world, which once seemed to be the most secure of all corporations, announces that it will have to lay off 75,000 people in order to survive.
 
Hammers Average Earnings
 At home in America today, the average earnings increase of our workers has declined from first in the world to 10th. This year, millions more of our workers find themselves unemployed and their family's health uninsured. Many state governments are slashing education and other services and raising taxes. The nations whose freedom we protected in the past continue to surpass us in high paying jobs and the industries of the future.
The standard of living of the American people is a first and fundamental measure of the state of the American union.
So the urgent, overriding task of 1992 is to restore growth and jobs. And the great challenge of the 1990's is to reclaim our industrial edge, revive our economic leadership and make America once more the most prosperous and powerful economy on earth.
For too long we were told to wait -- that things would get better on their own. There was even an effort to talk us out of the recession -- or to tell us that it wasn't really happening at all.
But the truth finally became all too painful -- and all too clear. The supply-side, trickle-down decade of the 1980's finally led to an economy in decline, and left us month after month with a national Administration adrift in domestic policy, seemingly without ideas and without apparent commitment or energy to move America ahead.
In the midst of this recession, the Administration even resisted extending unemployment benefits; Congress had to pass it three times last year before the President would sign it. Today, before the President had sent his message, Congress took action to renew that extension, and we now welcome the President's support.
 
A Democratic Tax Cut
 For many months, Democrats have set forth an agenda for change. We have proposed a tax cut for the middle class to help lift the consumer demand that fuels our economy. We have demanded policies to bring down the trade barriers that lock American products out of markets from Europe to Asia. We've called for national health insurance to make health care a fundamental right of all Americans.
Here too we will seek common ground with the President -- and the Republicans. To achieve all this and more, we will work with him and with them to do what is best for the country.
But we will also stand our ground when basic principles are at stake. We will not agree to do the wrong thing simply for the sake of doing something. In short, we seek a fundamental change from the unsuccessful economic policies of the past 12 years.
When we say a middle-class tax cut, we mean exactly that. Not more of the tax cuts of the 1980's, which gave most of the benefits to the very few and left most of our people actually paying more in taxes.
We will insist that this time, the benefits must go to working families, not to the privileged.
We will insist that a middle-class tax cut be paid for not by taking money that should go to schools and health care, but by calling on the richest of our citizens, at long last, to pay their fair share.
 
Seeds of the Recession
 We will oppose any efforts to misuse the present crisis as an excuse to repeat the worst errors of the last decade. Then we sowed the seeds of the recession we are now in; we must not go down that path again.
During the past two Administrations, there have been consistent efforts to undo government protection of public health and safety. Today, the hurt of the unemployed is no excuse to undermine regulatory rules that protect their families and all of us from pollution, deceptive advertising, unsafe food and medicine, workplace injury and death. This is not a way to create jobs or make American business prosperous.
Nor will we accept the kind of capital gains tax cut that will lead largely to accelerated profit-taking, not accelerated investment. One can play a lot of games with statistics, but the bottom line is that two-thirds of all the money from the Administration's capital gains tax cut would go to the richest 1 percent of taxpayers. Instead, we need targeted incentives to reward companies that build and buy now -- that hire instead of laying-off.
The President said tonight that when you aim at the well off you usually hit the little guy. The truth is, for 12 years they have been promising to help the little guy and then giving all the breaks to the well off, and it is time that that stopped. As Democrats our purpose is not just to end this recession but to begin a new time of economic growth and progress.
So we will propose a new commitment to civilian technology and research. For half a century American weapons were the best in the world; as we enter the new century, America must build the best consumer and industrial products.
 
Seeking Open Markets
 We will pursue a trade policy that opens markets on equal terms so that when we buy from Europe and Asia they will be buying from us as well. We will demand far-reaching changes in education and training so that our students will be the first, not the last, among the industrial nations in science and math -- and so our workers will have the skills and the chance to compete successfully with anyone, anywhere.
We will also fight for fundamental change in the area of health care.
Today, millions of Americans have no health insurance at all -- and even those who do have no assurance that they're safe. People worry that if they get sick their coverage will be canceled. Premiums and out-of-pocket costs continue to multiply. Workers who lose their jobs suddenly find their children without health insurance.
This issue will be a test of our national character.
Few Americans realize that the United States and South Africa are the only economically advanced nations that do not guarantee the health care of their people.
We will fight to change that in this Congress -- and in the next one -- as long as it takes -- because lives and health are at stake, and so is the financial health of America's families.
It is not enough to make minor changes, to tinker with the edges while tolerating basic flaws. We want to replace the status quo, not protect it. We want to help the middle-class family, not tax its health care benefits.
It is time for national health insurance. It is time to cover every American. It is time to control costs. Because otherwise we will continue to pay more and more for less and less.
And soon the burden will break the budgets of middle-class families, of business and of government at every level.
Health care is one of the great unfinished tasks of our society. Almost 60 years ago America decided that people should age with dignity -- and we passed Social Security. Now we must decide that families will live with dignity -- and pass national health insurance.
Finally there are other, urgent issues of basic justice that also go to our character as a nation.
So we will oppose any effort from any quarter to widen and exploit racial division -- or lessen our commitment to break down the barriers and at long last fulfill the pledge that millions of us make every day, from the schoolhouses of America to the floor of the House of Representatives: that we shall be "one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all." Appeals to race should have no place in our politics or our national life.
 
Civil Rights Promise
 We will stand for another civil right of every American -- the civil right to be protected from violence and crime.
Election after election, we hear tough talk; this year we will pass tougher laws if the President will ask the Republicans in the Senate to stop filibustering the crime bill that has already been passed by the House of Representatives. We will stand -- and we will fight -- for a woman's right to choose. If the Supreme Court removes the guarantee of choice from the Constitution of the United States, this Congress will write it into the laws of the United States.
We will stand for day care and family leave, so that workers who take time off to help a sick parent or child will no longer risk their jobs.
In closing, let me reaffirm our essential resolve -- which is to make America work again. For when the economy is wrong, nothing else is right.
We cannot undo all the mistakes of the past 12 years in a single year, or in a single Congress. The Administration has waited a long time to act. Over and over we have said we can fight this recession, and we will.
We can change this nation fundamentally, and we have to.
It is true the cold war is over; the old world is past; the ways of thinking and leading will not do.
It is time now to turn our attention to our own land and to our own people, to rebuild its economic strength and standard of life, to master the very different challenges of this new era.
Only a few times have Americans stood at so decisive a turning point. Now, with all of us working together, let's get this nation moving again.

PUB-DATE: January 29, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1080 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAING: Media;
Low-Key Tsongas Tries New, Louder Approach

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 28

 BODY:
At first, Paul E. Tsongas hoped his message alone would carry him through in his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Tsongas, the diffident former Senator from Massachusetts, refused to be packaged by consultants like some other candidates.
But after 10 months of campaigning and little evidence that his candidacy was taking off, he has discovered that some media savvy and aggressive television advertisements might sweeten the appeal of his tough prescription for economic recovery. 
 While it is not possible to show a cause and effect, Mr. Tsongas in recent weeks has strengthened his second- place standing behind Bill Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, in several surveys of New Hampshire voters. In the aftermath of assertions about Mr. Clinton's personal life, one poll this week even showed him ahead.
But before he agreed to be coached in public speaking and to use message-oriented advertising, Mr. Tsongas had to overcome his own dislike of consultants and what he saw as President Reagan's reliance on them. "It's never been a matter of my confidence," Mr. Tsongas said. "But perception is a function of television personality. I had such a strong negative reaction to Reagan that I didn't want to be a made-over person. I had to accept the fact that this is important."
Mr. Tsongas said that in the first televised debate, held in December, he thought that he let his supporters down.
"My instinct was to defer to someone and to look over at them and away from the camera," said Mr. Tsongas. But before the last debate Jan. 19, Mr. Tsongas took voice lessons and got coaching tips about television from his cousin Joyce Tsongas, who is a speech coach.
Mr. Tsongas also said he was getting better at controlling his urge in speeching to grab paper and pencil and draw charts and graphs that no one in the back rows can see. And for the most part, he has stopped letting his voice drop to inaudibility at the end of sentences. He has also bought two new suits.
 
Attacking an Image Problem
 The make-over appeared to be working during a day's campaigning here.
Mr. Tsongas attacked his image problem head on, joking with a insurance workers in Concord about how central casting would never pick "another Greek from Massachusetts" like Michael S. Dukakis as a Democratic Presidential candidate. He mixed humor and his message of economic responsibility when he added, "Look at the Japanese: Who was the last charismatic prime minister?"
And in a meeting with a group of environmentalists in Concord, when one person asked Mr. Tsongas which of the competitors he would be willing to serve with as a running mate, he replied, "At some point, I will interview them all as my running mate." The audience laughed.
Tonight, as he watched President Bush's State of the Union Message at the home of Ken and Sandra Lord in Salem, Mr. Tsongas passed around a bowl of popcorn and said, "This will taste better than that," in a reference to Mr. Bush's speech.
Afterward, Mr. Tsongas termedthe President's message, which included several proposals meant to invigorate the economy, "voodoo economics continued."
 
Seeing a Breakthrough
 Mr. Tsongas said that his two main goals in the final weeks before the Feb. 18 primary here were improving his television presence and emphasizing the differences between his economic message and those of the other candidates.
Mr. Tsongas said that he felt the second debate, which was broadcast by a local television station and C-Span and seen by 90,000 New Hampshire adults, was a breakthrough for him and that voters were taking a second look at his candidacy.
Delmar (Doc) Anderson, the Democratic committeeman for Raymond who introduced Mr. Tsongas at a recent gathering, underscored that point when he told the audience they should focus on whether "you like what he says rather than thinking about whether he can be elected."
Mr. Anderson, a former Boston University professor who now raises goats, said of Mr. Tsongas: "He's got a dry sense of humor and I don't think he's going to be talked into riding a tank." Mr. Dukakis was derided in the last Presidential campaign as trying to show he was tough by riding a tank.
 
Wishing for Two Votes
 At the town meeting in Raymond, Laura Caron stood up and told Mr. Tsongas that she agreed with everything he had to say.
"But who is on the cover of the news magazines?" she said. "That's my concern for you."
Ms. Caron's question crystallizes Mr. Tsongas' political problem in this first primary state and beyond. Some Democrats here give Mr. Tsongas high marks for his tough economic message, but they just as often doubt whether the dour, low-key Massachusetts native with the plaintive voice and deferential stance can succeed in New Hampshire or beyond.
"People feel a really big responsibility in this primary," Mr. Anderson said. "A lot of people wish they had two votes, one for the person they think could be elected, the other for Tsongas as president."
After the meeting, Ms. Caron said, "What he's got to say isn't easy to swallow, but it makes sense." Mr. Tsongas offers an uncompromisingly tough message to voters. In his latest advertisement he stands outside a closed factory, and says: "All the Japan bashing in the world won't open this factory."
Mr. Tsongas differentiates himself from the other Democratic candidates who vow to get tough on what they describe as unfair trade practices. "Let's not kid ourselves," says Mr. Tsongas in the advertisement. "America must take control of its own fate."Mr. Tsongas promises to "shake things up" from the board room to the factory floor and beat the Japanese the "American way," by making "quality come first again."
Mr. Tsongas said upon his inauguration as President, he would overhaul what he says is an antiquated economic system. He would freeze Federal spending, and order regulators to halt banks from calling the loans of viable businesses and home owners.
Mr. Tsongas said he must finish first, second or a strong third in the New Hampshire primary, Feb. 18, if he is to remain in the race.
Mr. Tsongas's campaign manager, Dennis Kanin, said the campaign organization was set to take that same message to the nation, but that Mr. Tsongas would not be redesigning his message for other primary and caucus states.
"There is no reason to," said Mr. Kanin. "We think people are looking for straight answers and that is what Paul Tsongas is about."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul E. Tsongas, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, talking to voters last week at Notre Dame College in Manchester, N.H. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: January 29, 1992

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1566 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Pools of Memory, Waves of Dispute

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALTHAM, Mass.

 BODY:
Henry Burkhardt is scheming to ambush the computer industry.
His radically different supercomputer, intended for both scientific and commercial markets, has still not been formally introduced, although a handful of university and government research labs are putting prototypes through the paces of Big Science number crunching. But in recent weeks, Mr. Burkhardt's design has fired an emotional debate inside the usually clinically calm community of elite scientists and engineers who build the world's fastest computers. 
 On one side are experts who contend that Mr. Burkhardt's company, the Kendall Square Research Corporation, has built a conceptually clean and simple machine. The computer's fundamental difference lies in the way it creates a giant pool of memory, rather than the many smaller puddles that characterize the memory of other supercomputers.
The Burkhardt machine, advocates say, will make it far easier for business and scientific computer users and software designers to adapt existing work station or mainframe programs for tasks requiring a supercomputer's speed and capacity.
On the other side of the controversy are engineers -- and competitors -- who argue that Kendall Square's vaunted advantages are so much hype and hooey and predict that the five-year-old company committed a fatal blunder by basing its machine on a custom-made chip that could quickly fall behind the industry's rapidly evolving technology.
At the center of the storm is Mr. Burkhardt, who is 47 years old, a Princeton dropout who started his career in the mid-1960's as a computer designer at Digital Equipment. He subsequently helped to found Data General and Encore Computer before forming Kendall Square in 1986.
"There is an extraordinary transformation taking place at the high end of the computer industry, and there is a tremendous interest in running applications beyond the reach of today's machines," Mr. Burkhardt said in a recent interview at Kendall Square headquarters, just yards from Route 128, the central artery of the Boston area's high-tech industry. Large photographs of his supercomputer's custom chips dominate the three-story atrium of the secluded brick building.
If his business plan plays out, Mr. Burkhardt said, the company will become a force in the commercial market for high-end computers. Target customers for his KSR1 include companies like banks or airlines that must frequently search huge data bases and quickly retrieve information for thousands of transactions or customer reservations.
Mr. Burkhardt hopes to begin installing machines for commercial customers by the middle of the year. "We resisted the urge to hold a press conference and tell all sorts of lies," he said.
 
 
How Controversy Began
 Igniting the Kendall Square controversy was an article by the economist George Gilder, published this month in a narrowly circulated but closely read Silicon Valley magazine called Upside. Mr. Gilder, perhaps best known as the supply-sider whose book "Wealth and Poverty" provided the intellectual underpinnings of the so-called Reagan revolution, has no experience in computer design. But he has written widely on the subject in recent years and his opinions, though often controversial, are taken seriously among the computer digerati.
Mr. Gilder's article endorsed Kendall Square's system while fiercely challenging the design work of one of Mr. Burkhardt's principal competitors, Danny Hillis.
In October, Mr. Hillis, co-founder of the Thinking Machines Corporation, based in Cambridge, Mass., introduced a new version of his own pioneering supercomputer, the Connection Machine. Like Mr. Burkhardt's, it is a so-called massively parallel computer.
"There have been more letters in response to this article than I've provoked since I stopped writing about feminism," Mr. Gilder said in a telephone interview.
 Mr. Gilder's article attacks Thinking Machines' new computer and argues that Mr. Hillis erred in redesigning his new CM-5 system around thousands of off-the-shelf microprocessor chips rather than building a custom machine from the ground up.
But Mr. Hillis, whose industry supporters include I.B.M. and Sun Microsystems, responds that he is being unfairly attacked on the basis of false information about his computer's specifications. "The article has so much wrong information in it," he said. "There was absolutely no fact checking done."
The dispute has focused on the best way to design massively parallel supercomputers, machines that harness the power of hundreds or hundreds of thousands of microprocessors and break complex problems into small pieces for quick solutions.
Most computer designers believe that massively parallel systems will soon displace conventional supercomputers, such as those originally designed in the early 1970's by Seymour Cray. Those machines gained their speed with either a single or small group of specially engineered processors.
But while there is general agreement on the inevitability of massive parallelism, there is little agreement about which of the designs will prevail. Into this debate waded Mr. Gilder with his article, which seems to have incited sniping within the usually cordial community of computer architects.
"I don't want to hurt Danny's feeling's, but I really don't like his computer," said Gordon Bell, a widely respected computer designer in his own right, who is also an investor in Mr. Burkhardt's company.
David Patterson, a well-known computer scientist at the University of California at Berkeley and a consultant to Danny Hillis and Thinking Machines, fired back: "I was disappointed in the article. It was entertaining and provocative, but Gilder is breaking the Golden Rule of computer design. There has to be a current market for your current machine. Otherwise you don't get the gold to design the next one."
Mr. Patterson said Mr. Gilder's article was wrong about such details as the cost of a Connection Machine, its speed and the rate at which information is transmitted between processors within the system.
Mr. Gilder, however, said he stood by his article.
More than a dozen small and large firms are working on different massively parallel designs.
Nearly all of the current generation of massively parallel machines are designed around commercial microprocessor chips, the same chips that are found in today's work stations and personal computers.
Thinking Machines, Intel and Alliant for example, have decided to use off-the-shelf chips like Intel's i860 microprocessor or Sun's Sparc design, hooking thousands of them together through a complex switching network to pass information from chip to chip.
In contrast, Kendall Square has designed its own processors, taking advantage of new chip-design tools to customize the system.
There is a second crucial difference between Kendall Square's approach and the designs of the other massively parallel computers, Mr. Gilder contends. He says that systems like the Connection Machine from Thinking Machines and similar computers from Intel and Ncube are little more than expensive collections of work stations and that they will be surpassed by a new generation of supercomputers that have what is called a "shared memory model."
In this approach, the designer hides much of the complexity of the massively parallel hardware design from the programmer, so the system appears to function like a conventional single-processor machine.
But computer scientists working with early versions of the Kendall Square supercomputer say it does not entirely free the programmer.
 
 
'A Simpler Picture'
 "It's a simpler picture, and it's one that is more convenient," said Jack Dongarra, a computer scientist at the University of Tennessee, who has worked on a entry-level Kendall Square system being used at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. "However, one shouldn't have a false sense of security. It's still critical for the user to understand how the machine is put together to get performance."
The crucial issue is whether a piece of data is indeed automatically placed in the correct location when it is needed by a particular processor. If it turns out to be in another part of the machine, performance suffers because of the time taken to route the data along the computer's internal network to place it closer to the appropriate processor.
In this regard, Mr. Hillis argues, there is far less difference between the Kendall Square computer and the new CM-5 Thinking Machines system than is claimed by Mr. Gilder. Mr. Hillis says his new machine can automatically restructure standard Fortran programs just as Kendall Square's computer can.
 
 
Eyeing Mainframe Markets
 For his part, Mr. Burkhardt sees Kendall Square's principal opportunity as entering markets that were previously the province of conventional mainframes. He says the new KSR1 supercomputer will have almost four times the speed of a high-end I.B.M. mainframe but cost less than an eighth of the price -- starting in the $1 million price range, rather than the $8.5 million an I.B.M. customer can easily spend.
But he acknowledges that the new company has a limited amount of time to rush its system out.
"My theory is that if you wake up one morning and figure out that you can build something 10 times better," he said, "go do it, because somebody else might have had the same idea."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 770 words

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: Unemployment;
Accord on Extending Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Agreeing to sidestep a bitter election-year issue, President Bush and House leaders decided today to spend $2.7 billion on another 13 weeks of unemployment benefits for about two million long-term jobless people.
Democrats in the Senate did not commit themselves to the plan immediately, but Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, said he was confident a bill could be sent to Mr. Bush for signing "by the end of next week." 
 If Mr. Bentsen is right, Republican lawmakers and Mr. Bush will have put aside a painful political issue that Democrats used for months last year to paint Mr. Bush as uncaring about hardships on the home front and endlessly concerned with foreign problems. Last year Mr. Bush killed two versions of the bill, arguing that the budget deficit should not be increased. But he ultimately did sign an extension into law last November.
This time around, Democrats seized a quick, certain agreement with the Administration, abandoning a partisan advantage in part to avoid a fight that could make Congress appear to be bickering while thousands of unemployed Americans suffered.
For some workers, the extra benefits adopted last November will begin running out in mid-February.
Instead of trying to roll over the Republicans and adopt the $4.5 billion measure proposed last week by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Democrats settled for a less costly measure that expires in July. The measure proposed by Mr. Rostenkowski would have expired in October.
The bill would make some workers in states with high unemployment eligible for a total of 59 weeks of jobless benefits, which average about $170 a week. That would be a longer period of benefits than in any previous recession. In 1976, up to 55 weeks were paid. The bill would benefit people who have already run out of their benefits or who will by July 4.
The committee sent the compromise measure, sponsored by Mr. Rostenkowski and Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, to the floor on a voice vote today. The whole House will vote next Tuesday, under a procedure allowing only 40 minutes of debate and requiring a two-thirds majority for adoption.
Like November's measure, this bill would be financed with accounting devices and not by imposing any new taxes or cutting other Federal spending. Part of the cost would come from $500 million raised by requiring some corporations to make higher estimated tax payments sooner.
The remaining $2.2 billion would be from savings that the Office of Management and Budget says were achieved last year by Congress. A budget office report this month concluded that Congress had raised that much more money by extending taxes in future years and by other financial devices that it had put into extra Federal spending.
 
'The Land of Oz'
 Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Suffolk Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee who was a leading sponsor of extended benefits last year, told reporters today, "Only in the land of Oz could you take a $350 billion deficit and find $2 billion in savings."
The bill would allow workers in all states who have exhausted their regular unemployment benefits, which are limited to 26 weeks in most states, another 13 weeks of payments.
Those could be added on to the 13 to 20 weeks adopted last fall, so that some people could receive as many as 26 weeks of regular benefits and 33 weeks of extra benefits. Others would receive less, depending on when their benefits were exhausted and whether they lived in the handful of states eligible for 20 weeks of benefits because they have particularly high unemployment rates.
Last November's measure is to expire June 13. The Rostenkowski-Michel bill would expire July 4. If no further legislation is enacted, people exhausting basic 26 weeks after July 4 would not be eligible for extra benefits.
But at today's committee meeting Mr. Rostenkowski supported Mr. Downey's call for permanent changes that would remove those anomalies. Republicans on the committee urged that the trust fund that pays extended benefits be taken out of regular budget accounting altogether, so that it would not affect the deficit. That trust fund, filled by taxes paid by employers, now contains about $6 billion.
President Bush, in a letter to Mr. Rostenkowski, said he was pleased that the Administration and both parties "have been able to reach agreement." He said he hoped to have the bill on his desk for signing before the Congress begins its recess, now set for Feb. 7.

HEADLINE: In a Cold Setting, Numbing Speeches

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 28

 BODY:
If they happened to be paying attention, delegates and assorted hangers-on at the Moscow peace talks got tipped off to what lay ahead for them as soon as they stepped off the plane.
Pasted to a broad pillar at the airport was a sign saying "Middle East Conference." 
 It was the sort of sign that is normally accompanied by arrows telling arrivals exactly where to go to get through the landing procedures.
This time, there were no arrows, no pointers, no guides, nothing, just a curious sign saying "Middle East Conference" suspended there, having nothing to do with anything else swirling around it.
 
At the Same Table
 Just like the peace conference itself, one could say, as it got under way today in the colonnaded ballroom of an 18th-century mansion called the House of Unions.
By rights, this gathering of diplomats in flowing robes and pinstripes merited the shopworn label of "historic."
There they were, Israel and a sweeping arc of the Arab world, sitting together. The two dozen participants included Saudi Arabia, which for decades has led an economic boycott that continues to scratch away at Israel's frayed pockets. Now the Saudis and Israelis were at the same table, talking, albeit only in theory, about possible economic cooperation.
If peace ever does come calling in the Middle East, the abstractions under discussion today -- regional development, water resources, arms control -- may one day prove to be the most lasting achievements of the entire peace process.
Yet inside the House of Unions -- once called the Nobles' Club and perhaps destined in the post-Communist age to be renamed again -- it all seems suspended in gauze, filmy and divorced from the world outside.
 
Palestinians Stay Away
 Part of it was due to the fact that the Palestinian delegation stayed away. However the various sides may debate that development, it was like watching a performance of Chekhov's "Three Sisters" with one of the sisters written out of the play.
Muscovites could not have cared less. Even the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, could not be bothered with these talks, which were the last major diplomatic achievement bearing the stamp of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet President.
Only a handful of people stood at police barricades to gawk at the Middle East visitors. The real crowds were a few blocks away in Lubyanka Square, near the K.G.B. headquarters. Hundreds of Russians stood there in long, grim ranks, silently holding forth clothing and other goods for inspection by hundreds of others who filed past looking at the merchandise.
It was a quorum of desperation. One man held up for sale a single boot and nothing else. Another held two mismatched sneakers. This woman offered a sweater, that man a shirt. One man held nothing but a pinwheel that spun gently in the breeze.
On the wintry plaza, talks about occupied Arab lands, desalting of the Red Sea, Palestinian refugee camps and Israeli agricultural techniques might as well have been taking place on the moon.
 
Baker Is Keynote Speaker
 "People," said a clerk at the Hotel Moskva across the street from the conference hall, "are thinking about other things."
As though to underline the Russian nonpresence, the real master of ceremonies and keynote speaker was Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, not the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, who was technically the host.
The building where they met could fit any sort of symbolism one might seek.
It is a lime-green gem tucked among hulking monuments to totalitarianism. It is a place for concerts. Great writers have been celebrated there.
But it is also where many of Stalin's show trials were held in the 1930's, and according to some accounts Stalin watched the malevolence from a secret room high up in the Hall of Columns where the delegates met today.
There in 1880, Dostoyevsky delivered an emotional eulogy to the Russian poet Pushkin, and later he wrote his wife, saying that "when at the end I proclaimed the worldwide unity of mankind, the whole hall was in hysterics."
"People in the audience who were unknown to one another wept, sobbed, embraced each other and swore to be better men in the future," the writer said.
 
A Verbal Overload
 Certainly, mankind's unity and betterment were recurring themes in the speeches today, but if anyone wept, sobbed or embraced someone else, the act went undetected. In fact, after a few hours, most of the delegates looked numb from verbal overload, and many did not bother to show up for the afternoon session, joining the teams from Yemen and Algeria (not to mention the Palestinians) that stayed away entirely.
Still, there were bubbles of lightness.
One involved Foreign Minister David Levy of Israel, who had to interrupt his speech just as he started because of balky speakers that carried translations of his speech from Hebrew into other languages.
As Mr. Baker played with the device in front of him, Mr. Levy turned and said:
"Jimmy, O.K.?"
"Let's try again," the Secretary replied.
"O.K.," Mr. Levy said, ending an exchange that for Israelis was notable as much as anything else because it involved more English than some had thought he knew.

LENGTH: 2219 words

HEADLINE: Betting, in Harmony With Nature

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEDYARD, Conn.

 BODY:
Atlantic City and Las Vegas have the glitz and glamour, with neon cowboys and glittering marquees beckoning gamblers inside to a world of fantasy and chance.
Here, they have windows. 
 The Mashantucket Pequot Indians insisted on a wall of bay windows in the new Foxwoods casino -- an absolute no-no in traditional casinos, where bettors are encouraged to lose all track of time and money. Tribal leaders said that the densely wooded landscape was integral to the point of building a casino and could not be shut away.
"The land is everything," said Theresa D. Bell, the tribal affairs coordinator. "If you lose the land, you lose yourself."
As the $58 million casino's Feb. 15 opening day approaches, the doings in these piney woods have drawn the attention of a whole universe of people who stand to win or lose from a Pequot success, including the casinos of New Jersey and Nevada and politicians in Hartford, where pressures are growing to expand legalized gambling.
Here in southeastern Connecticut, the land of the Seawolf submarine and the sinking military dollar, the interest is keenest of all. With tens of thousands of jobs threatened as Pentagon spending falls, politicians and residents are desperately hoping that the Mashantucket Pequots can rescue this area from economic disaster.
For the short term, at least, it will certainly help. With an initial payroll of 2,300, and 1,000 more workers projected by the end of the year when the first of two hotels is completed, the Mashantucket Pequots will become an economic force to be reckoned with. The 250-member tribe hopes to gross $100 million a year, and pump $40 million into the local economy in annual payroll alone.
Some local business and community leaders have grander visions still. They say that with two of the top three tourist attractions in the state within 15 miles of the casino, southeastern Connecticut might be able to reinvent itself as a resort location even as military spending collapses.
But no one, least of all the tribe, expects easy sailing. The Mashantucket Pequots, having decided to retain control of the casino, rather than hire a management company from Las Vegas or Atlantic City, as some Western tribes are considering, found no bank in the nation willing to lend them money.
Eventually, they borrowed $55 million from a company in Malaysia that operates hotels and casinos in Asia.
And as with the bay windows, tribal control has meant occasional conflicts between ancient tradition and hard-headed profit-making.
When the water line to the casino was discovered to be in the path of ancient tribal encampments, for example, it was rerouted. When the motif for the casino, a beaded Pequot wampum belt, was deemed too close in design to a belt found in a tribal grave, the design was changed to avoid offending the spirits of a long-dead ancestor.
The council also agonized for weeks on a name for the casino, forcing printers and other contractors to cram their work into the final weeks before opening day.
"They're dealing with a culture; I'm dealing with a business," said Alfred J. Luciani, who was hired by the tribe last year from the Merv Griffin Resorts in Atlantic City to oversee the construction and startup of the casino. "We think in the short term; they're worried about the next 100 years," Mr. Luciani said.
A long downward spiral began for the Mashantucket Pequot tribe in 1636, when a trade dispute culminated in the bloody Pequot War. As many as 700 men, women and children were shot or burned alive by Puritan militiamen in one battle alone in Mystic. Survivors were sold into slavery.
By 1900, the last native speaker was dead. By the early 1970's, only about 40 people identified themselves with the tribe. And only one old woman, Elizabeth George, a quarter-blood Pequot, lived on the reservation, which had shrunk to 213 acres. State officials said the land would become a state park when she died.
 
Power to Poverty
 To tribal members and their allies, the turn of history's wheel in the late 20th century has been something to savor.
"In 1636, they were the economic power of the region, and they are about to be again," said Kevin A. McBride, an assistant professor of anthropology at the University of Connecticut who has worked on the reservation since the 1970's, excavating and identifying tribal cultural sites.
With revenues from a high-stakes bingo operation that the tribe started in 1986, the reservation has grown to 2,000 acres, with another 2,000-acre purchase under negotiation. There is full employment on the reservation. Dozens of traditional New England-style white colonial homes have been built on the winding wooded roads leading up from Elizabeth George Drive.
Last year, when Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. vowed to block the casino because it would attract organized crime, the tribe also showed its sophistication in turning the gears of government. Flanked by lawyers and some of Connecticut's highest paid lobbyists, the tribe saw the Governor's plan killed in the State House of Representatives.
But success, and the prospect of greater success to come, has not been without costs.
The council chairman, Richard A. Hayward -- one of Mrs. George's nine grandchildren -- is said by tribe members and lawyers to be gripped by anxieties about the casino opening. Unable to sleep, he reportedly haunts the unfinished buildings until 4 A.M. or later. Mr. Hayward declined to be interviewed.
 
Hiring Other Indians
 Another sign of the times is posted in the tribal office: "Ten ways to control stress." The poster advises tribe members just to stop and take a walk when it all gets to be too much.
And although the tribe has announced a preference for hiring American Indians, including members of other tribes, there is resentment. The Mashantuckets are the only tribe in Connecticut with full recognition from the Federal Government, and thus the only tribe that can take advantage of Federal statutes allowing gaming on Indian lands. And the casino's scale has also turned heads. Gambling experts say Foxwoods will be the most ambitious Indian gaming hall in the nation.
"This is a good decade for the Indians," said Mark Sebastian, an Eastern Pequot Indian who works as a guard outside the gate to the casino. The Eastern Pequots are closely related to the Mashantucket branch but are not entitled to full tribal rights. "It's giving everyone that spark," Mr. Sebastian said. "If they can do it, anyone can do it."
"But there's a lot of jealousy," he conceded.
 
Business of Gambling
Slots and Compact With Connecticut
 Foxwoods Casino will be oddly quiet compared with the clanking, change-clattering siren-calls of Atlantic City: here there will be no slot machines. Although the tribe spent more than $500,000 to have 50 video-bingo games designed and built, the machines will not be producing revenue when the casino opens.
Whether the games will be stored or used for nongambling purposes has not been decided. Under the compact between the state and the tribe that took effect last year, the Mashantucket Pequots may offer almost any game of chance that they choose except the very game that makes the most money and draws the biggest crowds: slot machines. In Las Vegas, for example, about 60 percent of profits are generated by the machines, which require little maintenance, no dealers and less security surveillance than table games. The Federal Indian Gaming Commission has ruled that the tribe's bingo electronic game is a form of slot machine.
"The Mashantuckets will not seriously challenge Atlantic City without slots," said Paul M. Dworin, publisher and editor of Gaming and Wagering Business magazine.
But industry experts like Mr. Dworin also say that the state and Federal regulations are in flux and that the Pequots are wise to have slots ready in case the rules change.
In Connecticut, the rules could be changed because of budget pressures. The state will collect no tax windfall from the Foxwoods Casino because the Mashantucket Pequots pay no taxes to the state or Federal Government. In addition, revenues from existing state gambling enterprises like jai alai and dog racing have plummeted because of the recession.
State lawmakers say the Pequot casino will only further the decline in revenue. That could heighten pressure on the state to strike back by expanding gambling off the reservation, possibly including slot machines in Off Track Betting parlors.
And that in turn, under the quirky rules of the 1988 Federal Indian Gaming Act, would complete the circle: if the state expands legal gambling, the tribe has the right to negotiate with the state to do the same thing.
And slot machines are a possibility, state lawmakers say. The co-chairman of the General Assembly's Public Safety Committee, which oversees gambling in the state, said he believed the state would expand legal gambling this spring.
"People are going to try and get the video slots -- this session you might see that done," said Senator Frank David Barrows, a Democrat from Hartford who heads the committee. "It's better than 50-50."
 
How About Bridgeport?
 Whether that would be a victory for the Mashantucket Pequots is the next question. With slot machines, industry analysts say, Foxwoods could compete with Atlantic City for the New York City market. Casino managers here say New England will be the main market -- Boston is 100 miles away. Ledyard is 125 miles from New York City, five miles farther than Atlantic City.
But with one casino on Indian land, some politicians say that Connecticut might find the momentum irresistible for a second casino, one that would pay taxes. Bridgeport, the state's largest and most financially troubled city, has been mentioned as the likely site.
And if that happens, some industry analysts say the tribal casino might simply be too far from New York City to compete, however many windows look out on the revered landscape.
 
Impact on Economy
Lure of Prosperity As Jobs Disappear
 A study commissioned last year by the state said that under the best-case scenario, New London County will lose 13,000 jobs, or more than 10 percent of all its jobs, over the next five years as military expenditures decline. The worst case would mean 27,000 jobs lost.
The Mashantucket Pequots predict, on the other hand, that about 13,000 people a day will be drawn to the Foxwoods Casino and High Stakes Bingo, or 3.9 million tourist visits, assuming the casino closes one day a week. By contrast, Connecticut's No. 1 attraction, the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium, drew 765,000 people in 1990.
The prospect of such a flood of new visitors has excited business owners. But while some see an economic miracle that could rescue southeastern Connecticut from its dependence on the Navy, others see congestion and a decline in the quality of life.
There is little argument that change will come. Even the best-case scenario put forward in the state study projected the eventual end of the Navy's Seawolf submarine program, which has almost single-handedly kept the region's economy functioning in recent years. In his State of the Union Address, President Bush proposed canceling the Seawolf.
 
Slowing the Fall
 The Electric Boat division of General Dynamics employs 23,000 people alone building Seawolf submarines. Out of 110,670 jobs in the county in 1990, fully 66,000 were jobs dependent on the Pentagon. Here in Ledyard, 39 percent of all households had at least one person in a job related to the military, according to a town survey.
The question facing local officials is how much casino gambling could help arrest the fall from the recession and the end of the Cold War.
"The longer the recession continues, the more positive the casino development appears," said William R. Haase, the Ledyard town planner. "What the tribe is doing is presenting an opportunity for economic diversification."
On the two-lane winding section of Route 2 where the casino is situated, the concerns are more narrow: are there enough gas stations, enough restaurants, is the road wide enough?
"The infrastructure can't handle it," said William D. Moore, president of the Chamber of Commerce of Southeastern Connecticut. "If you've ever been here in the summer months, with the beach traffic, you know what a nightmare it is," he said. "It's really going to have a much more significant impact than anybody anticipates."
Mr. Haase and other planners working with the tribe envision a national marketing campaign for the region as a full resort destination, with something for everyone, patterned after the tourism campaigns for James City County, Va., where Colonial Williamsburg and the Busch Gardens theme park have joined forces. Economists say that such a transformation, with tourism replacing military work, is possible, though it would involve wrenching dislocations, including pay cuts for many. At Foxwoods, many of the jobs pay only the minimum wage, plus tips.
"What you could be looking at five years from now is a completely different economy," said Donald L. Klepper-Smith, an economist at Southern New England Telephone. "There is tremendous upside potential for that side of the state," he said. "But it's a painful process getting there."

HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE TO GET FULBRIGHT AWARDS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
This year, for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War, Washington will be offering scholarships for Vietnamese to study in the United States under the 46-year-old Fulbright fellowship program.
Fifteen scholarships have been set aside for 1992 and another 15 for 1993 as part of the legislation that provides money for running the State Department and the United States Information Agency. The agency, which has been allocated $300,000 for the program, is now beginning the process of recruiting competitors for the awards in a country with which Washington does not have diplomatic relations. 
 Addie O'Connell, chief of academic exchange programs for the agency, said that U.S.I.A. is about to begin discussions with the New York-based Institute for International Education on how to locate and evaluate potential fellows, since American testing programs are not available in Vietnam. Ms. O'Connell said the agency hoped to have at least of few of the first Vietnamese Fulbright scholars in American universities by the fall.
The Fulbright scholarship program, conceived and sponsored by Senator J. W. Fulbright of Arkansas, came into being in 1946 as a means of using the sale of war materiel to aquaint Americans with overseas cultures. The new program is specifically limited to Vietnamese residents in Vietnam, and will not be open to exiles.
 
Discussing Embargo
 Under the legislation passed by Congress in October, it was decided that preference would be given to Vietnamese "intending to pursue studies in economics and commercial law."
Vietnam and the United States are still discussing steps to be taken by Hanoi before Washington will lift a trade and investment embargo, 17 years after the end of the war. This week, the Pentagon's new Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs, Alan Ptak, is to meet Vietnamese leaders in Hanoi to talk about resolving the cases of Americans still unaccounted for.
He will be accompanied by John Vessey, the retired army general who is a special Presidential envoy to Vietnam, and Brig. Gen. Thomas Needham, the head of a newly expanded office set up to coordinate all P.O.W.-M.I.A. efforts.
On Wednesday, a meeting will take place in Washington between Trinh Xuan Lang, Hanoi's representative at the United Nations, and Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Kenneth Quinn, who heads the American team in continuing talks with the Vietnamese on normalizing relations between the two countries.
 
Ways of Training Sought
 Hanoi has been looking for ways to train economists, business managers and international lawyers in the West. American law firms are eager to establish branches in Vietnam and have offered to assist the private United States-Vietnam Trade Council in setting up legal training. The council hopes to set up its own legal exchange.
The Fulbright program had been available to scholars in what was formerly South Vietnam before the collapse of the country in 1975.
Students from unified Vietnam have been granted visas in increasing numbers for individual programs in the United States over the last five years, according to John McAuliff, director of the U.S.-Indochina Reconciliation Project, a private organization that has been helping Vietnamese scholars come to this country and Americans go to Vietnam.
"These exchanges were done fairly quietly at first because there was a fear that the overseas Vietnamese community would harass people from Vietnam," Mr. McAuliff said. "But that seems to be a thing of the past. The numbers of students coming increased dramatically in 1991."
The Vietnamese Fulbright scholarship program originated in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, under the sponsorship of Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts. Senator Kerry, a Vietnam veteran, is also chairman of the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Bill to Improve Schools

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
After scuttling the heart of President Bush's school program, the Senate today overwhelmingly passed an $850 million Democratic education bill that would channel money to schools in poor communities and schools trying experimental improvements.
Even supporters of the bill say its financing, the equivalent of what it takes to build one B-2 Stealth bomber, is insufficient to improve the performance of most American schools. But the bill is intended to set new national goals to improve teacher performance, increase graduation rates and expand student access to training in science and mathematics. 
 After Republican members expressed bitter disappointment last week with the defeat of most of their education program, they signed on to the Democratic bill, saying it was a partial remedy that was better than no effort to improve education at all. The bill passed by a vote of 92 to 6, with 37 Republicans joining 55 Democrats voting to endorse the measure. All six negative votes were cast by Republicans.
The Senate last week rejected Mr. Bush's plan, which would have provided Federal money to a limited number of poor parents wishing to send their children to private schools. It also would have granted Education Secretary Lamar Alexander the power to select 535 new model schools for special financing.
 
Highly Partisan Debate
 Instead, the Democratic bill would grant the states the power to select the new experimental schools and seek to provide assistance only to public schools, most of which have been characterized by inadequate performance.
Mr. Alexander was somewhat critical of the bill, saying: "The President will keep fighting for more radical change in the American system. We will especially keep fighting to give middle- and low-income families more of the same choices of all schools that wealthy families already have."
In a highly partisan debate last week, Senate Democrats accused Mr. Bush of offering little more than privatization and rhetoric to resolve the nation's education needs.
"If President Bush wants to be the education President, he has to do more than talk about it," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, a principal sponsor of the Senate bill. "We cannot expect to compete in tomorrow's global economy when today's students are already far behind those of other nations."
Republican Senators said that by laying aside the President's proposals, the education bill would reward failure by pouring money into the least successful schools. They also argued that by helping disadvantaged parents send their children to private schools they would pressure public schools to improve. The National Catholic Conference and several of the country's bishops lobbied hard for that proposal until it was defeated in a near party-line vote last Thursday.
The education bill lays out national education goals to be met by the year 2000. Among them are the inclusion of all eligible preschoolers in the Head Start program, more Federal money for updating teacher training in mathematics and science and a sweeping extension of adult literacy programs. The bill also establishes a council of political leaders and education experts to develop a national academic report card to measure educational progress and shortcomings across the country.
 
Grants to the States
 The core of the legislation provides $850 million in grants to the states for distribution among local schools that would apply for the money by proposing improvement plans. The states could withhold a fraction of the money for statewide efforts to create new model schools and to finance programs to train teachers. At least three-quarters of the money would be set aside for the most needy schools.
Before the Senate bill can be enacted, it must be reconciled with a House education bill. The House bill would provide money for private schools in states where local law permits it. Only two states, Vermont and Wisconsin, fit in that category, but some Senate Democrats are strongly critical of the House version, saying it breaks the boundaries between church and state.
The Administration has been critical of the Democratic bill, and Mr. Bush in his State of the Union Message tonight, hours after the bill's passage, was still insisting that Congress "pass my proposals for new American schools."
But before the speech, Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, said he thought the President would find "more reasons to sign it than not to sign it."
Earlier today, by a vote of 55 to 43, the Senate tabled a Republican amendment that would have allowed states to require welfare recipients to make their children attend school or cut their benefits. Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, who sponsored the amendment, said it was necessary "to break this cycle of dependency."
But Democrats argued that the proposal would penalize children in cases where their parents were delinquent because of drug or alcohol abuse.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton, Cheered by New Polls, Again Assails Bush on Economy

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 28

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, restored to good humor and some short-term political stability by news of several polls showing that most New Hampshire voters care little about recent accusations of marital infidelity, today returned to criticizing President Bush about the nation's troubled economy.
Even Mr. Clinton's opponents acknowledge that his organizers in Texas have assembled the most extensive network of endorsements so far this year. They also say that the assertions of marital infidelity against the Governor do not appear to have cost him any of his early strength in Texas, one of the 11 states whose voters will participate in primaries on March 10. 
 But there were signs today that even Mr. Clinton's staunchest supporters have been concerned by the widespread reporting of the accusations by Gennifer Flowers, who is now an Arkansas government employee, that she and Mr. Clinton had a 12-year affair.
 
Endorsement of House Speaker
 At a news conference at the State Capitol here announcing some endorsements of Mr. Clinton by Texas Democrats, the House Speaker pro tem, Wilhemina Delco, introduced the Governor warmly. "I don't know about you, but I want a strong man for President, not God," she said.
But when Mr. Clinton responded by laughing and placing an arm around her shoulders for a hug, she also felt compelled to add, "just in case you misunderstand," that she and her husband have been friends with Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, for years.
In his subsequent remarks, Mr. Clinton also acknowledged what many of the supporters were apparently thinking as they applauded and cheered him when he entered the ornate State Senate chamber. "You'll never know how much it means for us to receive this warm welcome when I walked in this room," he said. "I think I know what it is you were trying to say.
"I knew what I was getting into when I entered this race," he said. "But what I want you to think of is what you are going to get into in the next four years. The issue in this race is not me, it's you, and the you's in America."
In a poll of New Hampshire Democrats taken Monday night, The Boston Globe found that Mr. Clinton had retained a high favorable rating and a lead over his opponents. The Globe's poll found that the Democratic voters thought the news media had been unfair to Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Clinton turned his attention to President Bush, who he said is promising too little, too late in his State of the Union Message.
"We cannot do the things we must do -- I'm talking about fundamental change in this country -- until we have a new commitment to equal opportunity in this country, both economic and political," Mr. Clinton said.
Echoing the theme raised by national Democrats who hope to take advantage of the politically weakened Mr. Bush this year Mr. Clinton derided the President's plans for rescuing the battered economy, including cutting the capital gains tax.
Such solutions, he said, are "a whole bunch of Band-Aids that are good for scratches but won't fix the open wounds of the American economy."
Mr. Clinton released a statement today saying he had tried unsuccessfully to reach Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York by telephone to apologize for comments attributed to him on the tape played by Ms. Flowers on Monday. On the tape, Mr. Clinton describes Mr. Cuomo as "aggressive," and when Ms. Flowers said she thought he might have some "mafioso" connections, Mr. Clinton replied, "Well, he acts like one."
In the statement released today, Mr. Clinton said: "If the remarks on the tape left anyone with the impression that I was disrespectful to either Governor Cuomo or Italian-Americans, then I deeply regret it. At the time that conversation was held, there had been some political give-and-take between myself and the Governor, and I meant simply to imply that Governor Cuomo is a tough and worthy competitor."
In Albany, Mr. Cuomo said in a news conference that the apology missed the point. "Don't limit your explanation to Italian-Americans," Mr. Cuomo said. "This is part of an ugly syndrome that strikes Italian-Americans, Jewish people, blacks, women, all the different ethnic groups."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
P.& G. Profits Are Up 6.7% In Quarter

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Fueled by strong sales in the United States and overseas, the Procter & Gamble Company yesterday reported profits for its second fiscal quarter that were better than expected, sending the company's stock up by more than 5 percent.
For the three months that ended on Dec. 31, Procter & Gamble's net earnings totaled $523 million, up by 6.7 percent from the $490 million reported in the comparable period in 1990. 
 The company's earnings per share rose by 8 percent, to $1.47 from $1.36, and sales totaled $7.50 billion, up by 9.4 percent from $6.85 billion.
Procter & Gamble, based in Cincinnati, said the higher earnings and sales resulted from "broadly based unit volume growth in the United States and international businesses."
 
Lower Profits Expected
 The stock jumped $5.50 a share, to $102.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, because Wall Street analysts had expected the company to post lower profits for the quarter. The consensus estimate had been about $1.36 a share.
The gains came despite what Procter & Gamble's chairman, Edwin L. Artzt, characterized as "continued recessionary market softness" in the United States. He said sales in the United States rose by 5 percent in most major product groups. Mr. Artzt said the company's international business grew at double-digit rates for the first six months of the fiscal year.
"They are gaining market share in every market they compete in," said Joseph H. Kozloff, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "P.& G. is out there hurting people," he added, referring to the company's competitors in the coffee, diapers and detergent business.
Analysts said Procter & Gamble was finally beginning to benefit from its heavy spending in new products and advertising throughout the recession. The company's spending hurt profits for the last 12 months. Last year, for example, the company introduced a new line of diapers and spent heavily to promote them.
"They didn't really pull back when other companies did," said Jay H. Freedman, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company. "It's pretty well documented that companies that are willing to bite the bullet and invest wisely through a recession tend to pick up share."
Because of the continuing investment, Mr. Kozloff of Smith Barney said P.& G.'s earnings were poised to improve, predicting a series of quarterly earnings increases. "Procter is getting ready to explode on the upside," he said.

HEADLINE: Robert Brooks, 86, Dean at Williams And Labor Expert

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Robert R. R. Brooks, an expert on labor economics who had been the dean and a professor at Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., died yesterday at the house of his sister-in-law, Ruth Brooks, in Nyack, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Williamstown.
Dean Brooks, who was a deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration in World War II, died of cancer of the pancreas, his family said. 
 When his book "Unions of Their Own Choosing" (Yale University Press), about the National Labor Relations Board, came out in 1938, it was praised by Francis Brown in The New York Times Book Review as a "timely and temperate study." Lewis Gannett, writing in The New York Herald Tribune, called it "a sober, circumstantial and impressive history."
His 1937 book, "When Labor Organizes" (Yale), was lauded by R. L. Duffus, also in the New York Times Book Review, as a "well-poised study of union labor in the United States."
Dean Brooks was born in Rome and grew up in Vermont and Florida. He earned a bachelor's degree in 1926 at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., studied from 1926 to 1928 at Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, receiving another bachelor's degree, and earned a doctorate in economics at Yale in 1935. He was dean and the Orin Sage Professor of Economics at Williams from 1945 to 1963. He retired in 1971 as a professor of economics there.
A volume of his memoirs, "A Tumult of Years," came out in 1980. He wrote, co-wrote or edited six other books.
His wife, the former Mary Elizabeth Storer, died in 1975. They had been married 46 years.
Dean Brooks is survived by a sister, Helen Coombs of Essex, Conn.; a daughter, Patricia Skidmore of Takoma Park, Md.; two sons, Robin, of Orrs Island, Maine, and Jonathan, of Waterport, N.Y.; nine grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A 4.3% Gain For Workers

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Restrained by the weak economy, wages and benefits for American workers rose just 4.3 percent in 1991, the smallest gain in four years, the Government said today.
The gain in compensation, as measured by the Employment Cost Index, compared with a 4.9 percent rise in 1990, the Labor Department said. 
 Most of the slowdown last year was because of smaller wage gains in the public sector, where compensation lagged behind private industry for the first time since record-keeping began a decade ago.
The last time total compensation gained so slowly was in 1987, when the overall increase in wages and benefits was 3.6 percent.
"The good news is labor costs are under control," said Michael Evans, head of a Washington-based economic consulting firm. "The bad news is that employees are broke."
Total benefit costs, most of which are for health care, rose 5.6 percent last year, after gaining 6.7 percent in 1990, the department said. Benefit costs also include employer-sponsored pension plans and other items.
